DOC.HEAD: Dogs and Mushers Set to Start Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race
DOC.TEXT: Seventy dog teams and mushers were set to start the ``Last Great Race on Earth'' on Saturday, the grueling 1,100-mile-long Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race from Anchorage to Nome. Teams were expected to encounter some of the harshest weather in the race's 18-year history, said Race Manager Jack Niggemyer. Sub-zero temperatures accompanied by strong winds, the heaviest snowfall in a quarter-century, ash from Redoubt Volcano and starving, aggressive moose have combined to make it a tough year to race and a tough year to train, he said. ``Awful weather,'' Niggemyer said. ``It's probably snowed 40 inches in the last two days.'' The race usually lasts from 11 to 18 days. The record time, set by Susan Butcher of Manley, Alaska, in 1987, is 11 days, two hours and five minutes. Butcher won the race in 1986, 1987 and 1988. Some participants and race observers said they expect this year's race to be slow going because of the deep snow and poorly-packed trail. ``We might run out of trail,'' said Lavon Barve, a musher from Wasilla, Alaska. ``It's up to the mushers to snowshoe or whatever,'' he said. It will be Barve's ninth race; he finished fifth last year. The Iditarod began in 1973. It commemorates the 1925 emergency delivery of diphtheria serum to Nome on the Bering Sea. The serum, taken overland by sled dog because airplanes couldn't get through, was credited with saving hundreds of lives in the remote coastal town. The trail begins in Anchorage and heads northwest across the giant Alaska Range and onto the treeless tundra. Eventually it winds along the Yukon River to the Bering Sea. Since 1973, the Iditarod has grown in fame and stature. This year, mushers have come from as far as France and Switzerland. Companies spend tens of thousands of dollars to sponsor top competitors. Rick Swenson of Two Rivers, Alaska, the only person to win the Iditarod four times, will be trying for a fifth win. Butcher will attempt to equal Swenson's four-time win record.

DOC.HEAD: Carol Guzy, Eugene Richards Named Photographers Of The Year
DOC.TEXT: Carol Guzy of The Washington Post was named newspaper photographer of the year Friday, with Magnum's Eugene Richards winning the top magazine award in the 47th Annual Pictures of the Year competition. The winners were announced by the University of Missouri School of Journalism, which co-sponsored the 47th annual Pictures of the Year competition with the National Press Photographers Association. The entries were judged last month at Columbia by a 12-member panel. The competition is supported by grants from Canon USA Inc. and the Professional Photography Division of Eastman Kodak Co. DOC.HEAD: Latvians Worry Voting Soviet Troops Will Distort Elections
DOC.TEXT: Latvians allege 70,000 Soviet troops are pouring into the Baltic republics to skew the voting in the independence-minded republics' elections in the coming weeks. A Soviet military commander indicated Friday that the troops are coming into the Baltics from Czechoslovakia and won't be transferred that quickly. Pro-independence activists are hoping to win majorities in the parliamentary elections in Latvia and Estonia on March 18, but both republics have substantial Russian populations who may vote against independence candidates. A substantial influx of soldiers, who can vote wherever they are stations, could change the balance of power. The Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia already have heavy concentrations of troops, reportedly one out of every eight people in Estonia. Lithuanians already have elected a majority of pro-independence activists to their parliament and run-offs are scheduled. Baltics military commander Fyodor Kuzmin told the Latvian legislature Friday that the Soviet troops being withdrawn from Czechoslovakia will be transferred to the Baltics, though not necessarily permanently, reported Anda Anspoka of the Latvian People's Front. In his comments, Soviet commander Kuzmin reportedly gave no timetable for the troops arriving in the Baltics. However, the Soviets have told the Czechoslovaks they need 16 months to withdraw all 73,500 soldiers because there is no housing for them and their families in the Soviet Union, which has a chronic and severe housing shortage. The first units, consisting of 22 T-62 tanks and 33 armored vehicles, left Czechoslovakia on Monday. People's Front representative Janis Jurkama said on Finnish television Friday that ``our information is that they are coming to Latvia just before the elections'' and they would vote. ``I tell you people are being very nervous, and that is why a lot of letters have been coming to the Supreme Soviet (legislature) asking our deputies to express a very strong protest to Moscow,'' he said. Kuzmin told the Latvian legislature that the troops were going to Lithuania and Estonia rather than Latvia, Anspoka said. Disbelieving lawmakers decided to protest to Moscow and request that no more troops be sent to the Baltics, she said. The Latvian legislature also passed a law removing judges from the control of the Communist Party. A judgeship is now ``incompatible'' with membership in a political party, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. The Latvian parliament also created a state bank empowered to issue currency independent from the Soviet ruble, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Retirement Haven For Radicals To Close
DOC.TEXT: The elderly communists, religious liberals and social reformers at Sunset Hall are used to being outnumbered, but there aren't enough left now even to keep the house open. Sunset Hall, a 36-room Spanish-style home for retired radicals, is being sold for $1.2 million to a developer who wants to convert it into an apartment complex, Ann Maupin, president of the board governing the home, said Friday. Residents of the home, which is running an annual deficit, have until March 22 to move out. Of the 14 residents, age 77 to 99, eight have no place to go or don't want to go. The rest have made other plans. ``It's the loss of a very important people's institution,'' said Sadie Tomkin, 89, who once managed the communist newspaper People's World. ``If this was a decent society, this would never have happened,'' she said. Sunset Hall residents can count among their brethren former resident Ruben Burroughs, editor of Upton Sinclair's newsletter during the socialist's 1934 gubernatorial campaign. Others helped form the union backbone for blue collar workers in the United States in the 1930s and some fought McCarthy-era blacklisting in the 1950s. Founded in 1924 by the First Unitarian Church of Los Angeles, Sunset Hall was designed to house religious liberals. The home is funded primarily by residents' monthly fees and has operated at a deficit for almost two decades, said administrator Thomas E. Brandlin. It is expected to post an estimated $95,000 deficit this year, its worst ever, he said. Residents pay between $900 and $1,400 a month, although some are charged less because of need. ``We're almost broke,'' Brandlin said. ``A big chunk of money might help for a while but what Sunset Hall really needs is to be filled up with 30 paying residents.'' ``We need enough residents to bring in $75,000 per year, or fund-raising,'' added Mrs. Maupin. ``But that's fund-raising at a very high level.'' She said there are 12 members on the board that governs the home, with two who want the home to remain open. The board is elected by the 240 members of the Sunset Hall Nonprofit Corp., which is open to anyone who pays a $35 fee. To fight the closure, attorney Kent Ten Brink said he intends to seek a court injunction blocking the planned sale. Residents, some who must use canes and walkers, have participated in recent years in demonstrations in support of the Los Angeles teachers' strike and a picket by Eastern Airline workers. And they say they may fall back on a timeworn strategy and stage a demonstration outside Sunset Hall, which features a large, tree-shaded patio, a library and a living room equipped with a grand piano, the day they get evicted. ``We have people here who expressed their thinking on world events and took part in them,'' said Drusilla Falk. ``I'm about the youngest here. I'm 78 and when I arrived here four years ago, I thought maybe I won't have to make any more moves.'' Waldemar Hille _ Wally to friends _ said the band of old rebels is not taking news of the closing lying down. ``I'm a musician by trade and not accustomed to getting mad, but we do have a lot of people here who are,'' said Hille, who plays piano, organ and a little guitar when he's able. ``I'm going to try and keep my place here and quite a few other members will too,'' he added, ``but we don't expect miracles.'' The 82-year-old Hille used to accompany singer Paul Robeson and was once a collaborator with folk singer Pete Seeger. He said he moved to Sunset Hall about two years ago. Hille feared that without the intellectual stimulation provided by the home, some residents may just fade away. ``As a musician I can write and practice my instruments,'' Hille said. ``I can stay alive at least. Other people aren't as fortunate as that and they have only to look forward to a single apartment some place.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Seek Assailant Who Cuts Off Womens' Hair
DOC.TEXT: A nocturnal assailant in a ski mask has held at least seven women at knifepoint before cutting off locks of their hair and fleeing. None of the women were injured in the attacks, but some were threatened, said police. The attacks all were reported in the last five months by women who had been walking alone at night. The most recent episode occurred Feb. 17. As in previous attacks, the woman was unable to provide an accurate description of the man because he wore dark clothing and a ski mask, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Dealers Scramble for East Marks in Surge Against Deutsche Mark
With PM-Germany-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Black market currency dealers on their sidewalk trading floor outside a train station are scrambling for East German marks as the non-convertible currency soars against the West's mighty deutsche mark. Germans from both countries and the region's wheeling-and-dealing Poles who trade on the black market are facing a run on the East German mark amid speculation over a pending monetary union between the Germanys. Talks are under way on a plan to introduce the West German mark as legal tender in East Germany, and some East German officials have called for a 1-to-1 exchange rate at the outset. That proposal has brought a sudden switch at the sidewalk trading spot. ``You can hardly get East marks these days _ it was a lot easier only a week or two ago, although the exchange rate is a lot better now for sellers,'' said one dealer, who identified himself only as Harald K. The 24-year-old East German, who deals in West Berlin on his days off from the army, said East Germans a month ago had to pay 20 East marks for one West mark. Now they can buy one shiny deutsche mark coin for only a green 5-East mark note. When East Germany's Communist government opened the Berlin Wall in November, the boom in traffic between the nations boosted business on the sidewalk exchange in front of the train stop at the zoo in West Berlin. A few West Germans bought East marks to travel East and buy cheap staples like rice, pasta and fresh meat, or dine like kings at subsidized restaurants. But most customers were East Germans out hunting for consumer goods unavailable back home. Now though, East marks are in demand and more West Germans are buying in the hope of turning a quick profit when the nation's economies are merged as part of a monetary union. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has proposed the union as a first step to unification of the countries. Some West German officials also say that East Germany's economy is crumbling and will collapse without the union. ``People are expecting with a currency union, the East German mark will be exchanged at a 1-to-1 rate,'' said Reinhard Pohl, a monetary expert at West Berlin's German Economic Research Institute. Pohl said some West Germans are trading their convertible deutsche marks at the favorable black market rate, then depositing them with friends or relatives in the East and hoping for the favorable exchange rate once economic union is announced. The East mark has surged 30 percent against the deutsche mark at currency trading offices in West Berlin and Frankfurt, and in Vienna, Austria, and Zurich, Switzerland. Uncertainty over how economic unification will be carried out also has made West German stock and bond markets jumpy. ``The markets are being driven by emotion, speculation and politics, and that's not going to change before the elections'' in East Germany on March 18, said one Frankfurt bond trader, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said West Germany's mass-circulation Bild newspaper had contributed to the speculation Friday, with a report that East German and West German finance officials have agreed to a currency union by July 1. Bild said a joint currency commission had decided that East Germans' savings _ which alone amount to 17 billion East marks in bank accounts _ would be exchanged over an unspecified period of time at a 1-to-1 rate. For savings that couldn't be swapped immediately, for lack of ready cash, West German interest rates would be paid, Bild said. Only savings deposited in East German bank accounts before Jan. 1, or possibly before Nov. 9 _ when the Berlin wall was opened, would be converted, it added. The paper said cash of up to 1,000 marks could probably be exchanged at a 1-to-1 rate, but that larger amounts would be cashed at a less favorable rate. The East German government declined to comment and the West German Bundesbank denied the report, saying no decisions would be made on the conversion rate before the election.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Rock singer Billy Idol, who suffered a broken leg and forearm in a motorcycle accident last month, has been released from the hospital. Idol, 34, was released Friday from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center and will require a period of rehabilitation, hospital spokesman Ron Wise said. The spike-haired singer suffered a compound fracture of his right leg between the knee and ankle and a broken left forearm on Feb. 6. He underwent several operations on his leg. Police said Idol ran a stop sign and hit a car while riding home from a Hollywood studio where he had just completed work on the album ``Charmed Life,'' which is scheduled for release April 17.

Comedian Bob Newhart says he had fun making ``Newhart'' for the last eight years, but this year is the last for the CBS situation comedy. ``Newhart,'' in which the comedian stars as an embattled hotelier, will have its last broadcast in April. The 60-year-old Newhart said that another year for the sitcom was scuttled by demands made by MTM, the show's producers. He and CBS are in talks to develop a new situation comedy. ``Our series was the perfect example of how much fun episodic television can be,'' Newhart said.

Soviet parliamentarian Boris Yeltsin kicks off an international tour here next week to promote his book ``Against the Grain.'' Yeltsin arrives in Stockholm on Monday, the worldwide publishing date for the book which promises rare insight into the political games behind the Kremlin walls, said Inger Sjoholm-Larsson, spokeswoman of publisher Forum AB. Sjoholm-Larsson said a first Swedish edition of 15,000 to 18,000 copies was being printed. Yeltsin, 58, is a member of the Congress of People's Deputies and a deputy in the Supreme Soviet legislature. Excerpts of ``Against the Grain'' have appeared in Swedish papers. They described the privileged lives of the Soviet political elite, and criticized Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev for moving too slowly in reforming Soviet society. Yeltsin will tour Norway, West Germany, Italy, France, the Netherlands, Great Britain and the United States.

Psychiatric social worker Sophie Freud, granddaughter of Sigmund Freud, the founder of psychoanalysis, says she's never undergone psychoanalysis and doesn't plan to. ``I'm just the kind of addictive person who would get lost in some kind of dependency relationship'' in analysis, she told about 200 people Friday at the University of Pittsburgh. ``It's too dangerous to my psychic makeup.'' Ms. Freud, 65, is a professor of social work at Simmons College in Boston and a noted therapist. She poked fun at some of her grandfather's ideas, saying, for example, that she doesn't agree with his contention that only men are capable of true passion. ``Women love only themselves with an intensity comparable to man's love for them'' her grandfather wrote in 1914. ``Nor does their need lie in the direction of loving, but of being loved; and that man finds favor with them who fulfills this condition.'' That's ridiculous, Ms. Freud said. ``Sometimes, I question whether men are capable of love,'' she joked before the predominantly female audience.

Former model Hazel Diane Moore, who lured Washington Mayor Marion Barry to a hotel where he was arrested on drug charges, has been fined $927 for drunken driving and put on probation for three years. Miss Moore, 38, who also goes by the name of Rasheeda Moore, also was ordered Friday to enroll in an alcohol abuse education program and had restrictions placed on her driver's license for 90 days. Miss Moore did not have to appear for the Van Nuys Municipal Court proceeding and was not present when attorney Ronald J. Lewis entered her no-contest plea to driving under the influence. The Burbank woman was arrested Jan. 1 at 11:30 p.m. for driving under the influence of alcohol. Police said her blood alcohol level was .12 percent. A driver is considered legally drunk in California at .08 percent. Miss Moore became an undercover informant for the FBI, calling the mayor to a Washington hotel room where he was arrested Jan. 18 for investigation of possessing cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Uses Windsurfer to Flee Cuba
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager fleeing Cuba crossed most of the hazardous Florida Straits on a windsurfer that an East German tourist had given him, a Coast Guard spokesman said. Lester Moreno Perez, 17, was in good health after being picked up by a Bahamian freighter about 30 miles south of Key West, Petty Officer James Wentworth said Friday. The youth had begun the trip from Cuba 16 hours earlier, on Thursday, and had sailed about 60 miles on the windsurfer before it broke, Wentworth said. ``It wasn't a cheap windsurfer,'' he said. ``It was a nice one, it wasn't homemade.'' Moreno Perez told Coast Guard officers he was given the Austrian-made, three-meter long surfboard by an East German tourist who ``wanted him to have his freedom,'' said Petty Officer Richard Rodriguez. The wishbone boom _ which the windsurfer holds while sailing _ broke in the early morning Friday, forcing Moreno Perez to rig up a makeshift device, Rodriguez said. Moreno Perez, who told officials he has family in Miami, was being questioned Friday by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Hundreds of Cuban refugees have attempted the dangerous passage to the Florida Keys on homemade rafts, rickety boats or innertubes. Many have died along the way.

DOC.HEAD: Gershwin Comes to Life on Computer-Driven Player-Piano Rolls
DOC.TEXT: Using a computer-driven descendant of the player piano, a music scholar gave new life to more than 100 rare George Gershwin solos recorded on piano rolls. ``It is as if you are being treated to a live performance in your living room,'' the scholar, Artis Wodehouse of San Francisco, said Friday as she showed off the technology that saved the songs. Gershwin recorded the pieces on rolls for player pianos between 1916, when he was 17, and 1926. Player pianos were the jukeboxes of their day, Wodehouse said, and most of the Gershwin performances were his elaborate arrangements of then popular songs. Eighteen were his original compositions. Sheet music for his compositions and for his arrangements of the other pieces did not survive. Wodehouse, a pianist herself, found 105 of the 120 piano rolls through a Michigan collector in 1988. She then found a computer firm, Micro-W Distributors Inc. of Butler, N.J., that had developed a technology that turns piano rolls into a format computers can read. Micro-W put the Gershwin rolls on floppy disks that can be played on synthesizers or a computer-driven update of the player piano, the Yamaha Disklavier. On Friday, the Gershwin songs emanated from a Disklavier in a performance at Yamaha's Communication Center in New York. Gershwin ``would love it,'' Wodehouse said. ``He would be tickled with the technology. He was a great believer in the new. And he would have been delighted to learn that people still cared about his music.'' Gershwin, one of America's greatest composers and a piano virtuoso, died in 1937. His first big claim to fame came in 1919 with the release of ``Swanee,'' but his position in the annals of music history was secured in 1924 by ``Rhapsody in Blue.'' A few years ago, Wodehouse transcribed sheet music for several old 78 rpm Gerswhin records. ``I went over and over them,'' she said. ``It took about 150 hours to transcribe a three-minute piece'' because his arrangements were so elaborate. When those pieces were published, she became well-known among Gershwin lovers and about a year ago she won a National Endowment for the Arts grant to study Gershwin piano rolls. Micro-W had just created a technology that could read the piano rolls, which Wodehouse compares to long pieces of toilet paper with little pin pricks in them. Player pianos read the rolls by blowing air through the holes, triggering hammers inside the pianos. The computer data was made by taking pictures of images of light aimed through the holes, and putting that data onto disks, she said. Wodehouse then persuaded the Coda Music Software Co. to adapt its music transcription program Finale to transform the Micro-W disks into sheet music. Seven of the original Gershwin compositions found on the rolls are scheduled to be published by Warner Bros., she said. If all 18 of the Gershwin works are published, it will more than double the existing Gershwin solo sheet-music repertoire, Wodehouse said. Plans also are in the works to create recordings of the Gerswhin rolls. Player pianos fell into disuse during the Depression, when they were hacked up for scrap wood and replaced by record players. The Disklavier, which can be used as a conventional piano as well as a mini-recording studio that will tape and recreate whatever is played on it, ranges in price from $7,000 to $22,000. The disks are sold by Micro-W.

DOC.HEAD: Government Orders Open Skies for Handicapped, but Restricts Blind
DOC.TEXT: The government is forcing airlines to open the skies to the handicapped, but says blind people still can't sit near the exit door. Transportation Department rules requiring more accommodations for the disabled on airliners brought immediate criticism from an airline industry trade group and from a national organization of blind people. Both said they were considering lawsuits. The rules call for moveable aisle armrests and more space for wheelchairs and require airlines to make other provisions for handicapped travelers. Billed as an anti-discrimination measure required by Congress, the rules will cost airlines an estimated $400 million over the next 20 years _ for training personnel and modifying airliner interior design to accommodate more disabled people, said Don Trilling, DOT director for regulatory affairs. ``You don't treat handicapped passengers differently or force restrictions on them unless you have a very good safety grounds for doing it,'' said Bob Ashby, a department lawyer who briefed news media on the directives that will take effect in about five weeks. All new airliners with more than 30 seats will be required to have moveable armrests on half the aisle seats, and wide-body planes _ generally those carrying 200 passengers or more _ must have at least one lavatory that can accommodate a handicapped passenger. The rules also strictly limit airlines' ability to refuse service to handicapped people, prohibit any restriction on where they can sit except for safety reasons and prevent airlines from requiring handicapped passengers to be accompanied by an attendant. If they do require it, the airline must fly the attendant free. ``These regulations will ensure that U.S. air carriers provide consistent, predictable service to disabled travelers, without discrimination and with accommodations the passengers need,'' said Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner. ``The regulations accomplish this goal consistent with the safety of all passengers.'' The Air Transport Association, which represents U.S. carriers, said the requirements would ``diminish safety and service for air travelers and impose an unacceptable economic burden on the airlines and all their customers.'' The trade group said requiring 50 percent moveable aisle armrests was ``way out of proportion with the real need to accommodate disabled passengers.'' Another provision that would give both manual and electric wheelchairs priority in main cabin storage areas will ``seriously diminish storage space for carry-on items of other passengers,'' ATA said. Airliners built in 1992 or later will be affected, and older aircraft will have to comply as their interiors are refurbished, usually about every seven years. The rules prohibit carriers from restricting seating on the basis of handicap except to comply with Federal Aviation Administration safety regulations. An accompanying FAA rule limits seating in exit rows to passengers who can locate the door quickly, follow instructions for its use, physically open the heavy doors, determine whether it's safe to go out, understand both verbal and hand-signalled instructions from flight attendants, and get around obstacles to lead other passengers off the aircraft. Tony Broderick, FAA associate administrator, said the rule was reached ``reluctantly'' but ``does not single out any group.'' He said among those prohibited would be parents with small children, people too frail to operate the door, passengers with broken legs or other disabilities that would inhibit movement, obese people and children under 15, as well as people who are blind. Marc Maurer, spokesman for the National Federation of the Blind, said the rule ``continues a pattern of discrimination the Department of Transportation has permitted airlines to carry on for some time.'' A bill is pending in Congress that would allow blind people to sit wherever they want on airliners. Maurer said the group is also considering legal action. ``Blind people don't need anything in these rules, except to be left alone,'' Maurer said.

DOC.HEAD: Expedition Gets Scare When One Member is Lost in Blizzard
DOC.TEXT: An explorer on a dog sled trek across Antarctica disappeared in a blizzard for 11 hours, as foul weather threatened the team's plan to finish the first non-mechanized crossing of the continent by Saturday. Keizo Funatsu, the Japanese member of the six-man international team, was found early Friday after surviving a night of 70 mph winds and 20-below temperatures by burrowing into the snow. ``When he was found, he was yelling, `I'm alive.' He was found in very good condition,'' said Jennifer Gasperini, headquarters spokeswoman for the Minnesota-based expedition. Funatsu disappeared Thursday after meeting with a French film crew that hauled a mobile home to the team's campsite, 16 miles from their goal. Team members roped themselves together and searched for six hours. They gave up because of darkness, but found him in the morning after a two-hour search, Ms. Gasperini said. It wasn't known if Funatsu would be able to complete the last 16 miles of the trek to the Soviet scientific station at Mirnyy, on the eastern Antarctic coast, under his own power. The 1990 Trans-Antarctica Expedition was stalled for a second day Friday on the last leg of a 3,800-mile, seven-month journey by dogsled and skis from western Antarctica to the eastern coast on the Indian Ocean. The wind dropped to 30 mph Friday afternoon, but conditions remained too hazardous to risk a final push, Ms. Gasperini said. Especially dangerous was a maze of ice crevasses along the route. They had hoped to end the $11 million, corporate-sponsored journey by 6 a.m. EST Saturday at Mirnyy, where they planned to meet television crews. The expedition, led by Will Steger of Ely, Minn., and Jean-Louis Etienne of France, hopes to parlay interest in the feat into public support for preservation of Antarctica, and to lobby world leaders who are reviewing the 1961 Antarctic Treaty. Team members reached the South Pole _ the halfway mark of their journey _ on Dec. 11 to become the first to reach the bottom of the world by dogsled since Roald Amundsen discovered the Pole in 1911.

DOC.HEAD: Panel's Plan Would Provide Insurance for All
With PM-Health Care-Recommendations
DOC.TEXT: A bipartisan commission's plan to overhaul the nation's health care system would provide private or public insurance coverage to all Americans, regardless of whether they can afford it. However, the plan already is drawing fire for failing to say how the $65 billion annual bill would be paid by taxpayers. The proposals adopted Friday by the U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care are aimed at providing universal access to health care and assuring that the elderly and disabled will be able to receive care _ at home or in nursing homes. Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., chairman of the commission, said the recommendations to Congress respond to a crisis in U.S. health care that leaves more than 31 million people without any health insurance and an additional 20 million with inadequate coverage. He called it ``wrong, outrageous, morally repugnant'' that Americans are denied care in emergencies. ``We can't offer easy answers, but we can offer a challenge to this country,'' he said. The panel voted 8-7 for the plan to achieve universal access, and 11-4 for the long-term care plan. The three members appointed by President Bush divided 2-1 in favor of both proposals. The other 12 members of the commission are members of Congress. The commission's plan relies on both increased federal spending for health care coverage, including a federal takeover of the Medicaid system now shared with the states, and private coverage. In addition to its estimated $66.2 billion cost, an additional $20 billion would be paid by private businesses through increased contributions to employee health plans, or to the public plan. ``Without a way to pay for it, it is a non-starter. It is legislatively dead,'' said Rep. Fortney ``Pete'' Stark, D-Calif., a member of the panel and chairman of the House subcommittee on health. He criticized the Bush administration for failing to provide leadership in finding a way to provide health insurance. Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn., also a member, said the plan failed to provide any restraints on health care costs. ``It's going to skyrocket our costs,'' he said. Rockefeller said the plan would need a revenue source that could be counted on to increase by 8 percent to 9 percent a year automatically, because of anticipated rising costs. The plan would be phased in over five years. In its first year, health care coverage would be extended to all children and pregnant women. The plan would require all businesses with more than 100 employees to provide private health insurance to their workers, or to contribute to a public plan for employees and non-working dependents. Smaller businesses would be encouraged to provide insurance through tax credits and subsidies, but might eventually be required to provide coverage if they did not meet targets by the end of the five-year period. The long-term care plan would pay the full cost of the first three months in a nursing home by anyone, regardless of income. Benefits for additional time in a nursing home would be improved, permitting recipients to keep their homes and certain other assets. The commission was created in 1988 when Congress voted to expand Medicare catastrophic care coverage. That coverage was repealed last year after groups representing the elderly abandoned their support, complaining about the cost. The commission was called the Pepper Commission for its first chairman, the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. It was directed to recommend ways to assure health care and how to pay for it.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Plans To Turn Titles Over to Those Working Land
DOC.TEXT: The new United National Opposition government is planning to turn land seized by the leftist Sandinistas over to those working it and compensate the previous owners, UNO officials said. Confiscated land now idle will be rented and priority will be given to its previous owners, said Francisco Mayorga, a senior economic adviser to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Mayorga told reporters Friday that 40 percent of the nation's 2.5 million arable acres is owned by the Ministry of Agrarian Reform. People now working that land will get title to it, Mayorga said, adding that former owners will be compensated with government bonds based on pre-confiscation tax values _ something that may be painful for owners who deliberately undervalued their land. ``We aren't going to throw anybody out of their homes,'' said another adviser, Alfredo Cesar. ``The person affected will have to petition through mechanisms we will establish.'' Land ownership is one of the key issues during the transition between the Sandinistas and Mrs. Chamorro's coalition, which defeated them Sunday and will take office April 25. After ousting dictator Anastasio Somoza in 1979, the leftist Sandinistas began nationalizing businesses and expropriating huge private farms and ranches as part of a land redistribution plan. UNO campaigned on a free-market platform that proposed selling off state enterprises and increasing private ownership to spur the ailing economy. The Sandinistas _ who still control the army and police _ said firing public workers or making the banking system private could endanger the transition. Mayorga, heading Monday to the United States to seek assistance, said the government would have to move fast to help farmers plant crops before the May rains. He said the nation would need $500 million to $600 million in annual aid from all sources, about what the same as it was receiving under President Daniel Ortega. The bulk of that aid, however, came from Eastern Europe, Cuba and the Soviet Union, sources which were drying up even before the UNO victory. Also Friday, a Honduran official joined talks got under way to discuss disbanding U.S.-supported Contra rebels who are based in Honduras. A source close to the talks said the discussions were ``constructive'' but that there was a long way to go. Both the Sandinistas and UNO have urged the Contras to immeditately dismantle their bases and return, but the Contras said must have talks first with Mrs. Chamorro's government to guarantee their safety. Honduras' new president, Rafael Leonardo Callejas, wants the Contras out of his nation's territory and peace established in the region in order to attract foreign investment and get his economy back in gear. ``Every day that goes by that they are not dismantled the situation becomes more explosive because it is interfering with the normal transition,'' said Alejandro Bendana, secretary-general of the Foreign Ministry, in an interview with reporters Friday. Meanwhile, Mrs. Chamorro said that transition negotiations overall were going smoothly. ``It's all going peacefully, very peacefully,'' Mrs. Chamorro said in a brief interview. Bendana said the Sandinistas would turn over full powers of the executive to Mrs. Chamorro. Transition talks are focusing on control of the Sandinista army and Interior Ministry security forces, which the Sandinistas don't want to reduce until the Contras disband. Including the army, security and militias, those forces are about 150,000 strong; UNO wants to reduce them sharply and eliminate the draft. That position was already enticing some soldiers to desert in anticipation of Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration. When asked why there was negotiation if the Sandinistas were willing to give up control, Bendana said that was part of the political process. ``Yes, you're going to have a tug of interests, but that's what democracy is all about,'' said Bendana. Despite the Sandinista leadership's conciliatory attitude, discontent continued to appear at lower levels of the party. Outside the city of Masaya, 17 miles southeast of Managua, a group of at least a dozen armed men occupied an abandoned stone fort once used as a prison by Somoza. At another location near Masaya, the head of a seized operation that grows a variety of crops and gins cotton said workers there would not give the business up to private ownership. Esteban Correa, a Sandinista loyalist who manages the operation, said he had 50 rifles and was asking the party for more.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Health Care
DOC.TEXT: Here are key points in the Pepper Commission's recommendations for health care. The recommendations fall into two areas, access to health care, and long-term care. ACCESS= _Businesses with 100 or fewer employees would be encouraged to provide health insurance for their employees and non-working dependents. Tax credits and subsidies would be available, and self-employed and unincorporated businesses could deduct 100 percent of premiums. Employers who buy coverage and achieve a specified coverage target would not be required to participate in the federal public health insurance plan. _All businesses with more than 100 employees must provide private health insurance, for a specified package of benefits, or contribute to the public plan for all employees and non-working dependents. _The public plan would cover employees and dependents that contribute and non-working individuals who buy in or are subsidized. It would replace Medicaid and pay providers according to Medicare rules. It would be financed and administered primarily by the federal government, although states could opt to administer it. _The minimum benefit package includes primary and preventive care, physician and hospital care and other services. There would be cost-sharing, with subsidies for low-income people and limits on out-of-pocket spending. _At full implementation, all Americans would be required to have health insurance through their employer or the public plan. _The plan contains a provision that could require the secretary of health and human services to submit to Congress a plan for insuring any remaining uninsured employees of small companies after five years. LONG-TERM= _Severely disabled people of all ages would be eligible for social insurance for home and community-based care. _A nursing home program would be established providing protection so that no one must be impoverished before receiving covered long-term care. Individuals could keep their homes and $30,000 in assets _ couples could keep up to $60,000. _The federal and state governments would share financial responsibility for the nursing home program. The federal government would finance the home and community-based care program and the first three months of care. _States are responsible for cost containment, quality assurance and consumer protection. _Private long-term care insurance fills gaps not covered by the plan, subject to government standards.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Don Simpson did some quick soul searching after finding a wallet containing $1,900 in an Interstate 44 restroom but decided it wouldn't be right to keep the money for himself. ``I heard the ol' devil saying, `Take it,' but I just couldn't do it,'' he said. Simpson, 47, found the money last week while cleaning the men's room at a rest stop west of Joplin in southwestern Missouri. He turned the wallet containing 18 $100 bills and two $50s over to Linda Dewitz, his supervisor at Joplin Workshops Inc. The wallet contained no identification other than a bank slip from Boatmen's Bank of Carthage. The bank tracked down the owner, who asked not to be identified, and Mrs. Dewitz returned the money to him. ``He was crying,'' she said. ``He had taken the money out to pay a lawyer in another state over a probate deal. He said, `There's just not honest people like this left in the world.' He said we were angels sent. He was overjoyed.'' Not too overjoyed: He gave Simpson and Mrs. Dewitz each a $25 reward.

With a little help from the Georgia College basketball team, police have returned an old barber pole to its rightful place. After a weeklong absence, the rotating barber pole that has twirled outside the Ideal Barber Shop since the early 1930s is once again on display. The pole, about 3 feet tall, was ripped from the wall outside the barber shop last week, apparently by college pranksters in this central Georgia town. Ken Vance, Georgia College police chief, said he recovered the pole with the help of several members of the college basketball team who have their hair cut at the shop. ``They were pretty incensed,'' he said. Vance said he had obtained ``a good idea who did it,'' and left word he wanted the pole back. It was returned undamaged. ``It's just like an old buddy of mine come home,'' shop owner James Wooten said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says Space Tapes Endangered
DOC.TEXT: Irreplaceable scientific information from U.S. space missions is in danger because of the ``deplorable'' conditions in which NASA allows hundreds of thousands of magnetic tapes to be stored, a congressional agency says. The General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress that audits the performance of federal agencies, said Friday that investigators found tapes in dusty hallways and in a basement where some had been partially submerged by a flood. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, in a letter signed by John E. O'Brien, assistant deputy administrator, told the GAO, ``We take ... strong exception to the implication that NASA is not safeguarding the space science data as a national resources for future generations. ``We believe that the tone of the report is unnecessarily harsh and contains sweeping generalizations and extrapolations which we believe to be unfounded and unsubstantiated,'' O'Brien said. NASA said it had experienced ``no significant loss of scientific data as identified by our science customers.'' It also said its own testing has shown ``a more than satisfactory preservation of data.'' The GAO in turn rejected NASA's criticism and said there was reason for concern that data stored on the tapes is ``at serious risk of becoming partially or completely unusable.'' The congressional monitors said they had visited 10 tape storage and processing facilities and had found that eight failed to comply with at least two of the regulations established by the National Archives and Records Administration for the handling of magnetic tapes. In a summary of its findings, the GAO said, ``Hundreds of thousands of tapes containing space science data are stored under deplorable conditions.'' Five of the facilities lacked ``adequate temperature and humidity control, fire protection, water protection or tape maintenance,'' the congressional agency said. ``In some instances, GAO found tapes stored in hallways, basements, and dusty warehouses not designed for tape storage. For example, in one major facility, GAO found nearly 300,000 tapes packed in boxes covered by dust and stacked on shipping pallets.'' In one place, the agency said, it found more than 4,000 tapes stored in a dirty basement that had been flooded in 1985, submerging approximately half of some of the tapes and leaving a film of debris on them. The GAO said that ``some of the most significant tape management deficiencies'' were found in the two largest facilities: the National Space Science Data Center at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., which stores more than 113,000 magnetic tapes; and the Tape Staging and Storage Facility in Landover, Md., which stores and tracks more than 860,000 tapes. By contrast, the agency said the U.S. Geological Survey's EROS Data Center in Sioux Falls, S.D., and the Digital Equipment Corp.'s Data Protection Services in Dominguez Hills, Calif., were in full or partial compliance with federal standards and industry guidelines. Other facilities visited were the National Archives' Los Angeles Federal Records Center in Laguna Niguel, Calif., and its Washington National Records Center; the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Washington; the Multi-Mission Image Processing facility of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory and the Infrared Processing and Analysis Center of the California Institute of Technology, both in Pasadena, Calif.; and the Center for Astrophysics and Space Sciences of the University of California at San Diego in La Jolla, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Council Says U.S. Should Explore Use of Nuclear Power in Space
DOC.TEXT: Space explorers will have to use nuclear power on Mars, and the National Science Council says the United States should study employing nuclear rockets to get travelers to the planet. In a Friday report to Vice President Dan Quayle, the council acknowledged ``formidable barriers of public acceptance'' to the use of nuclear power in space. However, it said the use of such power ``eventually will be essential'' on both the Moon and Mars because of heavy energy demands. It also recommended testing and possibly a demonstration in space of the feasibility of sending rockets to Mars by nuclear propulsion. The report analyzed a study done by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration as part of President Bush's initiative to put bases on the Moon and Mars early in the next century. Among its findings: _NASA needs to study the effects of long-term space flight on human beings because on the basis of present knowledge ``a multiyear exposure to weightlessness, even with on-board exercise and countermeasures and an intermediate stay on the surface of Mars, presents unacceptable risks to the crew.'' _Operation of a U.S. space station by the late 1990s as scheduled is a ``reasonable assumption,'' but plans for the station are not adequate for a Moon-Mars mission. The station ``may not be the most appropriate staging base for the Moon and Mars'' and it is possible that ``an additional station ... will eventually become necessary.'' _Although the NASA proposals envision bases on Mars, ``it appears that a station in Mars orbit requires a less demanding infrastructure than a surface base and might serve a useful purpose in the early stages of human space exploration.'' _Possibilities for international cooperation should be explored because breakthroughs have been made in Europe, Japan and elsewhere and ``most importantly, the USSR has substantial relevant capability, demonstrated continued interest in Mars, and an apparent strong desire for cooperation with the U.S. in Mars exploration.'' The council's study, made by a 14-member committee named in January, said nuclear rockets would reach Mars in one-half to one-third the time needed for single-stage chemical propulsion systems. Unmanned spacecraft have made the 111 million mile voyage to Mars in six months. ``The use of nuclear technology in space faces formidable barriers of public acceptance, however, especially if employed in Earth orbit,'' the council said. ``Therefore, issues of safety are paramount in research and development.'' It said one type of nuclear technology, known as the NERVA class, ``is available for full-scale development'' and ``should be evaluated for injection to Mars in competition with hydrogen-oxygen chemical systems.'' ``If careful systems studies ... show a significant advantage for nuclear rockets in trip time or in weight to orbit, an in-space demonstration of this technology should be done as soon as possible,'' the council said. ``It will not be feasible to select the nuclear rocket as a baseline in a system architecture until such a demonstration has been conducted.'' After announcing the Moon-Mars initiative July 20, the 20th anniversary of the first Moon landing, Bush asked Quayle, chairman of the National Space Council, to explore ways of carrying it out. NASA made a 90-day study, and Quayle asked the National Research Council, an arm of the congressionally chartered National Academy of Sciences, to evaluate it.

DOC.HEAD: Street Renaming Sparks Controversy in Placid Portland
DOC.TEXT: City leaders had hoped a street named after slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. would foster feelings of hope and pride, but now they worry the backlash will sully Portland's image. The street name has been met with an organized opposition led by a conservative political veteran. A white supremacist leader joined the opponents, and they collected 52,435 signatures on a ballot initiative to reverse the name change. A judge nixed their drive on Wednesday, but the opponents appealed Friday with the Oregon Supreme Court in hopes of meeting a March 15 deadline to put the initiative on the May 15 primary ballot. A civic leader says that the controversy, combined with the 1988 beating death of an Ethiopian immigrant by a group of neo-Nazi ``skinheads,'' may give blacks second thoughts about moving to the city. Three men have received long prison sentences for the beating death. ``Unfortunately, I think the city is going to take a bad rap over this, particularly as we try to attract other people of color to Portland,'' said Bernie Foster, a member of a citizens' committee that recommended the King street name. ``You have to ask what kind of message are we sending.'' If the story has a familiar ring, it is because the same drama has been played out in Seattle, San Diego, and Austin, Texas. In Seattle, a 1983 decision to rename a street Martin Luther King Way was upheld by the Washington Supreme Court. In San Diego, voters decided to strip King's name from a major street and return to the former name of Market Street. And in Austin, a court decision to overturn a 1975 street name change was upheld by a municipal appeals court. The King name was adopted in a separate action a year later. Portland's Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard is a 7-mile street on the city's east side formerly known as Union Avenue. It is a thoroughfare notorious for crime and prostitution. The citizens committee that recommended the name change hoped it would symbolize hope, stimulate pride and eventually lead to the street's revitalization. The City Council voted unanimously to approve the name change last April. Mayor Bud Clark was among the supporters. But when city officials and black leaders celebrated the name change last summer, Rosalie Huss and two dozen others picketed the crowd and heckled speakers. ``The City Council made a big mistake,'' Mrs. Huss told reporters, ``and they will probably have to pay for it with egg on their faces.'' Mrs. Huss, the executive director of the Citizens for Union Avenue campaign, maintains the name change was forced on an unwilling public. Two separate polls showed voters were leaning 2-1 in favor of the initiative, which was to have appeared on the May 15 primary ballot. John Baxter, treasurer of Citizens for Union Avenue, is another leading opponent of the King street name. He compares King to Betty Crocker. ``She was not a real person either,'' Baxter says. Mrs. Huss, who owns no property and has no business interests on the street, says her only stake is that of a concerned citizen. She and her husband, Walter, however, have a history of opposition to the civil rights leader that stretches back 30 years. In the 1960s, the Husses published a right-wing newspaper that frequently linked King's activities to communist causes. Huss denies any implication that her grass-roots campaign is racially motivated. She also says her group neither sought nor welcomed the support of Nationalist Movement leader Richard Barrett, a white supremacist who visited Portland last month to campaign for Union Avenue. The legal issue in Portland was whether the City Council action had been legislative _ setting policy _ or administrative, implementing a policy already in place. Multnomah County Circuit Judge Harl Haas agreed with King Boulevard supporters that the council's decision was administrative. Only legislative decisions are subject to initiative review under Oregon law.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel Investigating Durenberger Appearances
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee says it's investigating more than 100 paid appearances by Sen. Dave Durenberger in 1985-86, along with ``gifts of limousine service'' valued at nearly $5,000. A committee letter to the Minnesota Republican, released Friday, disclosed new details of an investigation into Durenberger's book promotion deal and the limousine trips. The committee voted last week to hold trial-like proceedings to determine whether Senate rules were violated by Durenberger, or whether any of his actions should be referred to the Justice Department for a criminal investigation. The panel's letter was a formal notice of the action and a statement of possible violations, a notice required by committee rules. ``I will continue to cooperate fully with the committee and will present evidence demonstrating that there was no intent on my part to violate or circumvent Senate rules,'' Durenberger said after receiving the letter. The committee revealed for the first time it is investigating 113 paid appearances by Durenberger in 1985-86 _ described by the senator as book promotions that should not have counted toward the Senate's outside income limits. Durenberger said his purpose was to sell his books on defense and health issues. Durenberger ``may have violated'' two federal laws, the committee said, when he arranged to charge fees for his speeches, give the money to his publisher and have the publisher pay him $100,000. The arrangement was not counted in the outside income limits. Some of the organizations that invited Durenberger to speak said they considered the appearances standard speeches by a senator, and that book sales were not mentioned. Paid speeches by senators in their official capacities are counted toward the outside earnings limits, which have changed over the years. The committee letter said Durenberger ``may have violated'' Senate rules _ and the Ethics In Government Act _ ``by failing to disclose in a timely fashion'' the travel expense reimbursements he received from 43 appearances. The committee previously had not disclosed the number of reimbursements under investigation. Durenberger amended his annual financial disclosure forms in July to include the reimbursement information on what he called book promotion appearances. He took the action only after the committee's investigation was under way. Durenberger may have violated Senate rules, the committee said, by ``accepting gifts of limousine service'' on 21 occasions in 1985-86 for a value of $4,935. Durenberger has said the limousines, provided by private organizations, shuttled him between official appearances in Boston and his marriage counselor in Concord, Mass. The committee had not previously revealed the number or value of the limousine trips. The panel said it's investigating ``whether you may have converted a campaign contribution to your personal use'' in violation of Senate rules, and ``failed to report and deposit'' the $5,000 donation in violation of federal law. The letter revealed, for the first time, the check was written by the Pathology Practice Association Federal Political Action Committee, and dated Dec. 30, 1986. The committee also said Durenberger may have violated federal law ``by giving speeches in the U.S. Capitol and Senate facilities'' to promote his books. The panel, for the first time, said Durenberger brought in $6,250 from the speeches _ which took place on six occasions between March and November, 1985. The panel also said it is investigating generally whether Durenberger engaged in improper conduct that may reflect upon the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Seeks to Smooth Over Differences With Shamir
DOC.TEXT: With tempers rising in Israel, the State Department is trying to smooth over a dispute with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir about the settlement of Soviet Jewish refugees on the predominantly Arab West Bank and in Gaza. But diplomatic sources familiar with Israel's views said Friday that differences over a $400 million U.S. loan guarantee and Baker's giving ``a clean bill of health'' to the Palestine Liberation Organization on terrorism could make it very difficult for Shamir to agree to opening Mideast negotiations. The sources, declining to be identified, said Shamir had been prepared to recommend the Israeli government approve in principle a three-way meeting among Baker and the Egyptian and Israeli foreign ministers. But now, the sources said, that would be ``almost impossible.'' Shamir is due to meet with leaders of his governing Likud political coalition tonight and with Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, Finance Minister Shimon Peres and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin on Sunday. The sessions are critical to Baker's five-month drive to launch negotiations by meeting here with Arens and Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid and then having Israelis meet with Palestinians in Cairo. ``Obviously there are some tough decisions that have to be made,'' said Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman. ``We hope that we will be able to take the next step to implement the prime minister's initiative.'' She referred to Shamir's plan for elections among the 1.4 million to 1.7 million Palestinians who live on the West Bank and in Gaza. The winners would negotiate with Israel a trial period of limited self-rule to be followed by broader talks on an overall agreement five years later. Baker has endorsed the plan as a starting point for negotiations. However, he has been stymied by a dispute between Israel and Egypt over the composition of the Palestinian delegation and the agenda for the Cairo meeting. On Thursday, testifying before a House subcommittee, Baker took two steps that stirred controversy in Jerusalem. He said the Bush administration could not extend a $400 million guaranteed loan to Israel for housing for Soviet Jewish refugees if they were settled on the West Bank or in Gaza, as about 100 of the thousands of new immigrants have been. Also, Baker said he was satisfied that PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat was adhering to his December 1988 renunciation of terrorism against Israel. Baker said there was no evidence of Arafat's complicity or acquiescence in terrorism since then. The pledge and Arafat's acknowledgement of Israel's existence prompted the Reagan administration to open talks with the PLO in Tunisia. In the ensuing furor in Israel over Baker's testimony, the State Department on Friday emphasized Baker's support for the Shamir plan and for Jewish emigration. Ms. Tutwiler said Baker had called Shamir late in the afternoon _ after testifying _ to underscore that the Shamir plan was the centerpiece of U.S. diplomacy on the Arab-Israeli dispute. However, the U.S. official reiterated that the U.S. loan guarantee, which is in addition to $3 billion in annual U.S. aid to Israel, depended on ``some assurances'' the housing would not be used by Soviet Jews settled on the West Bank and in Gaza. Asked about Shamir's reply, Ms. Tutwiler said: ``I cannot characterize for you that the secretary has received assurances.'' But she said ``there was no indication'' in the conversation that the prime minister was unhappy with the testimony. Ms. Tutwiler said Baker had decided to call Shamir on Wednesday and it ``had nothing to do with his testimony.'' Trying to accentuate the positive, Ms. Tutwiler said ``the prime minister once again thanked Secretary Baker for all of his tireless efforts and the amount of time he has devoted'' to trying to implement Shamir's plan. Yossi Ahimeir, an aide to Shamir, confirmed in Jerusalem there was a call from Baker, but disagreed with Ms. Tutwiler's description. ``The prime minister expressed his resentment about the connection Baker made between immigration and settlement,'' he said. ``There was a long talk about the whole issue.'' Ahimeir would not elaborate. On a related issue, the State Department late Friday criticized Israel for requiring that all material on immigration of Soviet Jews be submitted to the military censor before publication. ``Our position on freedom of the press and censorship is well-known,'' the department said in a statement. ``We are inquiring further into the details.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Panels Criticize Navy Report on Iowa Blast
DOC.TEXT: Congressional panels that strongly criticize the Navy's conclusion that Gunner's Mate Clayton Hartwig likely set off the USS Iowa explosion fault the service for reaching a tenuous hypothesis. The Navy's finding of a cause for the April 19 explosion that killed 47 sailors, including Hartwig, ``is based on evidence inadequate to support the conclusion,'' the panels said in a 48-page report released Friday. The two groups within the House Armed Services Committee _ the Investigations Subcommittee and Defense Policy Panel _ cited what lawmakers said were four major flaws in the Navy inquiry: the structure of the investigation, technical tests, police work and psychological analysis. ``By the standards of this subcommittee _ and the standards that we think should have been applied in the Navy's investigation _ there is only a hypothesis, and a tenuous one at that,'' the report said. The Navy concluded in its September report that Hartwig ``most likely'' caused the explosion by inserting some type of detonator between bags of gunpowder in one of the ship's 16-inch guns. Navy officials acknowledged then that their evidence was circumstantial since Hartwig and all the witnesses were killed. The Navy said in statement Friday that it ``stands by its conclusion that the explosion ... was the result of the wrongful, intentional act most probably'' committed by Hartwig. ``This conclusion was reached after an intensive investigation during which the Navy conducted more than 20,000 technical tests and ruled out possible accidental causes including mechanical failure, friction, propellant instability and personnel error,'' the Navy said. Ellis Rubin, a Miami lawyer representing former Gunner's Mate Kendall Truitt, who was linked to the blast in several news reports, said Truitt's family was ``gratified an official agency of the government has cleared up this matter.'' Truitt was the beneficiary of Hartwig's insurance policy. ``Congress is finally ruling on what we've known all along,'' Truitt said from the restaurant where he works in Land O'Lakes, Fla. ``Thank God for objective congressmen.'' The new report, ``USS Iowa Tragedy: An Investigative Failure,'' summarizes many of the complaints House members raised in December during three days of hearings into the explosion. ``The only thing more tragic than the deaths of the 47 young seamen last April was the Navy's failure to conduct a proper investigation of the event,'' Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., chairman of the investigations subcommittee, said in a statement issued with the report's release. The congressional report faulted the Navy for conducting a one-man inquiry and never upgrading to a board of investigators when it became clear that the explosion cause might have been criminal, not technical. In addition, it wasn't until May 8 _ nearly three weeks after the blast _ that the Naval Investigative Service focused on the possibility of a criminal act, the report said. ``At this time ... NIS was faced with a contaminated crime scene, no chain of custody for evidence and a virtual inability to conduct a proper criminal inquiry from an evidentiary standpoint,'' the report said. The congressional report also questioned the Navy's selective use of information from the FBI. The service asked the FBI to corroborate the findings of the Navy's technical team regarding the possibility a timing device caused the blast. But when the FBI was unable to back up that finding, the Navy did not use the report, deemed it inconclusive and told the FBI that additional tests were unnecessary, the congressional report said. At the same time, the panels attacked the psychological analysis conducted by the FBI and cited the assessment of 10 of 14 experts the subcommittees consulted who determined that the FBI analysis was invalid. Three FBI psychologists testified in December that Hartwig _ based on his letters, interviews with the seaman's family and friends and his personal history _ was ``egocentric, shy ... not sufficiently aggressive, had a low self-esteem,'' that added up to a suicidal loner.

DOC.HEAD: Newest Kohl Stance On Border Issue Gets Sharp Reaction from Poles
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl proposed a treaty guaranteeing Poland's western border if the Warsaw government confirms German minority rights and a 1953 renunciation of war reparations. Poland's prime minister responded by saying he is ``astonished'' by the demands. While Kohl's offer Friday was apparently intended to defuse domestic and international criticism over the borders of a single Germany, Polish officials said it only broadened the dispute over unification. Facing close elections in December, Kohl has tried to appease a minority of West German voters who want to lay claim to some or all of Germany's prewar borders, which would encompass one-third of modern-day Poland. On Friday, demonstrators in Warsaw marched for a second day in support of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's demand that Poland take part in international talks on a unified Germany. Demonstrations were held in six cities Thursday. Mazowiecki told West German television Friday night: ``This hour which is very important for the Germans, the hour of the reunification process, is not just a German hour. It it is an hour of Europe, of Germany's neighbors.'' Earlier Friday, Kohl's government offered an eventual treaty guaranteeing Poland's western border after German unification but linked it to confirmation of Poland's 1953 decision not to seek war reparations. Such a treaty also would be tied to reassurances of Poland's pledge to protect the rights of its German minority, said West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel. Kohl has come under intense criticism for his stance on lands east of the Oder and Neisse rivers ceded to Poland after Nazi Germany's 1945 defeat. Poland wants reassurance that once Germany is united it will not seek to reclaim those lands. Poland in turn lost some of its eastern territory to the Soviet Union after the war. Mazowiecki has also demanded that Poland be included in the talks on German unification between the two German states and the victorious World War II allies: the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France. The process was announced last month in Ottawa. Kohl has repeatedly said Germans have no designs on the territory but has insisted that final say can only come from a future united German government. Mazowiecki, after hearing of Kohl's latest position, said ``there is no reason to think we won't keep our word'' on guaranteeing the ethnic rights of Poland's German minority. He also said Poland sees no reason to expand the scope of the border issue. ``But if Bonn wants to expand the problem, please, we also have something to say. For example, there's the question of compensation for Polish forced laborers in the Third Reich,'' said Mazowiecki. West German-Polish relations have been sensitive for much of the postwar period, mainly because of uneasy feelings that still linger 51 years after Nazi Germany's 1939 invasion of Poland. East Germany's Communist premier, Hans Modrow, has backed Mazowiecki's demand for a place in the talks. For the first time Friday, Kohl openly said both Germanys could conclude a treaty that would recognize Poland's western border for a united Germany. But at the same time he demanded Poland's 1953 decision on war reparations be an element of such agreement, as well as Poland's assurance last year that the ethnic rights of its German minority would be guaranteed. In the statement delivered by Vogel, Kohl also again avoided stating outright that a united Germany would claim to land ceded to Poland. According to Vogel, Kohl reiterated his support for both German parliaments passing an identical declaration pledging to respect the current borders after East Germany elects its first freely chosen Parliament on March 18. Vogel said ``such a declaration must at the same time make clear that the August 23, 1953 declaration of the Polish government, in which reparations against Germany are renounced, continues unchanged.'' The Western powers ended reparations collections from West Germany in 1952. The Soviet Union did the same for fellow Communist state East Germany a year later, while Poland also said it would not seek reparations. Vogel said that ``on the basis'' of a border resolution by the German parliaments ``a treaty between an overall German government with the Polish government should be concluded and be ratified by a united German Parliament.''

DOC.HEAD: KGB Defector Goes Public
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: A KGB defector, who is looking for a publisher for the book he's written, is going public with tales of alleged Soviet involvement in a plot to kill the pope and spies inside the State Department. Victor Ivanovich Sheymov, once KGB agent 04035, said Friday that in the late 1970s the Soviet Union had two sources inside the State Department able to deliver secret information on U.S. policy and negotiating positions. But he said he had no idea who they might be. He also said he was present in the Warsaw station of the KGB in 1979 when a cable arrived from Moscow ordering what he believed to be the initial stages of a plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II. Nearly a decade after the CIA arranged his disappearance from Moscow on May 15, 1980, Sheymov, 43, held a news conference to tell at least some of his story in public and to announce: ``I have written a book and am thinking how to publish it.'' After a 78-minute session in which he dodged or declined to answer questions on specific Soviet espionage activities, Sheymov passed out business cards bearing the name Victor Orlov, which he has used for the last decade. His most sensational allegation was that while on a trip to Poland in 1979, the chief of the KGB's Warsaw station showed him a cable from Yuri Andropov, then the KGB's chief, reading: ``Obtain all the information possible on how to get physically close to the pope.'' ``In KGB slang it was clearly indicated that there was only one reason to get close to a person and that was to assassinate him, kill him,'' he said. Allegations of Soviet involvement in a plot to murder the pope surfaced after an attempt on the pontiff's life in 1981 by a Turkish gunman. No connection to Moscow was ever firmly established. Sheymov, a former KGB major and communications expert whose 1980 defection was kept secret for a decade, said he told his story to the CIA but does not know what was done with the information. Sheymov told the news conference that the Soviet spy agency had two sources inside the State Department. He was asked to provide specifics and declined, saying, ``I cannot comment on these kinds of matters.'' He said that the information received from the alleged spies included ``policy matters, positions on negotiations, outlines of arms control positions.'' When asked for a reaction to Sheymov's allegations, David Denny, a State Department spokesman said, ``As a matter of policy we do not comment on intelligence matters, such as this.'' The department is trying to fire Felix S. Bloch, a career diplomat suspected of spying for the Soviet Union. No charges have been brought against Bloch who was reportedly videotaped passing a suitcase to a Soviet agent in Paris. Asked if he knew for certain that Bloch was a spy, Sheymov replied: ``I cannot answer that question.'' In his meeting with reporters, Sheymov wore tinted glasses and what appeared to be a bushy blond wig. The defector answered many questions with non-responsive one-liners. ``I live in a wonderful section of the country,'' he replied when asked where he resided. When asked how much he had been paid by the CIA, he replied: ``Are you a salesman for mutual funds?'' What had he told his neighbors when they asked about his background? ``I told them I was not who I was,'' he said. ``I lied.''

DOC.HEAD: Dole's Dog a Daddy, But Should Have Been Neutered, Animal Shelter Says
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bob Dole's dog missed a date with the doctor, and that has some people howling in protest. Leader, the power pooch owned by the Senate minority leader and Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, became a media star earlier this week when the schnauzer was displayed at a Capitol news conference along with a litter of his puppies. But it seems that Leader wasn't supposed to become a daddy. The Doles adopted the dog from the Washington Humane Society in November 1984. The adoption contract required that Leader be neutered within seven days. But it hasn't happened yet _ more than five years later. Proof came from the Doles when they unveiled the litter of eight puppies sired by Leader. The other half of the canine couple was a schnauzer owned by Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C. Jean Johnson, executive director of the Washington Humane Society, was reluctant to discuss the case but confirmed Friday that the organization is ``working with the Doles on how best to resolve our concerns.'' ``It's put us in a most awkward situation because we're very strong proponents of sterilization and making every effort not to contribute to the animal overpopulation problem,'' Johnson said. Walt Riker, press secretary for the Kansas Republican, couldn't explain why the Doles failed to neuter their dog. But he said the Doles have no plans for more puppies and emphasized that the Thurmond-Dole litter would go to loving homes. ``He's not on the loose ... which made this a selective breeding,'' Riker said of Leader. ``It wasn't like he was roaming the streets of Washington creating litters all over town.'' According to Johnson, the standard policy is for an adult dog such as Leader to be neutered before the would-be owners take the animal home. But exceptions are made on ``a rare occasion,'' she said. After the seven-day deadline passed in 1984, the Humane Society asked the Doles to follow through with the neutering. Johnson declined to say whether there were more reminders. One animal welfare activist said the case was troubling because of the widespread publicity about the puppies and their prominent owners. ``This is a slight case of somebody who makes laws for all of us, not obeying this one,'' said Kay Richter, who helps find homes for unwanted dogs in the Washington area.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves AZT for People Infected With AIDS-Causing Virus
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration says the drug AZT may be recommended for adults infected with the virus that causes AIDS even if the patients don't have symptoms of the disease. The drug has been used for three years to treat patients severely ill with AIDS and related problems. ``The studies and the change in labeling mean that better treatment can now be offered to thousands of people at earlier stages of infection with the AIDS virus before their health deteriorates critically,'' Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said in a statement. FDA on Friday approved new labels expanding the drug's use after two federally sponsored studies showed that AZT slowed progress of the disease when administered to infected patients with early symptoms or none at all. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and Burroughs Wellcome Co., the drug manufacturer, conducted trials involving 2,000 volunteers. AZT was shown to slow down the progress of AIDS while causing far fewer severe side effects than those suffered by patients in advanced stages of the disease. The FDA move should make it easier for patients to obtain reimbursement under their health insurance policies, said Burroughs Wellcome vice president J.R. Whitehead. Earlier this year the FDA approved a labeling change that cut in half the recommended adult dose of AZT. The change reduced both the frequency of side effects and the cost of treatment to patients. On Oct. 26, the FDA approved the use of AZT for children with advanced cases of AIDS. The expanded application announced Friday applies to adults only, but an agency spokesman said the question of making AZT treatment available earlier to HIV-infected children is expected to come up at an FDA advisory meeting later this month. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is a contagious disease that attacks the body's immune system, rendering it incapable of resisting other diseases and infections. As of Dec. 31, 1989, AIDS had been diagnosed in 117,781 Americans, of whom 60 percent, or 70,313, have died since June 1, 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Overturns $43.2 Million Ruling Against Toyota
DOC.TEXT: A judge set aside a $43.2 million judgment against Toyota and ordered a new trial in a civil case brought by a woman who watched her husband, two daughters and two other people burn to death in a 1982 car fire. Arthur C. Lesher Jr., a retired state district judge, overturned the Dec. 14 ruling after a three-hour hearing Friday. In an interview later, Lesher said, ``I found that in the interest of justice and fairness, it should be tried again.'' He would not elaborate. Lesher presided over the six-week trial against Torrance, Calif.-based Toyota Motor Sales USA Inc. last fall. A jury found Toyota negligent in the design of its 1973 Corona station wagon. On Dec. 29, Lesher signed off the jury's award of $18.2 million in actual damages and $25 million in exemplary damages to Nike Adegbite, 36, whose husband and two daughters died in the burning car along with two others. The $43.2 million judgment was the largest award ever entered against the Japanese car company. Texas courts on occasion call retired judges back to the bench because of a statewide case backlog. Houston attorney Stan Pfeiffer, who represents Mrs. Adegbite, was angered by Friday's ruling. ``This trial judge has felt compelled for whatever reason to completely ignore the findings of the jury,'' Pfeiffer said. ``There was no substantive complaint about the trial procedure alleged by Toyota nor that this jury was being unreasonable.'' But Douglas M. West, Toyota's vice president-general counsel for product law, said the company believed the verdict and the size of the damage award were unfair. ``We felt, taken as a whole, the evidence presented to the jurors did not support the finding of a defect in the 1973 model and it did not support the damages that were awarded, particularly the $25 million in punitive damages,'' West said by telephone from California. During the trial, Pfeiffer said the Sept. 26, 1982, accident happened when the driver of the Toyota station wagon, Boyo Adetoye, tried to steer off a roadway because he had a flat tire, and his car was struck by a van. The impact pushed the station wagon's fuel tank forward and the tank was punctured by an empty spare tire carrier and a valve on the rear axle, Pfeiffer said in December. The car burst into flames.
