Adetoye and Mrs. Adegbite escaped with burns and minor injuries, but Adetoye's wife and child were killed the fire, as were Mrs. Adegbite's husband and two children. Adetoye has settled with Toyota for an undisclosed sum. West argued that the accident ``was extremely violent and far beyond the kind of accidents that can be designed for.'' But jury foreman Larry Phipps said he was ``very much astounded'' that the verdict was overturned. ``It's almost as though several weeks of going down there (to the courthouse) daily was just thrown down the drain for no apparent reason,'' Phipps said. ``I do feel the jury did fulfill their responsibility as prescribed by the court and rendered their decision in good faith.''

DOC.HEAD: Gun Law Crackdown Will be Mounted in 8 Cities
DOC.TEXT: Federal task forces are moving into eight cities later this month to try to catch people breaking federal gun laws that bring mandatory prison sentences. The Project Achilles task forces will be in place by March 26 in New York, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami, Detroit, Washington and Phoenix, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said Friday. The ATF conducted a similar, four-month Armed Career Criminal operation in Washington last year as a prelude to the upcoming project. Congress last year included $4.5 million in the ATF's budget for 1990 specifically as salaries for 75 fulltime workers in the Achilles task forces in five cities, but the ATF expanded that number to eight. The agents will work with state and local law enforcement officials. The task forces will be targeting people under two sections of federal law that call for mandatory sentencing. One says anyone convicted of a felony crime of violence or drug charge who is carrying a gun automatically is sentenced for at least five years on the weapon-possession charge. The other section says that a person who has three previous felony convictions for a violent crime or drug offense will be sentenced to at least 15 years on the firearm charge.
DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Move To Block Secord's Appeal Of His Guilty Plea
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutors are trying to block a court appeal by Richard Secord until a lower court judge decides whether to reinstate 11 other criminal charges against him. Secord, a retired Air Force major general, pleaded guilty Nov. 8 to making a false statement when he told congressional investigators he was unaware of any money that went to benefit Oliver North. But Secord announced his intention to appeal after his sentencing Jan. 24 and the government says he is trying to circumvent his plea agreement with the government. Under that plea agreement, the government agreed not to pursue 11 other criminal charges against Secord. The appeal is based on a contention by Secord's lawyers that independent counsel Lawrence Walsh lacks jurisdiction to prosecute for an offense arising out of Secord's testimony to Congress. Iran-Contra prosecutors Feb. 5 asked U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson to reconsider his decision dismissing the 11 other charges. ``While the District Court has before it important questions relating to the effectiveness of the plea agreement in this case,'' the appeals court proceedings should be stopped, prosecutors said in a court filing Friday. The government argues it was ``an act of bad faith'' for Secord to plead guilty with the undisclosed intent of challenging the validity of the plea.
DOC.HEAD: Auditors Cite Risk of Earthquake Damage at Nuclear Arms Site
DOC.TEXT: The Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina is inadequately protected against severe earthquakes and won't be fully protected for several years, say federal auditors. The report Friday by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said the vulnerability to earthquake damage at Savannah River has been known for many years. But it said the government only recently made serious corrective efforts. The plant has nuclear reactors to produce tritium, a radioactive gas needed to make nuclear warheads. The installation also contains other nuclear-related buildings, including a fuel processing center for the Navy and a radioactive waste treatment building. The three reactors have been closed for nearly two years because of safety problems. One of the three is expected to resume production by the end of this year. The auditors, in a report requested by Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on the environment and energy, said seismic improvements at Savannah River would not be completed for several years. Planning of improvements is under way, but ``it will take several years to accomplish adequate seismic protection at Savannah River,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Family Leaves Panama For Exile
LaserPhoto PAN1
DOC.TEXT: Surrounded by hundreds of people shouting ``Go away beggars!'' the family of deposed dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega left for Caribbean exile. The crowd shouted at Noriega's wife, three daughters, son-in-law and grandson as left the Cuban ambassador's residence Friday, where they sought refuge after the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion that overthrew the general. Throwing pennies at the Noriegas, some people said, ``This is to pay your husband's bail,'' referring to comments Noriega's wife, Felicidad Siero, made saying she would travel around Panama asking for donations for her husband's defense. Noriega is awaiting trial on drug charges in Miami, where he was extradited after taking refuge in the Vatican Embassy and later surrendering to U.S. authorities. The family arrived at the airport Friday night surrounded by Cuban diplomatic personnel, then left for Havana on Cubana de Aviacion. An airline employee said the Noriegas took ``dozens of trunks, cradles and suitcases.'' On Wednesday, the Panamanian government said that it would allow safe passage out of the country for Mrs. Noriega, daughters Lorena, Sandra and Thais, a son-in-law, Jean Rene Beauchamps and a 7-month-old grandson. Beauchamps, a Dominican who was the only family member to stay behind, is scheduled to leave next week after discussing allegations of financial irregularities with authorities. He is to pay a $10,000 bond before leaving. Beauchamps said the family would be going to the Dominican Republic, which offered them asylum. It was not clear when they would go from Cuba. After leaving the Cuban ambassador's residence Friday, the Noriegas went in a caravan of cars to the beachfront apartment of Sandra and her husband. Daughters Sandra and Lorena are accused of corruption, and Sandra paid a $50,000 bond to leave the country. The government granted safe conduct passes for the Noriegas on the condition that they would face extradition if they failed to return to face any charges. The U.S. and Panamanian governments allege that Noriega earned billions of dollars through illicit activity. Several of his bank accounts in various countries have been frozen.

DOC.HEAD: Unarmed Cruise Missile Crashes in Utah Desert
DOC.TEXT: An unarmed cruise missile malfunctioned during a test flight and crashed in southwest Utah about a quarter-mile from a main highway, the Air Force and a local official said Friday. The air-launched missile was being tested for the Strategic Air Command when it went down Tuesday southwest of Delta, said Lt. Col. Portia McCracken, spokeswoman at Ogden's Hill Air Force Base. A malfunction inside the missile triggered a system that sent it to ground to avoid an uncontrolled flight, she said. ``It fell in an unpopulated area,'' she said. The crash site is a desolate stretch of land about 100 miles southwest of Salt Lake City. But Millard County Sheriff Ed Phillips said the missile crashed about a quarter-mile from U.S. Highway 6-50, a main east-west route. ``We've had several of 'em go down over the years,'' Phillips said. ``That's really concerned me that it came down so close to the road.'' Two F-4 chase jets reported the crash and local authorities were notified, McCracken said. Phillips said a deputy was dispatched to guard the wreckage until Pentagon officials arrived. The wreckage was removed Thursday, McCracken said. Cruise missile tests are run by the 6545th Test Group based at Hill Air Force Base, McCracken said. The missile was aimed at the Utah Test and Recovery Range, about 60 miles northwest of the crash site.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am, TWA Flights Make Emergency Landings At O'Hare
DOC.TEXT: Two airliners bound from New York made safe emergency landings at O'Hare International Airport within five minutes of each other after reporting mechanical trouble, officials said. No injuries were reported Friday evening aboard either Boeing 727. TWA Flight 829 reported a warning light indicating problems with its ``anti-skid mechanism'' and landed safely at 7:55 p.m. CST, said Mort Edelstein, a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman. ``They have so many light signals on their panels, that when they go on, (pilots) don't monkey around _ you've got passengers on board,'' he said. The pilot of Pan Am Flight 2027, with 150 people, reported hydraulic problems and said he was worried about making the runway, officials said. The pilot manually lowered the landing gear and the plane was towed to the terminal after it landed safely at 8 p.m. CST, Edelstein said. Edelstein said airport officials alerted emergency personnel and had a score of fire trucks and ambulances on standby by the time the TWA flight landed. Flight 829, with 173 people on board, left O'Hare for Kansas City, its final destination, at 8:30 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Late Letter From Forbes Spooks Senator's Staffers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 2nd graf to say two sted three days after death
DOC.TEXT: A letter in which the late Malcolm Forbes offers jokingly to vote on behalf of the dead for Rudy Boschwitz startled the senator's staffers when it arrived in Boschwitz's office this week. The letter, written on stationery from Forbes' New York office, was dated Feb. 14 but did not arrive in the Washington, D.C., office until Monday, two days after Forbes died in his sleep at age 70, said Boschwitz's press secretary, Tim Droogsma. Forbes apparently wrote the letter to say he would not be able to appear at a fund-raiser for the Republican senator, Droogsma said. But in a bit of oddly prescient humor, Forbes also referred to the old vote fraud practice of casting the votes of dead people. ``I'm certainly supportive, and if you can locate a tombstone or two for me to vote from, I'll be happy to,'' Forbes wrote. Droogsma said the letter elicited a lot of ``oohs'' in the Boschwitz office.

DOC.HEAD: Electoral Violence Hurts Acapulco Tourism, State Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Election-related violence that blocked airport roads and left three people dead is scaring tourists from Acapulco and Ixtapa, costing the resorts millions of dollars in lost revenue, a government spokesman said. ``It's hurting the tourist industry. We're worried that the people who make a living from tourism are affected,'' Guerrero state spokesman Francisco Javier Rangel said Friday in a telephone interview. Tourism is Mexico's third-largest source of foreign exchange and the largest industry in western Guerrero state, where 60 percent of the population depends on tourism for a livelihood, Rangel said. On Tuesday, one policeman and two members of the opposition Democratic Revolutionary Party died as a result of armed confrontations between officers and protesters on airport roads in the Pacific coast state. The center-left party alleges fraud in official results from 20 of the state's 75 municipalities in elections Dec. 3. Other protests have occurred in neighboring Michoacan state. Supporters are blocking entrances to the 20 city halls in Guerrero where they claim election results were doctored, and they have taken control of tax collection in one of the towns. Acapulco and Ixtapa, 100 miles away, are not among the municipalities contested, but the demonstrations are affecting business there, Rangel said. An Acapulco hotel and restaurant association estimates losses at more than $6 million, he said. Rangel said charter planes and hotel reservations were canceled as a result of Tuesday's incidents, but that officials at the state's two international airports report that flights are running as usual. He said the state has doubled its highway patrols on all state highways since Tuesday to protect travelers. The opposition party is appealing state election returns at the Federal Electoral Commission, where Guerrero Gov. Francisco Ruiz Massieu discussed the problem Friday with Interior Secretary Gutierrez Barrios, Rangel said. Both officials belong to the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. The state has charged 16 opposition party members with a variety of offenses related to Tuesday's violence and has arrested about 30 others, Rangel said. ``We're not pressing the cases because they're party members, but because they committed offenses,'' he said. The opposition party members are charged with attempted homicide, attacks on traffic routes, resisting arrest, robbery, illegal arms and drug possession, Rangel said. The state has called on all Democratic Revolutionary Party leaders to avoid violence, Rangel said. Party leader Cuauhtemoc Cardenas on Wednesday blamed the governing party for ``unleasing'' the violence. ``If the authorities respected the law, there wouldn't have been electoral fraud on Dec. 3 and the continuing incidence of violence,'' Cardenas said. Cardenas ran for president in 1988, supported by a multiparty coalition, whose members later formed the Democratic Revolutionary Party. Cardenas and his supporters claim he won the presidency but was cheated out of victory by the PRI-dominated government.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Produces Record Amount of Food; Exports For First Time
DOC.TEXT:
Communist Vietnam said it exported grain last year for the first time, and it credited credited agricultural reform and favorable weather for the increased productivity. The official Vietnam News Agency, in a report seen today in Bangkok, also said the country increased its reserves in producing a record 21.4 million tons of food in 1989. Vietnam is one of the world's poorest nations, with chronic difficulties in feeding its 64 million million. In the past, it had to import about 750,000 tons annually. The report dated Friday said production rose because of good weather, increased state investment, reforms in agricultural management, high-yielding rice strains, and a single nationwide price policy. After a decade of disastrous economic policies, Vietnam in 1986 introduced reforms such as deregulating prices, permitting private enterprise and vastly curtailing subsidies to state enterprises.
Substantial gains in food production and in fighting inflation were made last year. The report said millions of tons of grain were exported but it did not further specify or say to which countries the food was shipped. It did not say what last year's production was or when the previous production record was achieved. The announcements were made at a Feb. 27-28 conference to review progress in agricultural production.

DOC.HEAD: Flying Glass Injures Two Passengers in Greyhound Strike
LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: Stranded Greyhound bus passengers were running out of money and patience waiting for buses to roll past lines of angry pickets after drivers went on strike against the only nationwide bus company. The strike's first day was mostly peaceful, but in Chicago two people were slightly injured on Friday by flying glass when a sniper fired two shots at a Greyhound bus leaving the city, Illinois State Police said. Greyhound Lines Inc. said it was operating 20 percent of its system with 700 newly hired replacement drivers, plus an unspecified number of union drivers who crossed picket lines. Passengers on a bus arriving in Des Moines, Iowa, early Friday also said strikers fired four shots at their bus as it left a Chicago depot. There were scattered reports of angry confrontations between strikers and replacement drivers in other cities. Union leaders appealed for calm. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, which represents more than 9,000 employees, including all 6,300 drivers and most maintenance and office workers, went on strike Friday after negotiators in Scottsdale, Ariz., failed to reach agreement on wage issues. In all, the company said 1,100 union-represented employees came to work. Greyhound said it would increase operations as more replacements become available. No talks were scheduled, and negotiators were planning to return home. Passengers, meanwhile, tried to figure out how to get home. Some angrily denounced the company for not warning of the strike. ``I'm stuck here and I don't know what to do,'' said Alvira Sheffield, who left from Maine on Thursday and spent the night in the Port Authority bus terminal in New York City. ``They knew about the strike. I don't know why they let me board the bus.'' Greyhound spokeswoman Elizabeth Hale said: ``Obviously we have not lived up to our expectations of making sure that our passengers were taken care of. ``I am sorry and it certainly was not intentional to leave anyone where they didn't want to be.'' Greyhound serves 9,500 destinations, including 9,000 where it is the only intercity transportation available. The company offers the cheapest form of such transportation, including an advance purchase one-way fare of $68 anywhere in the country, and the strike stranded many poor people trying to leave or return home to smaller communities. In Omaha, Neb., about 60 people _ many passengers on coast-to-coast trips _ filled the small downtown bus terminal, where babies sat on blankets, in car seats and in the arms of parents walking around luggage, bags and boxes. Amtrak told agents to honor Greyhound tickets when buses are unavailable, railroad spokeswoman Sue Martin said. Clifton Lenoir, 37, a New Orleans truck driver stranded in Dallas, said he was down to his last 85 cents but he wasn't angry at the drivers. ``They just want better working conditions and benefits. I don't blame them,'' Lenoir said. Other passengers were less sympathetic. ``It's getting to the point where we're ready to go out there and fire one of the buses up, run over the strikers and say, `See ya,''' said Frank Rzepski of Philadelphia, waiting in Indianapolis. ``I was supposed to be in Portland early (Friday) afternoon for a job interview,'' said Margaret Huffstadler of Eugene, Ore., as she waited in a bus depot. ``I guess I can kiss that one goodbye.'' Pickets outside the terminal in Columbus, Ohio, met buses crossing picket lines at the entrance and tried to stop drivers to ask them not to cross their lines. But the drivers inched their buses forward, nudging strikers. ``We certainly are intending for this to be a peaceful strike,'' union spokesman Jerry Nelson said. ``We do not condone violence during the strike nor destruction of property. We urge both sides to show restraint.'' A 47-day Greyhound drivers' strike in 1983 included several violent incidents. The drivers' union said in its final proposal Thursday that it would agree to wage increases limited to $17 million, or 5 percent, in the first year of a new contract, with $15 million in both of the final two years. The company was offering $14.1 million, $21 million and $27.7 million over the three years, but with some increases contingent on increased ridership, safety records and productivity factors. The union refuses to accept the contingencies. Greyhound drivers, who according to the company earned an average of $24,743 last year, took a 22 percent pay cut three years ago in negotiations prior to a leveraged buyout of the company.

DOC.HEAD: Caught in the Bus Strike
With PM-Greyhound Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The strike against Greyhound Lines Inc. disrupted the only nationwide bus company, dumping a few passengers in mid-journey to spend the night in terminals and to scramble for alternate transportation. Here are some vignettes:

In Des Moines, Iowa, passengers arriving from Chicago said they were shot at three times as their Greyhound bus left Chicago. There were no injuries and a small area on the windshield was broken and covered with tape. ``When the window cracked, everybody thought they were throwing rocks and then they hit it again, and they shot again and we got down a couple of more blocks,'' said passenger Terry Fisher. ``They chased the bus and threw cans and garbage cans at us. I didn't think we were going to make it to tell the truth.''

Passengers stranded in Atlanta, bored and busless, poured quarters into coin-operated television sets turned up loud to drown out a floor polisher and waited for a way out. A few grabbed cat naps. ``They left us, they flat left us here,'' said Simon Belle of Memphis, Tenn., who said he was trying to visit relatives in Florida. ``Now they won't do diddley, they wash their hands just like Pontius Pilate.''

In Raleigh, N.C., Carmen Bartee said she's been all over the state in her quest to get to Wilmington from Texas. ``Greensboro, Winston-Salem, where else did we go today?'' she asked. ``We've done a little bit of everywhere. ... I don't know how I got here. ``If you ask me, I think they should go back to work and let people go home,'' she said.

Rob Wilkins, 22, of London, said the strike had disrupted his plans to tour America by bus. He was trying to get from Minneapolis to Memphis, Tenn. ``I'm not going to see Elvis,'' he lamented. ``I come to bloody America and they're on strike.''

Sam Byler, an Amish farmer from Fort Plain 40 miles west of Albany, N.Y., took a Seneca Coach Line bus to Syracuse, hoping to board a Greyhound bus to reach a wedding in Pennsylvania. ``We didn't know about the strike, because we don't have radios and TVs like you people,'' Byler said. ``If we had known, we probably would have stayed home.''

Some passengers complained that they were unaware that a strike was looming and criticized Greyhound for selling them tickets when it was likely they wouldn't be able to complete their trips. ``They haven't even apologized,'' said Lisa Olkon, who was stuck in Atlanta while trying to get home to St. Paul, Minn., from Florida. ``I called about an hour before I went to get on the bus'' and was told nothing.

``I had heard of a possible strike, but I had no idea they were going to dump us,'' said Jennifer White, waiting in Indianapolis to return to Cleveland from a business trip in St. Louis. ``Because I'm afraid to fly, I chose Greyhound to leave the driving to them,'' she said, laughing.

After spending the night on a hard floor in the Indianapolis bus station, Frank Rzepski of Philadelphia had little sympathy for the drivers. ``It's getting to the point where we're ready to go out there and fire one of the buses up, run over the strikers and say, `See ya,' '' he said.

``I sympathize with them (passengers), but sometimes it comes to this,'' said Dwight Moody, an 11-year veteran driver from Charlotte. ``We're not asking for an arm and a leg, just a little something. A couple of cents a mile.'' Moody said despite Greyhound's ads that say first-year drivers can earn about $24,000 a year, he only earned about $16,000 in 1989. ``I got a W-2 (tax form) to prove it,'' he said.

Robert Eldridge of New York City said his trip home from San Diego came to a dead halt in Washington, D.C. ``It was 2:30 in the morning and Greyhound said we would have to finish on Amtrak. It's about nine blocks from the bus office to the train, but it's the middle of the night and the people at Greyhound said that a cab's $3,'' Eldridge said. He said cab drivers were soliciting riders at the Greyhound counters. When he and two fellow passengers arrived at the station, they were charged $16.

Jim Redel, Greyhound's Indianapolis area general manager coped with angry passengers. ``We try to console them and tell them help is on the way,'' Redel said of his advice to stranded passengers. ``I'm sorry it happened. Seems like nobody ever wins in a strike situation.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Experts, Activists Say Much Work Remains to End Sex Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: Economic hard times gripping Third World countries have created dire conditions for women and impeded efforts to wipe out sex discrimination and exploitation, U.N. experts and activists say. ``There has been some progress worldwide in life expectancy for women, declines in infant mortality and improvements in nutrition,'' said Vivian Lowery Derryck, president of the African-American Institute in New York. ``But when you get to the equality issues, the picture is starkly gloomy,'' she said. Deteriorating economic conditions have forced women to turn to begging, prostitution and other ``quasi-legal and illicit activities'' in India, Peru and several African nations, according to a UNICEF study. The observance of International Women's Day on Thursday and related activities worldwide will focus more attention on work to promote equal rights for men and women. The U.N. Commission on the Status of Women, meeting this week in Geneva, has concentrated on political and economic obstacles facing women, with a special interest in areas affected by armed conflicts or foreign intervention. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, in a special address to mark International Women's Day, plans to call for a renewed global commitment to improve conditions for women. ``Both men and women must work together as equal partners in order to ensure a sustainable future for the generation to come,'' the U.N. chief says in a prepared statement. Recent U.N. reports stress there is much more work to do. ``Poor women have become poorer, more women are poor, and women are now poorer in relation to men,'' one U.N. report says. ``Through their hard work they try to ensure the survival of the poorest segments of the population, but at great cost to themselves. ``This drain on women's time, resources and energy also inhibits their ability to participate in political life and hence in having an influence in changing the policies which affect them so adversely,'' the report adds. Economic problems also have diminished opportunities for young women, particularly in Latin America and Africa. ``The crisis has diminished educational and economic opportunities for young women, thus affecting their future ability to contribute to society on an equal basis with men,'' the U.N. report said. A UNICEF-sponsored study on Mexico found that the economic crisis had worsened conditions for women, particularly in rural areas. Because families could no longer survive intact in the countryside, young women were forced to migrate to find work. The report by UNICEF said women were pulled off the land to work as day laborers where they had no social benefits, lived in sheds and were easy targets for sexual abuse. And for those women left on the farms there was more work to do, the report said. Another UNICEF study concluded that at least one-third of the population with the lowest incomes in Latin America and the Caribbean has been kept afloat by poor women working harder and longer hours. UNICEF research has found that Brazilian mothers, because of their increased responsibilities in coping with the financial crisis of the 1980s, are experiencing greater mental health problems. Those women feel ``doubly guilty'' for the plight of their families, the UNICEF study says. Activists point out there are significant signs of progress. ``In Eastern Europe, South Africa and Central America you can see that it's the all boats rising with the tide phenomenon,'' Ms. Lowery Derryck said. ``Women can see change, and it empowers them. Now we need to capitalize on these changes.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Against Deukmejian Administration In Toxic Warnings Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled that hundreds of chemicals found in cosmetics, foods and drugs must meet the standards of a law enacted by California voters that requires warning labels on toxic products. Judge Ronald Robie said Friday that Gov. George Deukmejian's scientific advisory panel, which drew up the list of compounds that must bear the labels under Proposition 65, had incorrectly exempted numerous products from the 1986 initiative. Robie's decision finalized a tentative ruling he issued last fall in a lawsuit brought by environmentalists and labor groups who argued that Deukmejian was seeking to sidestep the regulations approved by voters. Robie said the state had created an improper exemption ``for selected industries without specific regard to the chemicals involved.'' If upheld on appeal, his ruling could force food, drug and cosmetic companies to evaluate thousands of products to determine if they pose a significant chemical risk. If that determination is made, Proposition 65 requires that those items carry a warning label. Companies will have to spend millions analyzing their products to show that they pose no significant risk, said Peter Hutt, a Washington lawyer representing the Grocery Manufacturers of America. Steven Berzon, an attorney representing the coalition that challenged the Deukmejian administration, said Robie's ruling ``goes 100 percent in our favor.'' Proposition 65, the so-called clean water initiative, requires warning labels on substances that pose a ``significant risk'' for cancer and birth defects. The standards established by Proposition 65 are stricter than those set by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, and in interpreting the initiative state officials initially said FDA standards could be used for at least 20,000 consumer products. Grocery industry representatives had argued that ``significant risk'' was a vague term, and said that removing the exemption would prompt unnecessary warnings and undermine consumer confidence. Robie flatly rejected that argument. ``Defendant's interpretation that the initiative accepted business as usual in regulatory terms as to these important industries is not correct,'' he wrote. Gene Linvingston, a lawyer in Sacramento for the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association, said many companies will put warning labels on their products even if they pose no risk in order to avoid being taken to court.

DOC.HEAD: Writers Settle With CBS; Wages Go Up, But So Do Health Costs
DOC.TEXT: CBS television and radio writers in four cities have reached a tentative agreement with the network under which their wages would rise 5 percent immediately and another 5 percent in September 1991. Under the agreement reached Friday between CBS and the Writers Guild of America East, they would also pay up to 20 percent of their health costs. The rank and file is scheduled to vote on the pact Monday. The new package also provides improvements in employee safety and increases in special fees for newswriters, desk assistants and others, the union said. The average newswriter's weekly pay goes from $863 in the current contract to $949 by the new contract's end, said Guild spokesman Martin G. Waldman. The new agreement covers 325 employees at CBS network television and radio in New York and Washington; at WCBS-TV and radio in New York; WBBM-TV and WBBM radio in Chicago; and KCBS-TV and KNX radio in Los Angeles. ``The agreement that has been reached is equitable and makes progress in key areas,'' Mona Mangan, the eastern Guild's executive director. ``If our members approve the settlement, we will have avoided the unfortunate situation of three years ago when management attempts to gut our contract forced us to strike.'' CBS spokesman Tom Goodman said no one at the network was available to comment on the contract. The agreement that writers will pay a maximum of 20 percent of the health benefit premiums kicks in the same day as the second raise. ``This is not that uncommon these days,'' said Waldman. Writers Guild East news staffers at Capital Cities-ABC network television and radio and local stations in New York and Washington approved the same wage package Feb. 5; they already had been paying a share of their health costs, Waldman said. The members of the Writers Guild, East and West, are newswriters, editors, desk assistants, researchers, promotion writers and graphic artists.

DOC.HEAD: Dogs and Mushers Face Brutal Trail Conditions
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Race to start 2 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Among the perils threatening the 70 racers and dog teams who mush today in the 18th annual Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race are hunger-crazed moose and ash from the Redoubt Volcano. Not to mention the weather. Temperatures hit the 40s and turned snow into slush on the streets of downtown Anchorage, where the race begins. But conditions are some of the harshest in the history of the race along the 1,100-mile trail to Nome on the Bering Sea. ``Awful weather,'' said Race Manager Jack Niggemyer. ``It's probably snowed 40 inches in the last two days.'' The heavy snow has kept moose from grazing, setting the stage for violent encounters between the huge animals and sled dog teams on the remote trail, and prudent mushers are packing rifles. Redoubt has been erupting intermittently since December, spewing ash as far north as the area around Anchorage. The race usually lasts from 11 to 18 days. The record time, set by Susan Butcher of Manley in 1987, was 11 days, two hours and five minutes. Butcher also won in 1986 and 1988. Since Libby Riddles became the first woman to win in 1985, women have won the race four of the last five years, inspiring a popular T-shirt saying, ``Alaska: Where men are men and women win the Iditarod.'' Some participants and race observers said they expect the pace to be slowed this year because of the deep snow and poorly-packed trail. ``We might run out of trail,'' said Lavon Barve, a musher from Wasilla who finished fifth last year. ``It's up to the mushers to snowshoe or whatever.'' The Iditarod was begun in 1973 to commemorate the emergency delivery of diphtheria serum to Nome by mail carriers driving dog teams in 1925. Taken overland after bad weather grounded airplanes, the serum was credited with saving hundreds of lives in the remote town. From downtown Anchorage, the course goes northwest across the Alaska Range and over the tundra before dropping down along the Yukon River to the Bering Sea. Mushers must lay over for 24 hours of rest at some point along the trail. The mystique of the Iditarod has grown steadily, with mushers this year arriving from France and Switzerland. Companies spend tens of thousands of dollars to sponsor top competitors. Rick Swenson of Two Rivers, the only person to win the Iditarod four times, will be trying for a fifth win. Last year's winner, Joe Runyan of Nenana, expects the teams to start out slow because of bad weather. ``The big strategy this year in terms of snow is to reduce injury,'' Runyan said. But the teams can't afford to be too slow, he said. ``Even if you're conservative, it's better to be in the front of the pack.''

DOC.HEAD: Big Apple To Vie With LA for 1991 Grammy Awards
DOC.TEXT: The Big Apple has launched a formal campaign to snare the Grammy Awards from Los Angeles. ``Our campaign to get the Grammys is a major economic development effort that can add some $30 million in commercial revenues to our local economy next year,'' New York City Mayor David Dinkins said at City Hall Friday. The revenue the 1991 ceremony would bring would be ``music to my ears,'' he said. Dinkins named Edwin Cooperman, North American president of American Express, to chair the NYC Host Committee-1991 Grammy Awards. ``New York City has a rhythm all its own,'' Cooperman said, ``the swing of 52nd Street, Broadway's melodies, the pulse of steel drums in parks around town. Ladies and gentlemen, the Grammys belong where the beat is _ and that's in New York City!'' The Grammys were held in New York in 1988 after seven years in Los Angeles. They were back in Los Angeles the last two years. The Grammys honor talent in recorded music. The ceremony is broadcast live nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Killed During Election Campaigning; Traffickers Rehire Mercenaries
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed a judge, three police officers and two city councilmen despite a truce declared by leftist guerrillas during of a local election campaign, authorities said. The country's leading newspaper reported Friday that the Medellin cocaine cartel was preparing to renew its terrorist campaign against the government and had hired two British mercenaries. Police on Friday blamed members of the People's Liberation Army for killing the judge and his three police bodyguards. Police gave no motive for the shootings late Thursday near the village of Puerto Hungria, about 300 miles south of Bogota. The slain criminal court judge, Carmen Elisa Rosas, was the 74th magistrate killed in the last nine years. Authorities blame drug traffickers or allied guerrilla forces for most of the assassinations. The killings Thursday occurred just hours after the Maoist group declared a unilateral halt to attacks to let voters go to the polls March 11 in the municipal and legislative elections. The leftist group said the truce will be in effect until April 1. In other attacks Thursday, gunmen assassinated Jaime Barrientos, a city councilman for the governing Liberal Party in the town of Amalfi in Antioquia state; and Eutimio Campos, a Conservative Party councilman in Muzo in Boyaca state. The national police said they did not know who killed the councilmen. In its report Friday, Bogota's El Tiempo indicated Pablo Escobar and other leaders of the Medellin drug cartel were planning to abandon a cease-fire they declared Jan. 17 in their anti-government terrorist campaign. ``The leaders of the Medellin cartel are preparing for war,'' said the daily, which has a reputation for gaining access to the highest counsels of Colombian government. It cited a report by the intelligence police. The newspaper said the Medellin cartel had once again contracted two British mercenaries, Brian David Tomkins and Peter MacAleese, who allegedly trained death squads in 1988. Tomkins and MacAleese have already returned to Colombia after fleeing the country two years ago, according to the report quoted by El Tiempo. A spokeswoman for the intellegence police, Diva Rojas, confirmed the report but said she could not discuss its contents. ``I don't know who leaked it. It is supposed to be confidential,'' Rojas said in a telephone interview. In January, the cartel declared a halt to attacks and said it had been defeated in a government crackdown. The announcement came a month after the group's No. 2 leader, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, was killed in a Dec. 15 gunfight with police. The government began its push to destroy the cartels in August after a leading presidential candidate, Luis Carlos Galan, was assassinated by drug traffickers. Leaders of the leftist Patriotic Union Party announced Friday that, lacking guarantees for their safe participation in March elections, the party will ask former President Jimmy Carter to lead an international commission to observe the balloting. Carter served as a foreign observer for Sunday's elections in Nicaragua and oversaw elections in May in neighboring Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Students Evacuated By Bomb Threat Sit on Bleachers That Collapse
DOC.TEXT: Students evacuated from a school because of a bomb threat sat down on bleachers that had been vandalized by aluminum thieves, and the bleachers collapsed, slightly injuring 19 students, officials said. Some bolts and braces had been removed from the aluminum football field bleachers at Cedarcrest Junior High, about 10 miles south of Tacoma, investigators said. About 650 students were evacuated from the school Friday morning when someone called in a bomb threat, said Spanaway Fire Department spokeswoman Shirley Corbett. One class, with about 40 students, was relocated to the bleachers, which collapsed. No bomb was found. The injured students were released from area hospitals after treatment for cuts, bruises and sprains, officials said. Detectives doubted there was a link between the vandalism and the bomb threat, said Pierce County sheriff's spokesman Curt Benson. But bleachers at three other area schools also had been vandalized, apparently by thieves lured by the high market for scrap aluminum. ``All have similar braces, and we have found the braces from those bleachers at the other schools missing as well,'' Benson said. A spokeswoman for the Reynolds Aluminum Recycling Co. said scrap aluminum prices vary from 20 to 30 cents a pound. It wasn't known how much aluminum had been removed from the school bleachers.

DOC.HEAD: Cease-Fire Holding in East Beirut
DOC.TEXT: The big guns fell silent in embattled east Beirut today under a cease-fire, but rival Christian forces exchanged sniper fire as civilians fled to safety in other parts of the country. Police said rescuers evacuated 12 dead and 26 wounded from the Nabaa and Sin el-Fil districts overnight after the savage fighting subsided into intermittent exchanges of sniper fire. By police count, the showdown for dominance of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has left 766 dead and 2,087 wounded since the clashes broke out Jan. 30 between Gen. Michel Aoun's forces and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. On Friday morning, Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir called the cease-fire and threatened to excommunicate Geagea, Aoun and their followers if they maintained the fight. Aoun and Geagea are Maronites, the Christian community which has dominated politics in Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Civilians used the relative lull today to flee the embattled Christian enclave for safety in north Lebanon, the eastern Bekaa Valley and the southern provinces. The police spokesman said long lines of cars, loaded with mattresses, clothes and furniture, were seen heading out of the enclave early today. The spokesman said about 200,000 people of the Christian enclave's 1 million population, have fled since Jan. 30. The spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said the cease-fire came after a 36-hour battle that left more than 70 dead and resulted in a ``standstill.' Aoun wants Geagea's 6,000-strong militia subsumed into his force of 19,000 mostly Christian army troops. Geagea has repeatedly declared his rejection of the general's demand, and vowed to confront it to the end. The prestigious newspaper An-Nahar said the cease-fire, the latest in a series of unsuccessful attempts to stop the fighting, ``reflected the balance of horror between both sides.'' Aoun had tried to penetrate the Lebanese Forces defenses and advance between Nabaa and Sin el-Fil to the seaside boulevard to prepare for an advance by his tanks to the militia's headquarters and adjacent Beirut port, a key militia supply line. Aoun has rejected parliament's election last fall of President Elias Hrawi, who has pledged to enact a peace pact. Aoun says he opposes the peace plan because it does not require the pullout of 40,000 Syrian troops, deployed under a 1976 Arab League mandate to keep the peace in the civil war. Hrawi fired Aoun as army commander, but Aoun refused to step down.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Analysis Finds `Brushy Bill' Not Billy the Kid
DOC.TEXT: A group that defends the legend of Billy the Kid says a computer photo analysis indicates a Texan nicknamed ``Brushy Bill'' who died in 1950 probably wasn't the famed outlaw, as he had claimed. The computer tests compared a photograph of Ollie L. ``Brushy Bill'' Roberts, who died in Hico, Texas, a week short of his 90th birthday in December 1950, and a tintype of William Bonney, who died at age 21 on July 14, 1881. Most people, including a coroner's inquest jury at the time, say Bonney was Billy the Kid and he was shot to death in Fort Sumter, N.M., by Lincoln Sheriff Pat Garrett. But Hico has its share of Brushy Bill believers who maintain the Kid escaped, perhaps with official help, to survive to a ripe old age in Texas. Billy the Kid was one of the primary players in the bloody Lincoln County War of the late 19th century. Now, the Lincoln County Heritage Trust is watching out for the Kid's legend, and it initiated the photo project. Trust director Robert L. Hart said Friday the computer tests were based on a similarity index of 25 landmarks on the faces. The computer also matched Billy to a database of 150 people from both sexes and many racial groups, Hart said, to show how many people in the sample, if any, were closer in appearance to Billy than was Brushy Bill. From the 25 landmarks of the face the computer mathematically derives a single number _ the index of similarity. If Brushy Bill and Billy the Kid were the same man, Hart said, ``then in the comparison, Billy is No. 1 and Brushy should come out No. 2.'' ``When the comparison was run, Brushy Bill was No. 42. ``That means there were 40 other individuals who look more like Billy the Kid than Brushy does. In short, Brushy doesn't look very much like Billy the Kid at all,'' Hart said. Hico Justice of the Peace Bobby Hefner, a Brushy Bill buff, said Friday the computer study means nothing. ``I don't accept the tintype as being Billy the Kid at all,'' Hefner said in a telephone interview from his Hico home. ``On the other hand, I don't accept the study. You let me program my computer, and I guarantee Brushy Bill'd be number one.'' But Clyde Snow, an Oklahoma forensic anthropologist known for his work on the remains of Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele, said the computer looks at photographs in a less subjective way than people do. ``As far as Brushy Bill Roberts is concerned, the weight of the evidence is to the point that if there were a court case, we'd be willing to go in and say beyond a reasonable doubt the two photographs are not photographs of the same individual,'' Snow said. Hart said the Brushy Bill comparison is the only one that has been done. But the project plans to look at a dozen or so other photographs, including pictures of two other claimants, John Miller of Ramah, N.M., and Walking Henry Smith, and photographs believed to be those of Billy taken at other times. That could take a couple of years. Hart called the project a ``marriage of history and technology.'' ``Historians don't seem to be able to solve the problem of whether Brushy Bill and Billy the Kid are the same person,'' and bringing in science was another way to answer the question, he said. The photographs, one from a Las Vegas, N.M., collection and the other owned by a San Francisco family, came to light after the project began last year. Hefner, 54, agreed research would continue into the legend of Billy the Kid. ``The old Texas Rangers had a saying that no one can stand up to a man that's in the right and keeps on a-comin'. And that's my approach to this,'' Hefner said. ``I'm in the right. I've enough evidence in hand to convince anyone that doesn't have a prejudice. ``I never met old Brushy,'' he said. ``Maybe it's my sense of fair play, of being justice of the peace: I want justice done for a local man. I'd like to see it on through to a just conclusion.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``This hour which is very important for the Germans, the hour of the reunification process, is not just a German hour. It it is an hour of Europe, of Germany's neighbors.'' _ Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland on German unification and Polish concerns that its postwar border with East Germany be honored.

``It's getting to the point where we're ready to go out there and fire one of the buses up, run over the strikers and say, `See ya.''' _ Frank Rzepski of Philadelphia, stranded in Indianapolis during the Greyhound bus strike.

``Obtain all the information possible on how to get physically close to the pope.'' _ former KGB agent Victor Ivanovich Sheymov, quoting orders he said were received in 1979 from Yuri Andropov, then the KGB chief, to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

DOC.HEAD: Miss Michigan, Carole Gist, Named Miss USA
LaserPhoto WIX1
DOC.TEXT: Miss Michigan, a 20-year-old from Detroit whose goal is to own a hotel, is 1990's Miss USA and will go on to compete for the Miss Universe title. Carole Gist is the first black Miss USA, pageant spokeswoman Donna Dilsaver said. She broke into tears as she was crowned Friday night by the reigning Miss USA, Gretchen Polhemus, in front of host Dick Clark, a black-tie crowd of about 3,500 and a live worldwide audience. The first runner-up was Miss South Carolina, Gina Tolleson, 20, of Spartanburg, S.C. The second runner-up was Miss New Jersey, Karin Hartz, 24, of Voorhees, N.J. Before the final three were picked, the field was narrowed to six contestants including Brenda Leithleiter, 22, of Smyrna, Ga.; Tiffany Tenfelde, 22, of Lakeside Park, Ky.; and Karin Meyer, 20, of Anchorage, Alaska. Miss Gist, 6 feet tall with dark brown eyes and hair, is a student in hotel and motel management and works for Holiday Inn. She said that after finishing her degree, she wants to enter a management training program, and would use the slogan ``Class for Less Cash'' when she opens her hotel. Miss Gist said her long-term ambition was to establish a performing arts foundation for disadvantaged children. During the semifinal round, Miss Gist was asked her opinion of letting women in the military participate in combat. ``If a woman is capable of defending her country as well as the next man she should be allowed to uphold her flag and do what she can for her country as well. She should have the opportunity,'' she said. Miss Gist said her most prized possession was her stuffed animal collection and her favorite food was Italian. She describes herself as aggressive, determined and energetic. Her final interview question from the judges asked why she should be chosen as Miss USA. ``I do believe I have something positive to share with the young people of America, especially young women,'' she said. Only in America can you achieve your goals if you ``believe in yourself and put God in front of you,'' Miss Gist said. Judges for the pageant included former Olympian and professional ice skater Robin Cousins, retired astronaut Gordon Cooper, Olympic track star Jackie Joyner-Kersee, music producer Kerry Gordy, romance novelist Rebecca Brandewyne and Eileen Fulton, longtime cast member on the soap opera ``As the World Turns.'' The judges scored the contestants on the swimsuit category, on evening gown competition and on responses to interview questions. The new Miss USA gets $88,000 in cash plus prizes that bring her winnings to about $220,000. The other prizes include a car, a boat, furs, jewelry, camera equipment, gowns, and a Los Angeles apartment. Five Miss USAs have gone on to be crowned Miss Universe. The Miss Universe contest will be held in April.

DOC.HEAD: Lombardi's Widow Instigated Gay Crackdown On Turnpike
DOC.TEXT: Complaints from the widow of famed football coach Vince Lombardi helped prompt the arrests of hundreds of homosexual men at a turnpike service area named after him, a state police spokesman says. Marie Lombardi complained to a detective more than 10 years ago about the reputation of the New Jersey Turnpike's Vince Lombardi Service Area as a hangout for gay men, Capt. Thomas Gallagher said Friday. Mrs. Lombardi, who died in 1982, told the detective she was disturbed by the service area's reputation and threatened to have Lombardi's name and football memorabilia removed, the state police spokesman said. The detective, whom Gallagher would not identify, said that there had been many such complaints about the rest station in northern New Jersey and that ``Mrs. Lombardi complained that it was getting all this media attention.'' In response to the protests, then-superintendent Clinton Pagano launched an undercover operation that led to hundreds of arrests between 1986 and last month. Officers working on overtime lingered in the men's room in teams of two, encouraged men to join them in homosexual activity and then arrested takers on charges of lewd conduct. The operation was halted last week by Col. Justin Dintino, whom Gov. Jim Florio named to replace Pagano. Dintino called the undercover operation ``repulsive.'' ``No matter who started it, what let it continue was police believing they could get away with this kind of behavior,'' said Evan Wolfson, staff attorney for Lambda Legal Defense Fund, a New York-based civil rights group that pressured New Jersey officials to halt the crackdown. That group and other critics have labeled the operation entrapment inspired by bigotry against a sexual minority. ``State police should not be preying on vulnerable minorities, let alone wasting valuable resources on such an absurd operation,'' Wolfson said. Pagano, the superintendent for 14 years, was moved to the less-prestigious job of director of the state Division of Motor Vehicles. The exact number of arrests ensuing from the service area crackdown is unknown, Gallagher said. The legal defense group has counted 540 arrests between February 1988 and October 1989, which covers only a portion of the period in which the operation was underway. Jean Adubato, a turnpike spokeswoman, said she was not aware of any complaints by the wife of the former Green Bay Packer coach, who coached high school football in Englewood before joining the professional ranks. ``We do not comment on what the state police do. It's strictly in their hands,'' the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Prepare Final Salvo in Hazelwood Case
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors prepared the final salvo in their case against Joseph Hazelwood as the defense team geared up to begin calling witnesses in the criminal trial of the Exxon Valdez skipper. Hazelwood came down with the flu Friday, causing cancellation of the day's court session and giving attorneys time for paperwork and witness interviews. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole, who has presented four weeks of testimony, said he had three more experts waiting to testify Monday before he rests his case. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone told Hazelwood's lawyers to be prepared to start calling witnesses on Tuesday. The judge also suggested that lawyers begin work on proposed jury instructions. Both sides will submit legal instructions and the judge will choose which ones to give jurors when they begin deliberations. Johnstone told jurors the trial could be over in two to three weeks. Meanwhile, the prosecution filed papers asking the judge to admit evidence on whether Hazelwood's ship was in danger of sinking after it ran aground on Bligh Reef, setting off the nation's worst oil spill. They urged rejection of the tanker skipper's claim that evidence about his ship's potential sinking is irrelevant. Hazelwood's lawyers contend it was impossible for the skipper to move his giant tanker off the reef once it was stuck there, and thus it makes no difference whether he tried to move it. They seek to bar evidence on what might have happened if the ship moved. The state seeks to bolster the speculation of expert witnesses on the subject by showing jurors the results of accident simulations suggesting the tanker was in danger of capsizing or sinking. The 43-year-old Hazelwood, from Huntington, N.Y., is charged with criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. He could receive 7\ years in prison and fines of $61,000. The Exxon Valdez ran aground on Bligh Reef on March 24, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound. The spill killed countless birds, fish and other marine animals and blackened hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline. A key element in the charges against Hazelwood is recklessness, and Assistant District Attoney Brent Cole is seeking to prove that the skipper's alleged efforts to try moving the ship constituted recklessness. According to a legal definition he has read to jurors, ``A person acts recklessly ... when the person is aware of and consciously disregards a substantial and unjustifiable risk ...'' It continues: ``The risk must be of such a nature and degree that disregard of it constitutes a gross deviation from the standard of conduct that a reasonable person would observe in the situation.'' To be found guilty of second degree criminal mischief, the felony, the jury must determine that Hazelwood recklessly risked the property of another in an amount exceeding $100,000. Thus, the prosecution must prove recklessness and risk. ``Captain Hazelwood is arguing that because it was impossible for the Exxon Valdez to come free, there was no risk involved,'' said the prosecution's legal memorandum. But it added, ``The issue is not whether it was possible for the vessel to come free, but whether Captain Hazelwood's mistakes in not realizing the vessel was firmly aground and not recognizing the danger in refloating were reasonable.''

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Allows South Korean to Visit North Korean Sister in Japan
DOC.TEXT: The government will allow a South Korean man to travel to Japan for a reunion with his North Korean sister, a former champion figure skater who he hasn't seen in nearly 40 years, officials said today. The Seoul government only last year liberalized travel allowing South Koreans to more easily obtain passports and travel abroad. It restricts contact with North Koreans overseas and forbids travel to North Korea unless authorized by the government, an approval seldom given. Han Pil-sung, 58, will be given permission to meet his sister, Han Pil-wha, 48, in Sapporo, Japan, during the March 9-14 Asiad Winter Games, government officials said, requesting anonymity. Han's sister, serving as an official for North Korea's delegation to the Asiad, arrived in Tokyo Friday night. Han's travel plans were not known. The two were among an estimated 10 million family members separated during the 1950-53 Korean War. The Korean peninsula is split into Communist North Korea and the capitalist South Korea and there's virtually no communication between citizens of the two countries. Han told newspapers he spoke by telephone with his sister in 1971 when she took part in international skating competitions in Austria and had hoped to see her during the 1972 Winter Olympics in Sapporo. The reunion was not held, he said, because of ideological differences between their two countries which remain technically at war. The border between the two nations remains one of the most heavily fortified in the world, and hundreds of thousands of troops man both sides.

DOC.HEAD: 650,000-Member Teachers Union Pledges to Boycott Start of Classes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to ADD details of anti-inflation plan, pvs interest rate; picks up 12th pvs, `Interest rates...'
DOC.TEXT: Argentina's biggest teachers union said it will strike Monday on the first day of classes to demand higher wages in this inflation-wracked nation. Also Friday, interest rates for interbank lending rose to record levels _ 28 percent a day _ ahead of the government's scheduled announcement of a new plan to try to rescue the economy. Analysts said the increase reflected concern about the new government measures to be announced Sunday. Few details have emerged about the plan, but President Carlos Menem said this week that it will include increaseing telephone rates by 300 percent. An official at the Economy Ministry, Raul Cuello, said it would be a ``hyperstabilizing shock.'' The announcement by the 650,000-member Confederation of Education Workers followed wage strikes that shut down the federal court system for two days this week and virtually all operations of the national airline Aerolineas Argentinas on Thursday. College professors pressing similar wage demands have refused to work for more than a week, delaying the taking and grading of entrance examinations. Bus and train drivers, doctors at municipal hospitals, state bank clerks, municipal employees and other have staged strikes in past weeks to demand higher wages or protest government plans to sell public companies and cut the fiscal budget. The teachers' union says it will keep up its strike if government does not grant a basic wage of $66 a month _ twice the present basic salary. Grammar schools are scheduled to resume Monday following a break for the Southern Hemisphere's summer season. High schools and colleges begin classes a week later. In 1988, a strike delayed the start of classes for more than two months. Menem has been beset by inflation, currency and labor woes since taking office in July. The cost of living soared by 79 percent in January, and it was projected at about that level for February. Reflecting higher interest rates, banks borrowing australs, the national currency, from other banks on Friday were paying 28 percent a day, according to the private news agency Diarios y Noticias. That broke the record of 17 percent, set Wednesday. The news agency called the new rate ``a world record.'' Interest rates have gone up steadily the past two months as the austral has fallen against the dollar, and banks have raised rates to keep deposits. At the close of the business day Friday, the austral traded at 5,450 per dollar. It was 655-1 when Menem took office eight months ago. When it was introduced in 1985, each austral was worth $1.20. The devaluations are linked with excessive money expansion by the Central Bank and doubts about the government's economic program. Menem has raised public service rates drastically during his eight months in office. He said four decades of economic decline can only be reversed by opening up the state-dominated economy by selling public companies, deregulating monopolies, lowering tariff barriers, raising taxes and cutting subsidies. Newspapers in Buenos Aires speculated the government on Sunday might announce controls on foreign exchange and restrictions on wages and prices. Export taxes might also be raised, public workers fired and utility rates increased a fourth time since Menem took office, the newspaper La Nacion said.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Lessens in Sierra Nevada; Rain Along Eastern Seaboard
DOC.TEXT: Rain spread today from the South to the Eastern seaboard and more snow was forecast for the weekend in the Sierra Nevada. Rain fell late Friday from southwest Idaho and northwest Nevada into southern Oregon as well as central and northern California. The rain was continuing today and moving into western Montana and Wyoming, and northward into Washington state. After three dry years, Friday's showers brought the accumulated rainfall in Northern California closer to normal for the area. Forecasters expected the rain to continue over the weekend. Rain was expected today in a band extending from North Carolina up through New England, with precipitation changing to snow in Maine. There were no reports late Friday of measurable snowfall in the Sierras, and it was to diminish early today. But another storm was expected to move across the mountains Sunday. Thunderstorms and rainshowers spread across the South, from northern Georgia and Alabama to northeast Mississippi, Tennessee, and eastern Kentucky. Rain also fell in southern West Virginia, Virginia, Delaware and Maryland. Heavy rainfall reported late Friday included three-fourths of 1 inch near Montgomery, Ala. and Chattanooga, Tenn. Two-thirds of 1 inch fell at Redding, Calif., and Pensacola, Fla. The high temperature for the nation today was 87 degrees at Yuma, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Thieves Pose as Room Service to Snatch Gems
DOC.TEXT: Two British visitors thought they were getting room service when they heard a knock on their hotel door, but instead they were tied up and ripped off _ and lost more than $2 million in gems, police said. Two men knocked on the door of The Halloran House hotel room in midtown Manhattan at about 2 p.m. Friday, said a police spokesman. When the door was opened, the robbers forced their way in, and ordered Darius Guppy, 25, and Benedict Marsh, 27, to open the safe in their room, and removed over $2 million in assorted gems, including rubies, sapphires, and emeralds, said Officer Fred Weiner. Then they tied up Guppy and Marsh, fired a shot and left, Weiner said. No one was injured. Guppy and Marsh, who work for Inca Gem Stores, a London company, had been in the hotel for about a week.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS item on Brazauskas; No separates moved for the PMs cycle. Merritt also moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Merritt, a third-generation blacksmith to four Kentucky Derby winners, died Tuesday of cancer at age 67. Born and raised in Nashville, Tenn., Merritt learned blacksmithing and the farrier trade from his father and grandfather. He moved to Louisville, Ky., in 1945, but was barred from the Gentlemen's Horse Shoe Union because he was black. He supported himself shoeing horses at a local bakery. Merritt later was hired to shoe eventual Kentucky Derby winners Needles, who won in 1956; Tim Tam, 1958; Tommy Lee, 1959; and Carry Back, 1961. He moved to Detroit in 1966 and had worked at the Detroit Race Course and Hazel Park Raceway.

Marion Weatherford, an Oregon agriculture pioneer, died Tuesday after a lengthy illness at age 83. Weatherford was one of three wheat growers who led the formation of the Oregon Wheat Commission, the first state wheat commodity group, in 1947. He served as chairman from 1953 to 1957. Weatherford also helped form the National Association of Wheat Growers in 1950. He was president of the Oregon Wheat Growers' League in 1954, president of the Pacific Northwest Grain and Grain Products Association from 1950 to 1975, and founding chairman of the board of the Agribusiness Council of Oregon. He was a trustee of the Oregon State University Foundation starting in 1953 and received that university's distinguished service award in 1979.

M.P. ``Rusty'' Duncan III, a Texas Court of Criminal Appeals judge, died Wednesday in an auto accident at age 43. Duncan was elected to the state's highest criminal court bench in 1986. Before joining the court, he had been a trial lawyer in Denton.

The Rev. Pius Brazauskas, a Roman Catholic priest whose religious paintings have been exhibited around the world, died Thursday at age 84. Brazauskas was born into a Lithuanian farming family and was ordained in 1930. He entered fine arts school in Lithuania in 1932, studying there until 1936. During World War II, Brazauskas fled with his sister, two brothers and another pastor to Salzburg, Austria, to escape the Nazis. In 1949, he accepted an invitation to become an assistant at a parish in St. Louis. Relatives invited Brazauskas to Oregon, and he worked as a chaplain for Sacred Heart Hospital in Eugene for 20 years. In 1958, he became a naturalized citizen, and in 1971 was appointed chaplain of St. Catherine's Residence and Nursing Center in North Bend. He retired in 1980, but remained active at the center and continued his painting.

DOC.HEAD: Airplane Demand To Take Off, Boeing Predicts
DOC.TEXT: World demand for commercial jetliners will keep soaring into the next century, partly because of new markets for Western planes in Eastern Europe, The Boeing Co. forecast. Boeing officials Friday increased their estimate of demand for planes to the year 2005 by 27 percent, citing growth in the world economy, disposable income and Far East air travel. For the first time, the world's largest commercial airplane manufacturer also included Eastern Europe in the projections, predicting that Warsaw Pact nations would start purchasing planes from Western manufacturers. The Soviet Union was excluded from the forecast. The greatest growth is anticipated from carriers with routes within Asia and between the Far East and Europe or the United States, and the average plane's capacity also will increase, according to the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group's annual market outlook. ``We believe that as the world's economies grow and as there is more disposable income, that will mean an increase in demand,'' said John Hayhurst, vice president of marketing for Boeing Commercial. The increase also reflects the $95 billion in orders placed with airplane makers last year, more than Boeing had expected, Hayhurst said. The company also forecast no major oil price shocks over the next 16 years. The company's projections pegged jet airplane orders from 1990 to 2005 at 9,935 planes worth $626 billion, 2,097 planes and $136 billion more than in the 16-year forecast issued last year. The projections are for all manufacturers, but Boeing expects to maintain its 54 percent to 55 percent market share, Hayhurst said. Hayhurst said the company hopes to launch the new mid-size 777, a 767 derivative, in the first half of this year. Designers are ``looking seriously'' into whether it will have folding wings to reduce airport crowding, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Suspends NJ Marine Operation in Wake of Spills
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. moved to shore up its credibility after two oil spills in two days by announcing an immediate suspension of tanker and barge operations at a major East Coast coast refinery and distribution center. Lee Raymond, president of the New York-based oil giant, announced Friday evening that marine operations in New Jersey, where the company operates its only East Coast refinery, would be halted pending an evaluation of procedures. ``We deeply regret the recent accidents at our New Jersey facilities and the impacts and concerns they have caused,'' Raymond said in a statement. ``We are seriously committed to conducting our operations in a safe and environmentally responsible manner, and we are taking this measure to demonstrate that commitment.'' Exxon said the huge refinery in Linden would essentially be idled by the move. But the company said alternate supply arrangements are being made. ``Exxon anticipates that gasoline, heating oil, propane and other products will continue to be made available to customers on an uninterrupted basis,'' the statement said. Exxon spokesman Barry Wood said deliveries by truck of oil already in the company's storage tanks would not be affected. The Bayway refinery in Linden and the Bayonne distribution center, the third largest of five such Exxon facilities in the United States, have been the site of three oil spills since Jan. 1. The spills have been a major setback in Exxon efforts to rehabilitate its image since last year's 11-million-gallon spill _ the nation's worst _ in Alaska's Prince William Sound. ``It was pretty clear that Exxon had lost the confidence of the public,'' said Rep. Robert Torricelli, D-N.J. Torricelli had written Friday requesting that the company make voluntary reforms. ``It's a bit better and faster response than I would have expected.'' The company's local troubles began Jan. 1, when an underwater pipeline sprang a leak and spilled 567,000 gallons of heating oil into the Arthur Kill waterway separating New Jersey from the Staten Island borough of New York City. On Wednesday, a leaking barge owned by a private contractor spilled 30,000 gallons of heating oil into the Kill Van Kull from Exxon USA Co.'s Bayonne terminal. Then Thursday night, while crews continued their attempts to contain the previous day's spill, a mechanical fuel line filling a Texaco barge at the Bayway refinery broke free and spilled about 4,000 gallons of crude oil into the Arthur Kill. Coast Guard Capt. Robert North, the officer in charge of New York Harbor, said Friday that a preliminary investigation into Thursday's spill had not yet determined whether Exxon was at fault. He said it was unclear whether the arm malfunctioned, which would be Exxon's responsibility, or whether Texaco's hookup on the barge was faulty. The spill was largely contained by booms and did not appear to have spread into the harbor, he said. But Wednesday's spill was more serious. Cleanup crews continued collecting tar balls Friday along a 40-mile arc of New York and New Jersey coastline, North said. Six more dead birds were pulled from the water, bringing the unofficial tally to about 32 dead. The leaking barge was owned by Staten Island-based Eklof Marine Corp. The Coast Guard said Eklof took responsibility for Wednesday's spill and its inspectors are probing the cause of the damaged hull.

DOC.HEAD: Kashmir Leader Calls For March To Indian Border
With PM-Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: A leader in Pakistan-held Kashmir said today that Pakistan's Kashmiris will march to the border of India's troubled state of Jammu-Kashmir to show support of their brethren's call for independence. Sultan Mahmood, president of Azad Moslem Conference, said the march Friday will only be a ``dress rehearsal'' for a plan to cross into the Indian state, where more than 160 people have been killed in protests by Moslem secessionists since Jan. 20. ``We are going to cross the cease-fire line very soon, in a matter of weeks,'' he told a news conference. ``Not only do we intend to attack them (India), we should also prepare ourselves defensively. We are in a sort of war situation.'' He said demonstrators on Friday will march to the Pakistani border town of Chakhoti. Moslem Pakistan and mainly Hindu India have fought three wars since independence from Britain in 1947 _ twice over Kashmir. The 840-mile cease-fire line is heavily guarded. Prime Minsiter Benazir Bhutto's government, while condemning the Srinagar violence and publicly supporting the militants, has warned against aggravating the confrontation. Last month, Indian troops opened fire on Pakistani demonstrators, who pushed aside barricades at the border near Chakhoti and swarmed across. Three people were killed and several more were wounded. Pakistan and Indian soldiers also exchanged fire for about 30 minutes before calm was restored. Pakistan has since strengthened its border barricades, and the military has warned Kashmiris that they will stop any attempted crossing. Indian-held Kashmir is India's only state with a Moslem majority. Its Moslem activists want a separate nation.

DOC.HEAD: Paramilitary Forces Return to Kashmir, Curfew Still On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with protester killed. Pickup 9th pvs, `In Washington...'
DOC.TEXT: India rushed hundreds of reinforcements to the Kashmir Valley after the largest-ever Moslem rally against Indian rule, police and airport sources said today. Police today killed a protester in the old downtown area of Srinagar when 20 to 30 people came out of their homes in defiance of the curfew imposed Friday, witnesses said. They spoke on condition of anonymity. Indian news agencies said the patrolling troops and paramilitary police had orders to shoot curfew violators on sight. Nine planes carrying paramilitary police and border guards landed at Srinagar airport Friday night and today and more were expected in northern Jammu-Kashir state, the sources said on condition of anonymity. In neighboring Pakistan, a leader in the Pakistani-held section of Kashmir today said Pakistani Kashmiris will march to the border next Friday in protest and invade Jammu-Kashmir ``in a matter of weeks.'' Sultan Mahmood, president of Azad Moslem Conference, made his comments at a news conference in Islamabad, the Pakistani capital. At least 49 people were fatally shot Thursday by army and paramilitary troops as an estimated 1 million Moslem demonstrators converged on Srinagar to press demands for independence from predominantly Hindu India, police said. Today's shooting raised the death toll to at least 163 in Kashmir since the latest round of secessionist violence flared Jan. 20. In Washington, the State Department said Friday it had appealed to the Indian government to prevent the use of excessive force against the pro-independence demonstrators. ``We deplore the loss of life in Kashmir. We are disturbed at the rising number of casualties,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in Washington. An Indian government spokesman, speaking on the customary condition of anonymity, said troops opened fire Thursday in self-defense. Witnesses, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said some of the marchers tried to seize weapons from the government security forces. On Jan. 20, the government launched a crackdown on escalating protests, bombings and attacks on government intelligence agents and other officials. After the crackdown started, army and paramilitary troops were beefed up in Srinagar and surrounding towns in the Kashmir Valley next to the Pakistani frontier. Some of the paramilitary Central Reserve Police Force and Border Security Guards were withdrawn during legislative elections Tuesday in eight other Indian states. These troops were returning now, the airport and police sources said. Each plane landing at Srinagar airport carried about 100 men, they added. Heightened security also was in evidence in downtown Srinagar, center of the militant movement. For a week preceding the imposition of the curfew, processions ranging from about 20,000 to 1 million demonstrators had converged on the office of the U.N. military observer group that has been assigned to the Indian-Pakistani frontier for the past 40 years because of the two nations' dispute over Kashmir. Pakistan, an overwhelmingly Moslem nation, claimed Kashmir and twice went to war with India over the question of the predominantly Moslem valley's sovereignty. The Kashmir Valley is governed by India as part of Jammu-Kashmir state, the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. The western slice of Kashmir is under Pakistani control. Both countries claim all of Kashmir. Initially, Kashmiri separatists on the Indian side of the disputed frontier had pressed for union with Pakistan. But in the past year their call for secession has been coupled with demands for Kashmir's independence as a buffer nation between India, the region's military and political giant, and its long-time adversary, Pakistan. The two nations were once ruled as one unit by colonial Britain. But upon independence in 1947, they were partitioned along religious lines. The Kashmir section of India's Jammu-Kashmir state is mostly Moslem, while the southern Jammu region is mostly Hindu. Overall, Moslems make up 64 percent of the state's 6 million people. But nationwide, Moslems form only 12 percent of India's 880 million people, of whom 82 percent are Hindus.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Fundamentalists Stone Christian Churches
DOC.TEXT: Scores of Moslem militants stoned two Coptic Christian churches and a youth club in a southern Egyptian town, injuring 15 people, a town official said today. The state-run Middle East News Agency distributed a report making no mention of those attacks but saying the fundamentalists burned a Coptic-owned candy plant, a neighboring timber depot and four cars. The town official said the attacks occurred Friday at Abu-Kurkas, 150 miles south of Cairo in El-Minya province. El-Minya lies just north of Assiut, which has had frequent episodes of violence involving Moslem militants for nearly a decade. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said almost 100 militants threw stones at the churches and a nearby Coptic youth club, smashing windows and slightly injuring 15 worshipers. The assaults, he said, came during Coptic prayer services customarily held during a 55-day period of fasting preceding Coptic Easter, which this year coincides with Western Easter on April 15. Police detained 45 attackers and were seeking another 45, the official said. Police Maj. Gen. Maher Hassan Ibrahim, El-Minya's provincial security chief, referred questions to the Interior Ministry in Cairo, which is responsible for internal security. The ministry spokesman's office also refused to discuss the attacks but said a statement might be issued later.
