The government news agency report, which appeared to be an Interior Ministry handout, blamed the trouble on ``members of extremist groups,'' the ministry's standard euphemism for Moslem militants. It put the number of detainees at 37. The agency said militants last week abducted the son of the candy plant owner ``on suspicion of having a love affair with a Moslem girl.'' It said a friend of the son also was kidnapped with him. Quoting Interior Ministry sources, the agency said Friday's arson attack followed the arrest of the alleged kidnappers and release of the two captives. In Cairo, the state-owned newspaper Al-Gomhouria reported that the attackers tried unsuccessfully to set fire to the churches. ``Security authorities brought the situation under control,'' the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Official Backs Special Alliance Meeting
DOC.TEXT: NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner said today he favored calling a special meeting of foreign ministers of the Western alliance to discuss German unification and arms control. Smaller nations in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have complained about being left out of discussions among the four NATO powers on uniting Germany and suggested an emergency conference. ``I personally favor the idea,'' Woerner said at NATO headquarters after meeting with Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier of Czechoslovakia. ``We could have very useful discussions on (conventional arms) negotiations, and we could have discussions and an exchange of views about the process of German unification.'' Woerner said no final decision has been made or date set for a special meeting. But a NATO official, demanding anonymity, said dates in April have been discussed. The decision by France, Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union to meet separately to discuss German unity has angered some allies, including Italy, Belgium and the Netherlands. Under the ``two-plus-four'' process set up by the four victorious World War II powers, the two German states also will meet after March 18 elections in East Germany to discuss their future. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl will travel to NATO on Thursday to talk to ambassadors of the 16 alliance nations about German unification. Woerner said Kohl's visit showed the ``the importance he attributes to consulting with all allies. ... So I think all those who are thinking that this process will only be restricted to the two-plus-four structure are wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: Fourth North Korean Invasion Tunnel Discovered
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf pvs, `The tunnel...' with 2 grafs to ADD length of DMZ. Pickup 6th pvs, `South Korean...'
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and South Korean military engineers cut through nine feet of granite today to unearth a tunnel allegedly dug by North Korea under the Demilitarized Zone separating the two Koreas. The tunnel was discovered in a remote mountainous border area called Punchbowl, the site of a fierce battle between U.S. and Communist troops during the 1950-53 Korean War. ``Breaking through!'' shouted onlookers as engineers with giant drills and earth-moving equipment succeeded in reaching the tunnel. In Seoul, Defense Minister Lee Sang-hoon told a news conference the tunnel, located about 100 miles northeast of the capital, is ``a southward tunnel that can be used for...invasion.'' The tunnel is the fourth to be found since 1974. But Lee said his ministry believed there were more than 20 being dug by North Korea inside the 2.5-mile-wide, 155-mile-long DMZ, one of the most heavily armed borders in the world. South Korean officials claim North Korean leader Kim Il Sung ordered the tunnels built to infiltrate Communist troops behind South Korea's first defense lines. North Korea has denied digging any tunnels. A statement issued by the U.S.-led United Nations Command said the tunnel was ``apparently dug by North Korea to invade the South.'' It said the tunnel was six feet high and six feet wide, large enough for three armed soldiers to run through it side by side. A full regiment could pass through the tunnel in an hour, officials said. The man-made tunnel is 430 feet beneath the surface, the defense minister said. He said its length and age were not yet known. ``In view of the changing global situation and our sincere peace initiatives, the construction of such a tunnel into our area across the truce line is a serious violation of the armistice agreement and an intolerable act of aggression,'' Lee said. He urged North Korea to stop ``provocative acts of aggression'' and help pursue ways to cut tensions on the divided Korean peninsula. Col. H.T. Linke, spokesman for the United Nations Command, said the tunnel was first detected after a U.S. Army investigation team drilled into a tunnel-like cavity on Christmas Eve. Closer observation confirmed the probability that a tunnel existed, and work to confirm suspicions began Dec. 30, 1989, Linke said. ``This also confirmed our belief that North Korea has constructed other tunnels across the frontline,'' Linke said. South Korea found three tunnels, allegedly dug by North Korea across the border, in 1974, 1975 and 1978. Two of them were discovered near the truce village of Panmunjom, 35 miles north of Seoul. A third tunnel found in 1978 near Panmunjom was dug through granite nearly 500 feet below the surface and extends 1,300 feet into South Korean territory across the border. It has been open to the public. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist North and the capitalist South in 1945 after World War II. North Korea invaded South Korea in 1950 to start the three-year Korean War. The two countries remain technically at war. Despite sporadic dialogue, they remain arch enemies. No unauthorized travel or communication is allowed between citizens of the two sides.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Target Local School Issue As Anniversary March Nears
DOC.TEXT: Marchers assembled to commemorate the 25th anniversary of voting rights march to Montgomery kicked off the weekend with a parade for a new cause. The 300 marchers focused their protest Friday on the dismissal of Selma's first black school superintendent by the six whites on the 11-member school board. ``What is happening in Selma threatens education across the nation,'' said the Rev. Ben Chavis Jr. , executive director of the Commission for Racial Justice of the United Church of Christ in Cleveland, Ohio. The weekend's activities include a re-enactment Sunday of the 1965 march to Alabama's capital that helped prompt Congress to pass the Voting Rights Act. The law allowed blacks across the South to register to vote free of intimidation or rules designed to block them from the ballot box. The focus of Friday's march, however, was the school board's decision not to renew Superintendent Norward Roussell's contract when it expires in June. Protesters contend he is being fired in part because he dismantled a ``tracking'' system that tended to create segregated classrooms, with blacks placed on slower tracks in the 6,000-student system, which is 70 percent black. The marchers gathered outside Selma High School when classes let out Friday. When the crowd reached the Edmund Pettus Bridge _ scene of a confrontation in 1965 _ marchers knelt in prayer. Later, the marchers stopped outside the Selma school board building, where Roussell was cheered when he said Selma ``has a message for the rest of the country and the world. And that message is we will not allow our children to enter the 21st century undereducated or miseducated.'' The school board cited an evalution critical of Roussell's managerial skills for dismissing him. He contends the evaluation is unsubstantiated.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Say Labor Minister Received Money from Recruit
DOC.TEXT: A member of Japan's new Cabinet has acknowledged receiving money from the company at the center of a widespread influence-buying scandal, major newspapers reported today. Labor Minister Shunpei Tsukahara told Japanese reporters Friday that the Recruit Co. bought $42,000 in tickets to his fund-raising events in 1984-88, the Asahi Shimbun and Yomiuri Shimbun reported. Tsukahara is the first member of the new Cabinet, other than Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, to be linked to the Recruit scandal. Recruit Co. gave large donations and underpriced stock to dozens of prominent people, causing a public uproar that led to the resignations of numerous business and political figures. Kaifu has dedicated his new administration to political reform and said he would not pick anyone for his Cabinet who was tainted by the scandal. He formed the Cabinet Feb. 27. Tsukahara said he told his staff to investigate his financial records when he learned he was being considered for a Cabinet position in late February, the newspapers reported. They quoted Tsukahara as saying he was surprised to learn about his relations with Recruit, an information and publishing conglomerate, and decided to make them public. Tsukahara said he had not yet informed Kaifu of the fund-raising ticket purchases, the newspapers said. Kaifu left Friday for the United States for talks with President Bush. Repeated telephone calls today to Tsukahara's home and office went unanswered, and he could not be reached for comment on the reports. Kaifu was chosen prime minister in August after the Recruit scandal and a series of sex scandals rocked the governing Liberal Democrats and swept two prime ministers from power. Kaifu told a news conference when he first took office that he had received nearly $97,000 from Recruit, all in legal donations. But in its current issue, the weekly magazine Shukan Bunshun said it had obtained a list from Recruit which said Kaifu received $177,000 from the company in 1983-87.

DOC.HEAD: International Team Completes Seven-Month Antarctic Crossing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 13th pvs, `The journey...' with 1 graf to CORRECT spelling of Soviet station to Mirnyy, sted Mirnny. Pickup 14th, `The first...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Upcoming
DOC.TEXT: The six members of an international expedition arrived today at a Soviet base on Antarctica's eastern coast, completing what organizers called the longest unmechanized crossing of the forbidding continent. ``I'm feeling great happiness and great relief at the end of seven difficult months,'' co-leader Jean-Louis Etienne of France said in a live interview on French television moments after the arrival just after 1 p.m. Paris time (7 a.m. EST). In a hookup with reporters in Paris, Etienne said he was looking forward to returning to normal life. He said that apart from his companions and the dogs that pulled the sleds, he saw only three animals, all birds. ``I want to see nature. I want to see living things,'' Etienne said. The arrival ended a seven-month, 3,800-mile trek by ski and dogsled that risked turning to tragedy at the very close. Keizo Funatsu of Japan disappeared in a blizzard for 11 hours before being found by his worried fellow adventurers Friday morning. On Feb. 12, Italian mountaineer Reinhold Messner and West German adventurer Arved Fuchs completed what they said was a 1,699-mile crossing of Antarctica on foot, without the use of sled dogs. They are expected to arrive in Frankfurt later this month to provide details of their journey. The television images showed the final steps of the latest expedition live. The men in their bright red and blue suits stood out against the white snow as they and their 30 dogs reached a sign marked ``Finish'' in English by the gray waters of the Indian Ocean. Six national flags flapped in the wind representing the countries of the participants. Besides Funatsu and Etienne, the team members were co-leader Will Steger of Ely, Minn., Victor Boyarsky of the Soviet Union, Geoff Somers of Britain and Quin Dahe from China. The expedition was intended to generate support for Antarctica's preservation and to demonstrate the power of international cooperation. To attract attention, the team decided to attempt the first unmechanized crossing, using only dogsleds to help them transport their supplies and equipment. On Dec. 11, the team reached their halfway point, becoming the first to reach the South Pole by dogsled since Roald Amundsen discovered the pole in 1911. The journey began July 28 near the tip of the Antarctic Peninsula, which reaches out toward South America, and ended at the Soviet science station on the Indian Ocean at Mirnyy. But Etienne said in a television interview that the toughest part came earlier. ``The first two months were very, very hard,'' he said. ``We started to doubt after a month whether we would make it.'' He described Antarctica as ``huge and sometimes monstrous.'' President Bush sent a letter of contratulations to the team and invited members to the White House. ``Your spirit of international friendship and cooperation not only helped make this fantastic journey possible but also set a wonderful example for the world community of nations,'' Bush said. French President Francois Mitterrand sent a message of congratulations to Etienne, calling the trek ``a human adventure and a scientific testimony of the importance of the Antarctic continent for our environment.'' Mitterrand said he was looking forward to welcoming the six team members in Paris on March 21. It had been feared that deteriorating weather would keep the adventurers on the continent for as long as a month and jeopardize an elaborate international tour to tout the expedition later this month. But winds that reached 73 mph pushed the harbor ice apart, leaving a path for the Professor Zubov, a ship that is to take them to New Zealand. Soviet Antarctic officials in Leningrad told Cathy DeMoll, the expedition's manager in Paris, that unless conditions change, loading of the ship will begin Monday. ``They're talking about using lifeboats to carry everyone to the ship,'' DeMoll said. ``The trouble is, we don't know how dangerous that will be. We just don't know what's going to happen. We're completely at the mercy of the weather.'' The wind was howling at 70 mph and the temperature was 20 below zero when Funatsu left a Soviet mobile home where he was meeting with a French film crew Thursday, spokeswoman Jennifer Gasperini said from St. Paul, Minn. When Funatsu did not arrive back in his tent for dinner, team members tied themselves together and made a search of the area until 10 p.m., when they gave up because of darkness, Gasperini said. The search resumed at 4 a.m. Friday, and Funatsu was found about two hours later, she said. Etienne said that when expedition members came by calling ``Keizo, Keizo, Keizo,'' Funatsu ``jumped out like a mushroom from the snow. He was in very good shape.'' ``He had survived by digging a hole in the snow and crawling inside, just as the dogs do each night to stay warm,'' said Gasperini, who received the news from support staff. Team members ``were quite shook up by what happened,'' Gasperini said, explaining that in such blizzards it's easy to lose all sense of orientation, even in a small area. ``It's an extremely frightening situation,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Backing Off Plan to Join Maryland and D.C.
DOC.TEXT: Maryland Gov. William Donald Schaefer is beginning to think his proposal to annex the District of Columbia wasn't such a good idea after all. A week ago, Schaefer proposed joining the nation's capital with the Free State _ an idea that drew both laughs and sharp criticism from D.C. statehood advocates and elected officials in Maryland and Virginia. Within several days, Schaefer was saying: ``I'm not going to push this.'' ``We have enough problems in Maryland dealing with one major urban center, and that's Baltimore,'' said Thomas V. Miller, a Democrat who heads Maryland's Senate. ``We certainly can't take on Washington, D.C., with its attendant problems.'' From Virginia, which absorbed a chunk of the district back in 1846, came smiles and skepticism. ``It amuses me to see the governor of Maryland say they can take care of the district better than it can take care of itself,'' said Virginia state Del. Leslie L. Byrne of suburban Falls Church. ``I think he was talking off the top of his head.'' ``I can't see why Maryland would want it,'' said another Virginia legislator, Sen. Robert L. Calhoun, R-Alexandria. Such has been the reaction since Schaefer said last Sunday that he would entertain the notion of having the nation's capital absorbed by Maryland. Schaefer's remarks caught many people by surprise, especially in view of the negative headlines Washington has attracted lately. The mayor of Washington, Marion Barry, has been indicted on cocaine and perjury charges, and poor neighborhoods of the city are awash in drug-related murders. A ``broad range of allegations'' involving Barry is continuing, according to U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens. Meanwhile, District officials are struggling to control growing budget deficits while city prisons operate under court orders to control overcrowding. Some of Schaefer's critics, including the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, accused him of racism. ``Really what he's proposing is a kind of Bantustan concept,'' said Jackson. The term refers to South Africa's policy of separate communities for blacks. ``As we end Bantustans in South Africa, we do not want to transfer them to Washington. The issue here is sovereignty, self-respect.'' Maryland's flamboyant governor was quick to defend himself. Schaefer said financial gains that would come from annexing a city that, with a population of nearly 700,000, has more taxpayers than five states. ``It was a good intention. Now it's being interpreted as racism and all the rest. That's not true,'' Schaefer said. Jackson, who has taken up the cause of D.C. statehood, says full voting rights for the nation's capital is the only acceptable plan. ``The people of Washington want self-determination,'' said Frank Watkins, a top aide to Jackson. He said the idea of annexation ``is offensive to the people of the District of Columbia and Maryland.'' The House did pass a proposed constitutional amendment in 1978 to allow D.C. statehood, but the measure expired after being ratified by just 16 of the required 37 states.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Astronauts Prepare for Sunday Landing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with NASA announcement of landing time. Picks up 8th graf, `Astronauts generally...'
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis will end its secret military mission by landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., at 1:08 p.m. Sunday, NASA said today in an announcement that briefly broke a news blackout on the flight. ``The crew is doing well and beginning landing preparations and the orbiter continues to perform satisfactorily,'' the space agency said in the terse announcement. The anouncement made no assessment of weather conditions for the Sunday landing. Forecasts call for a Pacific Ocean storm to move into the landing site area in southern California. NASA sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the five-member, all-military crew of Atlantis on Thursday released into orbit a $500 million spy satellite. The satellite is designed to take detailed pictures of the Soviet Union, including areas never before viewed by shuttle-launched satellites, sources said. It also is able to tune into electronic communications worldwide. ``We can safely assume there are no problems'' as long as Mission Control does not interrupt the silence, said Bruce Buckingham, a spokesman for the space agency. NASA has not released details of astronaut activities aboard Atlantis, which was launched Wednesday, because the shuttle is on a classified Department of Defense mission. But Jeff Carr, a spokesman at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, said that if the astronauts follow shuttle mission routine, Friday was the final full day to complete the secret objectives. Astronauts generally clean up and start dismantling and stowing equipment the day before landing, Carr said. They also must test the reaction control jets and check other critical systems that Atlantis will need as it plunges through Earth's atmosphere. A general inspection of the solid rocket boosters has not revealed any abnormalities, said NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone. But ``we really won't know until they're taken apart,'' she said. The boosters were recovered from the Atlantic Ocean where they fell after liftoff early Wednesday morning, NASA's sixth attempt to launch the spaceship in less than a week. The boosters will be disassembled and refurbished for later use. The 1986 Challenger disaster was caused by a failed solid rocket booster. Atlantis' flight is 34th shuttle mission and the sixth dedicated solely to the military. Navy Capt. John O. Creighton is commander of the mission, piloted by Air Force Col. John H. Casper with mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot.

DOC.HEAD: Centuries-Old Anti-Semitism Returns to Haunt Soviet Jews
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A small black axe hangs just inside the door to Veniamin Gaufberg's apartment. Reinforcement strips glisten in the door's frame. The gaunt, 69-year-old Jew who fought the Nazis in World War II is preparing for a new battle against racial attacks. ``If they open the door, I'll cut off their fingers. What else can I do?'' asked Gaufberg. Although not all have resorted to axes, Gaufberg is typical of Soviet Jews anguished by what they say is a resurgence of anti-Semitism dating back centuries. Like record numbers of his countrymen, Gaufberg has had enough and is planning to leave his homeland for good, something he vowed he would never do. ``I have one goal now: to survive until the day I leave,'' he said in the western Moscow apartment he shares with four relatives. Jewish writers have been beaten, anti-Jewish graffiti has appeared, and hate-mongers openly distribute leaflets that borrow from Hitler to condemn the ``Zionist menace'' and call for attacks on Jews. Even the official press has carried blatantly anti-Semitic articles. Alexander Bushkov wrote in the newspaper Krasnoyarsk Komsomolets last June that Jews in the Soviet leadership ``participated in all the cases of genocide against the Russian people.'' No recent mob violence against the Soviet Union's 1.4 million Jews has been reported, but rumors and threats of pogroms, or organized racial attacks, are instilling a strong sense of danger, even panic. It has added to a Jewish exodus of unprecedented proportions. Aided by easier Soviet emigration policies, about 71,000 Soviet Jews left last year, the highest annual total since the 1967 Middle East War began a new wave of emigration. Nearly 5,000 left in January. ``Everyone I know is planning to run away, wherever possible,'' said Gaufberg. ``The situation is so intolerable. Every day I feel it,'' said Roza Gutman, a 23-year-old Jew from the Crimea. Huddled in a crowd of would-be emigres at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow, waiting to learn whether she and her family would be allowed to enter the United States, she explained the forces driving them away. She entered a Moscow music teachers' college because she felt that as a Jew, she stood little chance of being accepted at the more prestigious conservatory. But today there is greater danger than discrimination. Gutman said she is considering buying a gun to protect herself from threats, which she said included vandalism to her dormitory room and shouts from classmates to ``clear out of our country!'' ``It's become so acute that every Sunday, my friends say there will be a pogrom and don't go out,'' she said. ``Now it's simply dangerous. There's an elementary threat to life,'' she said. In December, the Soviet Union's first national Jewish congress in decades condemned the ``orgy of anti-Semitism'' sweeping the country and said it was causing an ``unprecedented panic among the Jewish population.'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's liberalization drive has been a mixed blessing for Soviet Jews. It has allowed freer emigration and the opportunity to practice their religion and culture without official harassment. But it has also allowed Russian nationalists to speak out, in some cases with anti-Semitic messages. The worsening economy and political upheaval of Gorbachev's rule have caused many Soviets to look for scapegoats, and Jews have been prime targets. Some Jews, like Gutman, suspect high-level complicity in anti-Semitism, but can offer little proof. The record of the country's previous rulers, however, is far from clean. Czar Nicholas I said in 1816, nine years before ascending the throne, that Jews were ``full-fledged leeches,'' and his regime portrayed Jewish traders as exploiters of the masses. Czarist forces either stood by or participated in beatings, murders and looting of apartments of Jews in pogroms of the 1880s and early 1900s. After the Soviets took power, with strong support and participation of Jews, Jews no longer were confined to a section of Russia known as the Pale. And although it was poorly enforced, a 1918 decree signed by Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin outlawed anti-Semitism. His successor, Josef Stalin, however, launched a campaign against ``cosmopolitanism'' after World War II, in which Jews were arrested and executed. The official Soviet encyclopedia boasted in 1953 that Soviet policy ``led to the disappearance of the `Jewish question,''' but anti-Semitism continued. Jews faced discrimination in education, jobs and the practice of their religion. The government has been accused to taking a lax attitude toward the threats. Authorities have countered with a propaganda campaign of their own. The regional Communist Party chief in Odessa went on television in late January to report that a commission ``condemned nationalist and chauvinist activity'' in the Black Sea port, which has a large Jewish population. Leaflets quoting Hitler's ``Mein Kampf'' and calling for Jewish pogroms had been spread in Odessa. In Moscow, the Interior Ministry said rumors of impending pogroms are unfounded, and that Soviet press articles reporting the threats ``mislead the public and can serve to promote ethnic strife and destabilization.'' The strongest official response has been the filing of criminal charges of ``inciting national and racial hatred and strife'' against Pamyat, the Russian nationalist group linked to the wave of anti-Semitism. The weekly newspaper Literaturnaya Gazeta said the charges were filed after Pamyat published a statement that said in part, ``Jews and their relatives must not be allowed to defend dissertations, to acquire knowledge and get academic titles, to join the Soviet Communist Party.'' About 50 people, identified in the official press as Pamyat members, stormed a meeting of a liberal writers group Jan. 18 in Moscow and beat participants, some of them Jews. An account in the magazine Ogonyok said the attackers called them Zhids _ a derogatory term for Jews _ and vowed, ``Today we came with a megaphone; the next time it will be with machine guns.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in House Fire
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a home outside Pittsburgh early today, killing a man and five children hours after a birthday party for one of the victims, officials said. Another man pulled from the burning home by police was hospitalized. Allegheny County homicide Lt. John Brennan said it appeared the fire broke out on the first floor of the three-story house but the cause was under investigation. Turtle Creek is 10 miles east of Pittsburgh. The 2 a.m. fire spread to two adjoining homes, but their residents escaped. Officials tentatively identified the dead as James Bennett, 23; Joshua Harris, 8; Carly Harris, 6; Jessie Harris, 4; Terrance Cleary, about 5; and Amanda Lee Cleary, about 3. Brennan said the Cleary children had attended Joshua's 8th birthday party and were staying overnight. Dusty Harris, 26, mother of the Harris children, was visiting neighbors and saw the fire when she left. Patrolman Frank Leonardo said when he arrived at the burning house, ``a woman was screaming, `My babies are in there, my babies are in there.'' Leonardo and four other officers tried to get in through the front door and a side window but were driven back by smoke and flames. Then they kicked in a back door. ``Because of the heavy smoke, we got down on our hands and knees and crawled in, where we saw a guy laying there about 15 feet from the door and we drug him out,'' he said. The injured man was taken to West Penn Hospital. The hospital declined to identify him or give any information on his condition.

DOC.HEAD: Former Indiana Supreme Court Justice Dies
DOC.TEXT: Frederick D. Landis Jr., who served as a justice on the Indiana Supreme Court and as a judge of the U.S. Court of International Trade, has died at age 78. Gov. George N. Craig appointed Landis to the state Supreme Court in 1955. Landis won election to two additional terms before President Lyndon B. Johnson appointed him to the federal judicial post in 1965. Landis retired in 1984 from the court, which reviews decisions by customs officials on tariffs and related matters. Landis served one term each in the Indiana House and Senate between 1950 and 1955. Landis was a nephew of Kenesaw Mountain Landis, first commissioner of professional baseball. Survivors include his wife, Irene; two sons, two daughters and two grandchildren. The funeral will be Monday at Calvary Presbyterian Church.

DOC.HEAD: Filmmaker and Fashion Chief Dies
DOC.TEXT: Honored filmmaker Robert L. McDonald, who also was credited with holding the Perry Ellis design house together after its founder's death, has died of complications from AIDS at age 45. McDonald died at his home in Manhattan Friday night. He was executive producer for two short films that won Academy Award nominations: ``It's So Nice to Have a Wolf Around the House'' in 1978 and ``Split Cherry Tree'' in 1982. He also received honors for films created for use in school study programs. In 1986, at the request of his longtime friend, fashion designer Perry Ellis, he became president of Perry Ellis International. He became chairman later that same year after the designer's death. McDonald is survived by his mother, Margaret Carroll McDonald of Toronto, a brother and a sister.

DOC.HEAD: Christians Flee Enclave During Cease-Fire
DOC.TEXT: Lines of cars and pickups piled high with mattresses, clothes and household goods snaked out of Christian east Beirut on Saturday during a cease-fire in the battle for control of the Christian enclave. Sniper fire crackled, despite the cease-fire, but there were no reports of new casualties. Police said civil defense teams evacuated 12 dead and 26 wounded from the battered districts of Nabaa and Sin el-Fil during the night after the fighting between Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and the Lebanese Forces militia subsided. That raised the overall casualty toll since the battles began Jan.30 to at least 766 killed and 2,087 wounded. The cease-fire took effect at 9 p.m. Friday after Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir threatened to excommunicate the fighters and their leaders if they did not stop shooting. Both Aoun and his rival, Lebanese Forces leader Samir Geagea, are Maronites, the Christian sect that has dominated Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Sfeir, speaking at a peace rally in Bkirki north of Beirut, lashed out at the antagonists and declared: ``A Christian worships God. He loves, has mercy on and helps his relative. He does not kill him, humiliate him or make him homeless.'' The battle for dominance in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has driven one-fifth of the area's 1 million inhabitants from their homes to relative safety elsewhere. A woman carrying a suitcase in one hand and a plastic bag of food in the other shepherded three children across Beirut's dividing Green Line into the Moslem sector. ``They've made us homeless. Only God is left for us now,'' she wailed. Another woman lugging three suitcases yelled at one of Aoun's soldiers on the Christian side of the 3-mile-long demarcation line, ``Finish this war!'' ``Go tell the patriarch,'' he answered coldly. Christians were also fleeing by ferry for the east Mediterranean island of Cyprus, 100 miles to the northwest. Most Christians feared the fighting would flare again, because Aoun appears determined to eliminate Geagea's militia, which has 6,000 fighters and thousands of reservists. Aoun has about 19,000 soldiers and has demanded Geagea disband his militia and merge it with Aoun's army to create a political organization. Geagea refuses. The cease-fire, the latest in a series of truces that have been either ignored or broken, ended 36 hours of fierce battles around the districts of Nabaa and Sin el-Fil. Aoun moved against Geagea at dawn Thursday with his U.S.-made M-48 tanks and advanced 200 yards to the edge of the districts, but he was blocked from moving into the narrow alleys of the two quarters. Aoun apparently was seeking to oust Geagea's strongholds to reach the wide coastal highway so he could attack the militia's headquarters in the Karantina district and the nearby Beirut port. The strategic 12-story Shalouhi building that once housed the offices of several Western companies was in a no man's land. It changed hands several times Thursday and Friday in savage room-to-room fighting. Aoun's headquarters said in a communique that he withdrew his forces as a ``goodwill gesture'' so mediators could resume efforts to work out a settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Kashmir: A `Romania in the Making?'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The appeal came from loudpseakers strung across mosques and by word of mouth: ``100,000 people have taken shelter in mosques. They are hungry. We need food.'' Within minutes, Moslem housewives collected their pots and pans. Within an hour, huge dinners of rice and vegetable curry were ready. The food was passed from hand to hand across narrow alleys and from rooftop to rooftop to avoid Indian patrols, until it reached the mosques that dot this city of nearly 1 million people. ``The appeal was for food, and it came. If the appeal goes for giving one's life, that will come too,'' said Mohammad Ramzan, a 74-year-old retired government employee. Moslems in the Kashmir Valley seem ready for a full-scale battle for independence. The relay of food was Thursday, the day government troops shot and killed at least 49 Moslems during marches by about a million Moslems demanding secession from Hindu-dominated India. It was the largest demonstration for secession ever in the Kashmir Valley, a Moslem-dominated region where residents have chafed and periodically broken into violence over Indian rule for the last four decades. ``Thursday was the watershed in the Indian government's efforts to keep the area under Indian control,'' said a local Moslem policeman, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Look at this,'' he said, pointing at his police uniform. ``Inside this uniform there is a Kashmiri first and a policeman later. I am no more an Indian, and I will never pick up arms against my brother Kashmiris.'' Urged on by militants, Moslems are starting to reject everything that is Indian. Billboards with the word ``India'' have been vandalized. Indian banks report low business. Many residents have set back their watches half an hour to correspond with the time in neighboring _ and Islamic _ Pakistan. Many people have stopped wearing wristwatches, fearful of offending either the militants or the government. ``Why take undue risk? I just don't wear a wristwatch anymore,'' a hotel doorman said. In the last few days a new directive went out to shopkeepers: Do not accept Indian currency. Instead, use the Pakistani currency that Indian sources say the militants are smuggling into Kashmir. ``Yes, we have heard about the directive not to accept Indian currency, but I don't think it has been put to practice,'' said an employee at one of Srinagar's top hotels. ``Indian currency is still legal tender, but if the campaign goes on the way it is going now, the day is not far off when we may have to refuse Indian money,'' he said, asking that neither he nor his hotel be identified. Under orders from the main Islamic militant group, the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, Srinagar's liquor shops closed or switched to selling other merchandise. Cinemas have closed, and one theater owner said he was thinking of converting his theater to a cold storage depot for potatoes. The refrain of independence reverberates throughout the city. ``Before, we _ the Kashmiris _ used to think that independence was not possible. But now we think it is not only possible, but it is only a matter of time,'' a Moslem high school teacher said on condition of anonynity. ``It is sort of Romania in the making,'' he said, comparing the Kashmir independence movement to the crumbling of the long-entrenched Communist Party regimes in Eastern Europe. But Indian officials said fear, not genuine feelings, has driven most people to join the demonstrations. ``These are stage-managed for the press,'' said Jagmohan, the federally appointed governor of Jammu-Kashmir state, where escalating violence by separatist groups prompted a massive government crackdown Jan. 20. More than 160 people have died since then, and most have been Moslem protesters shot by government troops. ``The number of hard-core terrorists will be at best 300 to 400,'' said Jagmohan, a Hindu who uses only one name, as he spoke in the heavily fortified governor's palace. ``The so-called sympathy you see is just a show, and some are out of fear.'' Events outside seemed to contradict this. ``I have never seen anything like that in my life,'' said Rahul Kapoor, referring to Thursday's processions of pro-independence demonstrators. ``My God, it was like a revolution,'' said Kapoor, a Hindu businessman from New Delhi.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Brand of Personal Diplomacy Brings Grumbling in Foggy Bottom
DOC.TEXT: A State Department official assigned to monitor dealings with a certain country heard rumors recently that his boss, Secretary of State James A. Baker III, was going to visit that country. Unable to confirm the rumors through official channels, the official hit on the idea of asking the department's pool of interpreters if they had seen correspondence to the capital in question. Bingo! They had seen enough to confirm his suspicions. His ploy was one of many ingenious methods devised by department aides frustrated by lack of access to Baker and a coterie of senior advisers who have held the reins of U.S. foreign policy for the past 13 months. Not since the Henry Kissinger era in the 1970s has decision making been such a private affair among a handful of officials on the seventh floor of the cavernous State Department building. Baker, a Texas attorney whose personal and political bonds with George Bush date back 20 years, prizes secrecy and direct telephone diplomacy with foreign leaders is not unusual. ``He believes that's the best way of doing things,'' said an aide familiar with Baker's style. ``You can't deal with delicate issues in a broad circle. Leaks endanger success.'' Access to Baker is a rare and valued commodity at Foggy Bottom. One of the half-dozen or so officials with easy access is department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. She was also his spokeswoman when he was Treasury secretary in the Reagan administration and she worked for Bush in 1980 presidential campaign. In her first briefing to the State Department press corps last February, Tutwiler apologized for her limited knowledge of foreign affairs. But she added, ``I do know this president and this secretary of state very well.'' For those out of the loop, especially officials who served under Baker's predecessor, George Shultz, the adjustment has been difficult. Many are awaiting assignments that will take them abroad _ and possibly into jobs with less frustration. But for those whose careers will keep them here for several years, disgruntlement is running high. None of the officials interviewed agreed to have their names used, but their complaints were uniform. Shultz, an economics professor who has returned to university life, chose his close aides from the ranks of the career foreign service and relied on senior bureaucrats to help shape policy. Baker, who brought all his aides with him from outside the department, is ``his own point man on most major issues,'' said one senior foreign service officer. When Baker wants to nudge Israel and Egypt toward the negotiating table, he phones his counterparts in those countries. He has 41 telephone extensions in his office. Officials at the Bureau of Near East Affairs, which includes the Middle East, are generally kept in the dark about high-level talks. Several have said they learn of developments by reading the newspapers or from ambassadors from Mideast countries. When Baker went to Capitol Hill last March to negotiate a Contra aid agreement, ``very few people in this building knew about it,'' said an aide. When reporters heard that Bush was about to announce a proposal for troop cuts in Europe in January, a senior arms control official said he knew nothing about it. ``I can assure you that only three people in this building know,'' said a close Baker associate. When Bush prepared to announce arms cuts in Europe last June, U.S. representatives at NATO headquarters in Brussels were learned about it from European colleagues. ``They (the Europeans) knew about it before we did here in the building because Baker briefed the allies,'' said one official. ``It's like reading tea leaves,'' said the official. ``Baker wants to control everything.'' To which the secretary's close aide replied: ``That's his perogative.'' The aide denied that Baker shuts himself off from other opinions. On his visit to West Germany last December, the U.S. ambassador in East Germany repeatedly pressed Baker to add Potsdam and a meeting with Prime Minister Hans Modrow to his agenda. Baker was undecided until the last minute but finally decided to go and become the first U.S. secretary of State to venture into East Germany beyond East Berlin. ``It was good advice, and the secretary was happy he took it,'' said the aide.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Poised to Change Gramm-Rudman Budget Law _ Again
DOC.TEXT: Congress and the White House are all but certain to make changes this year in the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law, which has dominated debate over the federal budget since its enactment in 1985. If the revisions are major, it would be the second time in its short life that the legislation _ designed to gradually force a balanced budget _ has been substantially altered. The changes will at the very least be forced by an issue that lawmakers have been fixated on in recent weeks: the gigantic surpluses accumulated each year by the Social Security trust fund. But with Gramm-Rudman's declining annual deficit targets scheduled to expire in fiscal 1993, when the budget is supposed to be balanced, there are other cross-currents as well. Conservatives want to extend the deficit targets into later years to hold down spending for domestic programs. Liberals want to eliminate the targets soon so that social spending can expand, and they want to have the Pentagon budget and taxes play a greater role in cutting the deficit. ``There are about 100 ideas in this place about how the process will be changed,'' says Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. The driving force for the changes is the ever-growing Social Security surplus, expected to be $74 billion next year alone. Critics _ and it's become hard to find members of Congress not sharply critical _ say this surplus makes the overall federal deficit appear smaller than it actually is, easing the political pressure to address the budget shortfall. The Congressional Budget Office projects the deficit for fiscal 1991 _ which begins Oct. 1 _ at $138 billion. Take out the retirement funds and the shortfall would be $212 billion. Almost everyone on Capitol Hill believes lawmakers will act this year to remove the Social Security surpluses from the deficit calculations. ``We believe we should separate the Social Security trust funds from the budget, and we will enact the legislation to do so,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said last week. But that raises another problem. Gramm-Rudman already requires that the federal deficit be sliced by about $37 billion next year . Unless the law's target is raised _ as seems likely _ removing Social Security surpluses from the arithmetic would force lawmakers to find $111 billion in savings, a task considered politically impossible and risky to the economy. ``A certain set of dominoes begin to fall here,'' says House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``If the first decision is to move Social Security off Gramm-Rudman calculations, that inevitably leads you to confront what you do with the remaining large deficit.'' More complex proposals to change the law are also under consideration, but all share a common element: the retirement system's surpluses would no longer be included when the deficit is added up. Sasser and Panetta have each offered their own plans, both of which would put off some of the fiscal pressure. Republican congressional leaders are working with the White House on a GOP alternative. Other members of both parties also have submitted legislation. The target of all this is a law enacted in the middle of the Reagan administration, when the conservative president and Democrats in Congress fought to repeated budget standoffs. With deficits growing out of control _ they peaked at $221 billion in fiscal 1986 _ Gramm-Rudman was enacted. A series of declining deficit targets were set, leading to a balanced budget in 1991. Failure to reach the shortfall goals triggers automatic spending cuts on most federal programs. Congress and the White House initially lowered the deficit somewhat, but haven't made steady progress. The law was eased in 1987 to stretch out the targets to 1993, but domestic spending has grown and Presidents Reagan and Bush have blocked tax hikes and sharp defense cuts. Critics charge that budget writers in the Capitol and the White House have not really become adept at cutting the deficit, only at finding loopholes around Gramm-Rudman and ignoring real deficit reduction. ``A desirable change would be to put a dynamite charge under Gramm-Rudman and blow it up,'' says Henry Aaron, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. But supporters say it has focused attention on the government's red ink and helped force savings. One of the law's authors, Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, says the legislation should be kept alive until the budget is balanced. ``I didn't do all this flirting just to get down to the altar and not get the `I do's' said,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Severe Earthquake Hits South Pacific
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake rolled through the South Pacific off the Fiji islands late Saturday, seismologists reported. There were no reports of damage or injuries. The quake struck at 9:27 p.m. (6:27 a.m. EST) and measured 7.5 on the Richter scale, according to reports from officials in Tokyo, Hong Kong, and the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. An earthquake of 7.5 can cause major damage in populated areas, but geophysicist John Minch at the information center in Colorado said, ``We don't expect any damage. It's out there where there's really nothing around.'' He said it was centered in the ocean 300 miles southwest of Nadi, in Fiji. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Kaifu Meet on Trade Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with today's talks starting; picks up 3rd graf pvs, The trade
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu met today for the second day at their desert summit to delve into divisive trade issues after an opening session focused on the U.S. military presence in Asia. In three hours of talks today, the two were expected to tackle thorny agenda items centering on growing U.S. unhappiness over the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met for an hour earlier today with Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama. Bush greeted Kaifu at the Morningside Country Club saying, ``I hope you got a little rest.'' Kaifu told Bush through an interpreter, ``I had a very good sleep.'' Bush was joined at the conference table by Baker, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and White House chief of staff John Sununu. The trade problems were touched on only briefly in Friday's warm-up talks, with both sides noting that they face ``difficult issues,'' said Shigeo Takenaka, deputy spokesman for the Japanese foreign ministry. ``We didn't discuss things in specific terms,'' Kaifu told reporters later, ``but there was a real sense of understanding. I sensed no irritation whatsoever during our meeting.'' On trade issues in general, Kaifu said, ``As you know there are some things that can be moved along and others that are more difficult.'' He added that there are some structural areas where Japanese action is ``absolutely necessary'' _ such as high land prices in Japan _ ``but we must have the cooperation and understanding (of the Japanese people) on these issues.'' But Friday's talks principally focused on defense matters, U.S. officials said. Bush and his wife, Barbara, later held a dinner for Kaifu at the estate of publishing magnate Walter Annenberg. Bush told Kaifu that administration plans for a 10 percent reduction in U.S. troop levels in Japan ``will not affect either deterrence or stability, nor its commitment to its Asian allies,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. The two also discussed the U.S. wish for Japan to increase its $2.4 billion annual support for U.S. troops stationed there. They both noted, Fitzwater said, ``the need for suitable arrangements for balanced cost sharing.'' Both Japanese and U.S. officials seemed eager to put a friendly cast on the meeting as talks got under way. The president told reporters at a photo session that Kaifu's two-day trip on a week's notice was ``quite a significant gesture of friendship between our countries.'' Takenaka told reporters that both leaders recognized the importance of addressing trade issues seriously. To solve these issues, he said, ``we must continue to strengthen cooperation in other areas,'' such as aiding Latin American nations and the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. ``We certainly didn't sense any ambush here,'' he said when asked if the Americans were coming down hard on Tokyo for trade inequities. Bush is staying at the Annenberg home in this desert resort before returning to Washington on Sunday. Kaifu arrived Friday afternoon, shortly after Bush flew in from a series of appearances in the Los Angeles area. In their talks today at the Morningside Country Club, Bush planned to put Kaifu on notice that Congress was in ``a very tough mood'' about Japanese barriers to trade, Fitzwater said. U.S. officials also planned to pointedly note U.S. law that calls for retaliatory moves that could double the cost of Japanese goods sold in the United States if the United States finds Tokyo is obstructing fair trade, Fitzwater said. Apparently attempting to signal good faith in advance of the hastily called summit meeting, Kaifu announced before leaving Tokyo that he was prepared to make concessions sought by the United States. He outlined proposals that mirrored steps sought by the United States to reform the Japanese economy and lifestyle in a way that would encourage more purchase of U.S. imports. The trade tensions have been intensified by escalating Japanese investment in America. The Bush-Kaifu meeting comes against a background of congressionally set deadlines for talks on a dozen issues ranging from supercomputers to lumber. In turn, Japan wants the United States to reduce its huge budget deficit and increase Americans' savings rate, thus reducing demands for Japanese imports. Last May, the United States cited Japan for alleged unfair barriers against the sale of American wood products, satellites and supercomputers. Under the 1988 U.S. trade law, if negotiations do not produce removal of the barriers by June 16, the administration can slap on severe retaliatory tariffs. A yearlong series of separate negotiations to resolve underlying causes of the trade deficit, such as Japan's exclusionary business practices and America's low savings rate have left U.S. negotiators frustrated at the lack of movement.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Filibuster Threat Dominated Clean Air Bill Negotiations
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: During last week's closed-door bargaining over a Senate clean air bill, negotiators haggled over countless numbers _ but the most important number was never mentioned. It was 60, the number of senators needed to make a compromise clean air bill ``filibuster-proof'' and assure its Senate passage in the months ahead. Through the 22 days of negotiations the number hung over the meeting room like a blanket of smog. The agreement between Senate leaders and the Bush administration over clean air legislation was a major victory for Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, who instigated the closed-door discussions in early February. He will bring the bill to the Senate floor for action on Monday, but while there is expected to be lively debate and attempts to make changes, the bill likely will not be altered significantly The secretive negotiations, criticized by environmentalists publicly and some senators privately, were a masterful exhibition of legislative maneuvering. And the principal goal, according to various officials involved, was to produce a bill that would not become the victim of regional interests on the Senate floor as clean air legislation so often had in the past. For years Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., when he was majority leader, blocked clean air bills regularly because controls on acid rain would threaten thousands of jobs in the high-sulfur coal mining areas of his state. Much of the Midwest and parts of the South rely on high-sulfur coal to fuel electric power plants, the source of most of the sulfur dioxide emissions that cause acid rain. A bloc of 14 senators, primarily from the Midwest and headed by Byrd, had threatened to stall passage of legislation again, spurred by word from utilities across the Midwest that the tougher pollution controls would be far too costly for many of the plants that dot the region. Meanwhile, there also were factions in the Senate worried about other parts of the clean air bill as approved by the Environment and Public Works Committee: Senators from the West and parts of the South were worried that the pollution controls would inhibit future growth; the auto industry lobbied the White House against the bill's tough automobile emission controls, enlisting Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., to argue their case in the closed-door negotiations; and manufacturers buttonholed anyone they could to tell them of the high cost of proposed controls on toxic chemical releases. The dilemma facing Mitchell was how to eliminate enough of the concerns in the bill to forge an alliance strong enough to overcome whatever opposition remains. For that he needed the support of the White House. So the private negotiations began. The provision on controlling toxic chemicals was weakened and small businesses and industrial sources were exempted from smog-causing pollution controls. The Bush administration was now ready to accept both of those parts of the bill. The battle then turned to dealing with the chief objections of the auto industry. A provision that would have required automakers to increase the fuel efficiency of their cars was jettisoned early. But agreement on auto emission controls, which were targeted by the administration as too expensive, proved to be more difficult. Mitchell, trying to get the talks moving, set a deadline, saying if no agreement could be reached he'd take the legislation to the floor anyway. But the administration held some important cards as well: Without the support of the president, Mitchell might not have the votes to overcome a Midwest filibuster. White House chief of staff John Sununu sent that message when, after meeting with Mitchell, he suggested a rush to push the bill to the floor without agreement on automobile emission controls could be ``undermining ... the acid rain section.'' So after several days of marathon meetings that lasted past midnight, an accord was reached on the automobile issues: a second round of controls were significantly weakened so that they may never go into effect. Mitchell's strategy was about to bear results. The legislation now had the support of President Bush, who in turn could be counted on to produce enough Republican votes that a filibuster likely would be overridden _ no matter what the Midwest senators did. But there were still some loose ends. The concerns of the senators from the West and parts of the South over the impact of the acid rain controls on future growth had to be dealt with, for if they allied themselves with the Midwest in _ for different reasons _ opposing the bill, its chances were slim. A provision was crafted to deal with the problem by giving so-called clean states additional pollution allowances to better handle future growth. That brought another bloc of senators into line. As the discussions on acid rain began, the senators from the Midwest and Byrd from West Virginia were now alone and outgunned. ``We did not have a choice between the good, the bad and the ugly. We had a choice between ugly, uglier and ugliest,'' said Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., recalling his travail during the private negotiations on acid rain. When the compromise agreement was announced, Byrd said he would continue to seek some changes on the Senate floor, but rejected the possibility of a filibuster. ``We all have to be reasonable men and women,'' he explained. Mitchell's strategy had worked.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: H. Josef Hebert reports on environmental matters for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: California Attorney General Sues State's No. 2 Insurance Provider
DOC.TEXT: California's attorney general has sued Farmers Insurance Group, claiming the state's second-largest insurance company has defied Proposition 103, the voter-approved insurance reform law. ``Farmers has attempted to make a mockery of the law either by shunting some good driver applicants into a subsidiary called Mid-Century, which does offer new policies but only at outrageous prices, or by outright refusal to insure them at all,'' Attorney General John Van de Kamp said at a news conference Friday. The lawsuit was filed the same day six other companies were ordered by Insurance Commissioner Roxani Gillespie to issue good driver discount policies as mandated by Proposition 103. Notices of the Insurance Commission's findings were sent to Allstate Insurance Co., Chicago Insurance Co. and Interstate Indemnity, California Casualty Insurance Co., Cal-American Insurance Co., and Clarendon National Insurance Co. Proposition 103, approved by voters in 1988, requires auto insurance rates based primarily on a driver's safety record, experience and miles driven. Drivers with no more than one moving violation in three years are to be guaranteed lower rates. Van de Kamp's lawsuit, filed in Superior Court, seeks a preliminary injunction to force Farmers to comply with a good driver provision in Proposition 103 that states such drivers can get 20 percent discounts. Van de Kamp, a Democratic gubernatorial candidate, said he also is seeking $2,500 in fines for each good driver refused insurance policies at the discount rate. A spokesman for the Los Angeles-based insurance company said Farmers has been wrongly accused. ``Farmers is absolutely complying with the good driver discount and filed documents with the commissioner's office a couple of weeks ago showing its whole marketing plan for marketing good driver discounts,'' said attorney Leonard Venger, who represents the company on Proposition 103 matters.

DOC.HEAD: Lost Skiers Rescued in French Alps
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers in a helicopter found two skiers Saturday who got lost on an off-trail outing and survived six days in a makeshift shelter with nothing to eat but snow and chewing gum, police said. Hospital officials said Marie-Antoinette Meynet, 31, would lose a toe to frostbite and that her companion, 34-year-old Philippe Bensimon, was in ``very serious condition'' with both feet badly frostbitten. The search for the couple was delayed for several days by snowstorms in a wooded valley near Chamonix in the French Alps, 380 miles southeast of Paris. When the weather cleared Saturday, searchers in a helicopter found Bensimon unconscious outside the shelter, which was built with their skis, blocks of snow and pine branches. He and Miss Meynet, described as semiconscious at the time of the rescue, were taken by helicopter to the Chamonix hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Arabs Protest Soviet Jewish Immigration
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for story slugged Israel-Immigration listed on on news digest with AM-Soviet-Anti-Semitism.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Israeli Arabs have signed a petition urging the Soviet Union to stop Jewish immigration to Israel for fear the new arrivals will take away Arab jobs, organizers of the campaign said Saturday. The petition drive is a sign of the growing alienation of Israel's 800,000 Arab citizens. Yossi Olmert, head of the Government Press Office, called the petition drive a grave development that ``undermines the very foundations of the state.'' One of Israel's self-declared reasons for existence is the ingathering of exiles. ``Arabs who are citizens are protesting the immigration of Jews into Israel, and this must be seen as being orchestrated by the PLO as part of the worldwide campaign against immigration,'' Olmert said. The petition urges Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to stop the exodus of Soviet Jews, which is due in part to relaxed Soviet emigration rules and in part to fears of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. Israeli leaders have said they expect up to 750,000 Soviet Jews to immigrate this decade, and one government official said last week he expected as many as 230,000 to arrive this year. ``The Jewish immigration from the Soviet Union is at the expense of the Palestinian people. This immigration will escalate the racial discrimination that Arabs suffer,'' said the petition, which was written by Arab nationalist activists calling themselves ``The Sons of the Village.'' On Saturday, about 1,000 people signed the petition in the northern Israeli town of Nazareth, bringing the total in the past two days to more than 4,000 signatures, said organizer Mohammed Kayal, an Arab journalist. He said the drive would continue for another two weeks and that the petition would then be sent to Gorbachev. ``The Israeli Arabs are really worried,'' said Atallah Mansour, another Israeli Arab journalist. ``The Israeli government policy for the past 40 years has been not to treat the Arab population on egalitarian terms, and now the Arabs again have someone coming before them in the queue.'' The main concern is that that Soviet Jewish immigrants will take away jobs from Arabs who face an unemployment rate of more than 15 percent, compared to about 10 percent among Israeli Jews. ``For the unemployed and the young university graduates, this is a terrifying nightmare,'' Mansour said. Israeli Arabs frequently complain about being treated as second-class citizens. For example, they are barred from serving in the army, and are thus not eligible for many benefits given veterans, such as low-interest loans on housing. The concern over the influx of Soviet Jews has been complicated by fears that some might settle in the occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip, where Palestinians are fighting for their own state. Secretary of State James A. Baker III suggested Thursday that $400 million in loan guarantees to help build housing for the emigrants be linked to Israeli promises that no new settlements will be built in the occupied lands. Israel says it has no policy of directing immigrants to the occupied territories, and government leaders denounced Baker's proposal Friday. They said that of 12,000 Soviet Jewish immigrants last year, only about 200 settled in the occupied territories. Also Saturday, 33-year-old Sadi Abdel Fatah from Gaza's Bureij refugee camp died at a hospital after being stabbed and shot in the head by masked Palestinians who suspected him of being an informer, an Arab reporter said. The death brought to 191 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs during the uprising against Israeli rule, which began in December 1987. Another 659 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence. In clashes in Gaza City, troops wounded four Palestinians, including an 18-year-old who was in critical condition with a bullet in the abdomen, Ahli Arab Hospital officials said. An army official confirmed one wounded and said he was checking the reports of the death in Bureij and the other casualties.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Broadcasts to Cuba Gear Up For Mid-March Start
DOC.TEXT: Destabilizing Castro's Cuba isn't the objective for broadcasting U.S. television to Havana, says the chief of the new TV Marti. But if that's that result, so be it. ``If that's subversive,'' said Antonio Navarro of TV Marti's aim to provide objective and balanced news, ``then maybe it is. ... But that's not the intent.'' The potential impact of the U.S.-sponsored TV Marti has taken on added significance with the defeat of Nicaragua's leftist Sandinistas, a longtime ally of Cuba's Communist regime. Cuban exiles in Miami view the defeat as a precursor to Fidel Castro's fall. The Cuban government, for its part, says the planned broadcasts are an act of aggression and an attempt to ``subvert the order in Cuba.'' The Caribbean island nation, 90 miles from the Florida Keys, is preparing to jam the broadcasts and take retaliatory measures. The United States has been broadcasting radio transmissions to Cuba via Radio Marti _ named for Cuban patriot Jose Marti _ for about five years. Last year, Congress provided $16 million for television broadcasts to Cuba. TV Marti's testing start-up has been scheduled for mid-March. Whether or not it moves into full operation, the prospect of U.S. broadcasts has already further strained relations between Washington and Havana. Daily broadcasts of several hours of entertainment and sports programming are planned for the 90-day test period, said Michael Schoenfeld, spokesman for Voice of America, which will produce the shows. The broadcasts beamed to Havana are expected to have a potential viewing audience of some 2.5 million people, according to Schoenfeld. Radio Marti is heard by more than 85 percent of the Cuban population, he said. Jorge Mas Canosa, chairman of the Cuban American National Foundation, an anti-Castro group that lobbied for TV Marti in Congress, says the TV broadcasts will have an even greater impact on Cubans than Radio Marti. ``TV is a much more powerful means than radio,'' Mas said recently. ``It has much more impact on the public opinion.'' Proponents of TV Marti say it will provide an alternative to the government-controlled media in Cuba _ one that could prove even more damaging to Castro than news of upheaval in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union via Radio Marti. ``I believe that it's going to be a big help in this moment when we know the regime is falling down. ... They'll see how the rest of the world is,'' said Ceferino Perez of the Cuban Municipalities in Exile, a Miami group whose members are preparing to assist their countrymen in rebuilding Cuba in the event Castro is toppled. But there has been criticism of TV Marti, not the least from the Cuban government, which has vehemently protested the transmissions are a violation of sovereignty and international broadcasting agreements. Besides, said Ariel Ricardo, press officer of the Cuban Interests Section, in Washington, ``It's no secret to the Cuban people what's going on in the world.'' Cubans are ``quite well informed'' through the Cuban media and other sources such as the British Broadcasting Corp. and Miami radio stations whose powerful signals reach the island. And, Ricardo said, just because the Cuban government has tolerated Radio Marti, which it also opposes, ``doesn't mean we consider Radio Marti right.'' U.S. broadcasters, especially in Florida, are worried about retaliatory broadcasts from Cuba or direct interference from TV Marti's signal. Schoenfeld says TV Marti's specially designed, highly directional antenna will virtually eliminate interference to domestic broadcasters. Spanish-language programs from Washington will be relayed to a transmitter aboard a giant balloon tethered over Cudjoe Key and then beamed to Havana. Sydney Head, a expert on international broadcasting and author of ``World Broadcast,'' criticized TV Marti, calling it ``a tremendous boondoggle.'' ``There's no purpose in it except to satisfy the zeal of Cuban ex-patriots,'' Head said recently in a telephone interview from Oceano, Calif. ``They'll do anything to tweak (Castro's) nose, make him uncomfortable.'' Head said TV Marti is certain to capture a sizable audience simply because of the entertainment value of U.S. programs compared with what Cuba has to offer. But he doesn't think it will have much of an effect on public opinion.

DOC.HEAD: Goodbye to Shepherds and Milkmaids. Welcome Herdspersons
DOC.TEXT: Goodbye to the shepherds and milkmaids enshrined in English lore, and welcome herdspersons of the 1990s. The drive for sexual equality and professional standards has reached men and women who look after cows, pigs, goats, deer, sheep, chickens, and even llamas. The Professional Herdspersons Society, launched Friday at the Palace of Westminster, hopes to attract 10,000 members in its first year. Sir Richard Body, a Conservative Party lawmaker, former chairman of the House of Commons Select Committee on Agriculture and onetime pig breeder, said the society's aim is to put men and women who manage animals ``on the pedestal where they belong.'' ``They do a marvelous job in all sorts of weather, seven days a week, and their role must be more professionally recognized,'' he said. The society plans to set standards of care for various animals and provide a monthly journal, life and accident insurance, and medical coverage. Body, who will be an adviser to the society, said: ``My only worry is the word herdsperson.'' At the opening session, several officials of the new society slipped up at times, referring to the ``men'' and the ``chaps'' on livestock farms.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Paul McCartney returned to Japan's stage Saturday after a 24-year absence with a smoky, laser-studded show peppered with old Beatles hits. ``It's great to be back,'' McCartney told 60,000 fans at the Tokyo Dome, an indoor baseball stadium where McCartney will perform his six Japan concerts. It was a rousing comeback to Japan for the 47-year-old McCartney. The last time he tried to tour Japan he was arrested before even leaving the airport after customs officials found 219 grams of marijuana among his belongings. The ex-Beatle was held for 10 days before he was expelled and banned from ever returning. But based on his clean record for the past five years, he was granted special permission by the Justice Ministry to perform. McCartney said at a news conference Thursday he now would tell people ``be straight and stay natural and don't use any drugs or stimulants or booze.'' After playing ``Band on the Run'' from his days with his old band Wings, McCartney told the crowd he would take them ``to a very faraway place called the 60s,'' and whipped off ``The Long and Winding Road,'' ``Can't Buy Me Love'' and ``Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.'' McCartney's world tour started in Oslo, Norway, last September and has taken him through Britain, continental Europe and the United States. From Japan, the band travels to Australia, back to the United States, to Brazil and finishes in Europe in April.

Conway Twitty is picky when it comes to selecting songs for his country music albums. He says he reviews up to 3,000 songs before he chooses 10. ``We go through this town with a seine, or a sifter,'' he said Friday at the annual Country Radio Seminar. ``We go through 2,500 to 3,000 songs before I pick the 10 that I do. There's nothing more important than that song.'' Twitty said a career ``starts with great songs and ends with bad songs. So always do great songs and you'll stay in this business a long time.'' The seminar is for employees at country music radio stations. Twitty is a veteran country music performer known for his hit records ``It's Only Make Believe'' and ``Linda on My Mind.''

Tickets for the Farm Aid IV concert featuring four-time Grammy winner Bonnie Raitt didn't last long when they went on sale Saturday. The April 7 show was sold out in less than 90 minutes. Capacity for the show at the Hoosier Dome will be about 45,000, but some of those seats were being held back for promotional purposes, said Sunshine Promotions and Ticketmaster, which handled ticket sales. Singer John Mellencamp, a native of Seymour, Ind., has joined Willie Nelson and Neil Young in organizing the fourth concert to benefit family farmers. Dick Clark, Michelle Greene and Sarah Purcell will be hosts of the marathon show that tentatively features 60 acts. The lineup will be headed by Raitt, Don Henley and Richard Marx. Other major acts expected to participate include Guns 'n Roses, John Denver, LL Cool J, Carl Perkins, John Prine, Was Not Was, Forrester Sisters, Gorky Park, Arlo Guthrie, Kris Kristofferson, K.T. Oslin, Poco, Jackson Browne, Iggy Pop, Lou Reed, Ricky Van Shelton and Dwight Yoakum.

James Garner, who played ``Maverick'' in the TV series, and Clayton Moore, who was TV's ``The Lone Ranger,'' will be inducted into the National Cowboy Hall of Fame's Hall of Great Western Performers. The pair will be honored at the annual Western Heritage Awards and Silver Anniversary Celebration on March 17 at the Oklahoma City museum, the museum announced Saturday. Entertainer Glen Campbell will serve as master of ceremonies. Hosts for the evening are actors Steven Ford, Sam Elliott and Clu Gulager, star of the 1960s television series ``The Virginian.'' Garner, a Norman, Okla., native, has screen credits that include ``Murphy's Romance,'' ``Support Your Local Sheriff,'' and ``The Skin Game.'' He first achieved stardom playing the leading role in ``Maverick.'' Other actors previously inducted into the Western Performers Hall of Fame include John Wayne, Tom Mix, Gene Autry, Gregory Peck and Barbara Stanwyck.

DOC.HEAD: 4,000 Years Later, Sumerian Recipe Still Can Produce Good Beer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, `An article...' with one graf to CORRECT that article the brewer saw was in a newspaper, sted written by the professor.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PX1
DOC.TEXT: The recipe was part of a Sumerian hymn to the goddess Ninkasi, written in cuneiform on a clay tablet that dates back to 1800 B.C. It calls for ingredients you might not think of, but it makes a smooth, mild beer _with a little fruity taste. ``It's very good,'' Professor Solomon Katz of the University of Pennsylvania said as he opened a bottle. ``They used dates to make it taste that way.'' The bottle's label had cuneiform characters calling Ninkasi, the goddess of beer, ``the lady who fills the vessel with beer.'' The label also showed one of the earliest known tablets, showing two men using straws to sip beer from a narrow-necked jar. The beer was the culmination of two years of research by Katz and Fritz Maytag, owner of San Francisco-based Anchor Brewing Co. They sampled some of the last bottles of the beer last week in Philadelphia. They had brewed about 100 barrels in August, but said they were forced to use it up quickly since it contained no preservatives. ``The Sumerians didn't use hops, which help to keep beer from going sour,'' Maytag said in a telephone interview from San Francisco. Modern beer makers usually use malted, or sprouted, grain, but the Sumerians used baked bread, which adds to the mild taste, Katz said. ``They did that because the bread was almost magical to them,'' Katz said. ``You could eat it for dinner or you could brew with it.'' The cuneiform tablet, originally translated in 1964, records a brewing process interspersed with praises to the goddess. ``You are the one who soaks the malt in a jar, the waves rise, the waves fall,'' starts one verse. ``That's a brewing process,'' Katz said. ``That's exactly what brewers do today to turn the grains into malt.'' ``Real brewing is very simple,'' Maytag said. ``And we know that the brewers 5,000 years ago were extremely skilled. We ought to assume that these guys were just as good at brewing as we are.'' By the time the Ninkasi hymn was written, brewing was at least 5,000 years old, said Katz. By 2000 B.C., Sumerian had 55 words describing different varieties of beer. ``Beer recipes are the oldest we have,'' Katz said. Katz, an anthropologist specializing in nutrition, believes beer may be the cornerstone of civilization and has argued that ancient man turned from hunting to farming to raise grain for beer. Barley and wheat _ the two main ingredients of ancient beer _ were among the first grains man began to harvest. ``Why did people go out and domesticate a cereal grain that doesn't have much nutrition?'' Katz asked. ``They had plenty of other resources ... why would they go through the effort? Could it be because it was a source of fermented sugar?'' A 1987 newspaper story about Katz's theories, which the professor also had written about, caught Maytag's eye and led to the collaboration. ``I thought it was intriguing,'' Maytag said. ``It occurred to me we should try to make some of the beer, to see what we could learn.'' Katz had to pore over many tablets to determine some of the finer points of the recipe. He pointed at the translation of the Ninkasi hymn. ``See where it says, `Mixing ... with sweet aromatics?' We can't be sure if that meant grapes, raisins or dates,'' he said. They narrowed it down to dates using other recipe tablets from that time period. Maytag has no plans to market Ninkasi, although people have tried to buy it: ``I don't think the world is ready to buy Sumerian beer.''

DOC.HEAD: Angola Claims New Attack on Rebel Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: The Angolan government said air force planes bombed the headquarters of U.S.-backed UNITA rebels for the second time in a week. State television interrupted programing to broadcast a Defense Ministry statement saying two planes attacked the guerrillas' bush stronghold at Jamba on Friday in retaliation for UNITA raids on economic and civilian targets. Last week, the government claimed two fighter planes breached sophisticated, U.S.-supplied anti-aircraft defenses to bomb the rebel headquarters at Jamba, 850 miles southeast of Luanda. In Lisbon, Portugal, spokesmen for the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as UNITA, denied the government claims. UNITA's Lisbon representative Alcides Sakala said the government's Soviet-built planes instead bombed the area of Mavinga, some 160 miles north of Jamba to support a ground offensive launched in late December. He insisted Jamba was not hit. There was no independent confirmation of either report.
