According to the ministry statement, Friday's raid was in response to rebel attacks that left 26 civilians dead and destroyed a bridge in northern Uige and Malanje provinces. Government officials also said a UNITA attack on power lines Thursday cut electricity to the central port of Benguela for 36 hours. Rebels cut water and electricity in Luanda twice last month. UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi urged his forces to intensify attacks on economic targets around the country following the government offensive at Mavinga. Fighting has flared in recent weeks as government and rebel troops battle for control of the strategic airstrip and rebel base near Mavinga. The battle, said to be the heaviest in the 15-year conflict, has darkened hopes of getting government and rebel representatives back to the negotiating table. UNITA has been fighting to force the government to share power since shortly after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. The rebels want free elections, established by a transitional government, as a condition for peace. The government has offered terms based on an amnesty and integration of the rebels into Angolan society.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Uses Helicopter Gunships in Battle Against Traffickers
DOC.TEXT: Iranian security forces used helicopter gunships Saturday to battle drug smugglers in southwest Iran, killing an undisclosed number of them, Tehran radio reported Saturday. The smugglers were traveling in a caravan when they were ambushed by the security forces in Kerman province on Friday, said the report. It said all the dealers were killed, but gave no number or other details. The battle occurred during a weeklong, nationwide assault on the drug trade in which security forces killed 10 other drug smugglers, arrested 750 and rounded up 6,550 addicts, said the report, monitored in Nicosia. The broadcast said 6,300 pounds of drugs were seized in the crackdown, part of an anti-narcotics campaign launched in December 1988. The radio gave no details of the week's clashes. But the official media have frequently reported gunbattles between security forces and drugs gangs. A year-old, anti-narcotics law requires the death penalty for anyone caught with even small quantities of drugs with intent to sell. The state-run radio says more than 1,200 convicted drug smugglers have been hanged since the campaign was launched in response to a public outcry over Iran's mushrooming drug problem. More than 50,000 addicts have been sent to hard-labor camps or are in prison, according to official reports.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Driver Killed, Pinned Against Wall by Bus
With PM-Greyhound Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A striking Greyhound bus driver was killed today when he was pinned against a building by a bus driven by a temporary driver, who fled, police said. The driver and his bus were stopped on Interstate 5 at Bridge Bay north of Redding, said Officer Gary Hughes. The victim, whose name was not immediately released, was a 30-year veteran driver, said members of Local 1384 of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. The Council, which represents more than 9,000 employees, struck the nationwide bus company Friday over pay. The striking driver was pinned between the building and the bus, which was leaving the downtown bus terminal at 8:30 a.m., Hughes said. Union members said they tried several times to stop the bus after it hit the man, but it would not stop.

DOC.HEAD: One Reported Killed in Kashmir Violence
DOC.NOTE: EDS: One name cq for Gov. Jagmohan.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Kashmir-Moslems, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government rushed more troops to Kashmir valley Saturday to halt a Moslem rebellion, but curfew-defying protests continued and one person was killed by security forces, witnesses and officials said. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said paramilitary troops raided six hideouts used by militants demanding independence for the Moslem-dominated region. ``It was part of an ongoing process to break the back of the terrorists,'' said the officials, refusing to give details of the raids' outcome. State-run television said Gov. Jagmohan of Jammu-Kashmir dismissed 16 government employees for alleged involvement in ``militant and subversive activities.'' The television report did not give the employees' designations or identify their departments. Witnesses and airport sources said about 900 paramilitary police and border guards had arrived in Kashmir by aircraft and that hundreds of soldiers came by trucks Saturday. More were expected, they said. The security forces were sent to enforce an indefinite curfew clamped in Kashmir valley early Friday after at least 49 people were shot to death by army and paramilitary troops. The government, in keeping with regulations, refused to say how many troops and paramilitary police were deployed in the valley, but military sources put the number at around 25,000. Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state, is at the center of the Moslem secessionist movement. Witnesses said one person was killed in the city Saturday when troops opened fire on a group of people who defied curfew and came out of their homes. The witnesses spoke on condition of anonymity. A few other incidents of curfew violation were reported from other parts of the city, and militants and paramilitary troops exchanged fire downtown, the witnesses said. They said there were no casualties. The state government's information department has been closed since Friday. Its offices were locked Saturday and telephone calls went unanswered. Local journalists said the government asked reporters of non-Kashmiri newspapers and those of two national news agencies to leave Srinagar. ``They were advised that they could become the targets of the militants. Many have already left,'' a Kashmiri reporter said, speaking on condition of anonymity. At least 163 people have been killed in Kashmir since the latest round of violence flared Jan. 20 following a government crackdown on the escalating protests, bombings and attacks on state officials. The secessionist campaign has been alternately simmering and flaring for more than 40 years. Jammu-Kashmir was divided between India and Pakistan after the British colonial India was partitioned on gaining independence in 1947. Srinagar and the surrounding areas of the valley became part of Indian Kashmir. Sixty-four percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslems, but nationwide, Moslems make up just 12 percent of India's 880 million people. The militants had earlier campaigned for union with Pakistan, which claims Kashmir because of its predominant Moslem population. Now they demand independence and the status of a neutral country.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Nominee Holds Stock in Firm with South African Sales
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 new grafs bgng `International trade ... after 6th graf pvs to add context; pick up 7th graf pvs: `Dunne reported ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's nominee for the nation's top civil rights enforcement job holds nearly $20,000 worth of stock in a company that does business in white-ruled South Africa. Former New York state Sen. John R. Dunne has 400 shares of Schlumberger Ltd., with a market value of $19,650, according to the financial disclosure form he has submitted to the Senate Judiciary Committee. Schlumberger, a New York-based firm engaged in oil field services and oil products manufacturing, has direct investments in South Africa, according to Alison Cooper, a spokeswoman for Investor Responsibility Research Center, a Washington-based advocacy group that tracks such companies. Schlumberger's South African business accounted for less than 1 percent of its total sales of about $5 billion last year, said company spokesman Seth McCormick. Schlumberger has between 40 and 50 employees in that country, he said. Dunne, who faces a Senate confirmation hearing Wednesday, declined to comment on the South African investments and said he didn't know that Schlumberger did business in the white-ruled country. ``I don't really pay any attention to this,'' he said in a telephone interview Friday from New York. ``My brother handles my small account.'' International trade sanctions applied to South Africa to protest its apartheid policy of racial separation could cost that country's economy as much as $2 billion a year, according to Stephen R. Lewis Jr., president of Carlton College in Northfield, Minn., and author of ``The Economics of Apartheid.'' Fewer than 1 percent of all South Africans are employed by American companies. American companies doing business in South Africa currently number about 120, according to Steven Davis, a senior analyst at the Investor Responsibility Research Center. He said the total was down from a high of about 300 before the United States applied a bar on new investment and other sanctions in 1986. Dunne reported securities investments of $179,120 in a variety of companies, including Merrill Lynch & Co., Texas Instruments and several other technology firms. Cooper said none of the other companies did business in South Africa, although several have ``non-equity ties,'' meaning they have licensing, distribution or trade agreements in that country. Asked why he would not discuss his views on investing in South Africa, Dunne said: ``It seems to me it's the Senate's prerogative to have the first shot at me on these issues. It's not something I've discussed before and if they raise it, I will respond to their concerns.'' Meanwhile, civil rights groups have said little about Dunne's nomination as assistant attorney general for civil rights enforcement, although he has had little experience in that area. ``We're not opposing him,'' said Art Kropp, president of People for the American Way, a Washington liberal group. ``I think we agree the consensus is this is as good as we're going to get.'' ``He is, at bottom, a man without a record'' on civil rights, said Thomas B. Stoddard, executive director of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a gay rights advocacy group. ``It's hard to comment on nothing.'' The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People had no position on Dunne, according to spokesman Jim Williams. ``We're still looking at the record,'' he said. Civil rights groups protested vigorously against Bush's first choice for the job, William Lucas, a former Wayne County, Mich., sheriff who also had next to no civil rights experience. Lucas was opposed by the NAACP, People for the American Way, the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, among others. The Senate Judiciary Committee killed Lucas' nomination. Dunne, a Republican, spent 24 years in the New York Senate, where his major achievements included helping to rewrite state insurance laws and revamp the penal system after the deadly 1971 riot at Attica state prison. Dunne has voted for the Equal Rights Amendment and against busing to achieve school integration. He has supported the death penalty but also sponsored one of the first laws to protect the confidentiality of people who test positive for the AIDS virus. The New York Civil Liberties Union gave him low ratings every year for most of his career, including a zero in 1989. Dunne quit the Senate last year after losing the race for majority leader. Dunne also formerly belonged to clubs that did not allow women members but has since resigned.

DOC.HEAD: Public Interest Groups Woo Public Support for Campaign Finance Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Joan Claybrook is banking on the story of Charles Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan to persuade voters to demand changes in the way congressional elections are financed. Public Citizen, the organization Claybrook leads, is among a number of self-styled public interest groups pushing Congress to accept public financing of the campaigns, with spending limits and significant restrictions on political action committee donations. A new poll conducted for Public Citizen shows a clear majority of the public, 58 percent, supports the concept of public financing _ the highest level since just after the Watergate scandal. But the poll also found most voters know very little about the mechanics of public financing and are skeptical that any financing system would remove the influence of political action committees formed by special interests. That is where Claybrook hopes the story of Keating and the widespread problems in the savings and loan industry will help. The collapse of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan will cost taxpayers $2 billion. And Claybrook estimates that the $150 billion federal bailout of the S&L industry overall is costing each taxpayer about $1,000. The poll found overwhelming anger among voters who were told about five senators who intervened on Keating's behalf with federal regulators who were considering seizing Lincoln because of questionable lending and investments. Keating and associates previously had donated $600,000 to the campaigns of causes of the five senators. That anger, according to the pollsters, could provide Public Citizen and its allies with the opening they have always needed to persuade the public that the campaign financing system should be overhauled. ``The scandals surrounding the savings and loan industry, in particular, have created a political moment where voters are able to make the conceptual link between campaign money and their own interests and quality of representation,'' the analysis from the pollsters said. The pollsters cautioned, however, that while people are unhappy with the current campaign finance system and increasingly skeptical of Congress, they will be difficult to mobilize. ``The public, though increasingly unhappy with the current system, examines the issue through its larger political lenses, which do not focus easily on campaign finance as a political issue,'' the analysis said. Public Citizen and its allies have little time to redirect the focus. Congressional leaders have promised to bring campaign finance legislation to the floor this spring. But no bipartisan agreement is in sight and both Democrats and Republicans bickering among themselves. Lobbyists for Public Citizen, Common Cause and other groups are increasingly skeptical that their proposals will be enacted. The groups are hoping that a groundswell of public support will improve their chances, and the Public Citizen poll contained evidence to convince them that a well orchestrated campaign could attract supporters. Most encouraging to the groups was poll data showing that 58 percent of respondents favor the concept of public financing, the highest level of support since immediately after the Watergate scandal. Seventy-four percent said the congressional campaign system needs to be changed and 18 percent said ``the system is a mess and needs to be fundamentally reformed.'' Majorities supported several goals of the groups, including limits on political action committee contributions, overall campaign spending limits and a requirement that candidates raise most of their money in their home district or state. Also drawing wide support were proposals to provide each candidate with a fixed amount of television time and reduce mailing rates in return for promises of limited spending. ``The public is saying that it wants Congress back,'' said Claybrook. Yet the poll provided indications as well that there are tough obstacles to rallying the public behind campaign finance reform. The nationwide poll of 1,100 probable voters last month found campaign finance far from the top of the list of chief concerns. Just 5 percent ranked it first, ahead of other issues such as drugs and crime, the economy, taxes and the environment. The poll also found that support for public campaign financing _ the centerpiece of the changes sought by Public Citizen and its allies _ withered when voters were reminded their tax dollars could be used for negative ``attack ads'' or for support of extremist candidates. The public interest groups are adopting a number of strategies designed to convince voters that the faults of the current system should outweigh their reservations about public financing. Common Cause, long a critic of the use of money from political action committees, is getting personal, releasing detailed lists of every PAC donation accepted by incumbent members of Congress over the last decade. The U.S. Public Interest Research Group, a longtime advocate of clean air legislation, on Saturday released an analysis showing that PACs tied to companies and unions opposing the legislation have donated $27.4 million to Senate and House candidates in the past decade. For its part, Public Citizen is combining its lobbying of Congress with targeted field work, hoping to raise public awareness of the issue in the districts of lawmakers who are seen as impediments to reform. ``We've never failed to name names,'' said Claybrook. In the poll, 53 percent of respondents said they would vote for a challenger who supported public financing if the incumbent voted against it. The pollsters said that reaction was probably greatly overstated but it still shows ``voters are in an anti-political mood'' at least in part because they feel Congress is more responsive to financial backers than constituents.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING
Pressure Proved Ortega's Undoing, Officials Say
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Recasts 5th graf pvs bgng: `Secretary of ... deleting word `martyred'; pick up 6th graf: `For a decade ...
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega was a trapped man. He was under pressure not only from the United States but also Western Europe and even the Soviet Union. He was left with one course: Hold a free election. That, in the most succinct terms, is the way American officials described the plight in which Ortega found himself during the months leading up to last Sunday's history-making election in Nicaragua. For years Americans have been debating who lost China and who lost Cuba. Now there's a new question: Who won Nicaragua? The debate has already started. Was the administration smart, lucky or both? Did last Sunday's election vindicate or discredit President Reagan's policy of military support for the Nicaraguan Contras? Whatever the answers, seldom has any policy fallen into place quite so neatly as the administration's approach to Nicaragua. Secretary of State James A. Baker III felt a strong sense of vindication last Monday when former President Jimmy Carter, in Nicaragua as an election observer, telephoned him at 4:15 a.m. with the surprise news: Violeta Chamorro had won in a landslide. For a decade, Nicaragua seemed like just another intractable Third World dispute. It was one of those ``low intensity conflicts'' which appeared to be beyond resolution, much like Afghanistan, Angola and Cambodia. When the Bush administration took office last January, it was intent on shelving the previous policy of military support for the Contra rebels. But what other options were there for taming the Sandinistas? Less than a month after taking office, the admininistration saw an opening when Ortega promised his Central American colleagues that honest elections would be held in February 1990. The reaction among many conservatives here was deep skepticism that Ortega would keep his word. But the administration decided to cooperate with the process, switching its support from the externally-based Contras to the internal opposition to Ortega in Nicaragua. The administration also struck deal with the Congress that, in effect, ended a decade of internal warfare here over Nicaragua. The deal, while ending military aid for the Contras, enabled them to survive, through U.S. food donations, as a potential future threat to the Sandinistas. Until elections were held, Washington would withhold normal relations with the Sandinistas. As a show of support for democracy, the administration publicly discouraged the rebels from engaging in armed attacks and urged the Contra leadership to return home in peace. The U.S. Embassy in Managua quietly counseled Mrs. Chamorro's coalition to guard against splintering at all costs. Congress approved $9 million last fall to help Mrs. Chamorro's campaign and to promote non-partisan activities such as poll watching and voter registration. The United States and the Central Americans were not the only ones pressuring Ortega. He went to an aid donors conference in Sweden last April hoping to raise $250 million for Nicaragua's devastated economy and reportedly came away with only $20 million. The Europeans agreed with the United States that aid should be withheld until after a free election. As outlined by U.S. officials, the Soviet Union, the Sandinistas' chief military backer, also played a constructive role. As an example, under Soviet pressure, the Sandinistas promised opposition candidates last summer they would be allowed to campaign freely. Three weeks ago, a Soviet-American statement pledged mutual respect for the results of free and fair elections in Nicaragua. ``All of these elements combined,'' a senior administration official said last week, ``helped create an environment in which free and fair elections were the only opportunity for the Sandinista government to normalize relations with the rest of Latin America and with the United States and to obtain legitimacy and economic aid.'' But how would Nicaraguans vote? Most of the pre-election signs pointed to an Ortega landslide and Ortega himself thought he was a shoo-in. A Sandinista victory was suggested by public opinion polls in Nicaragua. Most of the 55 State Department officials who took part in a $2 office pool predicted a Sandinista victory. But the handful of officials who deal with Nicaragua daily, sensing the polls were unreliable, all predicted a Chamorro victory. Indeed, the Nicaragua desk officer, Craig Kelly, foresaw a 55 per cent to 41 per cent win for Chamorro, her precise margin of victory.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Delegate Fauntroy Running for D.C. Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Walter Fauntroy announced Saturday he will run for mayor of the nation's capital, saying he hoped to ``heal the hurt'' left by incumbent Marion Barry's indictment on drug and perjury charges. Fauntroy, the city's non-voting delegate to Congress since 1971, said he reached his decision to seek the Democratic nomination ``after weeks of painful and tearful consideration.'' ``I just might be able to attract and unleash the unprecedented partnership of talented people required to heal the hurt and end the polarization in our city,'' Fauntroy told a prayer breakfast. Fauntroy, 57, was an aide to civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. in the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in the 1960s. He is an ordained Baptist minister. In Congress, he has pushed statehood for the District of Columbia and is the No.2 Democrat on the House Banking Committee. As a delegate, he cannot vote on the floor but may vote in committee. Fauntroy joins a crowded field in the Democratic primary, where the political picture was turned into turmoil by Barry's drug arrest. Victory in the Democratic primary has long been tantamount to election in Washington. Barry, who is being treated for substance abuse at a South Carolina hospital, has not announced his political plans. But a recent Washington Post poll show the mayor would still lead a field of the other candidates. Barry was arrested Jan. 18 on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge. He was indicted last month on cocaine possession and perjury charges in connection with an investigation into his ties to a convicted drug dealer. The Justice Department has been investigating allegations that Fauntroy had a ``no-show'' employee on his payroll. Fauntroy's advisers told potential supporters last week that the Justice Department probe has been scuttled. But a law enforcement source, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said the probe has not been abandoned.
