DOC.HEAD: Furor Erupts Over Record-Labeling Bill
DOC.TEXT: Warning: this story may contain explicit descriptions of legislation designed to brand recordings with sexually graphic or violent lyrics. Pennsylvania's record-labeling bill, pending in the state Senate, has whipped up a coast-to-coast controversy pitting fearful parents and conservatives against panicky record producers, retailers and musicians. Supporters of the bill, citing tunes such as ``Me So Horny'' and ``Necrophiliac,'' say they are determined to save children from ruining their lives by monitoring their buying and listening habits. They cite cases of teen-agers who they say have committed murder or suicide before, during or after listening to objectionable songs. Opponents charge the measure would be an invasion of their constitutional rights. They say the labels would be unnecessary and would inhibit creativity. State Rep. Ron Gamble, the measure's sponsor, has touted it on ``Entertainment Tonight,'' National Public Radio's ``Morning Edition'' and in newspapers nationwide. ``I didn't dream there would be such interest in the bill, it wasn't like I had a big news conference. I just introduced it and that was it,'' he said. ``But it seems to have caught on ... we've had calls from California to Florida to Detroit.'' Under the measure, which has passed the state House and is now pending in the Senate, every record, tape or compact disc sold in Pennsylvania containing obscene lyrics would have to bear a fluorescent warning label. About a dozen states are considering similar bills. The label would say: ``Warning: may contain explicit lyrics descriptive of or advocating one or more of the following: suicide, sodomy, incest, bestiality, sadomasochism, adultery, sexual activity in a violent context, murder, morbid violence or use of illegal drugs or alcohol.'' ``It's a truth in labeling bill, just like when you buy a can of vegetables, they tell you everything that's in there. With cigarettes, too, there are labels that tell you what the ramifications are,'' said Peg Luksik, president of Pennsylvania Parents Commission, one of the groups lobbying for the measure. She said the group has 15,000 to 20,000 members. A voluntary agreement to label records has not worked and it's up to the government to act, said Michael Geer, president of the Pennsylvania Family Institute. Representatives of the recording industry, retailers, merchandisers and civil rights groups have vowed to fight the measure all the way to the courts. ``While I understand the concerns of the supporters of this amendment, legislation is not the answer,'' said a letter to senators from Jason S. Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America Inc. ``As a father of three teen-age daughters, I believe I, not record-store owners or government, should be the judge of what is suitable music for the home. If I am not concerned with my children's well-being, no label will make a difference.'' Tanya Blackwood of the association said the burden of the law will fall on record-store owners. ``It will make the retailer double-check everything that comes in the store and will force him to err on the conservative side rather than take a chance,'' Ms. Blackwood said. ``Retail stores will stop carrying products.'' Frank Adams of Specialty Records Corp. in Olyphant, said the measure would wreak havoc on his business, possibly leading to layoffs among his 2,000 employees. Specialty makes records, tapes and compact discs for several record labels. ``It could force some of the labels to have their products made somewhere else,'' Adams said. Stephen MacNett, aide to Senate Republicans, said the bill was put aside for recent automobile-insurance reform debate. ``There's no plans to put it on the schedule immediately,'' MacNett said. As to its chance for passage, MacNett said, ``I wouldn't rule it out.'' Vincent Carocci, spokesman for Gov. Robert P. Casey, said the governor is aware of the bill, but would not take a position until it crosses his desk.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Newspaper Suggests Prisoner Swap
DOC.TEXT: Two Americans jailed in Iran for several years could be freed if Washington agreed to release three American Moslems imprisoned in the United States, a Tehran newspaper suggested Saturday. The English-language daily Kayhan International said the release could come after the release of Western hostages held in Lebanon as a step toward ``improved ties'' between Washington and Tehran in the ``post-hostage era.'' The newspaper's mention of a ``post-hostage'' era was the latest in a series of recent indications from Iran and allied Shiite Moslem militants in Lebanon that Western captives held in Lebanon could be released. There are 18 Westerners missing in Lebanon, most of whom are believed held by pro-Iranian factions. They are eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held hostage. He was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Iranian officials and newspapers, as well as a Shiite leader in Lebanon, have over the past two weeks made statements urging the hostages be released. But, despite the optimism this has raised in some quarters that a release is possible, the hostages appear to be caught in the cross fire between Iran's so-called pragmatists led by President Hashemi Rafsanjani and hard-line, anti-Western radicals led by former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi. This is mirrored in the Shiite fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, which is believed to be the parent group for the hostage-holding factions. Hezbollah's political wing supports Rafsanjani, who is seeking to improve ties with the West. But the militants holding the captives are aligned with Mohtashemi. Nonetheless, Kayhan International's comments underlined that Tehran may be seeking new openings for dialogue with the West, particularly the United States. The newspaper said the two American prisoners, David Erwin Rabham and Jon Pattis, could be released if Washington freed Dhoruba-al-Mujahid, Elmer Pratt and Khalifa Hammas Abdul Khalis, whom it identified as ``political prisoners'' in the United States. The newspaper suggested that the Rev. Jesse Jackson or former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark could act as mediators in the release. In Washington, a State Department spokeswoman, Nancy Beck, said: ``We have no comment on that other than our general policy, which is that all of the hostages should be freed unconditionally.'' Pattis, a 53-year-old engineer, was arrested in June 1986 after being accused of passing Iranian military secrets to the Central Intelligence Agency for use by Iraqi bombers in the Iran-Iraq war. The daily referred to him as ``a self-confessed CIA operative'' who entered Iran on an Italian passport to work on a telecommunications project. It said Rabham, a businessman who has been jailed in Iran for about 10 years, was ``behind bars essentially because of an indiscretion by former President Jimmy Carter.'' It said Rabham's crime was that after Iranian militants stormed the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in November 1979 and held 52 Americans hostage, then-President Carter ``had a direct telephone conversation with his boyhood friend which has so far cost Erwin a decade of his life.'' No other details of Rabham's jailing were given. The militants held the 52 Americans hostage for 444 days. Kayhan International said Mujahid and Pratt were serving a combined jail sentence of 40 years. Pratt, the one-time ``defense minister'' of the Black Panthers, is serving a life term for a 1972 murder conviction. Khalis was the leader of the Hanafi Muslim group that in 1977 took over three Washington buildings, including city hall, and held several hundred people hostage for several days before surrendering. A reporter was killed by a shotgun blast fired by one of the Hanafis and then-City Councilman Marion Barry was wounded by gunfire. The Iranian newspaper called the shooting death accidental and said the takeover was a demonstration against American justice.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Future: Opponents and Backers Don't Give an Inch
LaserPhoto CR1
DOC.TEXT: For friends and foes of the newly licensed Seabrook nuclear power plant, visions of the future are as different as the twin reactors on the site _ one licensed and ready, the other rusty and unfinished. Seabrook operators and nuclear industry proponents see the completed reactor, poised to generate electricity for up to 1 million New Englanders. Opponents see the corroded containment dome of Seabrook's second unit as a beacon of their fight and the nation's anti-nuclear movement. By the time the Nuclear Regulatory Commission granted Seabrook's operating license on Thursday, the twin-reactor plant proposed in 1972 with a pricetag of less than $1 billion had evolved into a $6.5 billion single reactor and pushed its lead owner, Public Service Company of New Hampshire, into bankruptcy. Critics have promised to appeal the NRC decision. Once the appeal is filed, the U.S Court of Appeals in Washington would decide whether the reactor can operate while the legal fight continues. The focus of the court battle will be the federally required emergency response plans for 17 New Hampshire and six Massachusetts communities within 10 miles of the reactor. Seabrook is two miles from the Massachusett line. Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis became Seabrook's most prominent antagonist in 1986 when he refused to submit emergency response plans for the six Massachusetts communities, saying safe evacuation was impossible. The NRC subsequently accepted evacuation plans drafted by Seabrook's operators. ``It's correct to say there has never been a case where the court has overturned an NRC license. But it's also correct to say that there has never been a license issued which has been so legally vulnerable,'' said Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon, who plans to file an appeal along with anti-Seabrook groups in New Hampshire and Massachusetts. Two appeals already were pending in Washington even before the full commission approved the licensing. Arguments have been set for April on appeal of the NRC's decision to grant Seabrook a low-power license last May. And the NRC licensing board's Nov. 9 decision to authorize a full-power license also was appealed. While plant foes look to the courts, Seabrook operators are trying to move beyond history. In an interview Friday, Edward Brown, president of Seabrook's operator, New Hampshire Yankee, was weary of debating the merits of the evacuation plans. Brown instead said he would seek to mend fences with neighbors, including some New Hampshire communities, that had opposed the plant. ``We have and will continue to try to get them to work with us,'' he said. ``It's a matter of taking a conciliatory approach, not of ignoring the issue.'' Brown said he anticipated cooperation even from Massachusetts once the plant was operating. Also dominating Brown's future is the actual start-up. He said he expects glitches and shutdowns as the reactor embarks on its two- to three-month process that will bring the plant to 100 percent power. ``We can expect during the full-power ascension _ unless it goes absolutely flawlessly, which would be unusual _ there are times when we will take the unit off line to do some adjustments,'' he said. A court victory for plant opponents is not in his vision of the future. They've tried it before, Brown said, and failed.

DOC.HEAD: Transition Talks Going Surprisingly Smoothly
DOC.TEXT: As the surprise fades away over the United National Opposition's election victory, the tough work begins: how the Sandinista Front will turn over the reins of government to its successors. So far, the transition talks have been incredibly smooth. ``It's all going peacefully, very peacefully,'' President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro told The Associated Press. Transition talks started Wednesday, just two days after President Daniel Ortega conceded defeat in a moving speech. Both sides lost no time in naming transition teams: Mrs. Chamorro chose her son-in-law and campaign manager, Antonio Lacayo, to head the efforts of the 14-party UNO coalition. Ortega chose his brother and Defense Minister, Gen. Humberto Ortega. After a campaign that saw the worst in the political tradition of mud-slinging and outright threats, experienced observers are amazed at both sides' conciliatory attitude. ``They're moving around each other very, very carefully,'' an international observer said. ``We're doing our best to nurture that attitude.'' The promoters and caretakers of this new cooperative attitude have been dubbed the ``Holy Trinity.'' One of the three, Elliot Richardson, former U.S. attorney general and special representative of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, even wrote President Ortega a fan letter. ``Your attitude today constitutes an act of true leadership,'' Richardson wrote of Ortega's speech. ``You can count, Mr. President, with my sincere admiration and respect.'' La Prensa, Mrs. Chamorro's family daily and for the 10{ years of Sandinista rule Nicaragua's only opposition newspaper, has been emphasizing cooperation and reconciliation of this war-torn nation. It repeatedly calls Mrs. Chamorro a ``president of ALL Nicaraguans.'' On its front page Friday, La Prensa ran a story with UNO denouncing Sandinista distribution of weapons to supporters and another story with the U.S.-supported Contra rebels saying Sandinista soldiers are deserting. But this time the newspaper also ran a story with a Sandinista People's Army spokeswoman denying both reports. Before, it would have derided any official denial of disruptions in the army. ``Some of my friends are hard-line Sandinistas and I've seen their faces: they're stunned,'' an UNO strategist said. ``But my attitude is not to gloat in front of them. We have to treat them delicately.'' Indeed, the little that the press has been allowed to know of the transition talks has indicated a show of restraint and delicacy on both parts. As the talks progress, UNO leaders have issued measured, sober statements whose obvious intention is to calm the waters. ``We are going to guarantee the orderly, peaceful and democratic transmission of the supreme command of the republic, as corresponds to the sacred interests of Nicaragua and the desires of the Nicaraguan people,'' Lacayo said. Calming the waters is something very much needed, as the Sandinistas nurse the wounds of defeat and deal with the alarming thought that some of their dearest ``achievements of the revolution'' might be reversed. After his speech Monday, President Ortega met with more than 1,000 top Sandinista cadres, and delivered a fiery address to 15,000 angry and fearful supporters waiting outside a convention hall. ``The day will come when we will govern from above again because the Sandinista National Liberation Front will stay with the people, governing from below,'' he said. The words pointed to a Sandinista commitment to play the political game. Except for a subsequent statement by Mrs. Chamorro (``I'm the one who's going to give the orders''), there's been no balking by UNO so far about the positions Ortega outlined for a peaceful transition of power. Mutual accommodation seems to be the attitude of both parties. Just hours after Ortega demanded the dismantling of the U.S.-supported Contra rebels, Mrs. Chamorro urged the guerrillas to come home and rejoin civilian life to help reconstruct Nicaragua. President Bush issued a similar call to the rebels, who are in Honduran jungle camps. And the Honduran president sent a special representative to Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro to work out plans for the rebels' decommissioning. Now it only remains to persuade the rebels to return before Mrs. Chamorro is inaugurated April 25. Addressing another Sandinista demand, UNO leaders said they will name a civilian defense minister, but Gen. Ortega will remain in command of the army. UNO will set up a special tribunal to hear claims from people whose property was confiscated by the Sandinistas. But peasants who benefitted from the Sandinistas' agrarian reform _ some 100,000 families _ will keep their property and will even be given ownership titles to replace the Sandinista land-use certificates. Property confiscated from dictator Anastasio Somoza will remain so. The banking system will remain nationalized, UNO leaders have said, allaying Sandinista fears. But true to its pro-capitalistic policies, UNO also plans to allow private banks. For their part, the Sandinistas have allowed young soldiers to desert. That move is geared both to weeding the armed forces of non-Sandinista members and easing the shift to the time when Mrs. Chamorro, as she has promised, bans the mandatory two-year draft for boys age 16. The transition talks have been at the local offices of the Carter Center. Former President Jimmy Carter, considered the ``father'' of the ``Holy Trinity,'' has taken the commanding lead in drawing UNO and Sandinistas to the bargaining table to talk and reason together. Joao Baena Soares, the secretary-general of the Organization of American States is the third component in the triad. The short two months remaining until the new administration starts will be a time of great change and of promise to Nicaragua's future. If all goes well, it will be the first time in Nicaragua's history that one government hands over power peacefully to another, a remarkable achievement.

DOC.HEAD: 150,000 Demonstrate For Freedom; Union Says 10,000 Miners on Strike
DOC.TEXT: About 150,000 people shouting ``Victory,'' ``Democracy'' and ``Down with the Communist Party'' demonstrated for political reform outside a downtown cathedral Saturday. The rally, in support of Bulgaria's increasingly popular opposition, was held on the anniversary of a March 3, 1878, Russian-Turkish treaty, which ended nearly 500 years of Ottoman Turkish rule of Bulgaria. The demonstration came one day after 15,000 students marched through Sofia in protest of communist rule. The Communists in Bulgaria, unlike those in other Soviet bloc countries, have retained much of their clout in national politics, and their moves toward democracy have been hesitant and somewhat half-hearted. Meanwhile, Konstantin Trenchev, leader of the independent trade union Podkrepa, said 10,000 miners went on strike Friday to protest non-fulfillment of government pledges. Trenchev said his union has a membership of about 150,000 and plans selected solidarity strikes nationwide. The opposition Union of Democratic Forces, or UDF, organized Saturday's rally before the Alexander Nevski Cathedral and demonstrations planned for the next few days to increase pressure on the Communists to relinquish power. Talks on Bulgaria's future between the Communist Party and the opposition broke down on Feb. 12 after the Communists refused to sign an agreement on key political changes. Bulgarian Television covered the opposition rally and showed official events to mark the national day, including an early morning church ceremony attended by Premier Andrei Lukanov. Most speakers at the demonstration compared the 500 years of Ottoman Turkish oppression with the lack of freedom and democracy under 45 years of Communist rule. ``It is a pity that the democratic evolution of the Bulgarian people was halted by force 45 years ago,'' UDF chairman, Zhelyu Zhelev, told the packed square.``In Bulgaria, like in other East European countries, there began the establishment of a totalitarian society following the example of the Soviet society, called socialism.'' ``The result you can see for yourself: All the countries that followed this road find themselves today in a very deep economic, political and even demographic crisis,'' Zhelev said. ``The Communist Party proposes a new democratic socialism, but where is it? Can you see it?'' he asked. Then answering his rhetorical question, he said: ``Enough of experiments, leave us alone.'' Zhelev said: ``democracy is an ideal, and in the name of this ideal the UDF wages its battle for the future of our fatherland.'' He reiterated the opposition would agree to a government proposal that elections be held in June _ instead of November as the opposition earlier demanded _ only if certain conditions were met. He said the election should choose a provisional parliament, which would write a democratic constitution and enact electoral law for free multiparty balloting at the end of this year. Trenchev announced the miners went on strike because they felt betrayed by the government, which he said twice promised higher pay and better working conditions but did not fulfill key provisions of written agreements. Trenchev also explained the UDF position on the talks. ``We want to see the Communist Party become separated from the state; we want to dissolve this symbiosis,'' he said. The opposition has said it won't return to negotiations on the country's future if the Communists balk at political reform.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Defendant Denies Securitate Shot at Protesters in Timisoara
DOC.TEXT: The chief defendent at the trial of 21 former secret police officers denied Saturday that officers under his command fired on protesters in the early days of the December revolution. Maj. Gen. Emil Macri also alleged that members of the current government came to Timisoara to try to suppress the revolt before it spread across the country. Macri and six others are accused of ``committing genocide'' and face life imprisonment if convicted. The 14 remaining defendants could be jailed for up to 20 years if convicted on lesser charges of ``assisting genocide.'' The revolt against the Communist regime of Nicolae Ceausescu began Dec. 16 in Timisoara, where its violent suppression by security forces sparked nationwide reaction that eventually spread across the country. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were tried and executed Dec. 25 on charges they were responsible for the deaths of thousands of Romanians during their harsh rule. Macri was the first to testify in the Timisoara trial. While he spoke, the other 20 defendants were ordered to stay out of the courtroom. Macri repeatedly denied he ordered security forces to fire upon unarmed demonstrators, claiming the Securitate secret police force was not even issued arms in the first days of the uprising. ``I was sent to Timisoara on Dec. 17, by (former Securitate chief) Gen. Iulian Vlad, exclusively to find out whether there were any foreign spies inciting the people to rise up against the regime,'' Macri said. He at times drew exclamations of disbelief from the courtroom. Macri described as a ``typing error'' his reported admission in pre-trial questioning that the Securitate shot at the people in Timisoara, adding his forces ``never went out in the street under arms.'' In addition, Macri said Col. Gen. Victor Stanculescu, who last month was appointed Defense Minister, was sent to Timisoara on Dec. 17, to assist Ion Coman, a former Politburo member responsible for the army and police. Coman had been sent to the city to quash the revolt and is to be tried in Bucharest. Macri said the Interior Minister in the provisional government, Gen. Mihai Chitak, was also sent to Timisoara, as was Stefan Guse, the former chief of staff credited with bringing the military to the side of the revolutionaries. Macri said on Dec. 18, he overheard Chitak tell Coman, ``The boys have done their job well last night.'' He also said an unidentified senior Securitate official in Timisoara had told him they could ``sleep quietly tonight because Guse is here.''' He said the officers remained in Timisoara until Dec. 22 _ the day Ceausescu fled the capital _ and then returned to Bucharest.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Aren't Seeking Dukakis Endorsement
DOC.TEXT: Ask Democratic campaign aides if they are seeking Gov. Michael S. Dukakis' endorsement for their candidates this year and their first reaction is to laugh, or mumble something unintelligible, or to give a ``no comment.'' Their reaction suggests just how far the governor has fallen since he ran for president in 1988. During the campaign, when Dukakis appeared to have a good chance of reaching the White House, state Democrats were all too happy to have their name associated with the governor. Now, with the state's worsening budget problems, Democrats running for statewide office are wary of appearing too closely associated with him. Even Dukakis has quipped that the best favor he he could do for one Democratic candidate for state treasurer, House Speaker George Keverian, is to endorse the Republican opponent, Joe Malone. The governor doesn't plan to endorse any Democratic candidate in the primary, according to his press secretary, Mindy Lubber. ``Obviously, post primary, he will be far more active in the race,'' Lubber said. ``For the harmony of the Democratic party, his position has always been he's going to stay out of a primary fight.'' There was a time Democrats would have lined up to court Dukakis. ``The level of positive support at the height of the Dukakis administration was remarkable, and the fall has been about as dramatic as one can imagine,'' said Paul Watanabe, who heads the political science department at the University of Massachusetts in Boston. This year even Democrats with a long history in state politics are calling themselves ``outsiders.'' An endorsement by Dukakis might not be the kiss of death, but it would probably do a candidate more harm than good, Watanabe said. He doubts any endorsements will be forthcoming. ``My guess is he would not endorse anyone without first consulting them, and my guess is that the advice being given at the campaigns at this point is to forgo an endorsement,'' Watanabe said. State Senator Richard Kraus, a candidate for state treasurer, laughed when asked if he was seeking the governor's endorsement this year. Then, in a diplomatic vein, said: ``It had not crossed my mind to ask for it.'' Kraus finally said an endorsement from the governor would injure his election bid. ``At first blush, I would have to say that it would probably hurt. The negatives are so high right now,'' he said. Former Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti, one of the leading Democratic contenders for governor, ``does not really place any value on an endorsement at that level,'' said Ernie Corrigan, his campaign spokesman. ``It's just not something Frank Bellotti has even thought about,'' Corrigan said. Mark Longabaugh, the campaign manager for Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, sounded more enthusiastic about an endorsement than officials from other campaigns. ``We want everybody's endorsement,'' he said. John Silber's campaign spokeswoman, Michael Regunberg, said ``Uh ... uh ... I don't think we'll comment one way or another.'' And Rep. John Flood, a Democrat from Canton who was an outspoken critic of the governor even during the presidential campaign, said he would use an endorsement of any of his party rivals against them. ``Obviously, it would be used by the campaign as a negative,'' he said. Flood acknowledged, however, he feels some sympathy for the governor. ``It's to the point where it's sad,'' he said. ``Except for the fact that he is the CEO in directing the state for the next few months, I'd show some sympathy for him.''

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Kidnap Mayors, Others
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas on Saturday held 20 people captive, including mayors and other public officials, in an apparent attempt to disrupt next week's national elections. The guerrillas also threatened to kill Colombia's most important Cabinet minister because he accused the rebels of killing a leftist mayor last week, a charge they denied. In the past three days, national police said, the National Liberation Army has kidnapped four mayors, three state assemblymen, one city councilman, three local party leaders, one reporter, four employees of rural government programs and four ranchers and businessmen. All of the kidnappings were in northeastern Colombia. The mayors are from the towns of California, Tibu, El Carmen and Hacari. The National Liberation Army, an insurgent group led by a former priest, has joined with other guerrilla groups in proposing a halt to hostilities through the elections, according to the radio network Caracol. The report could not be verified, and the government did not respond to the communiques. Colombians elect mayors and congressmen on March 11. The threatened Cabinet official is Carlos Lemos, the minister of government. Lemos is in charge of internal security in Colombia and stands in for President Virgilio Barco when Barco is out of the country. Baro is in Argentina on a state visit. The National Liberation Army denied killing the mayor and made the threat against Lemos in a communique sent Friday to the country's leftist party, the Patriotic Union. The slain mayor, Diana Cardona, of the northwestern town of Apartado, was a member of the Patriotic Union. She was assassinated Monday. Lemos said it appeared that the National Liberation Army had killed her, but he did not explain why leftist guerrillas would murder a leftist mayor. Apartado, in the heart of Colombia's banana growing region, has been the focal point of an intense struggle between right-wing death squads and leftist guerrillas over the past two years. The Patriotic Union Party's ranks have been devastated by right-wing death squads despite the government's promises to find the killers. Since the party was organized five years ago, 827 of its members have been murdered, 72 of them this year.

DOC.HEAD: President, Cardinal Join at Mass for National Reconcilitation
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega attended a Mass of reconciliation Saturday and joined the nation's top Roman Catholic leader in appealing for peace as the Sandinista party transfers power to a new opposition government. ``I thought it was very important to send a message in favor of peace because I think the situation is very tense,'' Ortega said after the Mass. Ortega and his Sandinista National Liberation Front lost last Sunday's presidential elections to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the United National Opposition. In a speech that has won him admiration and respect from friends and foes alike, Ortega accepted defeat and pledged to help carry out a smooth transition of power. His attendance at the Mass was another part of his effort to set an example in an effort to cool passions. Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo praised Ortega for gracefully accepting defeat in the election, calling it ``a gesture in favor of democracy and freedom ... a gesture of greatness.'' ``We are here to pray for peace,'' said Obando y Bravo, who hails from Ortega's hometown of La Libertad. ``We cannot have peace if there is hatred in the heart. Only from a heart at peace can come a desire for peace,'' he said. Many in the rank and file of the Sandinista party fear that their revolutionary social measures may be undone by the new government. There is also some concern among members of the ruling party over the future role of the Sandinista army and the Interior Ministry security forces, which are closely tied to the party. There have been public marches by Sandinista supporters urging that the party keep control of the army and the Interior Ministry, including one through a southern Managua suburb Friday night in which protesters burned tires in the streets. Transition talks are focusing on control of the army and the ministry's security forces, which the Sandinistas don't want to reduce until the U.S.-backed Contra rebels disband. ``Those are institutions created to defend the national sovereignty and the lives of the people. They must be preserved,'' Ortega said of the army and the Interior Ministry after Mass. In answer to a question, he said the Sandinistas were willing to work with the new government supporting ``everything that is in favor of the popular classes, but rejecting everything that is not in the national interest.'' The army, security forces and militias, which defeated the Contras militarily, have nearly 150,000 men in arms. The new government wants to reduce its size drastically. Ortega, and his wife, Rosario, both wearing blue jeans, came to the small La Sierrita Church accompanied by their eight children, including 1-year old Luciana, whom they adopted recently. ``We are here to show the president he is not alone,'' said Sergio Pilarte who, like many in the crowd, wore the red-and-black bandanna of the Sandinista party and had come to Mass with his wife and children.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Japan Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the statement President Bush made Saturday upon the departure of Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu following two days of talks. Well I was very pleased to welcome my friend, the prime minister of Japan, here to Palm Springs for two days of very useful and far-reaching discussions about the critically important relationship between the United States and Japan. In the first instance, I wanted to see Prime Minister Kaifu again and extend personally my congratulations for his victory in the recent elections. I also want to express my very high regard and admiration for the outstanding leadership he has given his country and his party since he was propelled into office just six months ago. We first met last September, and in the intervening months we've seen some of the most momentous changes in recent world history. It is important that the leaders of the United States and Japan come together and review the entire scope of their relationship at this time of profound change in the world. There are three things that are very clear to me: That our relationship with Japan will become even more important to us and to the world in the coming decades; that Japan is moving rapidly to assume a leading role in the world, as was evident in Prime Minister Kaifu's recent trip to Eastern Europe, and the nearly $2 billion in assistance that he pledged to the nations of Poland and Hungary; and that no matter where we look around the world _ from Eastern Europe to Panama to Cambodia _ the United States and Japan are working together to promote political and economic transformations that will strengthen democracies and market economies. Our meetings these two days were not formal negotiations. This has been an opportunity to come together and take stock of the entire range of our dealings, from security to economics and trade, to foreign policy, and to talk about where we're going together as we move toward the 21st century. We talked about how we can expand even further our global partnership. I believe that in the coming years we have a unique and challenging opportunity to expand even further our cooperation on international issues across the board; to strengthen the political trialogue among the United States, Japan, and our European allies; to expand our aid cooperation to embrace a larger effort aimed at prmoting economic and social development in the third world; and to think about how Japan can more fully play a leading role in the world's political and economic institutions. We talked about developments of recent months in Europe, and then U.S.-Soviet relationships, and I believe that we're agreed that our two countries must work closely together to promote the same kind of positive change in Asia. I reaffirmed to Prime Minister Kaifu, as did Secretary of Defense Cheney during that successful visit of his to Tokyo, that the United States is and will remain a Pacific power, that the United States attaches great importance, the greatest importance, to its security and political alliance with Japan, and that our two countries must continue to strengthen our defense cooperation. At a time of great change in the world, our treaty of mutual cooperation and security has become even more important to ensuring continued peace and prosperity as democracy and free markets spread across Asia and the Pacific. We also discussed our economic relationship, one of the most broad ranging and complex set of commercial and financial interactions in the entire world. And there are many areas of _ economic areas in which we have close cooperation. Think of the Third-World debt problems, economic policy coordination collaborated there. And we reaffirm our commitment to that process, including cooperation in exchange markets. We must also remember that Japan is the second largest market in the world for our manufacturers, and the largest market in the world for our farmers. Our exports to Japan already total $44 billion, only Canada buys more from us, and our exports to Japan are going up faster than our sales to the rest of the world. The Prime Minister and his government are very aware of the mood and concern in this country about the continuing impediments to further growth of our trade relationship. Even with that 18 percent growth in our exports to Japan last year, we still have a _ a $49 billion bilateral trade deficit. And make no mistake about it, I want to see that deficit come down, not by restricting our markets or managing trade, but by further increasing our exports to Japan. And so in the coming months, our common task must be to further open markets and expand trade. In addition to increasing our exports to Japan, our other key task is to ensure the success of the Structural Impediments Initiative that we launched last summer. We're facing some important deadlines and the Prime Minister and I are calling on our officials to redouble their efforts to achieve meaningful interim and final results. We must make the SII, the Strategic Impediments Initiative, and our other trade discussions a success. We must put our economic relationship on a solid foundation, if we're to achieve the full promise of our relationship. We feel that we've presented some valid ideas about removing structural impediments in Japan that will improve market access and reduce our trade imbalances and we look forward to the Japanese response. But let's face it, these talks are a two-way street. We Americans must increase our savings, reduce our budget deficit, provide more incentive for our investors, strengthen our educational system, focus on producing goods of the highest quality. So our task is to make the American economy even stronger and even more competitive and that is a task for America, not for Japan. So, Mr. Prime Minister, I am delighted we had this opportunity to discuss all these matters. I am confident that during our time here together, we have launched a process that will continue throughout 1990 and the coming years, a process that will create a breakthrough relationship and lead to an era of even greater cooperation between our two countries. Together, we must master our problems and expand our opportunities. By working together in partnership, the United States and Japan have the chance to lead, not only our two peoples, but the whole world, into a new era of peace, freedom, and prosperity. So, Mr. Prime Minister, Toshiki, my friend, thank you for coming, and I wish you a safe journey home. And may you have great success in your efforts in the coming months. You have our full support.
DOC.HEAD: End of text
Soldiers Clash With Demonstrators, Deaths Reported
DOC.TEXT: Security forces clashed Saturday with activists claiming election fraud in the Asian republic of Uzbekistan, and some demonstrators were killed, local activists and official sources said. One activist said up to 30 people died, but an official said fewer than 10 were killed. Abdurashid Sharif, a spokesman for the Uzbekistan grass-roots organization Berlik, said internal security soldiers opened fire on a crowd of up to 3,000 peaceful demonstrators in the city of Parkent, about 30 miles from the regional capital of Tashkent. He said an angry crowd then stormed the local police headquarters and set it on fire. It also broke the windows of the regional Communist Party headquarters, Sharif said. Speaking in a telephone interview from Tashkent, he said the activists were protesting alleged fraud in Feb. 18 elections and demanding the resignations of elected officials. Sergei V. Kharitonov, a spokesman for the Soviet Interior Ministry in Moscow, confirmed there was a clash in Parkent, a city of about 200,000 people. Sharif, who visited Parkent with other Berlik officials, quoted local doctors as saying up to 30 people were killed by gunfire by soldiers and police. But Kharitonov said in a telephone interview that both Sharif's figure and an estimate of 10 dead given by another Parkent resident were too high. Kharitonov said he could not give a figure. He said there was no curfew in Parkent and Interior Ministry soldiers were withdrawn following the afternoon clash. The city was reported calm late Saturday. Moslem Central Asia is the latest region of the Soviet Union to suffer ethnic violence as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev loosens decades of tight Kremlin control. Last month, 22 people were killed in rioting in Dushanbe, the capital of neighboring Tadzhikistan republic. In addition, tensions remain high in the Caucasus republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan to the west, where hundreds have been killed in the past two years. Sharif said the initial gathering in Parkent developed spontaneously without being called by Berlik or any other group. He charged that Interior Ministry soldiers were bussed from Tashkent and opened fire to break up the peaceful crowd. ``There were no aggressive acts on the part of the residents of the city,'' before the soldiers attacked, he said. But a much larger crowd then gathered and attacked the local police headquarters and the regional Communist Party headquarters, he said. Soldiers returned with armored personnel carriers and a helicopter, and they opened fire again, killing more civilians, he said. Sharif said the group of Berlik leaders from Tashkent saw no corpses when they arrived in Parkent. He quoted doctors as saying the bodies had been taken directly to Tashkent. A technician at the local telephone office, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said that he had seen the burned-out police headquarters. Sharif said electoral observers from Berlik had witnessed ballot-box stuffing in Uzbekistan in the Feb. 18 voting for local and republic offices. He said the demonstrators were seeking the resignation of regional party chief Ismail Salimov and others elected that day. They also demanded the resignations of two representatives to the national Congress of People's Deputies, who they say were elected in fraudulent balloting last year, Sharif said. He said Uzbekistan residents are upset by the poor state of the cotton-growing republic's economy. ``The election comedy exhausted their patience,'' Sharif said, bringing Parkent residents out into the streets.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Japan Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the statement of Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu upon his departure Saturday after two days of talks with President Bush. Thank you very much. (Applause.) (Through interpreter) George, thank you very much, first of all, for your warm remarks. I would also, first of all, like to express my appreciation for the heartwarming hospitality extended to me by you, George, and Mrs. Bush. I am particularly pleased to have had the opportunity to come together in scenic Palm Springs and to discuss issues at such length that our two countries face and that relate to peace and prosperity of the world. My meeting with you was a meaningful opportunity to discuss coordination between Japan and the United States as we move into a new era of turbulent international situation in search of a new order based on freedom and democracy. I am fully satisfied that I was able to share fundamental thoughts with you through in-depth exchange of views. I value very highly the careful but bold initiatives taken by the president to foster desirable changes in the East-West relations and to promote arms control and disarmament negotiations. I am determined that Japan must share responsibility from the standpoint of its being one of the countries who are responsible for maintaining and strengthening international order. During my recent visit to Europe, I have pledged in concrete terms support to the East European countries who are seeking to establish freedom and democracy, and introduce market economies. On the German reunification issue, the president explained to me that he conveyed the U.S. position to the Federal Republic of Germany at the recent meeting between the president and Chancellor Kohl concerning the adherence of the unified Germany to NATO and the continued presence of U.S. forces on German soil. I expressed my appreciation for his explanation, and expressed my admiration for the efforts by the president. The president and I exchanged views on the Asia-Pacific situation, and we shared the view that the diplomacy of new thinking of the Soviet Union needs to be actively applied in this region as well, and that it is important for both Japan and the U.S. to endeavor together to ensure the political stability and economic prosperity of this region. This year marks the 30th anniversary of the conclusion of the Japan-U.S. security treaty. Recognizing the roles played by the Japan-U.S. security arrangements for peace and stability of Japan, as well as the Asia-Pacific region, I, together with the President, confirmed the increasing importance of the treaty into the future. Furthermore, the president and I shared the view that the Japan-U.S. security arrangements continue to be the important basis of Japan-U.S. cooperation in the search for peace through deterrence and dialogue at the time of evolution of the new international situation. I value the continued role of the United States in this region as a Pacific power, which is irreplaceable by any other country. I expressed to the president my determination to extend the cooperation required to secure the continued smooth operation of the Japan-U.S. security arrangements, including host-nation support for U.S. forces in Japan.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Locally Heavy Rain Along East Coast
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rain fell along parts of the central and southern East Coast on Saturday and showers were scattered over the West, with snow in the mountains. Showers and thunderstorms developed over the East Coast along and ahead of a cold front. Showers and thunderstorms produced 1.46 inches of rain at Warner Robbins Air Force Base at Macon, Ga., and 0.77 of an inch at Charlotte, N.C. Showers were scattered over parts of the West, from Oregon and northern California to Utah and southern Idaho, with snow falling at higher elevations. A new storm developing off the West Coast was expected to bring heavy snow to some of the mountainous areas of the West, and winter storm watches were posted for Sunday for California's northern Sierra Nevada range and the Lake Tahoe area of Nevada. Strong northerly wind ushered cold air into the middle Mississippi Valley, the Ohio Valley and the Great Lakes region. Afternoon temperatures were still freezing in the upper Mississippi Valley and the Great Lakes region, with readings in the teens across parts of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Upper Michigan. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 10 below zero at International Falls, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Thanks Zambians for Years of Backing
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela thanked thousands of Zambia's urban poor Saturday for decades of support for his South African anti-apartheid group. Flanked by President Kenneth Kaunda, one of Africa's elder statesmen, the veteran black nationalist told a rally that Zambians had greatly suffered because their country played host to exiles of the African National Congress for more than two decades. The ANC has been waging a low-level guerrilla war against the white government of South Africa. ``I salute you for your unstinting support. ... I salute you for your commitment to our struggle,'' Mandela told a boisterous crowd of about 10,000 people at the Independence Stadium in Lusaka. Hundreds of Zambians died or were injured when South Africa mounted military raids or sabotage attacks on ANC targets in Zambia, Mandela said. South Africa ``terrorized innocent people'' in Zambia, he said. ``What greater sacrifice is there than the shedding of blood for other people? We in South Africa will not forget your sacrifices.'' Thousands of well-wishers lined the six-mile route from Kaunda's official residence to a stadium for the rally, billed as a celebration of Mandela's release Feb. 11 after 27 years in South African prisons. He was freed after President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC and announced other reforms. De Klerk says he wants to bring disenfranchised blacks into the political system and gain international support for his government. Mandela, who arrived at the stadium in an open jeep, told a restless audience Zambia lost foreign investment because of its support for African exiles fighting for justice since its own independence from British colonial rule in 1964. He said the Zambian government was spurned by South Africa's longtime allies in the West because of Kaunda's outspoken opposition to the apartheid racial system. Zambia, in central southern Africa, is one of the continent's poorest nations. ``The successes we have scored are to a large measure attributable to your support,'' Mandela said. The stadium is in the poor Lusaka district of Mandevu. Many people in the crowd who waved Mandela posters wore rags and had bare feet. But they danced to the music of traditional drums, choirs and an eight-piece jazz band. Mandela, who was elected ANC deputy president Friday, also called for an end to regional conflicts in Angola and Mozambique, where right-wing rebels are fighting the governments. He was to travel to neighboring Zimbabwe on Sunday on the second, three-day leg of his first foreign trip since 1962. Mandela then is to visit ANC facilities in Tanzania and fly to Stockholm, Sweden, to see ailing ANC President Oliver Tambo, who has been hospitalized since a stroke.

DOC.HEAD: RANCHO MIRAGE: in Japan.
DOC.TEXT: With regard to Japan-US economic relations, the President and I agreed to continuously enhance our relations with the understanding that the sound development of economic relations between our two countries is indispensable to the development of not only our economies but that of the world economy. Although negative aspects of the issues and problems in our bilateral economic relations tend to be emphasized, as the President said with profound insight, the two markets are extremely large for each of us, and our economies are moving in the right directions, due to the adjustment efforts in the past several years. Both the U.S. budget deficit and Japan's current surplus are being reduced, and their reatios to GNP have been halved. However, the imbalances are still very large, and we should continue to work harder. The SII is extremely important to consolidate this positive trend. I am determined to firmly tackle structural reforms of Japan as one of the top priorities of my new cabinet with a view to improving the quality of Japanese life, with further stress on the consumer-oriented economy. I hope that the U.S. on its part will promote structural adjustment, as the President has just said. I told the president of my determination to maintain such policies as expansion of domestic demand, improvement of market access, and deregulation. The president and I agree that both Japan and the US will make the maximum efforts for the early solution of pending issues in the spirit of cooperation and joint efforts between our two countries. The President expressed that Japan and the U.S. have worked closely in dealing with debt problems and economic policy coordination and reaffirmed his commitment, including cooperation in exchange markets. The president's statement convinces me to make maximum efforts for Japan-U.S. cooperation in these areas, including in exchange markets. Having in mind that our solid bilateral relations are indespensible to the future stability and prosperity of the world, the President and I share the recognition of the importance of consolidating our bilateral relations to be the constructive cooperation. In this context, we share the recognition that it is important and necessary to further strengthen and expand the constructive relations in the 1990s, including educational and cultural exchanges, science and technology cooperation, and two-way technology transfers. U.S.-Japan relations of today, transcending our bilateral framework, have acquired the significance of a global partnership with responsibilities for tasks facing the world. The President and I welcome that the Japan-U.S. global partnership is bearing specific fruit in such a broad range of fields as response to regional problems, the management of world economy, economic cooperation for developing countries, and debt problems, environment, drugs, and the fight against international terrorism. On the problem of drugs, in particular, I highly appreciate the series of initiatives of the President, and the courageous determination shown at the Cartegena drug summit. I expressed my determination to the president that Japan will actively participate in the international efforts to eradicate illicit drugs. I conveyed my intention to the president to promptly implement concrete measures in support of the democratic government in Nicaragua and my belief that an early economic recovery is important for the stabilization of Panama. I expressed Japan's position that Japan would look into economic assistance for the reconstruction of the region as the peace process in Central America progresses. The development of the South Africa situation contains the possibility towards dismantling apartheid. The president and I agreed that Japan and the U.S. will continue to consult with each other on how to eliminate apartheid. This year marks the final year of the Uruguay Round. The president and I agreed that the successful conclusions of the negotiations is extremely important for the fight against protectionism and for the construction of the basis for the continued progress of the world economy as we move toward the 21st century. The president and I reaffirmed our conviction that we should closely cooperate for the success of the round. Japan and the United States are faced with enormous challenges and opportunities in the strong current of history. Having in mind the significance of the Japan-U.S. partnership as a foundation for the stability of the world, I am fully determined to courageously pave the way, together with the president, toward the 21st century. Thank you. Ladies and Gentleman, I understand that George will stay on here and have a most wonderful time answering your questions in a press conference. I, however, will have to leave ... in order to return home in time to answer the questions that will be raised to me in the Diet, and also in just in time to arrive in Tokyo before the night landing time limit arrives at 11:00 p.m. in Tokyo. Well, I hope that you will not call this night landing time limit, another structural impediment.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Japan Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the transcript of President Bush's news conference Saturday following two days of talks with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Q: Mr. President, are you satisfied that the prime minister has given the sufficient political commitment to break the impasse in trade talks? Did he offer any trade concessions? A: Well, you heard his statement, which I thought was very good. And all I can tell you is, we had perhaps the best opportunity that I've seen to have genuinely frank discussions. I met with him one-on-one yesterday, and then last night sat next to him at dinner, so I had an opportunity to continue the business part of the discussion. Then I heard this statement _ we had our other talks too _ but, I heard this statement today _ and I'd say that _ that the Japanese side knows how important it is to move forward. And clearly, I have a renewed feeling of how important it is for us to do some of the things that they were talking about on this structural impediments side. So, I can't tell you in terms of a specific commodity or a specific date, but I _ we were just talking here and all of us are very pleased with the frankness as well as the spirit of cooperation that I think was reflected by the prime minister's statement. Q: But, do you think he went far enough, sir? A: Well, nobody ever goes far enough to do everything exactly the way we want it, but I think it's _ I think for those who understand the complexities of this relationship, at this juncture, I _ we got everything out of this meeting that we had hoped for. Obviously, we've got things to do, and clearly, the Japanese side has things to do. I want to say something on that meeting if I could. The fact that he came here now _ finished a tough campaign, just given a big speech to the Diet, indeed he gets home at 11 and has to go to answer questions in the Diet the very next morning _ should be interpreted by Americans in this manner; that the Japanese feel this relationship is very important. And to the Japanese side, the fact that I invited him when I did should send a very important signal that we have this right up in the forefront of relationships that are critical. And I was very grateful that he accepted in such short _ short notice, this _ and in a complicated time frame _ this invitation. Q: How confident are you that he can _ A: Well, I'm _ he's just won a good victory there. He's solidified his party's position. He himself emerges as a _ I would say, dynamic new leader. And so, we will simply wait and see. But, I wish him well. Q: Mr. President, there are reports out of Israel that Yitzhak Shamir is prepared to accept the U.S. formula for Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. Do you know anything about that, and if so, what shape will it take? A: Well as you know, we have been working on this for eight months. And I certainly _ Jim Baker and I were just talking about it, and I might say I commend him for staying in there, trying to be a catalyst to get this process going. So, we don't know any of the details of that. We just talked to our top officials here. But, I hope it's true, and I hope we can move forward. And if we do, I'll be glad to salute our secretary of State and others, including Mr. Shamir, Mr. Mubarak, for hanging in there, trying to get something moving toward peace. David? Q: Has there been any movement, sir? If you don't know about his final commitment, has there been any movement toward acceptance of the U.S. format? A: Well, there has over the months. But just like the real world, you take two steps forward and take one step back. I hope we're going to go forward now. Yeah, David? Q: Mr. President, a question about some testimony last week on the Soviets. Secretary Cheney said he still believes they are continuing with modernization. Director Webster said in some testimony he thinks that the military threat seems to be receding in some significant respects. With your experience in intelligence, how do you explain these divergent views? And have you adopted either of them? What would you tell the American people about what to think about this? A: You know, I get asked _ the question is, ``Who's the enemy?'' And I answer, ``Uncertainty, unpredictability.'' And I don't see a great disconnect between the way you phrased the question as to whether they are modernizing or as to whether the threat has receded. Clearly, as you see _ see those troops starting to move out of various Eastern countries and as you've seen the democracies coming in, that results in a diminished threat. But it doesn't say that there is _ that everything is certain and that stability is guaranteed. I was asked that question in relation to why I felt we ought to continue to have troops in Europe and why I felt that it would be good to have a unified Germany in NATO. And the answer is stability _ safeguard against unpredictability or instability. So I haven't gone into, David, the testimony of each, haven't read it. But I really don't see a big conflict there. Craig? Q: How long do you give Mr. Kaifu to produce? It seems we've heard this type of assurances he gave today before. What are you looking for specifically and when are you looking for it? A: Well, we have some time frames. We have some March talks that I'd like to see successful. But look, we weren't here to throw down definitive deadlines. That's not the way you deal with _ with Japan, in my view. But the sooner the better is the way I'd answer the question. Q: But were there any new initiatives, Mr. President? For example, I mean, you emphasized that this wasn't a negotiating session. But were there any new initiatives on either side? Any new proposals? For example, did you recommend some way that he could be of assistance in Nicaragua?

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Attacked by Government Partners for Polish Border Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The junior partner in West German chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition government joined Poland on Saturday in attacking Kohl for his latest position on the eastern border of a united Germany. One member of the junior party was quoted as saying the government could break up over the issue if Kohl persists in his stand. Meanwhile, former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt returned to East Germany to do more campaigning for East German candidates in the March elections. The Soviet news agency Tass announced in Moscow that East German Premier Hans Modrow will ``pay a working visit'' to Moscow on Monday and Tuesday. No other details were immediately available. Kohl on Friday offered Poland a treaty fixing its border with East Germany, but he said Poland should also confirm its 1953 decision to renounce any World War II reparations. He said Poland should also ensure protection of the rights of ethnic Germans in Poland. Poland has pushed for the treaty to prevent a reunited Germany from pressing claims to Polish territory that was part of prewar Germany. Polish officials angrily rejected Kohl's new proposal. On Saturday, Kohl's own government partner, the Free Democrat Party, added its voice to the criticism. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher was quoted by the Luebecker Nachrichten newspaper as saying the party and Kohl's Christian Democratic Union would discuss Kohl's proposal at a special committee meeting next week. ``Everyone knows, whoever keeps the border question open, closes the door on German unity,'' Genscher was quoted as saying by the newspaper. Other members of the liberal Free Democrats were even more blunt. Party chairman Otto Graf Lambsdorff said he was ``in no way happy'' with Kohl's offer. He said he was surprised ``that the very delicate topic of reparations should be mentioned by our side.'' The party's defense speaker, Olaf Feldmann, told West German state radio that Poland's western border was not something to be traded. ``We Germans have no territorial claims on Poland; we don't want to and will not question Poland's western border,'' Feldmann said. Cornelia Schmalz-Jacobsen, another leading Free Democrat, was quoted as saying by the Nuernberger Nachrichten newspaper that the coalition government could be threatened by any more delays by Kohl in openly agreeing to fixing the current border. While Kohl's offer seemed aimed at assuaging criticism at home and abroad over his refusal to give ironclad pledges on a fixed border, Polish government officials said it only broadened the dispute over unification. Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki said Friday he was ``astonished'' by Kohl's position. Poland wants reassurance that a united Germany will not claim lands ceded to Poland after Nazi Germany's World War II defeat in 1945. Mazowiecki has demanded a seat at unification talks among the Germanys and the victorious World War II allies _ the Soviet Union, United States, Britain and France. Kohl has repeatedly said Germans have no plans to claim the territory, but he insists only a future united German government can sign a binding agreement. Facing close races in December elections, Kohl has tried to woo a right-wing minority of voters who want to lay claim to the land. In Friday's statement, he again avoided stating outright that a united Germany would not claim the land, which makes up about a third of Poland. However, government spokesman Dieter Vogel said Kohl supports the idea of a reunited Germany signing a treaty fixing Poland's current western border. Vogel also said Kohl reiterated his support for both German parliaments passing an identical declaration pledging to respect the current borders after East Germany elects its first freely chosen Parliament on March 18. In Erfurt, East Germany, former West German Chancellor Brandt, who began a thaw in relations between the two Germanys there 20 years ago, returned Saturday for the East German campaign. Brandt, honorary chairman of the Social Democratic Parties in both East and West Germany, waved to cheering crowds from an upstairs window of the Erfurter Hof hotel. It was the same spot he appeared on March 19, 1970, after a historic meeting with then East German leader Willi Stoph. ``I'm very moved at this moment,'' the veteran statesman told the emotional crowds packing the square. ``It's a long road we have behind us.'' Now, he said, the final steps to unite the two Germanys must be taken in a ``responsible, just and balanced manner, and to a good final result.''

DOC.HEAD: RANCHO MIRAGE: in Nicaragua?
DOC.TEXT: A: Well, yes, there was a good discussion of that. And I was very pleased with his receptivity to helping the new democracies here. They gave 1.95 _ or pledged $1.95 billion _ to help in the reconstruction in Eastern Europe _ help with the democracies there. And he was very open minded in response to my plea to be of similar _ to be of assistance to Nicaragua and Panama. So, yes, we had some detailed discussion about that. But it wasn't as _ you know _ like, by a certain date we would expect a certain _ like to see a certain amount of money, or anything. Q: Anything you could tell us about any details _ for example, a new way to be of assistance? A: Well, just that I felt a commitment on the part of the prime minister of Japan to assist democracies. And I think that is very important. And frankly, I think that will help the U.S.-Japan relationship because I think the people in our country, as I told him, want to see the Chamorro government succeed, want to see democracy in Panama succeed. So, in that particular subject matter I was very pleased with the forthcoming comments from Prime Minister Kaifu. Yeah? Q Will you work to reduce some of the foreign aid to the largest recipients, like Egypt and Israel, so that you _ the United States can give more to Eastern Europe, Nicaragua and the countries that ... A: Well, I am against earmarking. I am for more flexibility. We have had discussions with our congressmen, including the chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Some of those discussions encourage the concept of a fund that gives the president the flexibility to determine a certain amount of foreign-aid money. So I'm less interested in reducing somebody than I am getting the flexibility so that when you see a country come forward and try to solidify their democracy or work cooperatively with us in the Caribbean _ as, say, Mr. Manley in Jamaica is doing _ we'd like to be able to help him more. Q: Would it be a bad signal right now with Israel trying to move toward talks with the Palestinians? A: Would what be a bad signal? Q: Would the reduction of aid to Israel? A: Well, I don't think that _ I don't know that moving towards peace need be totally equated with aid. I mean, we're talking about a quest for peace that comes not just in Israel but in Egypt and everything else. So, I'm not tying those two subjects. But Israel has some big economic problems. They've got some big problems facing them that require a very generous apportionment of aid money, and they are getting that. Right here -- this gentleman in the middle. Q: To follow on the question of aid to Israel _ Secretary Baker has suggested that we might tie aid to resettle the Soviet Jews to an Israeli willingness to not settle the West Bank and to withdraw some of the settlements from the West Bank and Gaza. Then, the State Department seemed to equivocate on that. What's your position? MORE

DOC.HEAD: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.: your position?
DOC.TEXT: A: Well, I'm not sure there was equivocation. My position is that the foreign policy of the United States says we do not believe there should be new settlements in the West Bank or in East Jerusalem. And I will conduct that policy as if it's firm, which it is, and I will be shaped in whatever decisions we make to see whether people can comply with that policy. And that's our strongly held view, and we think it's constructive to peace _ the peace process, to _ if Israel will follow that view. And so there's divisions in Israel on this question, incidentally. Parties are divided on it. But this is the position of the United States and I'm not going to change that position. Q: So will you link aid to resettle the Soviet Jews _ A: Well, I _ I will just simply reiterate the policy right here that we are not _ that we are not going to look favorably upon new settlements. Yes? Q: Mr. President, before coming to this meeting the prime minister outlined in a speech in his own parliament new measures to increase foreign exports to Japan, and he alluded to them in his departure statement just a few minutes ago. Did you discuss those with him, and how significant and serious do you see them to be? A: New _ new measures to increase ...? Q: Foreign exports, U.S. sales to Japan. A: Absolutely. It was discussed in _ by me, and the secretary of State had a good chance to discuss it with the foreign minister. At dinner our various participants, including our trade people, had a chance to discuss with _ that whole concept with the rest of the Japanese delegation, and I had every opportunity to discuss it. And so it's _ it's something they're quite clear on. We want to, and we must increase exports. I covered that in my statement and I listened carefully to what he said about the _ the deficit we have and the surplus they have. Q: Do you feel, though, that he has begun to make some good moves in the direction of _ A: Well, I'm very encouraged with _ as I told you _ with, or am encouraged by the talks we've had, and I am encouraged with the trend that seems to be taking place, but we've got to do more. Yeah, Sandy, and then over here to Owen and Frank. Q: Mr. President, regarding the hostages, is there any new movement to report? Is any third country, particularly the French _ there are reports that perhaps French mediaries are working on behalf of the U.S. to negotiate with people in _ either Iran or Syria. A: Nice try. Let me tell you all something. You people reported that I called Francois Mitterrand to discuss the release of some guy that I'd never heard of before, and we denied it, and you keep coming back at me. I'm not sure _ I think it's good for you to do that, though, because I have said that if I find a way to get these hostages released _ and the way to do it is through quiet diplomacy with the French, the British, the Iranians, or anybody else _ I will do it. I want those hostages out of there. So keep asking, but on this case, the answer to your question is no. Yeah, Owen? Q: What new ideas came out of your talks to propel the trade dispute so that you'd get more progress down the road? Any new ideas you put on the table or that the prime minister _ A: To do _ what's that? Q: New ideas that you put on the table or the prime minister did to propel the trade talks. A: I don't know that we need new ideas. We just need new energy on both sides. And I did say this _ I said, ``You've got a new cabinet. And some of your top cabinet officials that are not engaged in _ that are engaged _ will be engaged in trade negotiation are not here. And I will tell you that our cabinet officials _ and I was thinking of Carla Hills, thinking about Mosbacher, as well as Secretary Brady, and as well as Secretary Baker _ will be on the next plane, if it will help solve this problem.'' And he seemed to take on board that sense of urgency. And I _ I'm _ we'll see where we go. Frank? Q: Mr. President, I'm a little confused. In your statement you said you did put forth new ideas, and you were awaiting a response from the Japanese. I'm wondering if you could _ A: That was one of them. Q: Okay. Is that it? A: (Chuckles.) No, that's not entirely it, but there's some _ we're _ I think we covered the subject very well. Q: Well may I ask you, sir, if you believe now, based on your discussions here, that you will be able _ these two countries will be able to avoid the punitive actions specified under congressionally mandated deadlines? A: We had a chance to review that, and to review the question of Super 301. And we did discuss that. We discussed the time frames involved. We discussed product specificity. And we all know what they are _ satellites and forest product and super computers and semiconductors. And, so, yes, we did get a chance to go into all of that. Q: Do you think you'll be able to avoid sanctions? A: Well, I'm hopeful we will, because I _ it is going to require progress. But again, we _ both sides understand the U.S. law on this. And I think their side understands it more clearly right now. Q: Mr. President, 36 senators wrote you a letter on forest products. What do you tell them and the thousands of timber workers who think they will lose their jobs if Japan takes our logs and not our finished lumber? A: I tell them the U.S.-Japanese relationship is important. I tell them I want to see open markets. I tell them I want to see progress made in that category, along with the other three, and many others that I have referenced here. That's what I would tell them. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, why did Mr. Kaifu not bring his trade minister? A: He just _ I'm not even sure _ I don't know what their confirmation process _ I need help _ that they were all totally in place. Q: They are, but just barely. A: They are, but just barely. They were appointed, and they had eight hours to pack up. And I guess that wasn't enough time. But he just _ I think it was that they _ when I sent him the invitation, and when we started dealing with who was going to come, it was _ he wasn't quite sure that everything would be in place, I guess. I'd prefer that the Japanese side answer that question. Yeah, these two on the end here. Q: Mr. President, do you think these talks are going to be able to diffuse protectionist moves in Congress?

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed, 15 Injured in Blast at Hungarian Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with one graf to UPDATE with three of injured reported to have died; pickup graf 2 pvs, `The blast...'
DOC.TEXT: A hydrogen gas explosion occurred at a steel plant in northern Hungary Saturday just after the day shift arrived, and the official MTI news agency said five people were killed and 15 injured. The blast started a fire that heavily damaged the Ozd Metallurgical Works, 65 miles northeast of Budapest near the Czechoslovak border. Eleven of the injured were seriously hurt, according to MTI, which did not say what caused the explosion. It said the fire was put out.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaii's Hotel Workers Strike Over Wages, Benefits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with disruption of maid and dining services in hotels, bus drivers honoring picket lines; ADD name of hotel where quoted manager works; move up quote from hotel guest; RECAST lead. Pick up 15th graf pvs, `Rodriguez said...
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of workers at some of Hawaii's biggest hotels walked off the job Saturday, leaving some guests without fresh sheets and towels and otherwise disrupting the state's $6-billion-a-year tourist industry. The strike was called about 3:30 a.m. by Local 5 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union, which has 7,500 members, said spokesman Rod Rodriguez. The union's membership had voted to authorize a strike by a 97 percent margin earlier in the week in the dispute over pay and benefits. The strike affected 11 hotels that account for one of every five hotel rooms in Hawaii and two of every five hotel rooms in Waikiki, the state's main tourist destination. Many hotels were forced to cut back on meal and room services as managers scrambled to take the places of the strikers. Most of the hotels that were struck closed their restaurants and snack shops, and the hotel restaurants that remained open had buffet service rather than waiting on tables. There are many restaurants unaffected by the strike in walking distance of Waikiki hotels. Maid service was cut severely. Many guests didn't get fresh sheets or towels unless they asked, and those who did get maid service waited for hours. ``It's unfortunate, considering what I'm paying for a room,'' said Jennie Peters of Huntington Hills, Mich. ``We're not thinking of leaving, though.'' Union and management leaders couldn't agree even on what the last contract offer contained. Bill Crawford, executive director of the Council of Hawaii Hotels, said the union rejected a four-year deal that called for annual wage increases of 5 percent plus hikes in benefits that boosted the total package to around 7 percent a year. Rodriguez said the union calculated the management proposal at around 4 percent, which he said was lower than the 5 percent package offered Friday. ``Management seems to be going backwards,'' he said. ``The offer is meager and measly and shows they could really care less about the hotel workers.'' Crawford called the union's calculations ``voodoo economics.'' He urged hotel workers to return to work. ``The union is making a grave mistake,'' he said. ``Nobody likes a strike, but the hotels had to stand firm against totally unrealistic union demands that ultimately could hurt the employees themselves.'' One management employee at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki, forced to work a parking booth, said he didn't understand what the workers were striking for. ``I can't believe they want a raise for this job,'' said Merv Ching, manager of the resort's valet parking system. ``If anything, they should get a pay cut.'' Guests were mixed in their views. ``I'm a union man and I don't feel comfortable staying here,'' said Gary Flintoff, a member of Painters Local 64 in Tacoma, Wash. ``We've thought about going to another hotel.'' Tour bus operators _ both union and non-union _ refused to enter enter resort property to pick up passengers in a show of support for the strikers. Tourists using those buses were forced to walk to hotels' main entrances to board on public streets. Rodriguez said the union proposed a three-year package that called for annual wages increases of 8 percent and total economic benefits that would boost the proposal to 10 percent a year. In return, the union would drop its demand for a 5 percent room surcharge and a 15 percent food and beverage surcharge that hotel workers would share. Management rejected the offer, saying it would make their hotels uncompetitive. ``It's unreal and out of context with reality,'' said Crawford. The strike followed a ``holiday'' taken Friday by workers in what the union said was a good-faith effort to try to reach an agreement.
