Rodriguez claimed management failed to negotiate with the intent of reaching a settlement, and said the union would remain on strike until a substantial offer was made. ``There's got to be something to talk about,'' he said. ``We are calling their bluff.'' The hotels remained open and were being staffed by management. There was no word if the individual hotels affected would offer discounts. The affected hotels in Waikiki were Hilton Hawaiian Village, 2,523 rooms; Sheraton Waikiki, 1,900 rooms; Hyatt Regency Waikiki, 1,230 rooms; Princess Kalulani, 1,150 rooms; Ilikai Hotel, 800 rooms; Sheraton Moana Surfrider, 793 rooms; Royal Hawaiian Hotel, 526 rooms; and the Kahala Hilton, 369 rooms. Neighbor island hotels affected included the Kona Hilton on Hawaii Island, 445 rooms; Sheraton Kauai, 456 rooms; and Sheraton Maui, 495 rooms.

DOC.HEAD: Can Hazelwood be Convicted of Trying Something Impossible?
DOC.TEXT: The Exxon Valdez, with 10 of her tanks spouting oil, was an immovable object when her skipper called out orders to move ahead, according to expert witnesses in Joseph Hazelwood's trial. Which brought up the question: Can someone be convicted of trying to do something which is impossible? The three witnesses, whose expertise is costing the State of Alaska about $90,000, were not hired to comment on the impossiblity of getting the tanker off Bligh Reef after it went aground. That was a defense point. The consultants came to tell jurors that Hazelwood, charged with felony criminal mischief in the nation's worst oil spill, was reckless when he gave the order to start the engines because he risked capsizing or sinking the massive vessel. But defense attorneys Michael Chalos and Dick Madson used their cross-examinations to suggest there was no such risk because the Exxon Valdez was firmly impaled and wasn't going anywhere. Like most legal issues, the so-called ``impossiblity doctrine'' is a subject of debate and interpretation. In newly filed legal briefs, the prosecution contends that Hazelwood's intentions are the paramount issue because he didn't know in the darkness of March 24, 1989, whether his ship was capable of moving. ``Captain Hazelwood's reliance on the impossibility doctrine is misplaced because the issue is not whether it was possible for the vessel to come free, but whether Captain Hazelwood's mistakes in not realizing the vessel was firmly aground and not recognizing the danger in refloating were reasonable,'' said the prosecution's brief. The argument was offered in support of a prosecution plan to present the results of accident simulations showing the scientific probabilities of the tanker capsizing or sinking after the grounding. The 987-foot tanker, which left Valdez with a full load of Alaska crude oil, struck the jagged reef at the entry to scenic Prince William Sound. Its tanks were gashed, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of oil. Thousands of birds, fish and wildlife were killed and black goo coated hundreds of miles of rocky shore. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with the felony and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. Witnesses have said that Hazelwood gave orders to restart the engines and move ahead. Several times, they say, he gave rudder orders which changed the ship's heading, but it didn't budge. ``You don't know if the vessel was capable of moving even one inch, do you?'' Chalos asked expert George Kirk Greiner Jr. ``Obviously, it wasn't,'' said Greiner. ``It didn't move.'' Robert Beevers, a former tanker captain, was adamant in his testimony that Hazelwood risked further damage to the ship by trying to move it. ``But what if it simply couldn't move?'' asked Madson. ``That's what happened,'' said Beevers. ``...That doesn't mean he wasn't trying to get it off at that point.'' The third witness, salvage expert William Milwee Jr., said Hazelwood was reckless in trying to move the tanker because he didn't have enough information about the ship's position. ``I think it was reckless because Captain Hazelwood did not have enough knowledge of the situation to attempt an immediate refloating,'' he said. Chalos confronted Milwee with calculations of the tanker's engine horsepower and the ship's grounded condition. ``There is absolutely no question this ship would not have moved using its engines alone,'' said Milwee. ``No matter what Captain Hazelwood did?'' asked the lawyer. ``No matter what Captain Hazelwood did,'' said the witness. ``But Captain Hazelwood did nothing to try to determine that.'' He continued to assert that Hazelwood was reckless. With the defense scheduled to open this week, Hazelwood's lawyers plan to present their own computer simulations of the Exxon Valdez accident, and they will call experts in an effort to hammer home their impossibility theory. But they are not abandoning their original position of why Hazelwood gave the orders to move ahead. They say he was trying to stabilize the tanker on the reef.

DOC.HEAD: Saboteurs Fail Mission When Dolphins Stay Put
DOC.TEXT: Eight captive dolphins given a passage to open water by an environmental group's act of sabotage instead huddled together in their saltwater pen and refused to swim free. One of the would-be rescuers said the bottlenose dolphins identified with their captors at the Florida Keys tourist attraction. When the staff at the Hawk's Cay Resort discovered openings cut in the underwater fence, the dolphins were clustered yards away from a hole, looking at the gap. ``You could have driven a submarine through it,'' pen manager Kevin Walsh said Friday of the largest 12-foot by 5-foot hole in the plastic fence at the Duck Key facility about midway between the peninsula's tip and Key West. Sea Shepherd, an animal rights group, claimed responsibility Friday for the effort the previous week to free the dolphins. The sabotage was reported to the Monroe County sheriff's office Thursday. No one at the sheriff's office Saturday knew whether charges would be pressed in the case. Dolphins are trained at the resort before being shipped to sea-mammal pavilions across the country. Some were raised in captivity, but two were captured in Tampa Bay for Baltimore's National Aquarium last November. Ben White, Atlantic director of the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, said local members of a ``dolphin rescue brigade'' cut three holes in the holding pen to try to free the dolphins in several late-night forays with scuba equipment. The dolphins started ``identifying with the captors and would not leave the pen,'' White said, adding young dolphins become dependent on human providers and prefer to stay in familiar environments. Meanwhile, a scientist in Miami said the number of dolphin deaths in the Gulf of Mexico this winter is running about three times normal. A total of 162 bottlenose dolphins have been found dead from Texas' Matagorda Bay to Tampa Bay. In a normal winter, only about 50 deaths are recorded in Gulf waters, said Larry Hensen of the National Marine Fisheries Service. ``Some have been emaciated with lots of skin lesions and others have been nice and robust,'' Hansen said last week. ``Obviously something different from the normal pattern is going on, but right now we don't know what it is.'' The cold snap at Christmas is known to be a contributing factor, and a lethal strain of red tide that was implicated in a massive dolphin kill in 1987 and 1988 will be studied as a possibility, he said.

DOC.HEAD: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.: in Congress?
DOC.TEXT: A: I hope so, but I don't know. I think that depends on the results. I oppose protectionism. I'm going to continue to fight against it. I want to open markets. I want to see a successful Uruguay Round. But _ and I will do from the Executive Branch side what I can. But look, I'm not unsympathetic to those that say let's have markets open further. And that was what was good out of the meeting; we had a chance to say that. But I think the proof of the pudding is in the eating. Q: You talked to the Japanese? A: Yeah. And us on some areas. I mean, if you're talking about structural impediments, let's get on with some of the suggestions they make about us, on the deficit and some other areas. I've told them that we were trying to be more competitive in going forward with an education program. They happen to support the idea of capital _ capital gains reductions. And I'd like to see that take place. So it's not just a one-way street. Yeah, Frank? Q: Mr. Bush, a great deal of American money flows out of the United States through American companies purchased by the Japanese. Did you discuss the question of restraint by Japanese investment in this country and _ A: No. Q: Why? Why is that not _ A: Because I welcome Japanese investment in this country. You know why? Jobs. American jobs. People working that wouldn't have a job necessarily if there wasn't that investment. And we _ the Japanese are not the number one in terms of foreign investment. And so, the big thing is _ and also, the other reason, Frank, is I don't want to see barriers thrown up to U.S. investment in other countries. Q: How about _ A: So that's why it's a free trade concept, plus jobs for the American working man and woman in this country. Q: How about the corollary side of _ A: And it also has to do with financing a deficit that I'd like to see Congress help me get down. Q: Did you talk about the corollary of lowering barriers to American investment in Japan? A: Yes we did. Yes. Q: To what effect? A: Well, you've heard me discussing that. Q: According to Mr. Fitzwater's statement, you emphasized that this summit should raise a conceptual framework. What is the meaning of ``conceptual framework''? A: Well, I think I touched on that in my _ in the calling for a trialogue. We've asked the secretary of State to meet with the foreign minister of Japan to discuss how we can _ this is the global effort that we've been discussing, and so that _ I think that language relates to that particular part of our discussions. Q: Are you looking for some new structure for dialogue? A: Well, yes. But it's going to require now more conversation between our foreign ministries. But I think as we see the world developing into the 90s, it is essential that Japan be included _ U.S., Europe and Japan _ in a lot of these economic _ discussion of these economic areas. And so, that's what we were talking about there _ the global _ the global approach to some of these problems. But Japan is a key player there, and we've got to structure some of these organizations accordingly. I think it's thoroughly understandable that Japan, with its contributions and the size of its economy, wants to have a stepped-up influence in some of the multilateral institutions. Well, that would be a discussion. That _ that subject would be something that would come under these discussions that I've just outlined. Q: Just to follow up _ Q: When you _ A: You can't follow up on his question, you get a new one. No, you get a new one. Q: Mr. President, when you used the conceptual framework, you are in mind of SI talks and the Super 301? A: Excuse me? Q: When you used conceptual framework _ the word ``conceptual framework''? A: Well, I just thought I just explained that to this gentleman here, probably not as clear as I should have been. But we believe that Japan will have a _ more of a voice in these international _ international matters. And we are moving accordingly to expand what, traditionally or heretofore, has been dialogue into three major factors having an input into it. Yes, Carl? STAFF: We're going to take a final question, please. Q: Mr. President, you mentioned that the Japanese were aware of sentiment in the United States and in Congress. Did you specifically mention that to them, that there have been some letters in the past week, as you probably know, Senator Bentsen and Congressman Gephardt have said _ did you specifically tell them ``Congress is pushing very hard on this, we've got to do something''? A: I have _ I had _ in that one-on-one had the opportunity to be just as clear as any congressman would have liked me to be, and where this, what needs to happen to keep this terribly important relationship on track. And similarly, Prime Minister Kaifu was as frank with me as to how some of what we do is viewed in Japan. So, it was very good in that regard, and I hadn't seen probably all the letters from Congress, but you're right, there's a tremendous amount of interest on that. And those letters were, in a sense, helpful to me, because they _ the ones that I saw _ because they depicted a sense of urgency that I hope I was able to convey and that others in our party were able to convey to our Japanese counterparts. So, I think in that role _ in that context, those inputs were very helpful. Thank you all very much. Now _ Q: The bombing in Panama _ are American servicemen at greater risk? A: We oppose terrorism, and that seems to be a terroristic action. And it happens, regrettably, all around the world. And that would be the only answer I could give you, Ann, so I would hope not. The process of democratization is still strongly popular in Panama. So, I don't know what that was even about, but if it was some protest against democracy, why _ so be it. But it's _ must be condemned by all. Thank you all, very much, and I hope you have a pleasant day. I know I will. (Cross talk as President Bush walks away from podium.) Q: (Off mike regarding the donation to the United Negro College Fund) the $50 million gift of Mr. Annenberg? A: Well, it's a little premature. We were planning to discuss that, but I think it's a wonderful thing. I've long been a supporter of the United Negro College Fund. Our administration has stepped up support for historically black colleges and universities, the endowment concept there. And I think that generosity _ (inaudible) _ is a challenge _ (inaudible) _ that will bring on well-deserved support from others. It's most generous and one of the most brilliant thousand points of light I can think of. Q: How about a Nova? (laughter).
DOC.HEAD: END TEXT, 4 Takes
RJR Begins Advertising Dakota
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) _ The war of the cigarettes is on the move as R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. goes head-to-head with its competition in Marlboro country trying to sell its new Dakota in Texas and Tennessee. Dakota advertisements appeared in Friday newspapers in areas around Houston and Nashville, said David B. Fishel, a Reynolds spokesman. The cigarettes should be on shelves within two to three weeks, he said. ``We're going head-to-head with Marlboro, so we had to go where Marlboro is,'' Fishel said, describing the test-market regions as thick with Marlboro smokers. Marlboro, made by Philip Morris USA, is the nation's most popular brand with a 26 percent share of the cigarette market. Referring to protests from anti-smoking groups in Washington, Fishel told the Winston-Salem Journal, ``Smokers, not anti-smokers, are going to make a decision on Dakota.'' Reynolds' decision to proceed with its marketing plan is in sharp contrast with its reaction earlier this year to discontinue plans to market another cigarette, Uptown, in a test in Philadelphia. In both cases, anti-smoking groups criticized the company for trying to sell cigarettes to consumers who are most vulnerable to the health risks associated with smoking tobacco. Although Reynolds announced that it hoped to sell Uptown to black smokers, the company rejected claims from the Advocacy Institute that Dakota ads would target young, uneducated, blue-collar women. The organization, based in Washington, supported its claims with marketing documents that it leaked to the media. In abandoning Uptown, Reynolds said adverse publicity made it impossible for the company to get an accurate measure of smokers' reaction to the new brand. ``Because they were successful in making it a racial issue, there was just no way we were going to get any kind of unbiased read on the brand,'' Fishel said. Dakota is aimed at all Marlboro smokers and not at unschooled women, Fishel said. He also said Reynolds feels the adverse attention that Dakota has received wouldn't affect the test-marketing. The advertisements are direct in their bid to lure smokers from Marlboro. One of them reads: ``We wanted to develop a new, flavorful cigarette that's always smooth. With your help, it's finally here. Dakota. Designed with the Marlboro smoker in mind.''

DOC.HEAD: International Team Completes Seven-Month Antarctic Crossing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 5-6 pvs bgng ,`Interviewed on...' to CORRECT Steger quote; pickup graf 7 pvs, `The expedition...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic NY25, LaserPhoto PAR4
DOC.TEXT: Six weary but jubilant adventurers from six nations completed a seven-month, 3,800-mile trek across Antarctica on skis and dogsleds Saturday, in the longest unmechanized crossing of the continent. ``It's a dangerous land, without mercy,'' co-leader Jean-Louis Etienne of France told French television moments after the team arrived at a Soviet base on the Indian Ocean coast. The men were given a huge loaf of fresh bread and chugged champagne as the flags of their homelands flapped above them in a strong wind. Besides Etienne, the team included American co-leader Will Steger of Ely, Minn., Victor Boyarsky of the Soviet Union, Geoff Somers of Britain, Quin Dahe of China, and Keizo Funatsu of Japan. Interviewed on ABC-TV's ``Wide World of Sports,'' Steger was asked what he intends to do now that the journey has ended. He laughed and said, ``Take a sauna.'' ``We can relax and join the human race again,'' he said. The expedition almost ended in tragedy in its final hours. As the team struggled through a storm toward the Soviet research base of Mirnyy, Funatsu disappeared in a blizzard for 11 hours before he was found Friday. Steger said it was ``very close. We were lucky we found him.'' The crossing was by far the longest of its type across Antarctica, but apparently not the first without motor power. On Feb. 12, Italian mountaineer Reinhold Messner and West German adventurer Arved Fuchs completed what they said was a 1,700-mile crossing on foot, without the use of sled dogs. They are expected to arrive in Frankfurt later this month to provide details of their journey. Etienne's team is scheduled to return to France for welcoming celebrations March 21. They then head to the United States for ceremonies in Minneapolis _ which along with Paris served as expedition headquarters _ and in Washington, where President Bush is expected to meet them at the White House. Bush, in a congratulatory message, said: ``Your spirit of international friendship and cooperation not only helped make this fantastic journey possible but also set a wonderful example for the world community of nations.'' The expedition, undertaken at a cost of about $11 million after three years of planning, was intended to build support for Antarctica's preservation and demonstrate the power of international cooperation. The members had their expenses paid, but they received no salaries. ``Antarctica isn't threatened by pollution, it's still virgin and white,'' Etienne said in a hookup with reporters in Paris. ``All countries should forget their partisan interests and offer it to the world .... This continent belongs to everyone.'' He described Antarctica as ``huge and sometimes monstrous.'' In seven months, he said, the only other living things seen by the team were their sled dogs and three birds. Experts at expedition headquarters in Paris praised the performance of the sled dogs, which were trained by Steger. All but one of the 36 dogs used on the expedition survived, and a special high-nutrition diet appeared to have kept them in excellent health. The journey began July 28 near the tip of the Antarctic Peninsula, which reaches out toward South America. On Dec. 11, the team reached its halfway point, becoming the first to reach the South Pole by dogsled since Roald Amundsen in 1911. ``The first two months were very, very hard,'' Etienne said. ``We started to doubt after a month whether we would make it.'' It had been feared bad weather might strand the adventurers on the continent for as long as a month and jeopardize an elaborate international tour to tout the expedition. But high winds pushed apart ice that had blocked the Mirnyy harbor, leaving a path for a ship that will take them to New Zealand. Soviet Antarctic officials in Leningrad told Cathy DeMoll, the expedition's manager in Paris, that unless conditions change, loading of the ship will begin Monday. The wind was howling at 70 mph and the temperature was 20 below zero when Funatsu left a Soviet mobile home where he was meeting with a French film crew Thursday, spokeswoman Jennifer Gasperini said from Minnesota. When Funatsu did not arrive back in his tent for dinner, team members tied themselves together and searched the area for several hours before giving up because of darkness, Gasperini said. The search resumed early Friday, and Funatsu was found about two hours later, she said. Etienne said that when expedition members passed Funatsu calling ``Keizo! Keizo! Keizo!'' he ``jumped out like a mushroom from the snow. He was in very good shape.'' ``He had survived by digging a hole in the snow and crawling inside, just as the dogs do each night to stay warm,'' said Gasperini, who received the news from support staff.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Kaifu Pledge to Intensify Efforts to Reduce Deficit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 20th graf with need to reduce budget deficit
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu concluded their desert summit Saturday with no breakthrough on divisive trade issues but mutual promises to redouble efforts for resolving disputes. Kaifu said ``I am determined to firmly tackle'' the underlying causes of the $49 billion trade deficit with the United States and other economic conflicts. ``Make no mistake about it, I want to see that deficit come down,'' Bush said, standing alongside Kaifu under a blazing sun near a lush golf course at a country club where they held two days of talks. Despite the contentious problems, the two leaders went out of their way to show personal warmth and friendship. Bush called the prime minister ``Toshiki, my friend,'' and the Japanese leader referred to the president three times as ``George.'' Despite the lack of any major agreements, the upbeat tone of the talks could give a political boost to Kaifu, who lacks a broad base of support in his party. ``May you have great success in your efforts in the coming months,'' Bush said. ``You have our full support.'' During the discussions, Bush and Kaifu reviewed a wide range of issues from the advance of democracy in Eastern Europe to U.S. forces in the Pacific. But America's $49 billion trade deficit with Japan occupied centerstage at the hastily arranged meeting. Kaifu agreed that the trade deficit was ``still very large and we should continue to work harder.'' Kaifu said that working to open Japanese markets to American goods would be a top priority of his new government. ``I told the president of my determination to maintain such policies as expansion of domestic demand, improvement of market access and deregulation,'' Kaifu said. He added that both he and Bush had agreed to make ``maximum efforts for the early solution'' of the trade dispute. But neither he nor Bush mentioned any new proposals that had been advanced. Bush, speaking at a press conference right after Kaifu's departure, said the two sides did not need ``new ideas. We just need new energy on both sides.'' Asked if he thought the talks could produce enough Japanese movement to avoid possible trade sanctions, Bush said, ``I hope so, but I don't know. I think it depends on results.'' Assessing Kaifu's commitment for progress, Bush said, ``Nobody ever goes far enough to do everything exactly the way we want but ... we got everything out of this meeting that we had hoped for.'' Both leaders promised to press forward with negotiations aimed at resolving a variety of divisive trade disputes. And Bush said his top Cabinet officials dealing with trade matters would be ``on the next plane to Tokyo'' if that would aid the talks. The Japanese, he said, understood the sense of urgency with which the United States views the problem. Speaking to reporters before leaving for Japan, Kaifu called the next few months of negotiations ``extremely important'' although he cautioned that some of America's demands for the removal of trade barriers would be difficult to accomplish. ``We have to be clear about what things will take time, what we can accomplish and if it turns out that something is impossible, we need to explain why,'' Kaifu said. Both leaders also said the United States has to reduce its $152 billion budget deficit. On other issues, Bush said, ``No matter where we look around the world _ from Eastern Europe to Panama to Cambodia _ the United States and Japan are working together to promote political economic transformations that will strengthen democracies and market economies. He praised Kaifu for agreeing to provide almost $2 billion in assistance to Poland and Hungary and said the two had discussed ways to ``expand even further our global partnership.'' Kaifu said he told Bush that Japan would look into economic assistance for Central America, specifically Nicaragua and Panama. Bush said he reaffirmed to Kaifu that the United States would remain a Pacific power, and Kaifu indicated he agreed with that decision. Before the leaders met, Secretary of State James A. Baker III conferred separately with Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama. Baker promised that the administration would resist protectionist sentiment in the United States but warned there are growing pressures for sanctions against Japan unless trade frictions cool, Japanese officials said. Going into the discussions, Kaifu said action by Japan was ``absolutely necessary.'' His comment was seen as a positive response to U.S. demands for progress in talks aimed at attacking the underlying causes of America's $49 billion annual trade deficit with Japan, and negotiations on trade disputes involving satellites, supercomputers and lumber. U.S. officials said they did not expect any breakthrough on specific trade differences but hoped for a commitment from Kaifu for action. The two leaders met at a posh country club surrounded by mountains in this famous desert community, home to celebrities ranging from Bob Hope to former President Gerald Ford. Bush was the weekend guest of millionaire publisher Walter Annenberg. The hastily arranged two days of talks were aimed at defusing growing economic tensions that threaten to erode close political and security ties between the two countries. Relations between the world's two largest economic powers have been strained deeply by Japan's massive trade surpluses, amounting to nearly $400 billion over the last decade, and surging Japanese purchases of property and businesses in America. Moreover, there are persistent complaints about Japan's exclusionary business practices. Congress, facing election-year pressures, has imposed deadlines for talks on a dozen issues ranging from forest products to supercomputers and even the basic cultural foundations of the two societies. For its part, Japan wants the United States to reduce its huge budget deficit and increase Americans' savings rate, thus reducing demands for Japanese imports. Kaifu said before the talks concluded that there are some structural areas where Japanese action is ``absolutely necessary'' _ such as high land prices in Japan _ ``but we must have the cooperation and understanding (of the Japanese people) on these issues.'' Shigeo Takenaka, deputy spokesman for the Japanese foreign ministry, said both sides acknowledged they faced ``difficult issues'' on economic conflicts. To solve these issues, he said, ``we must continue to strengthen cooperation in other areas,'' such as aiding Latin American nations and the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, sent Bush a letter urging him to ``press (Kaifu) with all the formidable persuasion at your command to open the Japanese market.'' Friday's session was devoted to security issues. The United States is considering reducing its 120,000 troops in Asia by about 10 percent _ or about 5,000 troops in Japan. Washington also is pressing Tokyo for a sizable increase in Japan's $2.4 billion annual support for American troops stationed in the country. Last May, the United States put Japan on a ``hit list'' for alleged unfair barriers to American wood products, satellites and supercomputers. The administration has until June 16 to negotiate a removal of the barriers. If negotiations fail, the administration can impose retaliatory tariffs, which Japan argues would violate international trade law. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., and the chairman of a Senate trade subcommittee, prepared legislation that would force the administration to retaliate if there is no progress by June 16.

DOC.HEAD: Demolition of Lenin Statue Begins, But It's Not Easy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with workers giving up for night; pickup graf 8 pvs `Popescu said...'
DOC.TEXT: Authorities began to demolish Bucharest's imposing statue of Vladimir Lenin on Saturday, but after 10 hours of work it was clear he wasn't going without a fight. A pneumatic drill, blow torch and wrecking ball had little immediate effect on the 25-foot-tall, 7-ton bronze statue. ``He doesn't want to leave us,'' joked Florin Badinici, a member of the governing Provisional Council of National Unity as he watched the effort. The council, which is acting as a mini-parliament until national elections scheduled for May 20, voted Friday night to tear down the statue _ a symbol of 45 years of Communist rule that ended in December with a bloody revolution that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Hundreds of people clapped and cheered as workers hammered away at the statue in front of the massive, Stalinist-style state publishing house in the recently renamed Free Press Square. The workers vowed to stay through the night if necessary to remove the Lenin. ``Everyone wants to have it down right away,'' said Dan Popescu, an engineer supervising the removal. However, they abandoned their work for the night about 10:30 p.m. with the statue still standing. A few people tossed yellow paint at it as the workers left. Popescu said authorities originally planned to tear down the statue Monday but changed their minds due to public pressure and because a Romanian Orthodox priest had begun a hunger strike until the statue was removed. ``We have been improvising, but even we didn't expect this to be that hard,'' he said. ``Lenin is planted very well here.'' Popescu's firm, Combinatul Fondului Plastic, installed the statue in 1960. ``Right now, we are ashamed,'' he admitted. The pink marble base of the statue was covered with blue graffiti reading ``Down with the statue.'' Children scrambled for chunks of marble loosened by the workers. The statue depicts Lenin holding his cap and the lapel of his overcoat and staring into the distance down a broad avenue toward Bucharest's Arch of Triumph, a rough imitation of the French monument, built in 1922 to commemorate Romanian unity. Authorities said they had not decided what they would do with the statue. Throughout the day, Bucharest citizens stopped to gape as cables from a crane were looped under the statue's arms and workers blasted away at Lenin's feet with blow torches and a drill. A crane swung a small wrecking ball into Lenin's arm, causing him to shake slightly. ``I'm very glad,'' said Ion Ionescu, 59, watching the demolition. Asked his opinion of Lenin, he glared and said, ``I've been working for 40 years and I was able to buy only one car.'' ``I didn't have holidays or days off,'' Ionescu added. Fathers hoisted children to their shoulders to watch. A demolition worker standing in front of the statue monkeyed Lenin's pose at one point, provoking laughter. ``I'm really glad Lenin is taking off,'' said Mayor Dan Predescu, supervising the demolition. ``In his place we're going to have a real work of art.''

DOC.HEAD: Armenian, Azerbaijani Delegations Agree to Discuss Peace
DOC.TEXT: Armenian and Azerbaijani representatives agreed Saturday to begin talks about peace between their republics but set aside the territorial dispute at the center of the violence, an independent journalist said. Delegates from unofficial groups in the two southwestern republics met in the neighboring republic of Georgia, said journalist Kviria Dali. She said they agreed the two sides should debate a temporary settlement, but they excluded the issue of the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh enclave. Azerbaijan has staunchly resisted Armenian demands that it turn over control of predominantly Armenian Nagorno-Karabakh to Armenia. Ms. Dali, a journalist for an independent Georgian news agency Matsne, said the sides agreed the proposal from Azerbaijan should be presented to people in both republics for study. The sides agreed to continue their talks in two months, she said. The journalist said both sides accused Moscow of igniting the ethnic conflict that broke out in February 1988. Several hundred people have been killed and thousands have fled their homes since then. Azerbaijani delegates said the representatives should ``temporarily freeze territorial complaints until the fulfillment of genuine independence of both of these republics in the name of peace between the two peoples,'' Ms. Dali said. Delegates represented groups such as the People's Front of Azerbaijan and the Constitution Right and National Self-Determination groups from Armenia. None has official powers, but the strength of unofficial political organizations has increased rapidly in the Soviet Union as central authority has weakened. Talks between representatives of the Armenian and Azerbaijani people's fronts in the Baltic republic of Latvia broke down more than a month ago after renewed fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Restates Opposition to New Settlements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also includes Bush remarks on Panama, hostages and Annenberg gift to United Negro College Fund.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Saturday aid to Israel will be influenced by whether Tel Aviv allows new settlements in the West Bank and Gaza strip. ``We do not believe there should be new settlements in the West Bank or in East Jerusalem,'' Bush told a news conference after meeting with Japan's Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. ``I will conduct that policy as if it is firm. ``And I will be shaped in whatever decisions we make to see whether people comply with that policy.'' The president had been asked about Secretary of State James A. Baker's statement that U.S. aid to Israel would be conditioned on a halt to Jewish settlement of the Israeli-occupied territory. Baker told a congressional committee Thursday that $400 million in loan guarantees to help build housing for Soviet Jewish emigrants should be linked to Israeli promises it not be used for new or expanded settlements in the occupied territories. Israel says it has no policy of directing immigrants to the occupied territories, and government leaders denounced Baker's proposal Friday. Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters Saturday that the president's statements represented nothing new. He said Bush himself has told Shamir two times that new settlements must end in the occupied territories. But when Bush, and later Fitzwater, were asked directly whether the United States is linking aid to the settlement question, they seemed reluctant to put it specifically in those terms. ``I will just simply reiterate that the policy right here _ we are not going to look favorably upon new settlements,'' said Bush. ``We haven't expressed it in that policy sense directly,'' said Fitzwater. ``We don't believe the settlements in the West Bank and Gaza are conducive to the peace process.'' Bush was also asked about reports that Israel's Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has agreed to consider Baker's proposal for makeup of a Palestinian delegation in preliminary peace talks. However, diplomatic sources in Washington said no such decision has been made. On other topics, Bush said: _ An explosion in a Panama nightclub that wounded 27 people ``seems to be a terroristic action ... The process of democratization is still strongly popular in Panama, so I don't know what that was even about. But if it was some protest against democracy, so be it. But it must be condemned by all.'' _ A pending $50 million philanthropic contribution by publishing magnate Walter Annenberg, with whom Bush is staying in Rancho Mirage, is ``a wonderful thing.'' Annenberg was to donate the sum Sunday to the United Negro College Fund, one of Bush's favorite charities. _ There is no truth to reports that French intermediaries are working on behalf of the administration to free the Americans held hostage in Lebanon.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with new report that Shamir has not given final position, Bush reax; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A majority of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud Cabinet ministers Saturday reacted favorably to a U.S. compromise for choosing Palestinians for peace talks with Israel, Israel radio reported. Acceptance of the compromise by hard-line Likud ministers would be a major step forward in efforts to start a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue in Cairo, Egypt. Shamir's close ally, Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, presented the U.S. proposal to a meeting of nine Likud ministers, but a final vote was put off until Monday, said Shamir spokesman Yossi Ahimeir. ``There were points that were supported. There were other points which were viewed with suspicions,'' Ahimeir told reporters after the four-hour meeting. Israel Television reported during the meeting that Shamir had endorsed the U.S. proposals. Ahimeir declined comment on that report, but he said Shamir had not expressed an opinion at the meeting. The state radio reported that most of the Likud ministers, including Arens, favored the compromise solution. Environment Minister Roni Milo said he expected the issue to come to a vote in the decision-making, 12-member inner Cabinet later this week. Under the proposal by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Israel would agree in principle to delegates chosen from Palestinians who are officially registered as residents of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The compromise would allow inclusion of Palestinians who had been deported by Israel as well as residents of occupied lands who worked or had apartments in Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem. Asked about the reports that Shamir might be ready to accept the U.S. plan, President Bush said Saturday he had no details. ``But I hope it's true, and I hope we can move forward,'' he said at the news conference in Rancho Mirage, Calif. The issue of Palestinian representation has been the main sticking point in Middle East peace efforts. Likud hard-liners have staunchly opposed including deportees and east Jerusalem residents, saying such acceptance would endanger Israel's claim to Jerusalem as its unified capital. Palestinians have insisted their 10-member negotiating team include representatives from east Jerusalem, which they want as the capital of a Palestinian state. They also demand delegates to represent the 3 million Palestinians who live abroad. If agreement is reached, it would clear the way for Baker to convene a meeting with the foreign ministers of Egypt and Israel to discuss the proposed delegates on a name-by-name basis. Israel would have the right to reject candidates. Saturday's reports did not address another sticking point, however: the agenda for preliminary talks. Shamir has demanded it be limited to his plans for elections in the occupied territories. Palestinians want an open agenda. The elections would be held to allow Palestinians to choose representatives to negotiate an interim self-government plan for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied lands. Palestinians have been waging a 27-month-old uprising against Israeli rule. The hard-line Shamir has been under pressure from Washington and from members of the left-of-center Labor Party, Likud's partner in the coalition government, to accept a compromise so talks can begin. Israel army radio reported Saturday that Baker told Israeli Cabinet Minister Yitzhak Peretz during a meeting last week that if Shamir rejected the latest U.S proposal, Washington would drop its mediating efforts and blame Israel for the failure of Middle East peace efforts. Baker told a U.S. House subcommittee on Thursday that ``we have done pretty much all we can do, we think, from our end, and we are waiting for a response from the Israeli government.''

DOC.HEAD: Walter Annenberg Gives $50 Million to United Negro College Fund
DOC.TEXT: Publishing tycoon Walter H. Annenberg has pledged $50 million to the United Negro College Fund, saying he hoped the donation would raise the educational aspirations of young black people. The gift was scheduled to be announced Sunday at Annenberg's estate, where President and Mrs. Bush are weekend guests. It would be the largest contribution ever to black colleges. Asked about the donation Saturday, Bush, who described himself as a longtime supporter of the fund, used his best-known label for private charity in saying he hoped the gift would inspire others to donate. ``Our administration has stepped up support for historically black colleges and universities, the endowment concept there. And I think that generosity ... is a challenge ... that will bring on well-deserved support from others,'' the president said. ``It's most generous and one of the most brilliant thousand points of light I can think of.'' In a statement prepared for the Sunday presentation, Annenberg said black colleges are a ``major force for positive change ... As a society, we cannot afford to waste our most valuable resources _ our citizens.'' Comedian Bill Cosby made the largest contribution to a black college when he donated $20 million in 1987 to Spelman College in Atlanta. The United Negro College Fund, a consortium of 41 private black colleges, raised $45.8 million last year for distribution to its member institutions. The gift by Annenberg, 82, a former ambassador to Great Britain and former owner of TV Guide, would be one of the largest contributions to higher education in this country. The largest gift to a single institution was in the late 1970s when Robert W. Woodruff, former chairman of the Coca-Cola Company, gave $105 million to Emory University in Atlanta. ``Unless young blacks are brought into the mainstream of economic life they will continue to be on the curbstone. The key to this problem is education,'' Annenberg told the Los Angeles Times, which reported the donation plans Saturday, as did The New York Times. ``Black colleges have got to be supported,'' Annenberg said. ``The entire country has to get behind this. Foundations, corporations and private citizens. We can't just leave this for the government to do.'' In a prepared statement, Christopher Edley, president of the fund, said, ``Words cannot do justice to my feelings of gratitude.'' Annenberg's gift is the lead contribution to the United Negro College Fund's fourth capital drive, which seeks to raise $540 million for scholarships, capital expenses and faculty development. President Bush is honorary chairman of the drive. The fund was established in 1944 and has raised more than $650 million since then. The fund is well known for its motto: ``A mind is a terrible thing to waste.'' Annenberg, former owner of TV Guide and other publications, has donated $26.5 million to the University of Southern California and the USC School of Communications bears his name, as does a school at the University of Pennsylvania. Annenberg, who served as ambassador from 1969 to 1974, built his father's company, Triangle Publications Inc., into a successful conglomerate. He founded Seventeen and TV Guide, and bought the Philadelphia Daily News in 1957. In 1988, he sold Triangle for $3 billion to Rupert Murdoch.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Reform: The Limits of Thatcherism? ^Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Mrs. Thatcher's...' to ADD protests Saturday; pickup 6th graf pvs, `Since most...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's crusade to bury socialism has hit its most serious obstacle yet. Having decimated organized labor, boosted share ownership and denationalized vast chunks of state-owned industry, the prime target in Mrs. Thatcher's third term was to be the socialist bastions of local government. But the tax reform Mrs. Thatcher devised for the war on the local front _ combined with inflation of 8 percent and record interest rates of 15 percent _ has helped foment a rebellion. A Gallup poll published Friday put the Conservatives 18.5 points behind the opposition Labor Party, their worst showing in nearly 20 years. On Saturday, thousands of protesters _ many self-described Tory voters _ marched noisily in demonstrations around the country. The peaceful demonstrations _ in Plymouth, Taunton, Bristol and Manchester _ included families pushing strollers and senior citizens carrying ``No Poll Tax'' placards. Mrs. Thatcher's idea seemed simple initially: Instead of having homeowners pay varying amounts of taxes on their property, have local councils estimate their annual expenses, then divide the costs equally among all adults in the district. Since most local councils are run by socialists, and since socialists are big spenders, the voters will quickly discover the cost of electing socialists, Mrs. Thatcher reasoned. The new tax, formally known as a community charge, thus became known as the poll tax. The government figured that under the new system, which took effect this year, each adult would pay about $472. Instead, as amounts are announced, the average is shaping up to be $630, and surveys show most households will pay one-third more than under the previous system. Mrs. Thatcher insists that this is due to socialist profligacy, and she accuses councils of exploiting the tax reform to rake in cash. But high charges have also been levied in Conservative-run districts. A survey in The Times of London on Friday showed that community charges in only 3 of 69 local councils were close to the $472 estimate. Most showed increases of 30 percent to 50 percent over last year. On Wednesday, 18 of the 25 Conservatives who controlled the West Oxford District Council resigned to protest having to charge $700 this year, instead of a planned $430. The disillusioned Tories blamed reductions in central government grants and higher wage and welfare bills. Reductions of up to 80 percent of community charges are available to students, the unemployed, low-income pensioners and others. But at the same time, the reform means that a single person in an eight-bedroom apartment will pay less than a couple living next door in three rooms, since each taxable adult must pay the same amount. The Duke of Westminster, the richest man in Britain, previously paid $17,415 property tax on his estate. His community charge is $709, the same as his resident chauffeur and housekeeper must pay. ``I won't pay,'' said Sheila Jackson, a Conservative voter whose husband earns $240 a week as a plasterer in the south England coastal town of Weymouth. ``We want to pay to our way, we've worked to improve ourselves ... but now this government just makes it impossible,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``Perhaps this is a case of her (Mrs. Thatcher) being in power too long. I'm ashamed I voted Tory.'' The Jacksons paid $555 last year in property taxes, but this year they face a community charge of $1,140. Mrs. Thatcher is being blamed by worried rank-and-file Conservative lawmakers, gleeful Laborites and swaths of voters in the Tory heartlands of southern England. The media routinely refer to the community charge as ``the issue that could cost the Tories the next election.'' ``We will have to think again,'' said lawmaker Sir Marcus Fox, deputy chairman of the powerful 1922 committee of rank-and-file Tory members of Parliament. ``From the prime minister downward, I think we all now know we have a major problem.'' The next election is not due until 1991 or 1992, and Mrs. Thatcher has time to quiet the controversy by pouring in government money to cushion the hardest hit districts. So far she has adamantly insisted that the community charge is a fairer system and will not be changed.

DOC.HEAD: Jiang Urges ``Common Ground'' But Defends Tiananmen Actions
DOC.TEXT: The head of China's Communist Party says the massacre of protesters in Tiananmen Square last June should not stand in the way of economic and cultural cooperation with the United States. ``If both sides face realities and make efforts to remove the misunderstandings, which have not been created by us, we will have broad prospects in the future,'' Jiang Zemin, general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, told U.S. News & World Report. ``I suggest that we look forward and try to find common ground,'' he said in the interview, appearing in the March 12 issue. ``In such fields as economic exchanges, cultural contacts and other areas there is still a lot of room for more cooperation.'' But Jiang emphasized: ``We do not regret, or criticize ourselves for the way we handle, the Tiananmen event. ``We believe it to be an internal affair while the U.S. is saying that we have gone against U.S. values and the American view of human rights.'' Jiang said continuing tensions with the United States resulted from ``a big misunderstanding'' created by inaccurate media accounts and a limited perspective on the part of the U.S. government and people. Jiang, who became party chief last June amid international condemnation of the Chinese government's actions, said his government would continue to welcome foreign investment and open the country to the outside world. ``Because business is not based only on one track, you have to take the long-term view,'' said Jiang. Continued economic development in his country would help change U.S. and international opinion of China, he said. The government also would gradually move away from the egalitarianism associated with socialist economic enterprises, Jiang said, by stepping up its policy of incentive and bonus pay. Jiang said it was contradictory for the United States to criticize China's use of troops in Tiananmen Square while saying it understood why the Soviet Union sent troops to quell riots between ethnic groups in Azerbaijan and Armenia. Additionally, he criticized the U.S. invasion of Panama and capture of Manuel Noriega as ``a manifestation of power politics.''

DOC.HEAD: Political Demonstration Leaves 33 Police Injured
DOC.TEXT: Left- and right-wing demonstrators rioted in a Hamburg park Saturday, injuring 33 police and an undetermined number of demonstrators, a city official said. According to Werner Hackmann, Hamburg's city official for the interior, said the rioting began when police tried to stop about 2,000 leftist demonstrators of the Anti-fascist Coordination group from approaching a small group of skinhead youths in a downtown park. Some demonstrators on both sides attacked the 1,500 police officers on hand with rocks and firework rockets, and police responded by using batons and water cannons, Hackmann said. Witnesses accused the police of strong-arm tactics, but Hackmann said the officers had ``prevented much worse happening.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese `Satanic Verses' Nearly Sold Out
DOC.TEXT: Printers of the Japanese translation of ``The Satanic Verses'' said Saturday the controversial book has nearly sold out in half a month because of heavy demand and they plan to print another edition. A Shinsen Co. official said the 15,000 copies the company has printed are almost gone. ``We will publish another 5,000 copies on March 10 because of the continuing orders,'' he said on condition of anonymity. Many major bookstores will not display the book, however. ``Along with some other bookstores, we still are refraining from selling the book openly,'' said an official of Maruzen, a major Tokyo book dealer. The official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said Maruzen sells the book only through orders from customers. An official of Kinokuniya bookstore, another major book dealer with 30 branches nationwide, said there was ``no change in our policy of not displaying the book.'' Gianni Palma, the Italian publisher of the Japanese translation, was attacked by an angry Moslem during a news conference in Tokyo on Feb. 14 announcing the publication of the Japanese translation. Palma ducked and was unhurt when the 30-year-old Pakistani tried to hit him. The Pakistani was subdued by security officers and journalists covering the news confernce, held at the Foreign Correspondents Club of Japan. Moslems say the the book blasphemes their religion by depicting the prophet Mohammed's wifes as prostitutes. On Feb. 14, 1989, late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini urged Moslems to kill Salman Rushdie, the book's author. Rushdie has been in hiding in Britain ever since.

DOC.HEAD: Iran's President Pledges Reform After Protests
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Saturday promised economic reform and called for boosting industrial production to ease economic hardship that has prompted protests, according to news reports. Rafsanjani's office also set up a 24-hour hot line to handle complaints in the face of public frustration after a decade of economic troubles, revolutionary turmoil and an eight-year war with Iraq. Iranians are contending with soaring inflation, shortages of almost all basic commodities and high unemployment _ all in part due to the war with Iraq. A cease-fire was reached in August 1988. Tehran Radio, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Rafsanjani as saying Saturday: ``The only solution for economic problems and revitalizing the society is to increase production.'' Speaking to managers of state-run industries, most of which are operating at a loss, he said: ``We do not have political, cultural or military difficulties currently. Our difficulties are mostly from a shortage of production.'' Sources in Tehran reported a number of angry protests last week caused by popular resentment over continued economic hardship. The Mujahedeen Khalq, an opposition group, claimed security forces killed several hundred protesters. There has been no independent confirmation of that claim. Rafsanjani blamed high prices on middle-men, saying they take advantage of the government's foreign exchange shortfall to import goods and sell them at exorbitant prices. He acknowledged that keeping the Iranian rial artificially inflated at 70 to the dollar was at the root of the economic problem. The price of imported goods, when converted into rials, are prohibitively expensive and beyond the reach of most of Iran's 55 million people. The government offers the goods at a much reduced price, at a loss to itself. The subsidized imports, however, are too small in number to meet growing demand. Rafsanjani said: ``It is not advisable to continue the past policy and provide all goods with the 70-rial exchange rate, even if there is sufficient foreign exchange to do so.'' He added that ``what will save the country is that consumer goods are produced inside the country, and are offered to the people at reasonable prices.'' He said the country's reliance on imported goods must be reduced. Rafsanjani said in January that factories were operating at 40 percent of capacity. Since his election July 28, he has tried to boost the private sector to increase investment and encourage foreign investment to revitalize the economy. But his efforts have been frustrated by anti-Western fundamentalist radicals in the Tehran hierarchy, who advocate a totally nationalized industry and oppose foreign investment. Rafsanjani has advocated the privatization of inefficient state industries, which account for most of the $1 billion deficit projected in the $57 billion budget for the coming year.

DOC.HEAD: Managua Archbishop Hopes Pope Can Visit Nicaragua Soon
With AM-Nicaragua-Transition
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic primate of Nicaragua said in an interview broadcast Saturday he will invite Pope John Paul II to visit as soon as the political situation settles down. Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, archbishop of Managua, also told Vatican Radio the country's bishops want the Sandinistas to turn over all power to the new government in line with the ``will of the people'' shown in the elections last Sunday. He referred to the issue of relinquishing power over the country's security forces. John Paul made a 10-hour visit to Nicaragua in 1983. Sandinista supporters shouted political slogans, disrupting his Mass, and President Daniel Ortega greeted him with a tirade against U.S. imperialism. ``As soon as things return to normal, we will inform the pope of our desire. We hope that with all of his pastoral duties, he will be able to accept our invitation,'' Obando y Bravo said. ``We have great affection for him and infinite gratitude and know that the seeds of his visit have given abundant fruit.'' The cardinal, who has been a frequent critic of the Sandinistas, also spoke of a meeting he held with Ortega after the elections and said the Sandinista leader confirmed he would turn power over to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the United National Opposition. Obando y Bravo said Ortega mentioned the need for ``guarantees'' regarding the interior and defense ministries. The cardinal didn't elaborate but transition talks now under way are centered on control of the country's army and security forces. The Sandinista's don't want to give up control of those forces until the U.S.-supported Contras guerrillas disband.

DOC.HEAD: California Governor Signs 15-Day Wait for Long Guns
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Deukmejian signed a bill Saturday to require people buying rifles and shotguns to wait 15 days for a background check, saying it would ``keep more guns out of the hands of people who shouldn't have them.'' ``This new law will give peace officers an added tool in their courageous efforts to protect us from violence,'' the governor said. ``It will help save the lives of many innocent victims. And it represents a common sense approach to dealing with the criminal element in our society.'' Deukmejian announced in his weekly radio speech that he had signed the bill. The sponsor of the measure, Assemblyman Lloyd Connelly, said California is the first state to require a waiting period for police background checks for both pistol and long-gun sales. The new law, beginning Jan. 1, 1991, requires buyers of rifles and shotguns to wait 15 days and undergo the same background check that purchasers of handguns now have. The new law also expands the list of people who cannot buy a gun. The bill received impetus in January 1989 when drifter Patrick Purdy used a military-style assault rifle to kill five Stockton school children and wound 29 other children and a teacher. Connelly's bill was defeated in the Senate in September, but was given a second chance this month. Lawmakers were moved by the December killing of two children by their father 15 minutes after he bought a shotgun at a Yuba City sporting goods store and the January killing of a Sacramento woman by her estranged husband 40 minutes after he bought a shotgun.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Chairman Says Company Can Withstand Strike
With AM-Greyhound Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound has salted away millions of dollars to withstand the walkout by its bus drivers, Chairman Fred G. Currey said Sunday. Currey predicted the strike would be come irrelevant by the end of March, if it lasts that long, because the company expects to hire enough replacement drivers to run all its routes. The company already has enough drivers to operate half its runs, and has been overwhelmed with applications by people seeking to replace striking drivers, said Currey, who heads the only nationwide bus company. Currey said Greyhound would survive because it provides a needed service, and pays well enough to attract quality employees. Currey deplored the violence, including the death of a striker, that has marred the strike. ``I abhor it. It think it's nonsense; I think it's immature,'' Currey said in an interview. Greyhound was running at 25 percent Saturday, Currey said, and would be adding more runs each day, reaching full strength by the end of the month. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, representing all 6,300 drivers, plus more than 3,000 office and maintenance workers, went on strike Friday after the two sides failed to reach agreement over wage issues. Currey said 1,800 union-covered employees were at work Saturday, including 350 union drivers. Another 700 newly hired permanent replacement drivers were on board, with an additional 300 expected to join the force next week. ``We can operate 100 percent of our system this time of year with about 2,500 drivers, so 1,000 ... is enough to operate 50 percent of our route system after we get them evenly distributed across the country,'' Currey said. ``That's bogus,'' said union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson, when asked about Currey's count of union members at work. Although Nelson couldn't provide hard figures, he said union officials believe fewer than 10 percent of Greyhound's buses were running. Currey led an investment group that paid $270 million for Greyhound in 1987, then bought Trailways Lines Inc. four months later for $80 million. Prior to the buyout, the drivers union agreed to a 22 percent wage cut, but Currey said Greyhound drivers remain the highest paid in the industry. Although laden with debt, including about $340 million in long-term obligations, Currey said Greyhound had accumulated enough cash to withstand the walkout. He would not reveal how much was earmarked, but said one report of $54 million was ``a conservative'' estimate. ``If he's got so much to cushion against a strike, why isn't he prepared to pay drivers,'' asked Nelson, the union spokesman. Currey said money spent dealing with the strike could endanger a $100 million capital improvement program scheduled for the next three years, including upgrading buses and terminals. Last year, Greyhound earned its first small profit since Currey bought the company _ $730 million on $1 billion in sales. In the previous two years, Greyhound lost a total $20 million. Currey said the company had modified some of its original contract proposals without changing the $63 million, three-year package. The union has maintained the company never moved from its original position. Meanwhile, Currey said the company has asked federal courts in five cities to issue restraining orders against the strike's violence. Also, ``we've asked Ed Strait, the council president, in view of not only this (fatal) incident ... but violence in other places, to have the union join with us in going to the courts at every place we have employees to get a pre-emptive injunction ... to make certain that violators are dealt with as the criminals they are,'' Currey said. Union spokesman Nick Nichols denied that Strait had been contacted, but he repeated union calls for the walkout to be peaceful. A striking driver was killed in Redding, Calif., Saturday when a bus driven by a replacement driver was attempting to leave a terminal blocked by picketers. There also has been violence in Chicago, where shots were fired on a departing bus Friday morning, and in Philadelphia, where rocks were thrown.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb in Disco Wounds 16 Americans, 11 Panamanians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD Bush comment, INSERT 2 grafs after 13th graf pvs, `We ask...' Pickup 14th graf pvs, `Panamanian investigators...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAN1
DOC.TEXT: Two men yelling ``Long live Noriega!'' threw a grenade into a discotheque frequented by U.S. soldiers and wounded 27 people, including 16 American military men, witnesses and officials said Saturday. The attack late Friday was believed to be the first such raid on U.S. servicemen since the United States invaded Panama on Dec. 20 and overthrew the government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. One of the Americans was reported seriously injured. ``I heard something come in that broke the glass, hit the table and then I heard the explosion,'' said Eric Quintero, one of the wounded. ``There was a lot of confusion, people screaming ... people on the floor.'' ``There were people bleeding everywhere,'' he said. Witnesses said the grenade landed under a table, then exploded. It left a hole about half a yard in diameter in one of the disco's glass walls. Lisa McKay, who was outside the discotheque when the 11:30 p.m. attack occurred, said two men drove up, one got out and threw the bomb and they then sped away. The men yelled ```There goes Noriega! Long live Noriega!' and threw the grenade,'' she said. Another woman who was going into the disco at the time gave the same account. Panama's Judicial Technical Police, in charge of the investigation, gave no details, but an official said, ``It was against the gringos.'' He asked not to be identified. No one claimed responsibility for the attack, said Lt. Cmdr. Peggy Black, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Southern Command. Lt. Col. Terry Jones said one of the Americans was seriously injured. Thirteen others were being treated at the U.S. military's Gorgas Hospital and two were treated and released, he said. Three of the 11 wounded Panamanians had serious injuries and were in intensive care, a Social Security Hospital report said. It said six Panamanians were treated and released. Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, head of the Southern Command, appealed for help in finding those responsible. ``We ask Panamanian citizens to free their society of these types of terrorists and criminals. We must work together to bring these criminals to justice,'' Cisneros said during a meeting with Panamanian police. President Bush said the attack seemed to be a ``terroristic action. And it happens, regrettably, all around the world.'' ``The process of democratization is still strongly popular in Panama. So, I don't know what that was even about, but if it was some protest against democracy, why _ so be it,'' Bush said, adding that the attack must be condemned by all. Panamanian investigators and U.S. military police were inside the disco Saturday looking through the debris for evidence. American soldiers and Panamanian police guarded the building and kept onlookers and journalists away. The disco, My Place, known to be popular with American servicemen, is just off the busy Via Espana street and a block from the international banking center in Panama City. The attack occurred hours after Noriega's wife, three daughters and grandson left Panama for Havana. As they left Panama City, they were surrounded by hundreds of jeering people who shouted ``Go away beggars!'' Noriega is awaiting trial on drug charges in Miami, where he was taken after gaining refuge in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City days after U.S. invasion. He later surrendered to U.S. authorities. Officials of the new Panamanian civilian government installed at the start of the invasion have expressed concern that many weapons stockpiled by Noriega's Defense Forces around the country still have not been found. They say their locations are likely known to members of the Noriega's Dignity Battalions and other paramilitary groups Noriega organized. Some Dignity Battalion leaders have been arrested but most of the members appear to have returned to normal life in their communities. President Guillermo Endara expressed sadness over the grenade attack. ``It's truly lamentable that there are people so mentally sick that there is an act of such senseless violence, hurting innocent people,'' Endara told reporters. The Southern Command in Panama broadcast a warning over television telling U.S. servicemen and citizens to avoid discos, nightclubs, cafes, movie houses and other public places. But soldiers were not restricted to bases. The United States has about 13,500 troops in Panama, about the number stationed there before the invasion. In Washington, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, taping a Sunday talk show with CNN, said, ``Panama has been a violent place in the past and it is still obviously a problem,'' he said. ``You can't safeguard against every possible contingency. If somebody wants to to drive by someplace and toss a grenade, I guess that's a possibility. ``But again, we don't know what happened here _ whether this is an isolated act, whether it was part of some organized effort, whether it was a group or an individual. We just don't know enough yet to make those judgments.''

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Expects to Sign Pullout Accord in Week
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Gyula Horn said in an interview published Saturday he expected to sign an agreement in a week for the withdrawal of all Soviet forces from Hungary. Such an agreement would make Hungary the second East Bloc country to negotiate a pullout of Soviet forces on its territory. The Soviets began withdrawing the first of their 73,500 troops from Czechoslovakia earlier this week. ``All signs indicate that on March 10 we can sign the inter-governmental agreement and then get down to its implementation,'' Horn told the Socialist Party daily Nepszabadsag. Horn is scheduled to visit Moscow that day. Both sides in talks on the withdrawal of the estimated 50,000 Soviet troops in Hungary earlier had expressed optimism that agreement was likely by then. However, on Thursday, the head of the Hungarian delegation, Horn's No. 2 official at the Foreign Ministry, Ferenc Somogyi, said the two sides could not agree on a timetable. Somogyi said that ``in our estimate the pullout of the personnel and materiel can be completed by June 30, 1991.'' Soviet negotiator Col. Gen. Matvey Burlakov said Moscow needed an additional two months because of transport difficulties. In the same interview Saturday, Horn denied Hungary was considering leaving the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact alliance. Last month, Horn himself stirred speculation by suggesting it was ``not out of the question'' that Hungary could join the Western military alliance, NATO. But Saturday he was quoted as saying Hungary is ``not planning any steps which would create tensions within the Warsaw Pact, or which would dramatically put in question Soviet-Hungarian relations, and impair (Soviet leader Mikhail S.) Gorbachov's position.'' He did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Miss USA Says Beauty Is More Than Skin Deep
DOC.TEXT: Carole Gist downplays her place as the first black Miss USA. ``There is so much more to me than my blackness, the color of my skin,'' she said at a news conference Saturday, the morning after giving up her Miss Michigan-USA title to be crowned Miss USA 1990. Miss Gist, a 6-foot-tall, 20-year-old college student from Detroit, said she is part Cherokee. ``To tell you the truth, Miss Mississippi had a tan that was darker than me,'' Miss Gist said, drawing laughs from reporters and pageant officials at a news conference. Her fair skin color and her height drew taunts from classmates in grade school and junior high, she said. But being black helped her stand out among the blue-eyed blondes and brunettes in the pageant, she said. Miss Gist said she had a feeling a black contestant was going to win the contest. The contestants from the District of Columbia and Tennessee also were black. As the titleholder, she goes on to compete in the Miss Universe pageant in Hollywood on April 15. Five Miss USAs have gone on to win the Miss Universe crown. During her last two years in high school, she said she got her grade point average up to 3.8 and participated in choir and track. ``I had a volleyball scholarship, but I chose not to play volleyball because I wanted my nails. I didn't want to cut them off,'' she said. Raised by her mother, a legal secretary, Miss Gist said she got used to responsibility and hard work as a child. She said she was disappointed when she enrolled at Northwood Institute, a private college, and school officials would allow her to take only 17 hours of classes her first semester. Second semester she pushed her credit hours to 25. ``Never give up on your dreams,'' is the message she plans to carry to others during her reign. When she realized she had won title in a televised pageant here Friday night, Miss Gist put her hands together as if she was praying and looked up. She said Saturday she was thanking God. ``I felt truly blessed,'' she said. The first runner up was Miss South Carolina-USA, Gina Tolleson, 20, Spartanburg, S.C. The second runner up was Miss New Jersey-USA, Karin Hartz, 24, Voorhees, N.J. The new Miss USA gets $88,000 in cash plus prizes that bring her winnings to about $220,000. The other prizes include a car, a boat, furs, jewelry, camera equipment, gowns and a Los Angeles apartment.

DOC.HEAD: Government Revises Proposals to Quiet Unrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with ruling party revising pay cuts, proposing other reforms, new protests, key meeting postponed; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The ruling party Sunday trimmed proposed pay cuts that have caused unrest, but opposition leaders said President Felix Houphouet-Boigny has already lost public confidence with austerity measures. Leaders of the country's two unauthorized opposition parties called for elections, but suggested Houphouet-Boigny remain as a figurehead in this West African nation he has ruled since independence from France in 1960. Protesters demanding the downfall of 84-year-old Houphouet-Boigny accuse him of corruption, robbing state coffers and imposing austerity measures on the poor while government officials enjoy lavish lifestyles. Proposals to cut government workers' salaries by 15 percent to 40 percent and increase a tax on all wage earners from 1 percent to 11 percent have fueled increasing discontent. Also, a 10-year recession has provoked the worst economic crisis in Ivorian history. Student protesters have been joined by hundreds of civil servants and other workers who went on strike Friday. In a bid to quell the unrest, state radio Sunday said the Democratic Party's Political Bureau proposed that only Cabinet ministers and chairmen of state companies have their salaries cut by 40 percent. ``The other salaries will be relatively little affected by these reductions, while the very low salaries will be totally spared,'' said the ruling body of Ivory Coast's only authorized political party. It also proposed reducing prices of essential commodities, low-cost housing, electricity, water, fuel, school supplies and drugs. It said the statement was to reassure protesters involved in ``demonstrations, which some mischief-makers are trying to exploit, caused by lack of information of militants and people misled by all kinds of rumor-mongers.'' Protests that began in Abidjan on Feb. 19 and spread to at least six other towns in the past few days pose the stiffest challenge ever to confront the autocratic Ivorian leader. Protesters have reacted violently to soldiers and police who have dispersed peaceful demonstrators in Abidjan with tear gas and smoke and stun grenades. Demonstrators ransacked several stores in two Abidjan suburbs Friday and stoned cars and buses. The capital was calm Saturday. However, new protests involving stonings of buses, cars and shop windows were reported in the western towns of Diwo and Man. Unrest that began with similar complaints forced the military leader of nearby Benin, Brig. Gen. Mathieu Kerekou, to surrender political power Wednesday. Union opposition and mounting unrest forced Houphouet-Boigny to postpone three times a National Council meeting that previously has routinely endorsed his decisions. Friday night, the Democrats' Political Bureau announced it is indefinitely postponing the meeting. World Bank officials support Houphouet-Boigny's austerity proposals, saying there is little choice to resolve a liquidity crisis threatening payment of civil service wages. However, opposition leader Laurent Gbagbo, a historian who leads the Ivorian People's Front, said Houphouet-Boigny ``has his back against the wall'' and should call democratic elections. The president has ignored protesters' calls for a multiparty democracy, which he says endangers national unity on a continent divided by tribal rivalries. ``When I heard Houphouet-Boigny saying he was cutting salaries, I thought `He has gone mad,''' Gbagbo told reporters. ``He used to be very much in touch with the people and could have carried them with such proposals five years ago, but this shows he has lost touch.'' ``The people's misery cannot support ... pay cuts,'' Gbagbo said. Robert Bgai Tagro, a former civil servant who heads the Republican Party, proposed the government halt mandatory contributions to the ruling party by the country's 110,000 civil servants.

DOC.HEAD: Correspondence School Facing State, Federal Investigations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Investigators with...students,' to clarify that guaranty agencies trying to prevent defaults sted collect on loans. Pick up 13th graf, `Also, Florida's ...
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of mostly poor young women took out guaranteed student loans for a correspondence school they thought would train them for glamorous careers as travel agents. But only 20 percent of the 60,000 students at the American Career Training School graduated, and 90 percent were saddled with hefty loan bills for classes some said were nearly worthless, U.S. Senate investigators have found. The school, meanwhile, profited from $150 million in loans and the owners became overnight millionaires, said the investigators, who this week accused ACT of fraud in the first of a series of hearings on problems in the federal student loan system. ``It's just too much money being unaccounted for,'' said Grace T. McPhearson, investigator for the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee. The school, which trains travel agents and motel clerks through 20 home-study lessons and a three-week residential program, has built a recruiting network in 26 states. Its glossy pamphlets can be found in welfare offices and its ads in more than 100 newspapers and magazines, school officials said. ACT's ``campus'' is a two-story brick building, with classrooms full of computers, on a highway of outlet stores and fast-food restaurants a half-block from the Atlantic Ocean in Pompano Beach. Senate investigators say evidence shows ACT altered documents so that ineligible students could qualify for loans and to make it appear that dropouts received the refunds they demanded when in fact no money had been returned. The school's president and owner, Joseph A. Calareso, repeatedly refused to answer the subcommittee's questions Monday on the grounds that he might incriminate himself. Through his attorney, Eugene Propper, he denied the allegations and blasted the hearing as unfair. Calareso, a board member of the National Home Study Council, which accredited the school in 1985, also took steps to pre-empt further damaging publicity. He hired away the study council's director of student assistance, Phillip Rokicki, to solve his financial aid problems and deal with the media. ``Mr. Calareso has sent more than $1.25 million back to the agencies to correct the errors,'' Rokicki said this week. ``It was never his intention to defraud the government.''
