But the Department of Education's enforcement office has begun a criminal investigation into whether Calareso and his brother James committed fraud as they earned more than $12 million in salaries and dividends from the school in four years. Investigators with state loan guarantee agencies in Florida, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts are reviewing thousands of students' files in hopes of preventing defaults on more than $100 million in loans they backed for ACT's students. Also, Florida's Education Department is considering revoking ACT's license, and the National Home Study Council has put on hold its renewal of the accreditation ACT must have to qualify for federal loan money. Some 90 percent of ACT's students received federal loans to pay about $2,500 in tuition and rent for a room in one of the school's two hotels. But few managed to keep up with the program long enough to graduate, investigators said. Andrea M. Jones of Swansea, S.C., testified that the school insisted she was liable for the full amount of her $2,415 loan even though she dropped the course after claiming half the correspondence lessons weren't mailed to her. Rokicki says his records confirm the lessons were mailed to Ms. Jones. He admits some mistakes, such as delays in the return of unused tuition money to lenders, but says the school is trying to correct them. Andrea Lynn Merritts-West of New Smyrna Beach told the subcommittee that only when she began looking for jobs did she realize that the coursework _ in subjects such as basic typing, geography and airline reservation codes _ was hardly worth the cost. ``The manager of the agency told me that he could teach me more about the travel industry in just a few weeks than ACT teaches in their whole process,'' she said. Other students, who are paying $150 a week to share a room with three to four other women at one of the Calareso's hotels, praised the school this week. ``I could have got a job without coming here, but I can get a better job now that I came,'' said Heather, a student from Glens Falls, N.Y., who refused to give her last name. But Brenda Ann Brandon, a graduate who went on to handle student loans for ACT from 1985 until she quit in 1988, told the committee that the Calareso brothers didn't care about the financial burdens the school was placing on students. ``Joseph Calareso was not concerned about the school's default rate,'' she testified. ``He told me that if we could keep the volume of loans high enough and the loans spread out, it would take them forever to figure it out.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: A pet shop owner who wants to promote pricey pigs is squealing about a Denver zoning law banning ownership of the animals. Jon Cochran, owner of Pet City, says he gets four or five calls a month from people asking how they can get miniature pigs _ also called Vietnamese potbellied pigs. ``People are finally coming to the realization that there are things out there other than dogs, cats and hamsters,'' he says. Cochran raised the issue recently at a meeting of the city council's zoning committee. He was told to draft a formal proposal for changing the law banning pigs and present it March 21. ``Some of the council members thought it was ridiculous that we were even dicussing this,'' said senior city planner Merlin Logan. The potbellied pig, which sells for up to $6,000, is popular among those looking for a trendy pet. ``They're better than dogs,'' said Carolyn Sharp, who breeds miniature pigs in Fort Collins. ``They're not stinky. They don't have fleas. They don't bark, and they don't run around in packs annoying people.''

A 6-year-old dog named Booger Boy can receive $400 a month from his late owner's estate, a Superior Court jury has ruled. Two other beneficiaries of the will took the the dog, a chow, to court, but the dog won. When Booger Boy dies a natural death, the will of Martha Jane Dickie provides the estate will be divided among her eight human heirs. Meanwhile, Nelle Wilson of Chatsworth is given charge of Booger Boy, along with the dead woman's house and $400 per month to take care of the dog. The will specified that if any of the beneficiaries is involved in the dog's death, that person will be excluded from the will. Ms. Dickie died last June at the age of 70.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Landing Time Set _ if Weather Cooperates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with worsening wind conditions for landing time. Picks up 5th graf, `Weather has...'
DOC.TEXT: The secret military mission of the space shuttle Atlantis is set to end Sunday, but NASA said a storm front moving into Southern California would affect conditions at the landing site. Amateur observers said they had already spotted the shuttle's secret cargo in orbit. NASA broke a news blackout on the flight Saturday to announce that Atlantis would land at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., at 1:08 p.m. EST. ``Generally, the feeling is somewhat optimistic. It (the weather) is marginal, but we're going to have to look at it real-time,'' said NASA spokesman Steve Nesbitt. The wind was expected to gust up to 29 mph at landing time, with scattered clouds and seven-mile visibility, Nesbitt said Saturday night. Earlier in the day, forecasts called for wind gusting to 20 mph. ``That is a little beyond the gust limit,'' Nesbitt said. The storm front was expected to make conditions worse later in the day and ``it's even worse Monday,'' Nesbitt said. Weather has affected Atlantis' mission from the beginning. Four launch delays last week were caused by poor weather. A computer failure caused a fifth delay, one short of a record for shuttle missions. Atlantis' five-member, military crew spent most of Saturday preparing for the return to Earth, but because of the secret nature of their mission no details were released. Pam Alloway, Johnson Space Center spokeswoman, said shuttle crews routinely spend the day before a landing doing housekeeping chores and testing spacecraft systems. A two-sentence statement announcing the landing time also said: ``The crew is doing well and beginning landing preparations and the orbiter continues to perform satisfactorily.'' Atlantis was launched early Wednesday. NASA sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the astronauts released a $500 million spy satellite into orbit Thursday. Sources said the satellite is capable of taking high resolution photos and listening in on electronic communications around the world. According to sources, Atlantis' northeasterly launch, parallel to the East Coast, put it into an orbit farther north than any previous shuttle. That would have allowed the astronauts to place the satellite into an orbit that crosses parts of the Soviet Union never before observed by a craft launched by the shuttle. Though NASA and the Pentagon refused to give details, a network of amateur observers led by Ted Molczan of Toronto said they were able to see both the shuttle and the satellite in orbit. Molczan said in a telephone interview that an observer in Scotland saw Atlantis, appearing as a bright, fast-moving point of light, pass overhead early Friday. The shuttle was followed about a minute later by a smaller object that Molczan said apparently was the satellite. Later, around dawn over North America, Molczan said observers in Yellowknife, White Horse and Hay River, in Canada, and in Fairbanks, Alaska, reported sightings. ``For those sightings, the payload (satellite) came over at the time we predicted for the orbiter,'' said Molczan. ``The orbiter was seen earlier. This means that the orbiter had dropped into a lower orbit.'' Such a maneuver would put distance between the two craft since a lower object orbits faster. On a later pass over the observers, there was even more separation, he said. Molczan calculated that the satellite was in an orbit of 161 miles and the shuttle was at about 152 miles. ``The shuttle and the satellite are extremely bright,'' said Molczan. ``Brighter than any star.'' Atlantis' flight is the 34th shuttle mission and the sixth dedicated solely to the military. Navy Capt. John O. Creighton is the commander. Others in the crew are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Kills Five Children, One Adult After Birthday Celebration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with relationships of dead and injured men to children. Pick up 4th graf, `Several neighborhood . ..'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PG1
DOC.TEXT: A quick-moving house fire Saturday killed six people, including five young children spending the night together after a birthday party. One man was critically injured in the early-morning blaze that destroyed the three-story home about 10 miles east of Pittsburgh. Two neighbor children who stayed overnight after attending an eighth birthday party for Joshua Harris were killed, along with Joshua and two siblings, said Allegheny County homicide Lt. John Brennan. The injured man was a cousin of the Harrises and the dead man was a friend, authorities said. Several neighborhood children who left the party just after nightfall gathered near the burned remains of the home Saturday afternoon while firefighers cleared away debris. ``I finally made a good friend here, and now he's gone,'' Kevin Cook, 10, said. ``It's lucky we have something to remember him by,'' Richard Leiche, 5, said. ``We have the party invitation and the Batman toys we won for prizes during the games.'' The fire burned for about 1{ hours before firefighters brought it under control, authorities said. The blaze spread to houses on each side of the Harris home, but their residents were unhurt, police said. The cause was under investigation. In addition to Joshua, police tentatively identified the dead as James Bennett, 23; Carly Harris, 6; Jessie Harris, 4; Terrance Cleary, about 5; and Amanda Lee Cleary, about 3. The bodies were burned beyond recognition, hampering positive identification, the Allegheny County Coroner's Office said. A man tentatively identified as Ray Steele of Wilkinsburg was in critical condition Saturday at West Penn Hospital in Pittsburgh. Dusty Harris, 26, mother of the Harris children, was visiting neighbors when the fire began and saw the flames when she returned. ``There were 12 kids there, mostly school friends and kids from the neighborhood,'' said Michelle Loughner, a friend of Ms. Harris. ``The party was over about 7:30 p.m. and the kids were in bed by 9 p.m.'' The fire was reported at 2:15 a.m. Sharon Kelley, 37, who lives a half-block away, said she awoke just after the fire began. ``I heard a neighbor scream, and by the time I looked out, the whole front door was on fire,'' she said. ``My husband and another man tried to open one of their windows, but they couldn't _ too much smoke.'' Joshua turned 8 on Wednesday, but his mother delayed his party until the weekend. Turtle Creek Patrolman Frank Leonardo said he was driving nearby when the alarm sounded. ``As the call came in, I looked up and saw the fire on the hillside. When I arrived, a woman was screaming, `My babies are in there, my babies are in there.'''

DOC.HEAD: Endara Proposes Panamanian For Canal Administrator
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for LEAD to RESTORE AP logo, CORRECT dateline style; pickup graf 2 `Endara, in...'
DOC.TEXT: President Guillermo Endara on Saturday nominated a 60-year-old businessman to be the first Panamanian serving as permanent administrator of the Panama Canal. Endara, in his third day of a hunger strike to pressure the U.S. Congress for aid to his country, said he was recommending Gilberto Guardia Fabrega to the U.S. government for approval. ``He was chosen among several honorable candidates because in Panama there are many capable people, but he is the best of all. He has great experience, great honesty and civic and professional credentials,'' Endara said. No details on Guardia were immediately available. Under the 1977 Panama Canal Treaties, the U.S. government must approve Endara's nomination. Guardia would replace Fernando Manfredo, who President Bush appointed as interim administrator. Manfedo, the first Panamanian to run the shipping route since it began operations 75 years ago, took over Jan. 1 after the U.S. invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Family Arrives In Cuba
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with quote by Noriega's wife; pickup graf 9 pvs, `On Wednesday...'
DOC.TEXT: The family of deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega arrived Saturday in Havana after being granted safe passage by the Panamanian government, news reports said. Noriega's wife, three daughters and grandson were reported en route to the Dominican Republic, where they have been granted asylum in the Dominican Republic. Noriega's son-in-law is a citizen there. ``I'm grateful to the Cuban people and to President Fidel Castro for the hospitality they have given me,'' Noriega's wife, Felicidad Siero, was quoted by Cuba's official news agency Prensa Latina as saying in an interview on Cuban television. Presna Latina, which was monitored in Mexico City, said the Noriegas were met at Havana's airport by Miguel Brugueras, Cuba's assistant minister of foreign relations. There was no indication of when they would travel on to the Dominican Republic. The family had been staying at the Cuban ambassador's residence, where they sought refuge after the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion that overthrew Noriega. Noriega is awaiting trial on drug charges in Miami, where he was taken after surrendering to U.S. authorities. The family arrived at Panama City's airport Friday night surrounded by Cuban diplomatic personnel, then left for Havana on a Cubana de Aviacion flight. Hundreds of hecklers shouted ``Go away beggars!'' Some threw pennies at the Noriegas and said: ``This is to pay your husband's bail.'' The taunt was a reference to a comment by Noriega's wife that she would travel around Panama asking for donations for her husband's defense. On Wednesday, the Panamanian government said that it would allow safe passage out of the country for Mrs. Noriega, daughters Lorena, Thais, Sandra; Sandra's husband, Jean Rene Beauchamps, and the couple's 7-month-old son. Beauchamps, who was the only family member to stay behind, is to leave next week after discussing allegations of financial irregularities with authorities. He is to pay a $10,000 bond before leaving. Daughters Sandra and Lorena are accused of corruption, and Sandra paid a $50,000 bond to leave the country. The government granted safe conduct passes for the Noriegas on the condition that they would face extradition if they failed to return to face any charges.

DOC.HEAD: Beaker Explodes During Experiment, Injuring Children
DOC.TEXT: A scientist's beaker exploded during an experiment at a University of Illinois engineering laboratory Friday, injuring several children attending a campus open house. About 27 people suffered mostly minor injuries in the noon-time accident at the School of Engineering's Noyes Laboratory, authorities said. The beaker exploded when Steven S. Zumdahl, director of the university's general chemistry program, dripped molten iron into it to show the hot metal would cause the water to boil, said UI fire chief William Duckwitz. No chemicals were involved, and the demonstration had been performed safely in the past, officials said. Many of the injuries were cuts and abrasions, Battalion Chief Bob Walters of the Champaign Fire Department said. Most of the injured were children from an elementary school who were seated in the front row to observe the experiment, WCIA-TV reported.

DOC.HEAD: Fletcher Outlines Goals as Civil Rights Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Arthur A. Fletcher said Friday he hopes to make discrimination an insignificant part of American life during his tenure as chairman of the U.S. Civil Rights Commission. ``As a general mission I would like to see us set as an objective the goal of reducing discrimination to a level of insignificance,'' by creating an environment in which the ``so what?'' theory operates, said Fletcher. In that environment, Fletcher said he believed employers would examinine the qualifications, performance and competence of individuals without considering potential workers' gender, race, religion or disability. Fletcher said he envisioned employers saying ``so what?'' upon learning subsequently that qualified prospective employees were African-American, Hispanic, women or other minorities. Fletcher outlined the goal to members of the commission at the panel's first meeting of the year and its first since his appointment last month by President Bush. The commission, established in 1957, evaluates federal laws, monitors the government's equal opportunity programs and serves as a clearinghouse for civil rights information. Fletcher said the commission should once again become ``the recognized authority on civil rights matters.'' In November, Congress approved last-minute compromise legislation to extend the life of the commission for two years. The commission was criticized by civil rights groups and members of Congress for its positions, including opposition to affirmative action programs, during the Reagan administration. ``I would like to see this commission participate in causing economic opportunity to become the driving force behind the U.S. civil rights agenda,'' Fletcher said. Such an agenda would respond to an open, free market economy both domestically and internationallly, he said. ``I am convinced that our success or failure in that economy will rest squarely on how well we develop our human resources ... and the extent to which we let them perform at their peak performance level at the workplace and other places and reward them accordingly,'' he added. Fletcher, 65, a moderate black Republican who has served in three GOP administrations, also said he would work to restore bipartisanship to civil rights activity. ``Although the perception is that civil rights has been solely a Democratic Party enterprise, there was always the need for ... Republican votes,'' to pass civil rights legislation, he said. Also attending Friday's meeting were two other new commissioners appointed last month _ Virginia attorney Carl A. Anderson and Russell G. Redenbaugh, a blind Philadelphia business executive. There is one vacancy on the eight-member commission. The panel agreed its April meeting would be a two-day retreat focusing on restoring a colleagial atmosphere to the group. Under former chairman William B. Allen, who is still a commission member, the panel was marked by controversy and confrontation between he and other commissioners. A speech titled: ``Blacks? Animals? Homosexuals? What is a Minority?'' delivered by Allen to a conservative group was condemned by the commissioned as ``thoughtless, disgusting and unnecessarily inflammatory.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves Lochner Nomination to SEC
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Banking Committee on Friday approved the nomination of Philip R. Lochner Jr., deputy general counsel of Time Warner Inc., to a vacancy on the Securities and Exchange Commission. Lochner was nominated by President Bush in January to fill the unexpired term of David Ruder, the former SEC chairman who returned to teaching law at Northwestern University last year. Also confirmed by the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee were Arthur J. Hill, nominee for president of the Government National Mortgage Association, also known as Ginnie Mae, and John J. Adair, who was nominated to become the first inspector general of the Resolution Trust Corp. All three now await confirmation by the full Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Astronomers Report Finding New Dwarf Galaxy
DOC.TEXT: British astronomers, searching for quasars in far outer space, said Friday they believe they have stumbled across an undiscovered galaxy ``in our back yard.'' They said if their finding is confirmed, it is the first new galaxy discovered in 35 years. Richard McMahon of the Cambridge University Institute of Astronomy said he and colleague Michael Irwin discovered the very dim, dwarf galaxy, two weeks ago. He said they are doublechecking to make sure no one spotted it before. ``It's a bit like discovering a new planet; it's an exciting discovery,'' McMahon said. ``We usually work in a more distant part of the universe, and we pretty much assume that everything is already known about the vicinity of the Milky Way'' _ the galaxy around Earth. The scientists used a seven-ton, computerized laser machine that scans detailed photographic plates of space. ``After the plates are scanned, the data are computerized to look for more subtle variations,'' McMahon said. ``All the easy galaxies have been found by the eye; the machine finds the harder ones. The nearer ones are not so easy to see because the bright background of the Milky Way blurs the picture.'' The galaxy, named Sextans after the constellation where it was found, is the smallest of the 10 satellite galaxies of the Milky Way, the astronomers said in telephone interviews. The dwarf, spherical galaxy is 100,000 times fainter than the Milky Way and cannot be seen without a powerful telescope, they said. ``The sun is 30,000 light-years from the center of the Milky Way, and this particular galaxy is a factor of 10 farther out. The edge of the visible universe is about 15,000 million light-years away, so this is basically in our back yard,'' Irwin said. A light-year is the distance that light travels in a vacuum in one year. The scientists said they will follow up their finding with a more detailed study of Sextans. They predicted that five or six more galaxies would be found within the next three years. ``The odds are there won't be too many more found. If we find them, fine; if we don't, it's all right, as long as we keep churning out the unusual stuff,'' said Irwin, adding that he and McMahon consider themselves specialists in quasars, not galaxies. Quasars are starlike objects that emit huge amounts of light. They are thought to be the ancient traces of the exploding origins of new galaxies.

DOC.HEAD: James Courter, Six-Term Congressman, Won't Run Again
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. James A. Courter, who lost his bid for governor last year to Democrat Jim Florio, said Friday he would not seek a seventh term in Congress so he can spend more time with his family. The conservative Republican congressman made the surprise announcement at a news conference in the heart of his 12th congressional district. Two weeks ago, Courter announced that he would take a pro-choice stance on abortion in what many believed was a pre-cursor to his congressional campaign. Flanked by his wife, Carmen, and two daughters, Katrina and Donica, Courter said he will leave his seat ``with a sense of accomplishment and a degree of sadness.'' Courter flashed a familiar smile as he stepped up for the news conference, but as he spoke, his eyes moistened and his voice occasionally cracked. He declined to answer questions, promising to elaborate soon on his decision to step down. Hugging his wife, he said, ``I've never asked this before, but I'd like to spend some time with them.'' ``They've been a source of strength and inspiration and guidance during the good and the bad,'' he said. ``Because of my family I've decided not to seek re-election.'' ``It's a decision I'm at peace with,'' he added. ``When I first ran for Congress I said I would serve for 10 years. I guess this announcement is coming two years too late.'' Courter, a 48-year-old attorney, did not reveal any plans for the future. He scarcely mentioned the gubernatorial race, but has acknowledged in the past that the campaign had been difficult for his family to endure. After winning a tough Republican primary, Courter's campaign was damaged by what was seen as his changing stance on abortion rights and he was soundly defeated in his bid to succeed Republican Gov. Thomas H. Kean. Courter was hurt politically by the loss, but analysts said he retained his popularity in his heavily Republican home base and would have been odds-on favorite to win another term in Congress. Courter, who served as a key member of the House Armed Services Committee and later on the Iran-contra committee, was first elected in 1978 in an upset victory that presaged the Republican gains of 1980. He easily won re-election five times, and was a staunch supporter of President Ronald Reagan. Courter said the Reagan policies were responsible for the ``sweeping change in South America, Central America, Asia and Europe.'' ``I was glad to be a part of the process to get the U.S. back on its feet again,'' Courter said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Statements Raise Storm of Protest in Israel
With AM-US-Israel
DOC.TEXT: In a rare show of unity, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Labor Party leaders Friday defended resettlement policies in the face of U.S. threats to withhold aid if Soviet Jews are allowed to settle in occupied lands. Shamir, of the right-wing Likud bloc, said the Bush administration should reconsider its position, raised Thursday in Washington by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, his rival and partner in the coalition government, agreed. ``We cannot forbid (an immigrant) to settle wherever he wants, but basically we do not intend to build new settlements'' in the occupied lands, Peres said. At a hearing before the House Appropriations foreign aid subcommittee, Baker said the administration could endorse giving Israel $400 million in loan guarantees to build housing for Soviet Jews, but only if Israel promises not to put any new settlers in the West Bank or Gaza Strip. Israel maintains it has no policy of settling Jewish immigrants in the occupied territories, captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. It says that of 12,000 Soviet Jews who came to Israel last year, 200 settled in the West Bank or Gaza Strip. ``We do not accept this American position, and we intend holding a thorough discussion with the U.S. administration,'' Shamir said in a statement. ``The linkage of the issue of immigration and the problem of settlements was completely unnecessary.'' Stronger statements came from right-wing legislators and settlement leaders. Some proposed increasing Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to underscore Israel's displeasure. Likud legislator Benjamin Begin, son of former Premier Menachem Begin, said it was ``inconceivable that Jews would be barred from living anywhere in their historical homeland.'' Avner Shaki, a Parliament member from the National Religious Party, said Baker's remarks amounted to ``an unprecedented intervention in Israel's internal affairs.'' Rafael Eitan, head of the right-wing Tsomet Party, urged expanding the settlements. About 70,000 Jews live in the Gaza Strip and West Bank along with 1.7 million Palestinians who are campaigning for an independent state. During the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied lands, 659 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians and 43 Israelis have been killed. The United States considers further Jewish settlements obstacles to peace. In a sign of the touchiness of the issue, publication of monthly Soviet immigration figures now will be subject to review by the military censor. The censor's office said Friday ``all material pertaining to immigration of Soviet Jews must be submitted to the censor prior to publication.'' Censors are not expected to release the data, so the process is expected to amount to a ban. Maariv newspaper said the decision followed this week's estimate that up to 230,000 Soviet Jews will come to Israel this year, not 80,000 to 100,000 as estimated earlier. Maariv said the newest estimate ``created panic in the Arab countries, and the protests coming from these countries endanger immigration.'' The issue raised tempers at a time when Shamir is already under pressure at home and in Washington to get U.S.-mediated peace talks started with Palestinians. The State Department tried to smooth over the dispute Friday. Spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said Baker called Shamir to emphasize U.S. support for continued Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union. But she said Washington still wanted assurances that U.S.-funded housing would not be used in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Press Group Protests Journalists' Detention
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute said Friday it has protested to the Soviet Union over the detention of three Turkish journalists in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. Institute director Peter Galliner said he wrote to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on Tuesday to request the release of the three newspaper reporters detained Feb. 19 in the city of Baku. In his letter, he said the detentions violate the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which guarantees the right of journalists ``to seek, receive and impart ideas and information through the media regardless of frontiers.'' The Turkish Foreign Ministry said it has tried to obtain the release of Rafet Balli and Mucahit Buber of the Milliyet newspaper and Irfan Sapmaz of the Gunaydin newspaper. The journalists reportedly were detained while trying to board a plane to Nakhichevan, an Azerbaijani enclave, and charged with entering the Soviet Union illegally and attempting to enter an area closed to journalists. According to other journalists and unidentified Turkish officials, the three went to Iran at the end of January and took a boat along the Caspian coast to Baku. They had no visas for Iran or the Soviet Union, the sources said. The International Press Institute, with offices in London and Zurich, Switzerland, claims representation of leading journalists, editors and publishers in more than 60 countries.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Statistics on U.S. AIDS Cases
DOC.TEXT: Here are the latest statistics on acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the United States, as reported by the national Centers for Disease Control:
DOC.HEAD: Number of Cases
DOC.TEXT: Total cases reported since June 1981: 121,645. Total deaths: 72,580, or 60 percent of all cases.
DOC.HEAD: Transmission Categories
DOC.TEXT: Homosexual or bisexual males: 72,153, or 60 percent. Intravenous drug abusers: 25,200, or 21 percent. Homosexual male and drug abusers: 8,326, or 7 percent. Heterosexual cases: 5,853, or 5 percent. Transfusion or blood cases: 3,140, or 3 percent. Hemophilia patients: 1,207, or 1 percent. Children of parents with AIDS or at risk: 1,675, or 1 percent. Other or undetermined transmission cause: 4,091, or 3 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Age and Race
DOC.TEXT: Childhood cases (under age 13): 2,055, or 2 percent. Cases among whites: 68,034, or 56 percent. Cases among blacks: 33,419, or 27 percent. Cases among Hispanics: 18,980, or 15 percent. Cases among Asians or Pacific Islanders: 757, or 1 percent. Cases among American Indians or Alaskan natives: 159, or 0 percent.

(NOTE: These statistics are through January 1990 and have been rounded to the nearest whole percent. Cumulative totals are for AIDS cases reported since June 1981, and include at least 75 cases subsequently found to have occurred prior to that date.)

DOC.HEAD: French Suicide Attempt Causes Explosion That Kills Two
DOC.TEXT: A gas explosion and fire caused by a suicide attempt killed two residents of a low-income housing unit Friday, including a 14-month-old baby, and injured six, officials in this eastern French city said. Police said the explosion occurred as Regis Petet, 39, tried to kill himself after a fight with his girlfriend by turning up the gas on his stove. They said Petet was badly burned.

DOC.HEAD: Gay Writers' Conference Examines Contemporary Artistic Expression
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to clarify time frame of beat and hippie eras. ^By KATHLEEN MACLAY
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of writers, editors and publishers are holding a conference on homosexual literature to declare their creativity is ``far from being silenced.'' Jeffrey Escoffier, co-publisher of the San Francisco-based literary magazine sponsoring the weekend convention, said 1,200 writers, publishers and agents had signed up. Allen Ginsberg, a counter-culture poet of the beat and hippie movements of the 1950s and 1960s, was the scheduled keynote speaker. His publisher, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, was acquitted on pornography charges filed in connection with publication of Ginsberg's ``Howl, and Other Poems'' in 1956. The number of people registered for the conference showed that ``gay and lesbian creativity is far from being silenced,'' Escoffier said. ``The power of what we have to say will drown out Jesse Helms and other conservatives, no matter how much they try to silence us,'' Escoffier said. The North Carolina Republican U.S. senator was the driving force behind the National Endowment for the Arts censorship last summer of institutions exhibiting work of the late erotic photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. The NEA has said winners of its 1990 fellowships can't use federal funds to depict, among other things, homoeroticism _ a trademark of Mapplethorpe's work. Jack Fritscher, a writer and friend of Mapplethorpe's, contends that would-be censors want to silence ``people who believe in their own sexuality'' by promoting scare tactics to convince young people that ``if you do it (have sex), you'll get AIDS; do it and you'll die; do it and you'll get pregnant.'' Fritscher _ author of the just-released novel, ``Some Danced to Remember,'' about gay lifestyles in the pre-AIDS ``Golden Age'' of the 1970s _ also runs an adult video business north of San Francisco. But he said that 17 states won't allow him to ship the videos that include advice on safe sex because of ``moral fervor that boils over in an attempt to clean up society in general.'' Fritscher, who has a Ph.D. in American literature, said he believes in parental influence to protect children from sexually-explicit materials they can't understand, while allowing adults freedom to chose. ``If you can't burn the flag, there's no point in waving it,'' he said. ``And that, taken as a metaphor, fits the whole situation.'' In addition to censorship and politics, the conference at the Cathedral Hill Hotel will examine such issues as responsibility of authors to deal with AIDS in their writings, the role of gay journalism, gay writers and the mainstream, and gay magazines, mysteries, science fiction, poetry and history. Mexican playwright Juan-Jacobo Hernandez, founder of the first Latin American gay publishing house, will moderate a panel discussion on gay literature in the Mexican, Hispanic and Puerto Rican cultures. Joining him will be Santa Cruz, Calif., teacher Francisco X. Alarcon, whose poetry collection ``Body in Flames'' is billed as the first book published by an openly gay Hispanic writer.

DOC.HEAD: Principal Downplays Racial Element in School Disturbance
DOC.TEXT: A high school disturbance in which eight people were slightly injured and nine students arrested was not divided along racial lines, said the principal whose firing helped provoke the incident. Police clashed with hundreds of students at Morgan Park High School on Thursday in a confrontation that began when the school fire alarm was pulled four times about an hour after a brief student protest against the firing of Principal Walter Pilditch by a parent-led panel. ``I had one reporter call and tell me that all kids at the demonstration were white and all the kids injured and arrested were black,'' Pilditch, who is white, said Friday. ``That's all false,'' he said. ``There were blacks and Latinos in the demonstration for me, and there were two white students arrested and two white students injured.'' Four of the eight people injured were police officers. The confrontation was the most violent of several protests in recent days against the firing of principals under Chicago's new school reform program. Councils elected for each of Chicago's 540 public schools in October have the power to hire and fire principals, and a handful have done so in recent weeks. Some of the more controversial firings have involved white principals at mostly Hispanic schools. Board of Education spokesman Bob Saigh said he didn't know if the Morgan Park incident was racially motivated. But it appeared to have been triggered by the local council's decision to dismiss Pilditch when his contract expires in June. Most of Morgan Park's 1,800 students were in school Friday and there were no incidents, Pilditch said. About 60 percent of the students are black; 24 percent are white, 12 percent Hispanic and 4 percent Asian. Pilditch said about two dozen parents and a dozen ministers came to the school Friday out of concern for the safety of the students.

DOC.HEAD: Charges Filed Against Medfly-Fighting Helicopter Firm
DOC.TEXT: City prosecutors filed misdemeanor charges against a helicopter company accused of violating a city ordinance intended to stop aerial spraying of the Medfly-killing pesticide malathion. Six charges were filed Thursday against San Joaquin Helicopters Inc. of Delano and company operator James C. Josephson, City Attorney Victor Kaleta said. The charges were the first filed under a new law banning nighttime helicopter formations from flying below 700 feet. Six San Joaquin helicopters flew over Pasadena early Feb. 22 in violation of the law, Kaleta said. Arraignment was scheduled for March 22 in Pasadena Municipal Court. The charges each carry a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a $1,000 fine. The state hired San Joaquin to spray malathion over 400 square miles of Los Angeles and Orange counties to fight an infestation of the Mediterranean fruit fly. Malathion is mixed with corn syrup as bait, then sprayed. State agriculture and health officials contend the spraying is safe despite mounting citizen opposition to the nighttime missions. Pasadena's governing Board of Directors, worried about malathion's possible health risks, last month enacted the low-flying ban. But state officials contend an emergency declaration by Gov. George Deukmejian supersedes local laws and ordinances, including Pasadena's helicopter ban. The fly lays its eggs in more than 250 varieties of fruits, vegetables and nuts grown in California, rendering the produce inedible.

DOC.HEAD: Top Three Democratic Candidates Spar in Dallas Debate
DOC.TEXT: State Treasurer Ann Richards told a statewide television audience Friday night she isn't racially insensitive, and her two main Democratic rivals in the race for governor agreed. However, Ms. Richards' opponents used the televised debate to highlight her refusal to directly answer questions about whether she had ever used illegal drugs. Former Gov. Mark White and Attorney General Jim Mattox repeated earlier assertions they'd never used illegal drugs. When Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, was asked, she refused to give a yes or no answer. She said: ``I have revealed more about my personal life, including my alcoholism, than any other candidate that has ever run (for governor).'' Ms. Richards, whose no-holds-barred oratory during the 1988 Democratic National Convention brought wide recognition, is believed to be trailing White slightly in the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Most polls show Mattox well behind as the March 13 primary election nears. The most personal issue in the campaign to date has revolved around two remarks attributed to Ms. Richards. A newspaper report Feb. 21 said a handwritten text of a 1976 speech by Ms. Richards, who was running for Travis County commissioner, referred to illegal aliens as ``wetbacks.'' She denied using the word in the speech. Earlier, she was criticized for a remark during a televised debate that many heard as: ``No legislator, no judge and no bureaucrat has any business in determining whether a white woman has an abortion or not.'' Ms. Richards insists she said ``why a woman,'' rather than ``white woman.'' In Friday's debate, Ms. Richards noted she has been active in civil rights causes. White at one point turned to Ms. Richards and said: ``I don't think there's a racist bone in your body.'' Added Mattox, ``I don't think you're a racist by any stretch of the imagination.'' But Mattox criticized Mrs. Richards for moving slowly to address the issue, and also was critical of her refusal to say if she had ever used illegal drugs. ``Ann, Mark and I have known you a long time, and we understand why you don't want to answer the question,'' Mattox said. He said Ms. Richards had ducked the issue on eight occasions when reporters asked her about drug abuse, and that should she win the Democratic nomination, the Republican Party would have a heyday on the issue. The four main Republican gubernatorial candidates met in a similar forum Thursday night. They are oilman Clayton Williams, former Texas Secretary of State Jack Rains, attorney Tom Luce and Railroad Commissioner Kent Hance. Gov. Bill Clements, a Republican, isn't seeking re-election. Candidates with little following or chance to win weren't invited to either debate.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am, TWA Flights Make Emergency Landings At O'Hare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to UPDATE with details on TWA flight.
DOC.TEXT: Two airliners reporting mechanical problems made emergency landings at O'Hare International Airport within five minutes of each other Friday night, officials said. No injuries were reported. TWA Flight 829 reported that a warning light went on indicating problems with its ``anti-skid mechanism'' and landed safely at 7:55 p.m., said Mort Edelstein, Federal Aviation Administration spokesman. ``They have so many light signals on their panels,'' Edelstein said, ``that when they go on, (pilots) don't monkey around _ you've got passengers on board.'' Flight 829 was traveling from New York to Chicago and on to St. Louis, a TWA official said. The plane, which had 173 people on board, left O'Hare on its final destination at 8:30 p.m. Another airliner, Pan Am Flight 2027 en route to Chicago from New York with 150 people aboard, reported a loss of hydraulics, Edelstein said. Both planes were 727s. The pilot of Flight 2027 was concerned about making the runway, according to fire communications officials. Edelstein said the pilot manually lowered the landing gear and the plane was towed to the terminal after it landed safely at 8 p.m. To prepare for the emergency, Edelstein said airport officials alerted emergency personnel and had a score of fire trucks and ambulances on standby. ``We had everything out there because you had two planes that landed five minutes apart,'' Edelstein said. ``That's an unusual occurrence anywhere.''

DOC.HEAD: 20 Killed, 17 Injured in Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: A Hong Kong truck collided with a passenger bus in Guangdong province, southern China, leaving 20 people dead and 17 injured, according to news reports Saturday. The head-on collision occurred early Friday near the provincial capital of Canton. The official China News Service reported that the dead included the bus driver and 19 passengers.

DOC.HEAD: Makers of Bar Exam Company Accuse Prep Course of Stealing Questions
DOC.TEXT: The company that prepares most of the nation's bar exams filed a federal lawsuit Friday accusing a preparation service of stealing questions and undermining the integrity of the tests. The lawsuit was filed by the National Conference of Bar Examiners, or NCBE, a Chicago company that prepares the Multistate Bar Examination _ 200 multiple-choice questions administered to law graduates in 46 states. The suit accuses Multistate Legal Studies Inc. of Philadelphia and Santa Monica, Calif., of sending agents to purposely fail the bar exam, giving them the right to review the tests. While reviewing the exams, the agents memorized, photographed, hand copied or tape recorded the questions, according to the lawsuit. The suit names Multistate president Robert Feinberg as an agent. Feinberg, an attorney living in California, denied the allegations and noted that his company won a similar suit filed in 1978. The NCBE claims the ``integrity and quality of the process by which applicants are admitted to the practice of law'' was tainted by Multistate, which also operates under the name of Preliminary Multistate Bar Review. The suit seeks unspecified damages as well as injunctions against further copyright infringement. According to the suit, about 100,000 students in 40 states have enrolled in the courses with Preliminary Multistate Bar Review since 1977. The three- and six-day seminars cost $295 to $495 with an additional $395 for written materials, $100 for cassette tapes and about $50 for flashcards. The Multistate Bar Exam, used since 1972, is given twice a year on six subjects. About 58,000 applicants took the exam last year. Questions are prepared by committees of practitioners, judges and law professors and reviewed by others at a cost of about $250,000 per test form. The NCBE releases 50 questions to the public every other year, but does not reuse released questions. The NCBE also prepares other portions of the test, including a essay section and a section on professional responsibility. The Multistate Bar Examination is used in all states but Indiana, Iowa, Lousiana and Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Maine Supreme Court Upholds Roadblock That Snagged Illegal Fish
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with 2 grafs to UPDATE with attorney's comment.
DOC.TEXT: The state supreme court on Friday upheld the convictions of two men who got caught with a bag of illegal fish, then tried to get off the hook by arguing that the game wardens' roadblock was improper. Gary Sherburne and his son, Donald, were nabbed on Route 7 in Corinna in May 1988 with 19 salmon _ 15 over the limit. They were convicted in Penobscot County Superior Court and fined $325 each. The Sherburnes challenged the legality of a Maine Warden Service roadblock, in which authorities stopped motorists and searched the belongings of those who acknowledged they had been fishing. The Sherburnes contended on appeal that the fact they had gone fishing did not give authorities probable cause for a search. They called the stop a violation of their constitutional rights, but the Maine Supreme Judicial Court rejected their appeal in a 5-1 vote. Justice Robert W. Clifford, writing for the majority, agreed with the trial court that the roadblock was conducted reasonably. He said the state's interest in preserving game and fish outweighed the intrusion on motorists who were stopped and fishermen who were searched. The dissent came from Justice Caroline D. Glassman, who accused the majority of ``a faulty analysis'' of constitutional law. Ms. Glassman said catching a few fishing violations did not warrant the use of the roadblock. The Sherburnes' attorney, Robert E. Sandy Jr. of Waterville, said late Friday afternoon that he and his clients accepted the court's decision. ``We have been given a full and fair hearing before the highest court in the state,'' Sandy said. ``We lost the decision.''

A bipartisan commission recommended an ambitious $66 billion plan today to provide health insurance and long-term care to nearly all Americans. It immediately drew criticism from Congress and some of its own members for failing to recommend a way to pay for it. The U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care reported it had approved proposals to provide universal health insurance, phased in over five years, and a proposal to ensure long-term nursing care to Americans. The panel voted 8-7 on the insurance plan and 11-4 on the plan for long-term care. ``We can't offer easy answers, but we can offer a challenge to this country,'' said Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., chairman of the panel. It was known as the Pepper Commission for its first chairman, the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla.

The government is forcing airlines to open the skies to the handicapped, but says blind people still can't sit near the exit door. Transportation Department rules requiring more accommodations for the disabled on airliners brought immediate criticism from an airline industry trade group and from a national organization of blind people. Both said they were considering lawsuits. The rules call for moveable aisle armrests and more space for wheelchairs and require airlines to make other provisions for handicapped travelers. Billed as an anti-discrimination measure required by Congress, the rules will cost airlines an estimated $400 million over the next 20 years _ for training personnel and modifying airliner interior design to accommodate more disabled people, said Don Trilling, DOT director for regulatory affairs.

City leaders had hoped a street named after slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. would foster feelings of hope and pride, but now they worry the backlash will sully Portland's image. The street name has been met with an organized opposition led by a conservative political veteran. A white supremacist leader joined the opponents, and they collected 52,435 signatures on a ballot initiative to reverse the name change. A judge nixed their drive on Wednesday, but the opponents appealed Friday with the Oregon Supreme Court in hopes of meeting a March 15 deadline to put the initiative on the May 15 primary ballot. A civic leader says that the controversy, combined with the 1988 beating death of an Ethiopian immigrant by a group of neo-Nazi ``skinheads,'' may give blacks second thoughts about moving to the city. Three men have received long prison sentences for the beating death.

President Bush's nominee for the nation's top civil rights enforcement job holds nearly $20,000 worth of stock in a company that does business in white-ruled South Africa. Former New York state Sen. John R. Dunne has 400 shares of Schlumberger Ltd., with a market value of $19,650, according to the financial disclosure form he submitted to the Senate Judiciary Committee. Schlumberger, a New York-based company engaged in oil field services and oil products manufacturing, has direct investments in South Africa, according to Alison Cooper, a spokeswoman for Investor Responsibility Research Center, a Washington-based advocacy group that tracks such companies. Schlumberger's South African business accounted for less than 1 percent of its total sales of about $5 billion last year, said company spokesman Seth McCormick. Schlumberger has between 40 and 50 employees in that country, he said.

Thousands of mostly poor young women took out guaranteed student loans for a correspondence school they thought would train them for glamorous careers as travel agents. But only 20 percent of the 60,000 students at the American Career Training School graduated, and 90 percent were saddled with hefty loan bills for classes some said were nearly worthless, U.S. Senate investigators have found. The school, meanwhile, profited from $150 million in loans and the owners became overnight millionaires, said the investigators, who this week accused ACT of fraud in the first of a series of hearings on problems in the federal student loan system. ``It's just too much money being unaccounted for,'' said Grace T. McPhearson, investigator for the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee.

DOC.HEAD: BOXING CHAMPIONSHIPS:
DOC.TEXT: Photos from the U.S. National Boxing Championships in Colorado Springs have been delayed. We expect to have first photos by 11:15 pm. EST.
DOC.HEAD: The AP

DOC.NOTE: $adv05
For Release PMs Monday, March 5
DOC.HEAD: Economy Won't Sit Still For Picture-Taking
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation.
DOC.TEXT: It would be a lot easier to understand the state of the U.S. economy right now if things like the weather didn't keep blurring the picture. For the past few months, nearly all the statistical information on economic activity has come out amid a chorus of qualifications. Analysts said the numbers for December showed misleading strength in industrial production, for example, because frigid temperatures in much of the country swelled demand for heat and electrical power. In January, it was reported, retail sales figures were artificially inflated by a sudden swing to above-normal warmth that drew shoppers out of their homes. Thus, by the time a 1.1 percent upsurge in the consumer price index for January was announced a few weeks ago, numerous explanations had been prepared to show why it shouldn't worry anyone. If you excluded food and energy costs _ which are said to be especially prone to deceptive short-term fluctuations _ the CPI was up a less threatening 0.6 percent. To those who still found the latter figure disturbing, observers cited further special influences, including an increase in public transportation fares in the New York City area. The idea of screening out supposedly aberrant influences makes sense in principle. After all, analysts who study the numbers are looking for trends of lasting significance. When you are watching for changes in the tide, you don't want to be distracted by individual waves. Still, there may be limits to how many asterisks and footnotes an average citizen might accept. Veteran riders of the New York City subways, for instance, will have trouble swallowing the idea that what they encountered at the start of 1990 was a ``one-time'' fare increase. Twenty-five years ago, they recall, a trip cost 15 cents. Now it is $1.15. Similarly, consumers might balk at the idea that their actual experience with inflation is better portrayed if you don't count the cost of feeding their families or driving their cars. ``Inflation is a general rise in the price level,'' says Paul Boltz, financial economist at the investment management firm of T. Rowe Price Associates. ``It can occur even while prices of some goods are falling. ``Likewise, prices of some goods can rise more rapidly than the general inflation rate, but subtracting them out of the inflation measure does not lower inflation.'' The idea that the weather has somehow been abornally wild and wacky this winter also is suspect. True, temperatures have fluctuated widely day by day and week by week from their historical averages. But those things tend to even out. As of early this month, cumulative degree-day counts for the season in the Northeast were running very close to those of last winter at the same time, and to ``normal'' levels calculated by meteorologists. Many economic observers hold out the hope that a better fix on the economy will be available soon, now that winter is almost over. But evidently those bets are off if we have some sort of ``unusual'' spring.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday, March 5

DOC.HEAD: Inflation in Peru: What Once Bought a Truck Now Buys Cigarettes
DOC.TEXT: Their currency is named for the sun, but with inflation of nearly 3,000 percent last year, Peruvians got little warmth from it. ``The first truck I bought, 15 years ago, cost me 10 million soles; now that won't even buy me a pack of cigarettes,'' said Miguel Guzman, who owns a trucking company in Lima. Guzman quoted prices in the old currency, the sol _ Spanish for sun. In 1986, when the sol had fallen to 14,000 to the dollar, the government lopped off three zeros and renamed it the inti _ sun in Quechua, the Indian language spoken by nearly half the population. Four years later, a dollar buys 14,000 intis, which means it would buy 14 million soles if they were still around. To Peruvians, like nearly everyone else, jokes are spiritual life preservers against disaster. The latest one in Lima is that the government will chop off three zeros again and call its money the lupaca _ sun in Aymara, Peru's second major Indian language. The inflation rate for the past year, which meant prices ended the year 30 times higher on average than 12 months earlier, was surpassed only by Argentina's 4,924 percent. Doris Mandujano, 27, one of three daughters in a working-class family of 16, including grandchildren, says the last year has brought fundamental changes in the way they live. ``Sometimes at dinner there isn't enough food to go around,'' she said. ``We used to have milk and marmalade for breakfast; now it's bread and oatmeal. ``We've given up trying to provide clothing and medicine for everyone.'' Her family is squeezed into a three-bedroom, cement-block house Miss Mandujano's father built in Villa El Salvador, a shantytown on the outskirts of Lima. Miss Mandujano's parents and seven of the children, including herself, have jobs and contribute to meeting the family's needs. She has the additional job of trying to make and follow a budget. ``Our pay doesn't keep up with prices,'' she said. ``Sometimes by the fourth day of the month, we've already spent what was budgeted for two weeks, and so the crisis begins.'' Most economists blame government policies that favored consumption over production while creating a huge deficit that fed inflation. They say populist President Alan Garcia's administration has subsidized basic goods and services to the point of bankrupting the very state companies that provide the services. A gallon of gasoline costs the equivalent of only 40 cents, but the state oil company, Petroperu, is on the verge of bankruptcy. Electricity and water are among the world's cheapest, but both are rationed to Lima's 7 milliion people, largely because of the dilapidated systems. Some parts of the city have been without water for weeks. Ernesto Amans, president of the state water company, said nearly half the water leaving treatment plants was lost through leaking underground mains and the company could not afford the $18 million needed for repairs. While subsidized prices remain low, food and clothing rose more than 2,500 percent last year, entertainment soared more than 10,000 percent and education nearly 20,000 percent, according to official statistics. The magazine Analisis Laboral predicts that by the time Garcia leaves office July 28, accumulated inflation during his five-year term will reach 1,383,120 percent. Novelist Mario Vargas Llosa is favored to win the April 8 presidential election as the candidate of a center-right coalition. He has pledged to reduce annual inflation to 10 percent within a year, but says it will demand great sacrifice. After five years of Garcia, who campaigned as ``the president of hope'' and won by a landslide, many Peruvians are skeptical of politicians' promises. ``All that's left to believe in is ourselves,'' Miss Mandujano said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs, March 7

For Release Monday, March 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Few Companies Lead Way in Phasing Out Ozone-Depleting Chemicals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: Wiht LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Each year, manufacturers belch thousands of tons of chemicals into the stratosphere, eating the fragile ozone layer that protects the Earth against the sun's damaging ultraviolet rays. Until last year, the clear skies over IBM's circuit board plant in Endicott in south-central New York belied the plant's identity as one of the largest users of ozone-depleting chemicals in the United States, releasing more than 2 million pounds of the invisible chemicals annually from its white steel pipes. But in January, International Business Machines Corp. announced that after spending millions of dollars and years of research, the plant's emissions of ozone-depleting chemicals had been reduced almost 75 percent. In the face of growing evidence that industrial chemicals are eroding the ozone that filters ultraviolet rays, IBM is one of a number of American companies slowly beginning to change the way they do business. The destructive effects on the ozone caused by chlorofluorocarbons, used as refrigerants, cleaning solvents and to make bubbles in plastic foam, have been known for more than a decade. The Environmental Protection Agency has ordered a 50 percent reduction in the use of CFCs by the end of the century, and many companies have set earlier deadlines or pledged to phase them out altogether. But according to the National Resources Defense Council, emissions of two chemicals that are as yet unregulated _ methyl chloroform and carbon tetrachloride _ together account for 33 percent of the man-made, ozone-destroying chlorine in the stratosphere. As long as they are used, the ozone will be unable to recover even if CFCs are phased out entirely, the Washington-based environmental interest group says. Spokeswoman Deborah Sheiman said the group is particularly concerned about methyl chloroform, a chemical used primarily as a metal cleaner and degreaser, which has not been widely acknowledged as a threat to the ozone. ``Most of the attention has been on the CFCs,'' Sheiman said. ``We're hoping to turn that around. We believe that methyl chloroform has got to be controlled if we're going to repair the damage to the ozone hole.'' Although about 200 companies reported reduced methyl chloroform emissions in 1988 _ the latest year for which figures are available _ almost as many increased emissions, Sheiman said. At IBM's vast 88-building complex in Endicott, the company uses methyl chloroform in production of computer circuit boards. In 1987 and 1988, the plant emitted more than 1 million pounds of methyl chloroform, about 2 percent of the total amount of the chemical used at the plant, environmental engineering manager Dennis F. Whittaker said. Last year, IBM substituted a water-based solvent for methyl chloroform in one production line, resulting in an 89 percent reduction in methyl chloroform emissions, down to 121,000 pounds, Whittaker said. The new process, which IBM is implementing at plants in Texas, Japan and West Germany, was developed after more than five years' collaboration between IBM engineers and suppliers, Whittaker said. He estimated the cost of research, development and engineering changes at about $40 million. ``It takes a long time and it's a tremendous investment,'' he said. ``It's not something you do to improve your profit line.'' Methyl chloroform still is used in the company's advanced technology line, where more complex boards for mainframe computers are produced. IBM has not found a substitute precise enough to use in that process, Whittaker said. ``We're working on it,'' he said. ``We need a breakthrough. It's hard to schedule an invention.'' Pratt & Whitney of East Hartford, Conn., reported the highest methyl chloroform emissions in the country in 1987. The aircraft engine manufacturer has committed to reducing those levels by 80 percent to 90 percent in the next four years by switching to alkaline cleaners, spokeswoman Peggy Kay said. The company's emissions already dropped by more than 75 percent in 1988, she said. But Kay said it takes years of testing to ensure that changes made in the company's manufacturing processes do not hurt the product. ``You have to make sure that you're producing the same quality,'' she said. ``If not, then it's not worth it. You want safe aircraft engines.'' Companies switching to environmentally safer alternatives find they do not always work as well as methyl chloroform. The Johnson Controls plant in Watertown, Wis., has replaced methyl chloroform with a petroleum-based solvent, plant engineer Russell Miller said. ``I've gotten lots of complaints,'' he said. Methyl chloroform ``is a very good solvent, but it's very environmentally wrong,'' he said. At the Fischer Controls International plant in Marshalltown, Iowa, alkaline washers are replacing methyl chloroform as a degreaser, said Ron Allen, the plant's director of loss prevention. The new washers are more expensive and difficult to use, but ``much friendlier to the environment,'' Allen said. ``We are optimistic that we can make alkaline washers work as well,'' he said. ``We have a strong formal commitment to the environment, and we feel we need to be pacesetters for our customers.'' The National Resources Defense Council wants to see laws banning the use of methyl chloroform, but in the meantime, public pressure is pushing some companies to begin voluntarily reducing emissions of ozone-depleting chemicals, Sheiman said. ``I think it's having an impact,'' she said. ``That so many companies have come forth with these pledges ... it certainly has seemed to resonate in corporate boardrooms.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, March 5

For Release Monday AMs, March 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Violent Youth Gangs Plague Rural South Texas
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Like many residents, auto parts dealer Jose Chavez has developed a fear of teen-agers in his crime-plagued colonia near the South Texas border. His advice for visitors: ``If you stop there at nighttime and you see a bunch of kids, you better not stop.'' They might be Tri-City Bombers, a youth gang claiming Lopezville as its territory. Other gangs roam many of Hidalgo County's rural colonias, the scores of impoverished subdivisions where migrant farm workers live along unpaved streets without adequate water, sewers or drainage. In this farming region separated from the rest of the country by huge ranches, people wonder how they ended up with a social problem considered symptomatic of big-city angst and alienation. How did they get an ``asphalt jungle'' in a place where the streets aren't even paved? Officials say the Lower Rio Grande Valley's gangs remain relatively unsophisticated. Yet, just as in Los Angeles, Chicago and other cities, they steal, fight and attack enemies' windows with rocks and bullets. Sometimes, they kill. In January, a gunfight between what police said were rival gang members left two young men dead in the town of San Juan. It is the despair of poverty, some say, that leads to gang membership, along with a high school dropout rate that hovers around 50 percent. ``Kids are real bored, man,'' said Gabriel Benavides, a 17-year-old still in school who has been named by the Hildago County Sheriff's Department as a Tri-City Bombers leader. The gang, which claims about 200 members, is named for the cities of Pharr, San Juan and Alamo, which share a school district. The spray-painted ``TCB'' initials show up everywhere in Lopezville. ``It's like having an outside family. We're all brothers,'' Benavides said, putting his fist on his heart with the index and pinky fingers extended _ the TCB salute. They don't like to fight, he said, but cautioned: ``I have a tendency to cause pain. If you give me trouble, I have a tendency to cause pain. If you don't mess with me, I won't give you pain.'' TCB member Jorge Alberto Cantu, 20, remains in jail without bond, accused in the shooting deaths of two males who authorities said belonged to a gang called the Spoilers. TCB members confronted a group of Spoilers outside a San Juan video arcade the night of Jan. 5, said Police Chief Rene Lizcano. Parents of the victims, 14-year-old Guadalupe Gonzalez Jr. and his 21-year-old cousin, Miguel Ojeda, said neither belonged to a gang. ``He was going to get married a week later,'' Oralia Ojeda said of her son. Chavez gave up on keeping glass in the windows at his small store, Joe's Auto Parts. Gang members would throw rocks through them in revenge every time he painted over the graffiti they sprayed on his storefront, he said. Now, the windows are covered with heavy sheets of plywood. One night, a brick sailed through the front window of Chavez's house and hit his wife in the head, he said. Another day, someone fired shots into the cab of his truck. ``A lot of these people, they don't say nothing because they're afraid these kids will come and do something at their house at night while they're asleep,'' Chavez said. Two years ago, five area gang members were convicted of beating a 27-year-old man to death with a baseball bat outside a convenience store. They left his 33-year-old brother with permanent brain damage, said Chief Deputy Bob Davis of the sheriff's department. ``Apparently, it wasn't over anything,'' Davis said. ``These guys were on their turf.'' Davis estimates about 25 gangs operate in the county's rural areas, covered by only seven patrol cars. Gang members smashed the windows out of four patrol cars in a melee last Halloween. Some residents say the gangs have been around for nearly a decade but drew authorities' attention only after the cars were attacked. The developments worry J. Michael Olivero, a criminal justice professor at the University of Texas-Pan American in Edinburg. Olivero, who studied gangs in the Chicago area, believes the South Texas groups could become sophisticated crime rings involved in extortion, drug trafficking and other crimes typical of urban gangs. ``They found a kid with an Uzi,'' Olivero said. ``The things aren't cheap.'' Graffiti representing California and Illinois gangs has started appearing on area walls, which Olivero said could result from children of migrant farm families traveling to other states. Community leaders have been meeting recently to address the gang problem, and say parks and jobs would help kids stay out of trouble. School officials, meanwhile, have promised a late afternoon bus route to give students in outlying areas a chance to participate in extracurricular activities. Chris Willingham, head counselor at the local high school, said the transient lives of migrant farm workers keep many children off-balance at school. Many arrive late in the year and leave early, she said. ``We're going to have to address the educational needs of these kids,'' Olivero said, ``and we're going to have to get them water and get them roads and things like that to facilitate a sense of pride. Kids who are integrated with family, church and school don't join gangs.'' But while Lizcano, the San Juan police chief, acknowledges the county has a problem, he rejects the theory that gangs are fostered by poverty and hopelessness. ``I grew up in a colonia myself,'' he said, ``and I'm a chief of police.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, March 5

DOC.HEAD: Machinists, Still on Strike After a Year, Find Other Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Joe Cimino and Willie Hoskins put on red union T-shirts last March 4 and joined the thousands of machinists outside Eastern Airlines during the first hours of the strike against the carrier. They chanted the same protest cries. They rattled the chain-link gates near Eastern hangars. Today, Cimino and two other striking Eastern machinists are building up an automotive repair business. Hoskins has applied for a $5-an-hour job as a security guard so he can get health insurance to pay for dentures. ``When we went out on strike, it's like someone pulled the rug out from under you,'' said Cimino, who pooled $10,000 with the other workers to open the garage north of Miami. ``You can either stay down or get up. I'm union all the way, but you have to pay the bills,'' ``The last day I worked was my last day at Eastern,'' said Hoskins, a 34-year Eastern veteran who lived on his $400-a-month strike benefits and life insurance money from his late mother. For many of the 9,000 Eastern machinists who walked off the job with raised fists and high hopes, the past year has been a test of self-preservation and a lesson in the squeeze of a slowing national economy. Some have found work at other airlines. Others took jobs where they could: restaurants, factories, air freight companies. Few make the $19.99 an hour top-scale pay they were earning at Eastern. Eastern's Chapter 11 bankruptcy court filing locked up thousands of dollars many machinists had saved under a vacation-time reimbursement plan. Health insurance bills keep coming in. ``Some people have landed on their feet, but there have also been some real sad stories,'' said Machinist union local vice president Frank Ortis, who estimates at least a dozen suicides and many more divorces have occurred among the union ranks since the strike. Wage and work force reductions since the strike at Eastern _ once one of Florida's largest employers _ have had at least a $1 billion economic impact, said William O. Cullom, president of the Greater Miami Chamber of Commerce. Since the strike, Miami-based Eastern has shifted most of its hub operations to Atlanta. Miami accounts for less than 50 of the total daily flights of 800, airline spokesman Robert Hunter said. Before the strike, Eastern ran about 1,100 flights a day with about 28,000 employees. Now, the airline has about 20,000 employees, about half hired since the strike started. Very few of the pilots and flight attendants were able to return to Eastern when they called off their sympathy strike last fall. But the decline of Eastern in Miami has been compensated by the expansion by other carriers such as American Airlines and Pan American World Airways, which are battling over Eastern's Latin American routes. ``For the airport and the community as a whole, the strike's impact has been small. It's the individuals that are going through hell, in some cases,'' said Nicholas Glaskowsky, an economics professor at the University of Miami. For the 12,000 residents of Miami Springs near the airport, the strike has not been the economic menace predicted last spring. Fred White, a 24-year barber and part-time real estate agent, said a few Eastern workers moved out, but their homes quickly were purchased by newcomers. ``This town no longer lives or dies on what happens at Eastern,'' he said. ``Life goes on.'' Even at the Machinists local headquarters, reality is replacing rhetoric. There still are many handwritten placards urging unity and attacking Frank Lorenzo, head of Eastern Airlines' parent, Texas Air Corp. But most attention goes to reports of job openings, some as away far as Los Angeles, Denver and Honolulu. ``You can't be unrealistic and believe that people aren't going to take a job if they need it and leave town,'' said Ortis. Last month while in Miami, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland said there were no victors in the Eastern strike, since labor has not forced the sale of the carrier and management still is burdened by losses. Last year, Texas Air reported a loss of $885.6 million, the largest ever by a U.S. airline. But few strikers express regrets, saying the strike has strengthened the organized labor movement. ``We all knew what we were walking away from when we left Eastern: security and good pay. For good or bad, thousands of lives were affected by that decision. I'm still convinced it was the right one,'' said Bob Young, a partner with Cimino and striker Frank Weiss at the Pembroke Pines automotive shop. Last month, striker Vincent Parlatore had his day in court. A small-claims court judge, however, rejected his claim for $1,580 in back wages. It was another disappointment in a belt-tightening year. Parlatore peddled telephone books shortly after the strike and got extra hours as a policeman in a seaside town near Fort Lauderdale. His pay at an air cargo company in Miami is $13.25 an hour, about two-thirds what he made at Eastern. ``We're not out begging, but life's not as easy as it was,'' Parlatore said. ``If it's not a necessity, we don't buy it. We don't go out to eat. We can't go to movies.'' Parlatore has applied for an inspector's job with the Federal Aviation Administration. If hired, he might be forced to move. ``What can you do?'' he said. ``That's one less person on the picket line.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, March 5
