DOC.HEAD: Plan Devised To Control Development Gobbling Up Amazon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This is another in a series of stories planned in advance of 20th anniversary observances for Earth Day in April.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The chaotic development that is gobbling up the Amazon rain forest could finally be reined in with a new plan developed by officials of Amazon countries and leading scientists from around the world. ``That's some of the most encouraging news about the Amazon rain forest in recent years,'' said Thomas Lovejoy, a tropical ecologist at the Smithsonian Institution and an Amazon specialist. ``It contrasts markedly with a year ago, when there was nothing to read about conservation in the Amazon, especially in Brazil, except bad news,'' Lovejoy said in a recent interview. Sixty percent of the Amazon, the world's largest tropical rain forest, lies in Brazil, but the forest also covers parts of eight surrounding countries. Lovejoy was one of the organizers of an unusual workshop held in mid-January in Manaus, Brazil, a sprawling city of 1 million people in the heart of the Amazon. It was the center of Brazil's once-thriving rubber trade. The workshop, which brought together all the governments and scientists with interests in the rain forest, culminated with a plan to regulate development in up to 80 percent of the Amazon region. It was the first time that all parties concerned with the Amazon had met to pool their knowledge and agree on conservation priorities, the meeting's participants said. The plan devised at the workshop has no legal force. But it has broad government support and is likely to serve as a guide for national conservation programs, participants said. Many of the areas to be preserved will be open to so-called multiple-use development, which preserves the forest while allowing tourism and the commercial exploitation of fibers, fruits and medicinal plants. Brazil, struggling with a teetering economy and pressured by developers and peasant farmers to clear the forest for cattle ranching or farming, has been ambivalent about the need to conserve the Amazon. Brazil participated in the Manaus workshop, however, and the setting of priorities was ``all done with the blessing of Brazil,'' Lovejoy said. Tropical rain forests are giant, living warehouses for thousands of plant and animal species. The Amazon alone is home to 30 percent of the world's plant and animal species. One study found that a single square yard of leaf litter taken from the deep shadows of the Amazon floor contained 800 ants representing 50 species. Towering forest canopies up to 300 feet above the forest floor are home to countless birds and insects that live their lives without ever setting foot on the ground. One group of orchid species grows only near the top of the canopy; an entirely different collection of orchids grows at the bottom. At the Manaus meeting, more than 100 specialists met in small groups to assess conservation priorities. Insect specialists compared data on such creatures as the stinging ant that defends acacia trees against predators. Mammologists took inventory of the Amazon's screeching monkeys. Ichthyologists considered such oddities as the fish that eats fallen fruits and nuts on the Amazon River's banks when it overflows. Botanists, ornithologists and others did the same. Then they pooled their information and marked up maps of the Amazon. When they were done, the areas determined to be worth saving covered 70 percent to 80 percent of the Amazon. ``The bulk of the Amazon is a biological priority; there's no way of getting around that,'' said Russell Mittermeier, president of Conservation International and an authority on endangered monkeys. Mittermeier emphasized, however, that the plan set realistic goals for the establishment of national parks and reserves, along with multiple-use areas where some development could occur. It is not realistic to build a fence around 70 percent to 80 percent of the Amazon, he said. Only the most critical areas should be placed off limits to development. ``Ten to 20 percent of the entire Amazon should be in protected parks or preserves, ideally,'' he said. At present, 2 percent of the Amazon is protected. Brazil was not alone in its support for the conservation plan. ``The results of this meeting are a major contribution towards the work that has got to be done,'' said Stanley Malone, director of the Suriname Forest Service. Suriname was one of eight Amazon countries that agreed in 1978 to develop a unified approach to management of the Amazon, Malone said. What the officials lacked, however, was a guide to which areas most needed protection. That determination has now been made, based on the number of different species a given area contained, and on how many of those species were endemic, or unique, to the area. ``Now we'll have to see what develops from this,'' Mittermeier said. A new Brazilian president, Fernando Collor de Mello, will be inaugurated March 15, and with him will come a new Brazilian environmental policy. Whether the policy will include support for the Manaus plan is uncertain. ``As always, everything depends on key individuals,'' Mittermeier said. ``I'm basically always optimistic,'' he said. ``I feel sure that we can develop appropriate solutions, although it may take a lot of work.''

DOC.HEAD: The Audi V8 Quattro
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 Audi V8 Quattro is as close to a swagger as the folks at Audi get. This $47,450 power machine is quietly packaged in decidedly Audi styling _ the luxury Eurosedan look that's relatively unassuming. But take this new flagship of the Audi fleet out on the highway and revel with Audi in a new appreciation for what a luxury Eurosedan can be. The Audi V8 Quattro test car's 3.6-liter, 32-valve V-8 engine impressively dominated, going from 0 to 60 mph in 8.7 seconds, and is capable of producing 240 horsepower. Coupled with four-speed electronically controlled automatic transmission, it delivered smooth performance, especially in the economy driving mode. Drivers can change the shift points with a knob on the center console, depending on whether they want to watch fuel consumption (economy mode) or want maximum power (sport setting). I preferred the sport setting, though it made this nearly 4,000-pound car so quick I nearly took off the corner bumpers of a couple of cars I was trying to pass. And road handling? The Audi V8's suspension was masterful, making the vehicle feel as safe and in control at, let's just say, frightfully high speeds, as it did at the highway speed limit of 65 mph. And with full-time four-wheel-drive, this car can handle just about anything. It tackled snow with gusto, leaving other cars in a swirl of white. It tracked capably through icy slush, too. It was especially impressive, considering this is Audi's first merging of a powerful 32-valve V-8 engine, an automatic transmission and permanent all-wheel-drive technology. Of course, it's also the most expensive car the West German carmaker has marketed in the States. The previous top-priced Audi was the 200 Quattro wagon at $38,000. But wait. There's more to the Audi V8 Quattro. A microcomputer not only monitors the engine systems and maintains optimum performance but memorizes malfunctions for easier diagnosis at the shop. The test car's antilock brakes (ABS) came with a turnoff button on the dashboard for those driving conditions, such as loose gravel, where ABS can sometimes hinder a driver's ability to stop by preventing gravel from building up at the wheels. The Audi Bose sound system was superb, and the electronically controlled front seats _ leather, of course _ were roomy and comfortable. The front center armrest, which housed a cellular phone that was standard equipment, not optional, could be adjusted to various heights. Other thoughtful touches included heated seats in both the front and rear that worked wonderfully fast, a heated door lock on the driver door so you can't be frozen out of the car, and a dual windshield washer system. The system lets you use a special washer fluid that's particularly effective for salt and grime first, and then follow up with the regular fluid for picture-perfect vision no matter what the road throws up at you. The headlights received a washing, too, each time the regular washer fluid was activated. The front floor mats had fasteners to keep them in place, carpeting was all-wool throughout, and the shoulder belt height was adjustable so the belt wouldn't chafe against a short person's neck. There also was a reddish light that shone down on the driver floor area as an added safety feature when the headlights were on, wood grain tastefully swathed across the doors and dashboard, and a spot in the center of the instrument cluster that showed what radio station was tuned in so the driver never had to look below at the radio. That feature took some getting used to. My eyes caught the flickering of something changing in the instrument cluster, and at first, I thought it must have been a warning light that came on and went out. On examination, I realized it was just the changing radio station. I also noted the car can guzzle down the fuel _ I averaged under 17 mpg in combined city-highway driving, with the EPA rating the Audi V8 at 14 mpg in the city and 18 mpg on the highway. A gas guzzler tax of $1,050, by the way, is added on to the $47,450 base price for the Audi V8 Quattro because of the vehicle's poor fuel economy. Additionally, the person sitting in the rear middle seat would find the seatback a bit hard. That's where the rear center armrest is, and it just doesn't make for a very comfortable long-term resting spot. On the other hand, the rear legroom was good, and both the rear window controls and rear cigarette lighter could be disabled with the touch of a button on the driver door so children in back can't get hurt. Audi lists some impressive competitors for the V8 Quattro _ the Mercedes-Benz 420SEL, which starts around $63,000, the BMW 735i, around $53,000, and the Jaguar XJ6 Vanden Plas, around $48,000. Audi didn't mention Japanese luxury models, such as the Lexus LS400, which starts at $35,000, but they're bound to be a factor, too. Still, sales of the Audi V8 Quattro totaled more than 800 in calendar 1989, and the company projects about 1,500 sales in 1990. They're looking for mostly male buyers between 35 and 49, with household income of $150,000. They will be predominantly college graduates in professional jobs, Audi said. Because the Audi V8 Quattro is a new vehicle, Consumer Reports magazine does not list owner trouble reports.

DOC.HEAD: Should Skeleton in Retailer's Closet Scare off Investors?
DOC.TEXT: Nordstrom Inc., put on a pedestal for delivering extraordinary service at its department stores, may have had an unfair advantage over the rivals that have long looked up to the retailer. Some of the smiling salesmen and women known for writing personal thank-you notes to customers and going to unusual lengths to satisfy shoppers apparently have been scowling inside. Outsiders who saw a happy family of ``Nordies'' now are learning they may have gotten the wrong impression. The Seattle-based department store owner virtually admitted this past week that employees hadn't been fully paid for providing the impeccable service that has made Nordstrom famous. The company said it created a $15 million reserve for back-pay claims, a provision that eroded fourth-quarter earnings. For the quarter ended Jan. 31, earnings tumbled 34 percent to $31.4 million or 39 cents a share, from $47.5 million or 58 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 12 percent to $857.5 million in the quarter from $765.1 million. Much of the drop in quarterly earnings reflected higher merchandise markdowns to keep up with price-cutting competitors. Accusations have come to light that Nordstrom pressures its employees into performing tasks on their own time. The Washington state Department of Labor and Industry ruled last month that Nordstrom had a pattern of making sales clerks work during off-hours without compensation and ordered the company to pay them for uncompensated hours. Employees sometimes bring merchandise to customers' homes, thank them in writing for shopping at Nordstrom and do other good retailing deeds. Making matters worse, Nordstrom has been hit with two class-action lawsuits, one filed by three shareholders claiming they and others who own company stock suffered financial losses because Nordstrom officers failed to disclose the labor problems. Kurt Barnard, a New York-based retail consultant, says now that Nordstrom's dark secret is attracting national attention competitors may feel less inclined to emulate the company. By not paying fully for the work it got out of employees, a company its competitors considered the epitome of retailing excellence actually had an unfair advantage. ``Their competitors have been under tremendous pressure to render the kind of service that Nordstrom has been so famous for,'' he said. ``The question now arises: Will they be able to render the same type of service if they have to pay for it? Will other stores still be so eager to follow suit?'' Even before Nordstrom's dirty laundry began being aired in public, the company's stock had been taking a beating. The stock, 40 percent owned by the founding Nordstrom family, has slumped about 35 percent since reaching a high of $42.50 a share over the summer. It was trading around $27 last week. Some analysts pooh-pooh the idea that the bad publicity over Nordstrom's labor practices will cause lasting damage to a stock with heaps of potential. Richard Pyle, of the investment firm Piper Jaffray & Hopwood Inc., says now is an ideal time to invest in Nordstrom. ``We're comfortable recommending the stock as a buy for people looking to own a long-term growth company,'' Pyle said. ``The only time you get to buy this company cheaply is when it's in the midst of a mini-crisis.'' A severe case of inventory bloat in 1984 and the stock market crash in October 1987 provided two earlier buying opportunities, he said. The traits that he admires in Nordstrom haven't been altered. The company is a savvy fashion merchandiser and produces sales of more than $400 a square foot _ roughly double the volume of its competitors. Pyle predicts the labor issue will be resolved satisfactorily. In any case, not all ``Nordies'' are negative on the company as a support rally at the company's flagship Seattle store last Thursday attested. Nordstrom has 60 stores in Washington, Oregon, California, Alaska, Virginia and Utah. It plans 16 more, with expansion into Illinois, New Jersey, Maryland, Minnesota, Indiana, Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York. ``There are a lot of employees out there who are supportive of how Nordstrom runs its business,'' said Pyle, adding that there are plenty of real estate developers all over the country with space on their hands who would love to fill it with a Nordstrom store.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, March 5

DOC.HEAD: Corporations Don't Seem Bearish on Rates, Judging by Their Borrowing
DOC.TEXT: Despite all the dark forecasts that surging interest rates in Japan and West Germany will drive U.S. rates up, American corporations dependent on borrowed money show little sign of worry. Indeed, if their propensity to borrow is a good indicator, it appears that many companies regard the recent upturn in U.S. rates to be temporary and not the beginning of an upward worldwide spiral. That would be good news for the credit markets, which have been gripped in recent weeks by fears about foreign demand for U.S. Treasury bonds and the sorry state of the junk bond market. In the first two months of this year, borrowers issued a total of $9.7 billion in investment-grade bonds in the public market, according to Moody's Investors Service. That amounts to an annualized rate of just under $60 billion, a drop of more than 22 percent from the 1989 total of $77.8 billion. What's more, this year's total has been inflated by more issues from foreign borrowers such as the Canadian province of Nova Scotia, which offered $300 million of 30-year bonds this past week. ``The surprising upturn in long-term bond yields in early 1990 definitely has discouraged a significant amount of investment-grade corporate bond issuance,'' says John Lonski, senior economist at Moody's. ``Many a corporate treasurer perhaps still expects long-term bond yields to decline later in the year,'' he said. While corporations have been abstaining from the bond market, they have been actively peddling IOUs in short-term markets where rates haven't risen as much. The total amount of commercial paper outstanding issued by non-financial companies was $136.5 billion as of Feb. 21, a jump of $8.31 billion since the start of the year. Seth Waugh, managing director in charge of corporate bond trading and new issues at Merrill Lynch & Co., said most Wall Street bankers had thought rates would stay low and bond business would boom in the first quarter. Instead, rates have risen because of a spurt in inflation, a belief that the economy is on the mend and fears of more intense competition for global investment funds from Japan and West Germany. The yield on the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond has risen from a December low of near 7.8 percent to around 8.6 percent currently. Waugh says a pickup in new issues in the past two weeks shows some corporations want to lock in current rates to guard against an increase, even though many others are content to wait. A quarter-point move in interest rates would produce a rush of borrowings, he predicts, motivated by fear if rates go up or by the cheaper cost of funds if rates go down. `It's a pretty divided camp right now,'' he says. Analysts say it's far too soon to read anything deeper into the decline in borrowings. Nevertheless, Lonski says there are several reasons to suspect that corporate activity might stay subdued. The sluggish economy has slowed growth in capital spending, reducing companies' borrowing needs, he says. Also, the collapse of the junk bond market as a source of takeover financing has taken some pressure off corporate managers, he says. ``There is less of a need to leverage the balance sheet in order to boost your stock price,'' he says. If that's true, it would mark a stark change from the debt-happy 1980s. Moody's estimates net interest costs amounted to 42 percent of operating earnings for non-financial companies in last year's third quarter, up from 35 percent in 1988 and an average of 20 percent from 1972 to 1982. The rise in debt service largely reflected the explosive growth of the junk market. Today, that market is extremely sluggish thanks to the collapse of junk prices and of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Only $700 million in junk bonds have been issued so far this year, vs. more than $32 billion in all 1988. A treasurer for the financing arm of one of the nation's biggest companies says junk bond woes have turned investors off from even top-grade corporate bonds, making it difficult to borrow. This official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Wall Street's preoccupation with its internal problems also is to blame for the slump in borrowings. ``I don't think the investment bankers in this country with their problems are as aggressive or as innovative or as ready to put their capital behind transactions,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for March 5

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Claims Trump Stole Idea for `Trump: The Game'
DOC.TEXT: A man is suing Donald Trump, saying the billionaire businessman swiped his idea for the board game ``Trump: The Game.'' Walter Brockington III, a 29-year-old insurance man, filed the lawsuit Thursday in U.S. District Court. Brockington, who's seeking more than $50,000 in damages, said he sent a prototype of a board game he calls ``Mogul'' to Trump and other big shooters, such as Alfred Taubman, Ted Turner and the late Malcolm Forbes. Shortly afterward, Trump and game maker Milton Bradley signed a deal to sell ``Trump: The Game'' for $25, with profits going to charity. ``I don't think Trump did it for greed,'' said Brockington's attorney, Susan Winshall. ``He turned the idea into a publicity stunt.'' Milton Goldfine, general counsel for the Trump organization, said the lawsuit ``is completely without merit.''

DOC.HEAD: For Weekend Editions March 3-4
Stock Market Defies Expectations _ Or Does It?
DOC.TEXT: Bulls took the driver's seat on Wall Street this past week despite a shaky Tokyo market and a slew of divergent economic signals. Tokyo's problems actually helped improve the attitude toward U.S. stocks, while investors decided America's economic pluses now outweigh the minuses. ``We're not quite as bad as we had been viewed six months ago ... at the same time things aren't quite as good everywhere else,'' said Thomas Czech, chairman of the investment committee at Blunt Ellis & Loewi Inc. in Milwaukee. Everywhere else mainly means Japan. The Tokyo stock markethas been on a slide, which intensifed Monday with its second-largest point loss ever. A 4.5 percent drop extended the fall in the Nikkei average of 225 Japanese stocks to around 14 percent since the start of the year. To foreigners who for a long time have suspiciously eyed Tokyo's high price-earnings ratios, the downturn came as no surprise. Some ratios of stock prices to company earnings there had reached as high as 60 to 1, making Japanese stocks seem wildly overvalued to buttoned-down U.S. investors accustomed to far more conservative readings here. At least some of the money that has flowed out of Japanese stocks has found a home in the United States. Hugh Johnson, senior vice president and chief investment officer at First Albany Corp., in Albany, N.Y., said anecdotal evidence, based on discussions with colleagues in the investment community, suggests that U.S. investors have been pulling out of Japan. To some extent, similar maneuvers are being carried out by Japanese and West German money managers. ``This is the equity market's version of a flight to safety _ the safety of lower price-earnings ratios from the exposure of high price-earnings ratios,'' he said. An indication that more capital is flowing in our direction was that the dollar took flight on Friday, prompting various central banks to sell dollars on world foreign-exchange markets to check the currency's runup. The U.S. role as a safe haven was enhanced by reports that, on balance, implied the economy might be doing better than some gloom-and-doomers feared. A February survey of purchasing managers at the nation's industrial corporations, issued Thursday, showed the slowdown in the manufacturing sector eased. The National Association of Purchasing Management's widely watched index rose to 48.3 percent in February from 45.2 percent a month earlier. A reading below 50 means manufacturing is declining, but the improvement from January was nonetheless encouraging. On Friday, the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to foretell economic activity six to nine months ahead, showed no change in January. The flat reading followed two months of increase, but seemed to support ``the view that we're in a no-boom, no-bust trajectory,'' Johnson of First Albany said. ``The message of the financial markets today is that we will miss a recession,'' the analyst said. News on the leading indicators helped the stock market rally Friday to extend its winning streak to five straight sessions. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks closed at 2,660.36, climbing 24.77 on Friday which brought its gain for the week to 96.17 points. Other readings for the week showed the New York Stock Exchange composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 5.62 to 184.97; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 11.50 to 431.02; and, the American Stock Exchange's market value index rose 5.02 to 356.12. Big Board volume averaged 161.6 million shares a day, up from 159.84 million daily in the prior week.
DOC.HEAD: End of Adv Weekend Editions March 3-4
Ordinance Introduced to Block Plant Shutdowns Due to Takeovers
DOC.TEXT: An alderman is proposing an ordinance that would allow the city to use its power of eminent domain to prevent the shutdown of local manufacturing plants acquired in takeovers. The proposed law forcing businesses to sell under city order would be the first of its kind in the nation, although critics say it would amount to unconstitutional ``nationalization'' of companies. ``What we trying to do is focus on corporate raiders buying plants on the edge of going under,'' Alderman Bernard Hansen said Friday. ``They say they are going to improve the plant and keep it going, but instead they close them and take jobs to another country.'' Hansen said the proposed ordinance would protect jobs by giving Chicago's economic development commissioner the right to invoke eminent domain against the owner of a manufacturing plant that is shutting down. Laws of eminent domain allow governments to seize property in matters of public interest. Under the proposed ordinance, the city could force the sale of the seized plant if a buyer had been found to keep the plant open for business. The ordinance would apply to plants closing within five years of takeover by a new owner. The proposal was drafted by a group called Business and Professional People for the Public Interest on behalf of workers and community groups fighting to keep open a plant operated by Stewart-Warner Corp. The company, which makes electronics equipment, was purchased by Britain's BTR PLC, which last year announced plans to shutter the plant in 1991 and move manufacturing operations to Mexico. Hansen said there are potential buyers for the plant, but that BTR refuses to sell. But critics say the ordinance would allow unwelcome intrusions by the city into corporate affairs. ``This is a city equivalent of nationalizing a company,'' said Sam Mitchell, executive director of the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry. ``I can understand motivation of the ordinance, to keep jobs in the city. But I don't believe the city or any unit of government have the right to step into and effectively nationalize a company because they do something that doesn't please that government.'' Hansen, who heads the Chicago City Council's Ecomonic Development Committee, said a hearing on the proposed ordinance is scheduled for later this month. Lester W. Brann, president of the Illinois State Chamber of Commerce, calls the proposed ordinance a ``screwy idea.'' ``The marketplace is going to determine where companies locate and where they expand their plants,'' he said. ``They are going to expand where the governments operate efficently, where incentives are offered and taxes are low.'' Brann said the proposed ordinance could impose a new burden on taxpayers, and said companies taken over by the city could run into problems before a new buyer is found. ``The City Council would be well advised to take a good hard look at what the city is or isn't doing to encourage business expansion,'' he said, adding that the proposal could be an unconstitutional interference with interstate commerce.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Issue of Forbes Magazine Dedicated to Empire's Founder
DOC.TEXT: A few days after his death, flamboyant publishing tycoon Malcom S. Forbes is gracing the cover of the biweekly magazine bearing his name. The cover of the March 19 issue, due on newsstands Monday, is taken from a portrait painted about 10 years ago of Forbes wearing a silver motorcycling jumpsuit seated in a chair with several helmets at his feet. Forbes died of a heart attack last weekend at age 70. Motorcycling was one of Forbes' passions, along with hot air ballooning and collecting Faberge eggs and toy soldiers. Several Hell's Angels cyclists showed up for a memorial service for Forbes held Thursday in New York. The painting used for the cover, by Claudio Bravo, hangs in the lobby of the Forbes office building in midtown Manhattan. At the top of the magazine's cover is the phrase ``1919-1990: While alive, he lived,'' which will be inscribed on Forbes' tombstone. Forbes had directed that his body be cremated and the ashes interred on Lauthala, his island in the South Pacific. Ten of the 212 pages in the latest issue of the magazine are devoted to tributes to the unabashed capitalist. Forbes editor James W. Michaels said it wasn't ``terribly difficult'' to redo the issue after Forbes' sudden death last Saturday. ``We always keep a large bank of pages open til the last minute anyhow,'' he said Friday. ``It's the type of thing that one could do with any big story.'' Still, Michaels conceded, the last-minute changes meant printers had to be paid overtime and the issue closed a few hours late. It was finished around 5 a.m. Wednesday rather than around midnight as usual. Forbes' oldest son, Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., known as Steve, who has taken over as chairman and chief executive of the magazine and the family-owned company and as editor in chief of Forbes, says in a message to readers: ``There is no replacing my father, but I bring the same spirit of dedication and joy to the job that he did. We will continue to move ahead as he was doing.'' The Fact and Comment section, where the elder Forbes used to display his wit and breezy writing style, also was written in the latest issue by son Steve. The tribute to his father is entitled ``A Matchless Man.'' Former defense secretary Caspar Weinberger, the magazine's publisher, also weighs in with a eulogy. There also is a spread of photographs, including black-and-white shots of Forbes' family dating to around 1930. ``It is a family company and the owner was just down the hall,'' Michaels said. ``There aren't many such publications left in the world.'' The editor wouldn't disclose what was swept off the cover by the portrait of Forbes. ``We may use that story in the next issue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: France Plans Special Visas for Hong Kong Chinese
DOC.TEXT: France will grant special visas to Hong Kong citizens working for French companies after the British colony reverts to Chinese control in 1997, a government spokesman said Friday. ``If they have a valid passport, we'll give them a visa,'' said the spokesman, who asked not to be named. He said specific terms of the visas such as length, working rights and the possibility of permanent immigration had not been decided. The spokesman said the decision was not officials but was agreed to in principal by a government committee. French enterprises in Hong Kong have asked President Francois Mitterrand's government to act amid growing fear among their employees over the pending takeover by Beijing, the spokesman said. About 1,000 people, mostly in management, would be eligible for the visas, the spokesman said. He did not specify whether the figure would include families. Chinese authorities would have to agree to let them leave, the spokesman said, but the visas should reassure the employees that they would have a right to come to France. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has been embroiled in a dispute with the colony's population over rights to settle in Britain after Hong Kong comes under Chinese control. Last year's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in China rattled nerves of Hong Kong residents over what their future might be like under a government headed by hardline Communists. Britain has said it would allow certain managers and entrepreneurs immigration rights but that most of the colony's 5 million Chinese residents would have to stay in Hong Kong. British passports carried by the majority of Hong Kong subjects are valid only as travel documents and do not allow them to settle Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound and Eastern: Some Similarities, Many Differences
DOC.TEXT: When Greyhound bus drivers flexed their strike muscle and stranded thousands of passengers, they didn't read the skywriting of Eastern Airlines, another mass-transit business hit by a mass walkout a year ago. Eastern also was paralyzed for a while but is now flying on a smaller scale with replacement workers. Many strikers are jobless. The strike forced the airline into bankruptcy court protection, but Eastern expects to exit in months and report a profit in 1990 for the first time in years. If that's a lesson to unions on the futility of striking, the Greyhound drivers who struck the nation's only intercity bus system this past week evidently didn't learn it. In some respects, the drivers share the same complaints as the Eastern Machinists who struck last March 4. Both groups took pay cuts in the 1980s, a decade of labor givebacks and retreats. Both were dealing with companies purchased by tough business executives not known for union sympathy: Dallas investor Fred Currey, who purchased Greyhound Lines Inc. for $270 million, and Texas Air Corp. Chairman Frank Lorenzo, who bought Eastern for $676 million. But many labor experts say that's largely where the similarities between the Greyhound and Eastern strikers end. Some contend the bus drivers had much more leverage than the Eastern workers, partly because Greyhound had no other source of revenue except the bus line and only began preparing for a strike a few weeks ago by training some replacement drivers. On the other hand Lorenzo, whose company also operates non-union Continental Airlines, had an enormous advantage in weathering the Eastern labor confrontation. Texas Air was even accused by a bankruptcy-court official this past week of unfairly bleeding Eastern for Continental's benefit. The company denied the claim but will compensate Eastern with more than $280 million. ``Lorenzo has got the stuff to shuffle around,'' said Kim Moody, executive director of the Labor Education and Research Project, a Detroit-based group that follows the organized labor movement. It's hard to get a national bus line off the ground in short order,'' he said. ``Unless there's an awful lot of ex-bus drivers out there, these replacement drivers aren't qualified. You can't train people to drive one of these things even halfway safely over a couple of weeks.'' Others said the drivers also had public pressure on their side. While airline passengers waylaid by the Eastern strike eventually were able to fly on other carriers, bus passengers are hostage to what amounts to a Greyhound monopoly. In 9,000 of its 9,500 destinations, Greyhound is the only bus line. Some groups opposed to mandatory membership in labor unions contend the Greyhound drivers' union has a history of rough tactics to get what it wants. Steve Kerekes, a spokesman for the National Right to Work Committee, said ``While we respect the rights of bus drivers to strike, one hopes violence won't be used to enforce solidarity.'' A 1983 study of union violence by the Industrial Research Unit of the Wharton School suggested the drivers union was more violent than many other unions. The union claims it does not advocate violence. Nonetheless, the company's use of replacement drivers was seen as helping provoke early violent incidents during the strike. ``We're about the only country in the civilized world that does this sort of thing, running a business through a strike. Elswhere, the business just shuts down,'' said Paul Gerhart, a professor of industrial relations at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland. In other business and economic developments this past week: _Government reports provided mixed signals about the economy. For example, sales of new homes fell 7.1 percent in January to their lowest level in nearly a year and durable goods orders plunged 10.5 percent in January, suggesting economic weakness. Personal income rose 0.8 percent in January and 1989 fourth-quarter gross national product growth was revised upward slightly, suggesting strength. _Wall Street's slump deepened. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said it would lay off 2,000 employees. Another casualty of the securities boom of the 1980s, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., faced congressional scrutiny into the final weeks before it collapsed into bankruptcy last month. _The energy industry got a dose of good news and bad news. The Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire, a focal point of anti-nuclear movement protests, won full federal licensing approval, 14 years after construction began. Exxon Corp. was indicted on criminal charges stemming from the oil spill in Valdez, Alaska, nearly a year ago and faces fines exceeding $600 million.

DOC.HEAD: ABC's Costly Pro Football Deal May Make Sense Without Making Money
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Saturday PMs
DOC.TEXT: ``Monday Night Football'' games are the latest major sports events commanding eye-popping price increases from the broadcast and cable networks battling for the rights to televise them. But some advertising agency executives said Friday the bidders may be overestimating advertisers' willingness to help defray the costs of the huge television rights' contracts. ``I hear a lot more reluctance,'' said Allen Banks, media director at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Advertising Inc. ``It raises more questions about whether the networks have calculated the advertisers' mood correctly.'' Some media industry analysts said the bidders may be willing to shoulder a loss on the contracts as an investment in the broader welfare of their network _the games add to a network's prestige, attract large numbers of men who often don't watch TV and and provide a platform for promoting other programs. On top of that, they note when you have the games, your competitors don't. The National Football League and Capital Cities-ABC Inc.'s ABC Television Network announced late Thursday they had agreed on a four-year contract reportedly valued at $900 million to broadcast Monday night games. That works out to about $225 million a year, up 87.5 percent from the $120 million annual average in ABC's previous Monday night football contract. The increase in the payment per game is somewhat lower, however, because the new package includes 17 Monday night games in each of the first two years and 18 in the second two years of the contract. Under the old three-year contract, there were only 16 Monday night games. In addition, ABC will be getting the right to broadcast two new playoff games that are being added to the schedule this year and will get next year's Super Bowl, which will be the 25th annual championship game. The NFL still is negotiating over the rights to its Sunday afternoon games, which CBS and NBC broadcast under the previous contract. Media analysts said the threat of competition from cable networks and outlets such as the Fox television network were one reason behind the giant leaps made this year in contracts rights for football, baseball, basketball and college football and basketball games. ESPN was the first cable network to land an NFL contract three years ago, paying $153 million for the right to 13 games a year. But the NFL will be getting a reported $900 million from two cable networks, ESPN and Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc., for an expanded schedule of Sunday night games over the next four years. Unlike the broadcast networks, the cable networks can rely on a combination of higher ad rates and increased charges to cable system operators to help them pay for the sports rights. Steve Bornstein, executive vice president at ESPN, said he expects the network will boost ad rates and operator fees to pay for the larger contract. But he noted that an increase in subscribers who get ESPN and the addition of ``a couple'' commercials per game will also boost revenue. He said ESPN made a modest profit on its three-year contract and expects to break even on its NFL games over the next four years. ESPN felt it had to pay what it did for the contract _ Bornstein refused to confirm the reported figure of $450 million _ because Turner reached agreement first on telecasting a package of Sunday night games for a reported $450 million, Bornstein said. ``It's an important part of our programming menu,' he said. ABC refused to make any of its executives available Friday to discuss how it intends to pay for the sharp increase in the football contract. But Lisa Donneson, media analyst for County NatWest USA, said she figures ABC will lose about $7 million during the first year of the new Monday night contract, make a small profit the second year and larger profits ``in the teens and 20's'' in the last two years. Her estimates assume a single-digit ad rate increase each year and higher rates for ads in the new playoff games. She noted the networks also may add commercial time to their broadcasts to generate more revenue. Some analysts said ABC could ill afford to lose ``Monday Night Football'' particularly because CBS outbid it last year for the new major league baseball contract. Banks said the broadcasts also give ABC an extra way to promote other prime-time shows as the network tries to overtake the prime-time ratings leader, NBC. ``There is a belief that live sports is still very viable programming entity that creates a point of difference that nobody can copy,'' Banks said. But he noted that with sports ``proliferating across the channel,'' its continued power to draw crowds and willing advertisers will be sorely tested.

DOC.HEAD: Breeden: SEC Investigating Drexel Bonuses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Saturday PMs
DOC.TEXT: The fate of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was sealed not by $650 million in penalties agreed to pay to settle fraud charges but by the firm's own investment strategy, Securities and Exchange Chairman Richard C. Breeden says. ``I don't think you can justifiably say that it was the money they had to pay in fines,'' Breeden told reporters Friday after testifying before the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee. Breeden also said the SEC is investigating the multimillion-dollar bonuses Drexel paid its employees before its collapse. Drexel has said it paid $260 million in bonuses in December and January but that the decision to make the payments came long before its financial woes became apparent. On Thursday, a Drexel lawyer told another congressional panel that the firm needed to pay big bonuses to retain professionals after the bad publicity and uncertainty following the plea bargain in December 1988. If the bonuses were a dodge to reduce Drexel's assets before seeking bankruptcy protection ``then its possible we'll take some action,'' Breeden told the committee. Drexel, once the nation's fifth-largest securities firm, collapsed in the wake of a sharp drop in the value of its high-yield, high-risk junk bond portfolio and its admission of securities law violations in a plea bargain with federal prosecutors. The parent company sought protection from creditors under the federal bankruptcy law Feb. 13 after defaulting on $100 million in short-term debt and failing to gain new loans to help stem a cash crisis. The SEC is seeking bankruptcy court certification as a Drexel creditor because the firm still owes the government $150 million from the settlement. While conceding Drexel would ``have been a very different company had they not engaged in felony violations of U.S. law,'' Breeden said the firm's fate rested with its management's decisions. Drexel still had sizable cash and capital resources after pleading guilty to six felony counts and agreeing to the $650 million settlement, he said. ``They could have tried to run a smaller firm. They were unreasonably aggressive in maintaining a $28 billion balance sheet with the level of borrowing they had,'' Breeden said.
